column2: FISHER--Marjorie. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Marjorie Fisher, and extends sincere sympathy to her children, Mary Fisher, Phillip Fisher and his spouse Lauren, Julie Fisher Cummings and her spouse Peter Cummings and Marjorie Fisher Furman and her spouse Roy Furman, Jane Sherman and her spouse Larry Sherman and other members of her family. Jeffrey B. Lane, President Warren Spector, Club Secretary 1/3

BRENNAN--Bonnie Ternes. June 14, 2016. Age 73. Devoted mother of Bonnie and Reilly (Andrea); and proud Nana to Zoe. Survived by her siblings, Patricia, Valerie, Paul and Michael. Predeceased by her parents, Patricia and Paul Ternes. Raised in Detroit, she is a graduate of the Convent of the Sacred Heart and Marymount University. Funeral mass Friday 11am at the Academy of the Sacred Heart, Bloomfield Hills, MI. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Academy of the Sacred Heart, Bloomfield Hills and the University of Detroit Jesuit High School. 1/3

KASHA--Audrey Sission, a lifelong New Yorker, born December 30, 1927, died June 12, 2016. Daughter of the late Helene Sisson-Cerussi and Theodore R. Sisson; mother of the late Matthew P. Kasha; sister of B. Peter Cerussi and Maxine L. Sisson and Gloria M. Cerussi. Graveside service Friday, June 17, 11am, Warwick Cemetery, Warwick, NY. Contributions in her memory to an animal welfare group of your choice would be appreciated. 1/3

DWORK--Melvin, 94, died in New York City on June 14, following a brief illness. Born in Kansas City, Mel moved to New York to attend the Parsons School of Design, from which he graduated in 1945. A lifelong New Yorker thereafter, he was for several decades a highly successful interior designer renowned for his sensitive combination of eclectic styles to create a timeless modern look. Mel is survived by his brother Irvin of Kansas City and a wide circle of admiring friends across generations. Contributions in Mel's memory may be made to the John Butler Foundation. Alan Salz 1/3

CHILDS--Sally Hillman. November 21, 1927 -- June 10, 2016. On Friday, June 10, 2016, Sally Hillman Childs died in Boulder, CO. A resident of Pittsburgh, PA, for 85 years and beloved wife of the late J. Mabon Childs, she is survived by her four children: J. Mabon Childs Jr. (Holly), Marguerite Hillman Childs Detmer (Tom), Laura Childs Saverin (Ken) and Sally Childs Walsh (Alec). She is also survived by 11 grandchildren: Frazer (Adam) Roche, Ellie (Tim Romano) Childs, Margot (Will) Stanley; Matthew (Jennifer) Detmer, Tommy (Leigh) Detmer, Emily Detmer; Hilary Saverin, Diana Saverin; Sarah (Thatcher) Martin, Mary Walsh, Alex Walsh. Sally leaves behind six great- grandchildren: Nathan Detmer, Landon Roche, Mabel Romano, Emma Detmer, Audrey Martin and Harvey Stanley. She was preceded in death by her parents, James F. and Marguerite W. Hillman, and three sisters: Constance Hillman Oliver O'Neil, Marguerite Hillman Purnell and Audrey Hillman Hilliard. Friends will be received at Calvary Episcopal Church, Pittsburgh, PA at 10:00am on Friday, June 17th prior to a Celebration of her life at 11:00am. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, Remembrances may be made to Lydia's Place (Renewal, Inc.), St. Aidan's Church in Boulder, CO, Calvary Episcopal Church or the charity of your choice. Services by John A. Freyvogel, Inc. Pittsburgh 1/3

SILVERMAN--Gilbert. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the death of Gilbert Silverman. A longstanding member of the Museum's Trustee Committee on Archives, Library, and Research, Gilbert, along with his wife Lila, began collecting works by Fluxus artists in 1978. In 2008 the Museum acquired, through the generosity of Gilbert and Lila, the Gilbert and Lila Silverman Fluxus Collection and Archives, widely considered the largest and most important collection of its kind in the world. Assembled in Detroit over three decades by the Silvermans, the collection comprises over 4,000 works in mediums ranging from printed ephemera, multiples, drawings, and sculptural objects, to photographs and film. The Silverman Collection also incorporates an archival and library component of over 5,500 files containing artists' correspondence, notebooks and scrapbooks, and publications, as well as documents and photographs related to Fluxus performances and events from the 1960s to the 1990s. Gilbert and Lila's collecting was iconoclastic, as much as the movement of Fluxus was itself. With a love of experimentation, chance operation and unceasing inventiveness, Gilbert's vision embraced the lives of artists whose works he collected, as much as the works themselves. We extend our deepest sympathies to Lila, a member of the Museum's Trustee Committee on Archives, Library, and Research, his children, and their families. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art 1/3

MICKLE--Stuart Harding, aged 58, died May 11, 2016 after a long illness. Son of Perry Morgan Mickle and the late Peter Mickle, Stuart is survived by his mother and his brother, Peter Wilson Mickle. Funeral services private. 1/3

JELLINEK--Barbara. The Board and Staff of LiveOn NY deeply mourn the loss of Barbara, cherished wife of our esteemed Executive Director, Igal Jellinek. An ever present face at LiveOn NY events, we will miss her friendship and staunch support of our mission. We extend our sympathies to her family and many friends. David V. Pomeranz, President Joseph H. Girven, Vice President Joan L. Ryan, Chairperson 1/3

MURRAY--Mary Jane (nee Riordan), of Bronxville, New York and Londonderry, Vermont, wife of the late James J. Murray, passed away on June 12, 2016 at age 73. A native of Bayside, New York, Jane was an alumna of St. Helena's High School, Class of 1961, and Molloy College, Class of 1965. Jane was a wife, mother, friend and educator of boundless love, devotion and generosity. A teacher in the fullest sense of the term, Jane instilled in her children and her students the centrality of integrity, compassion and kindness, and imbued in them her insatiable intellectual curiosity. During her over fifty-year career, first in the New York City public school system, and, for the past 29 years, at The Ursuline School in New Rochelle, Jane was an unshakable advocate for her students and found joy in their success. In appearance, Jane personified elegance, but her legacy consists of the grace, magnanimity and nobility of spirit that she exemplified, and by which her family and countless friends will remember her. She is survived by her children, John, of New York, NY, Elizabeth, of Somerville, MA and James, of Yonkers, NY, her sister, Eileen Mulhern, and her husband, Eugene, of Stamford, CT and their children and grandchildren, and her brother, John Riordan, and his wife, Jane, of Southampton, NY. A wake will be held on Thursday, June 16, 2016 at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY from 2-4pm and 7-9pm and funeral mass on Friday, June 17, 2016 at the Church of St. Joseph's, Bronxville, NY, at 10:45am Donations may be made in her name to the James J. Murray Scholarship at The Ursuline School. 1/3

ARONOW--Irving B.,D.O., passed away on June 14, 2016. Dr. Aronow was born on December 24, 1937. He graduated from Brooklyn College and received his medical degree from Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine. Dr. Aronow practiced family medicine in Amityville, NY for 40 years before retiring to New York City and Shelter Island, NY. He is survived by his beloved wife of 56 years, Carole; sister Roberta and her husband Clark; son Michael and his wife Ronni; son Bruce and his wife Holly; and his grandchildren Benjamin, Brian, Alyssa, Alexander and Nicholas. Donations may be made to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. 1/3

JELLINEK--Barbara Ann, LCSW (Niemaseck), 63, passed away peacefully on June 12, 2016 at St. Peter's University Hospital, New Brunswick, NJ following a heroic battle with breast cancer. Beloved wife of Igal and loving mother to Briana, she was the cherished daughter of the late Edward Niemaseck and the late Jean Zawyrucha Niemaseck. She leaves behind brothers Don (Nancy) and Ken (Ruth), sister Kimberly Ann, stepmother JoAnn Landi, beloved nieces and nephews and great-nieces and great-nephews. A graduate of Rutgers University Graduate School of Social Work, Barbara was proud to be a social worker and was passionate about her profession, sharing her knowledge and gifts with those in need. Barbara lived her life with love, compassion and energy. She brought the best of herself to everything she did and everyone she knew, and is remembered with love and respect by the many people whose lives she touched. She loved life and especially her husband and their pup, Kira. The family is grateful to the dedicated staff of St. Peter's University Hospital and the special friends who cared for Barbara in her final days. As she led her life, Barbara fought her cancer with courage, grace and dignity and will be deeply missed. The funeral will be private; a celebration of Barbara's life will be held at a later date. Condolences may be made through Legacy.com. In lieu of flowers, if you would like to make a contribution in Barbara's memory, please consider either LiveOn NY, 49 West 45th St., New York, NY 10036 (www.liveon-ny.org) or St. Peter's Foundation to support The Monsignor James A. Harding Oncology Unit, 254 Easton Ave., New Brunswick, NJ 08901. 1/3

SCHURIN--Emily Van Ness, 68, died June 14 after a long battle with cancer. Survived by her husband Ron, sons Zachary and Matthew, daughter-in-law Leah Kamin, grandson Daniel, brothers James (Anna) and Michael and sisters Deirdre (Ron) and Molly (Jim), and many nieces and nephews. Calling hours Friday, June 17 6:00-8:00pm at Potter Funeral Home, 456 Jackson Street, Willimantic, CT; memorial service 2:00pm Saturday, June 18, Hope Lutheran Church, 62 Dog Lane, Storrs, CT; interment 12:00 noon Friday, June 24, Princeton Cemetery, 29 Greenview Avenue, Princeton, NJ. Contributions may be made to Peace Action Education Fund, 40 Witherspoon Street, Princeton, NJ 08542; Hartford Hospital CB-2, Hartford Hospital Fund Development, 80 Seymour Street, Hartford, CT 06102; or an organization of the sender's choice. 1/3

DWORK--Melvin. The family of the late Arthur G. Cohen is saddened by the passing of Melvin Dwork on June 14, 2016 at the age of 94. Mel, a U.S. Navy veteran who served honorably during World War II, brought his sense of style and love of beauty to three generations of our family. Though recognized professionally during his 70 years in the interior design field as one of Architectural Digest's Top 100 interior designers and as a member of the Interior Design Hall of Fame, to Arthur and Karen he was more importantly a dearly-loved, good-hearted friend and welcome presence at family gatherings, while to their adoring daughters, Lauren, Susan, Debra, Rochelle and Kathy, and their nine admiring grandchildren, he was simply "Uncle Mel". We will all miss him. 1/3

JELLINEK--Barbara Ann, LCSW (Niemaseck), 63, passed away peacefully on June 12, 2016 at St. Peter's University Hospital, New Brunswick, NJ following a heroic battle with breast cancer. Beloved wife of Igal and loving mother to Briana, she was the cherished daughter of the late Edward Niemaseck and the late Jean Zawyrucha Niemaseck. She leaves behind brothers Don (Nancy) and Ken (Ruth), sister Kimberly Ann, stepmother JoAnn Landi, beloved nieces and nephews and great-nieces and great-nephews. A graduate of Rutgers University Graduate School of Social Work, Barbara was proud to be a social worker and was passionate about her profession, sharing her knowledge and gifts with those in need. Barbara lived her life with love, compassion and energy. She brought the best of herself to everything she did and everyone she knew, and is remembered with love and respect by the many people whose lives she touched. She loved life and especially her husband and their pup, Kira. The family is grateful to the dedicated staff of St. Peter's University Hospital and the special friends who cared for Barbara in her final days. As she led her life, Barbara fought her cancer with courage, grace and dignity and will be deeply missed. The funeral will be private; a celebration of Barbara's life will be held at a later date. Condolences may be made through Legacy.com. In lieu of flowers, if you would like to make a contribution in Barbara's memory, please consider either LiveOn NY, 49 West 45th St., New York, NY 10036 (www.liveon-ny.org) or St. Peter's Foundation to support The Monsignor James A. Harding Oncology Unit, 254 Easton Ave., New Brunswick, NJ 08901. 1/3

HODGE--Jerrick, an ardent advocate for people in recovery whose positive energy and kindness made him a much loved staple at Alcoholics Anonymous meetings and throughout the recovery community, died on June 5 at his home in Canaan, CT. He was 61. The cause was lung cancer. His death was announced by Mountainside Treatment Center, where he had worked for more than 15 years. One of Mountainside's first clients, Mr. Hodge joined the treatment center's staff in 1998. A key, informal position that Mr. Hodge held was as the Ambassador of Mountainside. Tasked with handing out coins to celebrants at the Friday night AA meeting at Mountainside, Mr. Hodge forever transformed the traditional ceremony by injecting his positive energy and showmanship. Thousands of clients and other attendees from across the globe have a special place in their hearts for Mr. Hodge, as he not only gave them their first coin of sobriety but showed all of those in the room on Friday evenings that in sobriety you can have fun, laugh, and love. As a person in recovery, Mr. Hodge would pass on to others lessons he had learned about life beyond addiction, helping others to understand that being flawed was not only acceptable in life but is part of being human, a message that resonated with those in early recovery. Mr. Hodge, a former Non-Commissioned Officer with the United States Marine Corps, was always willing to share his story of addiction, so that others would feel comfortable sharing theirs. "Addiction took things I didn't know I had. Recovery gave me things I didn't know I wanted," Mr. Hodge would often say. Mr. Hodge is survived by his soulmate Eliza Raphael-Hodge and his four children - Jerrina Lashely, Tanika Hodge, Jerrick Hodge, Jr, all of Baltimore, MD, and Victor Hodge. Jerrick is also survived by his sister Patricia Carter, his brother Reggie Hodge and several grandchildren. He was predeceased by his two brothers, Ronald Carter and Carl Hodge. A memorial service in Mr. Hodge's honor will be held at Mountainside in Canaan, CT, on Saturday, June 25, at 2pm. 1/3

SILVERMAN--Gilbert. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the death of Gilbert Silverman. A longstanding member of the Museum's Trustee Committee on Archives, Library, and Research, Gilbert, along with his wife Lila, began collecting works by Fluxus artists in 1978. In 2008 the Museum acquired, through the generosity of Gilbert and Lila, the Gilbert and Lila Silverman Fluxus Collection and Archives, widely considered the largest and most important collection of its kind in the world. Assembled in Detroit over three decades by the Silvermans, the collection comprises over 4,000 works in mediums ranging from printed ephemera, multiples, drawings, and sculptural objects, to photographs and film. The Silverman Collection also incorporates an archival and library component of over 5,500 files containing artists' correspondence, notebooks and scrapbooks, and publications, as well as documents and photographs related to Fluxus performances and events from the 1960s to the 1990s. Gilbert and Lila's collecting was iconoclastic, as much as the movement of Fluxus was itself. With a love of experimentation, chance operation and unceasing inventiveness, Gilbert's vision embraced the lives of artists whose works he collected, as much as the works themselves. We extend our deepest sympathies to Lila, a member of the Museum's Trustee Committee on Archives, Library, and Research, his children, and their families. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art 1/3

AVAKIAN--Anahid Ajemian, renowned violinist, born in New York in 1924, died suddenly at home Monday, June 13. Graduate of Julliard, winner of the Walter W. Naumburg, Distinguished Achievement Medal and Laurel Leaf Award; co-founder of the Composers String Quartet. Survived by her husband George, children Maro, Anahid and Greg, and two grandchildren. JONES--Jeanne McNichols, 83, of 912 5th Avenue New York, NY, died peacefully on Tuesday, June 7th in Nice, France, with her loving family and friends by her side. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Carlisle Jones. Born in Chicago, IL on July 9, 1932, daughter of Austin A. McNichols and Marie Doherty McNichols, Jeanne was a graduate of Barrat College of The Sacred Heart. She was predeceased by her siblings Austin McNichols, Marilyn McNichols Hosty and Frank McNichols. Jeanne was a lover of life and the embodiment of classic New York. She surrounded herself with friends and family throughout the world. She could often be found in New York City, Chicago, Essex Fells, Bay Head, Princeton, Point O' Woods, Bermuda, the Bahamas, London and France. She brought love and laughter to all who crossed her path. Jeanne loved to entertain and play games of all sorts; with a particular fondness for bridge and crosswords. After a stint as a fashion model and a long career as a renown international interior designer, she settled in and devoted her time to charitable pursuits. She was a twenty year board member of the Central Park Conservancy; a member of the Tree Trust Committee; faithful benefactor of the Central Park Conservancy luncheon; and great patron of The New York Botanical Garden, to name a few. Survived by her loving children Joseph Fusco (Pamela), William Fusco, John Fusco, Thomas Fusco (Laurie), Stephen Fusco (Michele), Julie Fusco Lanning (Michael); her cherished grandchildren Davis, Scott, Tracey, Carly, Brooke, Katie, Austin, Matt, Kerry, Tommy, Lindsay, Dalton, Tripp, and Gardner; and her five dear step-children Debbie Jones Lupton (Steve), Geoffrey Jones, Leslie Jones Brittain (John), Betsy Jones Hall (Tyler), Andrew Jones, eleven step-grandchildren, and one step-great-grandchild. There will be a celebration of life in Manhattan during September, with time and place to follow. In lieu of flowers, please give donations to the Central Park Conservancy or The New York Botanical Garden. 1/3

KANTOR--Adrienne Christina, of New York, New York, passed away on June 16, 2016 after a long illness. She was the beloved wife of Robert Kantor, and loving mother of Mary Kantor. She was the dear sister of Leslie Matthews and Gregory Dick. She is survived by many nieces and nephews whom she loved. Adrienne was a woman who touched the lives and hearts of many. Those who knew Adrienne regarded her as a "generous soul". She also had a passion for animals, both big and small. She gave selflessly, and was sincerely devoted to her family as well as to her many horses. Adrienne had worked for many years in the Fashion Industry, developing her own successful company, Adrienne Victoria Designs Inc. Together with her husband, they launched several successful contemporary brands including Page III, Ginger & Java, and MaryL Dresses as well as a large private label business. Adrienne subsequently served as the Chief Merchandising Officer at publicly traded Cache Stores Inc. after selling her company to them in 2008. The family will be receiving friends at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel located at 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10028 on Sunday, June 19th from 2-4pm and 7-9pm, with Chapel Service on Monday, June 20th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in Adrienne's memory to The MSA Coalition, address as below. The MSA Coalition, 9935-D Rea Rd., #

Visitation will be held at Preston Funeral Home, 153 South Orange Ave, South Orange, NJ on Sunday, 3:00-5:00pm. She was predeceased by her husband Francis Chervenak. Beldner, and her sister Johanna M. Longo. 1/3

YOUNG--Henry A. F. of Port Washington, NY passed away a year ago today. In loving memory of our husband, father & friend whose knowledge and wit enriched our lives. He is deeply missed. 1/3
KAUFMAN--Dr. Herman S. March 31, 1922 - June 18, 1988 He gave of his heart and his mind. With us, always. Hiltzik and Kaufman families 1/3

BURTEN--Katharine, M.D.,a retired psychiatrist, passed away peacefully at her home in Larchmont, New York on June 16, 2016, at the age of 68. Dr. Burten grew up in the San Francisco Bay Area and was then a resident of New York for most of her adult life. She graduated from Redwood High School, Larkspur, California in 1965, received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Hunter College, New York in 1973, and went on to receive her Doctor of Medicine Degree from University of Miami in 1976. She will be greatly missed for her kindness, loving nature, wisdom and compassion. She was a loving and devoted wife to William Burten, M.D. (pre-deceased) for 30 years. She is survived by her loving family including son Michael Burten of Larchmont, New York; daughter Anne Burten of Ellensburg, Washington; sister Elizabeth Higgins of Sunnyvale, California and brother Mark Hammock of Petaluma, California. Donations to the Larchmont Library or the Audubon Society. 1/3

HOHOL--Barbara (Baer), passed away May 29 after a courageous final battle with cancer. Grateful for the six years she had after the first diagnosis, she lived well, traveling when she could and enjoying music and theatre. She was a community gardener, activist, craftswoman, and avid collector of folk art and crafts including northwestern coast and African sculpture and southwestern pottery. Her Upper Westside neighbors will miss her. Cats, Imp and Goblin seem happy together in their new home. A memorial celebration will be held at St. John the Divine on Monday, June 20 at 5pm. 1/3

RESTA-FLARER-- Francesco, M.D. - Anesthesiologist and connoisseur of art, wine, fashion, and culture, Franco died at the age of 66 on Thursday, June 16th. He was a devoted father, a dedicated physician, and a mentor to many, both old and young. His wife Bonnie, of 33 years, predeceased him in 2011. He is survived by his children, Morgan and Tessa, his daughter-in-law, Becky, and his granddaughter, Amelia, as well as his partner, Dorota Smyczek, and her family. He is also survived by his mother, Mariavica, his brother Nicola, and several nephews in Italy. A service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Sunday, June 19th at 12:00. 1/3

PEARLMAN--Sylvia D.,of New York City, New York on June 15, 2016 at the age of 89 years. Widow of Bernard Pearlman. Survived by her two sons, Allan and Robert, and grandson Daniel. Funeral service will be held on Monday June 20, 2016, 11am at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY. Interment at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY. 1/3

FINDLAY--Stella. We mourn with our dear friend David as we remember his and Stella's magical love story. Leslie and Ken Zuckerbrot 1/3

GLASS--David C. September 17, 1930-June 2, 2016. Died unexpectedly at the age of 85. Survived by his wife Kathleen Kehoe Glass and sister Mary Ellen Ashley Rubin. Funeral Service Saturday, June 18th at 11am, at Christ Church Riverdale, 5030 Henry Hudson Parkway East. 1/3

CASPER--Chester, of Quogue, NY, passed away peacefully at home on June 16, 2016 at the age of 85. The son of Moses and Anna Casper, born in Brooklyn, graduate of NYU with an accounting degree in 1951. He led Delaware Industries, an import-export textile company for forty years. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to East End Hospice, Westhampton, NY. 1/3

SACKS--Harry P.,(1934-2016), died peacefully at home in San Francisco, CA, on June 6, 2016. Mr. Sacks was a prominent New York lawyer and for many years was the senior partner in the firm that ultimately became known as Sacks Montgomery, P.C. He graduated in 1955 from Harvard, where he was a mainstay on the university's basketball team. After serving for two years in the Navy, he attended law school at New York University, graduating in 1960. Mr. Sacks grew up in Brooklyn and Long Beach, NY. He is survived by his wife, Joan Sacks, of San Francisco, CA; a son, Robert Sacks, of Pacific Palisades, CA; two daughters, Leslie Blaustein, of New York City, and Patricia Phelan, of Tappan, NY; a stepdaughter, Samantha Burggrabe, of Oakland, CA; a sister, Beverly Green, of Sands Point, NY; nine grandchildren; and three nephews. Mr. Sacks was predeceased by an older brother, Sheldon Sacks, of Chicago, IL. Interment was private. A gathering of Mr. Sacks' friends and colleagues will take place at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Mr. Sacks' memory to People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (www.peta.org). 1/3

BERKSON--Bill, born in New York City in 1939, died Thursday in San Francisco at age 76. A noted art critic, beloved teacher, and poet closely associated with second generation of the New York School, Bill was the author of more than 20 volumes of poetry and his art writing appeared Artforum, Art in America, Aperture, Modern Painters, and other publications. Son of journalist and publisher Seymour Berkson and fashion publicist Eleanor Lambert, Bill attended Trinity School and graduated from Lawrenceville in 1957. He dropped out of Brown after his father died and committed himself to poetry while taking Kenneth Koch's course at The New School for Social Research in 1959. Bill moved to Bolinas, near San Francisco, in 1970, where he taught regularly in the California Poets in the Schools Project. From 1984 to 2008, he was on the faculty of the San Francisco Art Institute, teaching art history and literature. In June 2004 Bill underwent a successful double-lung transplant. The family is grateful to the Pulmonary Division at UCSF for giving us all these past twelve years with him. Berkson is survived by his wife, Constance Lewallen; son Moses Berkson and daughter Siobhan O'Hare Mora Lopez from his first marriage, to Lynn O'Hare Berkson; stepchildren Jonathan Lewallen and Nina Lewallen Hufford; and six grandchildren. Memorial services will be planned for San Francisco and New York. Donations may be sent to the Foundation for Contemporary Arts and Poets in Need. 1/3

BACKUS--David. 1953-2016. It is with profound sadness that the Economics Faculty at New York University and the Stern School of Business mark the passing of our beloved colleague David Backus. Dave, the Heinz Riehl Professor of Economics at New York University's Stern School of Business died on June 12, 2016. The cause of death was leukemia. Dave was a renowned economist. He pioneered a new approach to international macroeconomics, infusing it with tools from finance. His approach shapes our understanding of credibility and monetary policy, exchange rate behavior and international finance. His work on asset markets, with a wide variety of authors, helped lay the foundation for the thriving new research area at the intersection of macroeconomics and finance. In addition to being an intellectual leader at the Stern School, Dave served for seven years as the Vice Dean for Faculty and as Chair of the Economics Department and the Accounting Department. Dave was much loved by his colleagues and by generations of Stern students for his strength of character, his generosity and kindness, and his sharp wit. Dave was a gifted teacher. Driven by his own deep intellectual curiosity, he developed and spearheaded many visionary courses for both undergraduate and graduate students. Dave was the consummate modern academic. He loved research, teaching, and students. He was also a skilled leader who valued and strengthened the culture of academic institutions. Dave was never happier than when he could bring people together socially to share a beer and talk about research and ideas. Dave, you will be deeply missed, you left us too soon. Friday afternoons will never be the same. Prior to joining Stern in 1990, Dave studied at Hamilton College (BA, 1975) and Yale University (PhD, 1981), taught at Queen's University and the University of British Columbia, served at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, and was a Research Associate of the National Bureau of Economic Research. He grew up in Pittsburgh and remained an avid supporter of the Pirates, Steelers, and Penguins. Dave is survived by his wife Marilyn Jason, his children Paul and Melanie Backus, his mother Marjorie Backus, and his sisters and brother Lois Backus, Laura Hoffman, Ruth Grillo, and Rudolf Ramsauer. 1/3

MARTELL--Michael J. 84, of Franklin Lakes passed away on June 16, 2016. Born in Minneapolis, Minnesota, he moved to Franklin Lakes, New Jersey in 1978 and became a member of the Indian Trail Club. He served his country honorably in the United States Army. After obtaining his Ph.D. in Pharmaceutical Chemistry and a B.S. in Pharmacy from University of Minnesota, he relocated to work at Lederle Laboratories, a division of American Cyanamid in Pearl River, New York. He spent his career working as a Director in the International and Medical Research Divisions, retiring in 1994. Dr. Martell received an Outstanding Achievement Award from the College of Pharmacy at the University of Minnesota in 1976 for his work in medical research. He published numerous scientific articles in peer-reviewed journals and authored numerous patents, however, his most notable career achievement was the synthesis of Minocycline, a tetracycline antibiotic (trademarked Minocin) which is still used to treat infections today, nearly 50 years after it was launched. He was a devoted husband to June Martell of Franklin Lakes; they were married for nearly 49 years. Beloved father to Karen Martell of Menlo Park, CA, Erica Martell of Montclair, NJ and dachshund, Max. He is also survived by his brother, Ronald Martell and his wife Saundra of Longville, Minnesota. A Graveside Service will be held at Acacia Park Cemetery, 2151 Pilot Knob Road, Mendota Heights, Minnesota, at a future date. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to University of Minnesota, College of Pharmacy. Donors can make out checks to "University of Minnesota Foundation", noting "Pharmaceutical Research Fund #

Her family considered her to be the strongest and sweetest person they ever met. A memorial service will be held at a future time. 1/3

SMITH--Philip. Dad, 15 years. Each day with us in our thoughts and hearts. Together again with Mom. Love Always, Michael and Jeffrey 1/3

ROSE--Stanley H. Stanley was the eldest child of Rose and Walter Rose. Stanley is survived by his beloved siblings, Marion and Martin. Stanley is also survived by his loving wife, Lenore, and their two sons, Michael Rose and Gordon Rose. Stanley and Lenore with some help have graced the world with six grandchildren, Garrett, Neilly, Margaret, Evelyn, Sam and James. Stanley was a long time New Yorker, a veteran of the Korean War and a graduate of Syracuse University and Columbia Business School. Stanley worked with Merrill Lynch and its predecessors for almost 40 years. Services 9:45am, Sunday at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

KLECKNER--Robert G.,Jr., 84, of New York City, died June 14 at home. Devoted husband of Carol; father of Tony (Tania) and Susan (Jonathan Goldstein); grandfather of four. A graduate of Yale College ('54) and Penn Law ('59), Bob was ROTC and served two years in Korea. He had a distinguished legal career on Wall Street, including Sullivan & Cromwell, Goldman Sachs and Johnson & Higgins. Outside work he kept active in Russian history and language, and was a member of the University and Union Clubs. Donations in his honor may be made to an animal shelter of your choice. 1/3

MARKS--Edith S. With profound sadness, we mourn the passing of Edith S. Marks at the age of 91 on May 31, 2016. Loving wife of the late Jason Marks and beloved and adored aunt to her nieces Selma Bromberg, Marilyn Swartz-Lloyd and Charlotte Bloomberg-Milby and nephews Jerry Bloomberg, Jerry Levine, Robert, David and Jeffrey Hirsch and the late David Levine. Edith, born in Maynard, MA, moved first to Washington, DC and then to Manhattan where she joined Career Blazers and co-authored her first book, "Job Hunting for the Disabled" followed by "From College to Career" and "Kitchen to Career." She joined the New York City Board of Education as a special education teacher, then became a staff developer and special education supervisor. She was an active member of ANYSEED, an advocacy organization for children with behavioral challenges. Edith was an avid gardener for more than 40 years and a central figure of the Westside Community Garden, making sure in her many endeavors that it continued to grow and thrive and benefit the community. A great loss to all - well loved and respected. After being diagnosed with glaucoma, she joined the New York Chapter Glaucoma Support and Education Group, of The Glaucoma Foundation and was a founding member of the World Glaucoma Patient Organization. She authored "Coping with Glaucoma" and "Glaucoma - Patient to Patient" and several works of fiction including "Ground Cover" and "Like Everybody Else." Although we have lost the presence of Edith, we will never lose the memories of her intellect, her love of literature, art and music, her love of life and her passion for improving the lives of those around her. She has left a legacy for us all. A Memorial Service will be held Thursday, June 23 at 4pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Westside Community Garden, P.O. Box 20301, NYC, NY 10025 or to the Glaucoma Education Research Fund/ GSEG, 205 East 64th Street, Suite 101, NYC, NY 10065. 1/3

TAYLOR--Dr. Jim. We are deeply saddened to announce the death of our beloved James Allen Taylor, 68, who died on June 5, 2016. He is survived by his loving wife Eleanor Taylor, and daughters Katherine Polley (Ray), Lana Goddu, and Yulia Goddu, along with his grandchildren Raymond, Lauren, and Patrick Polley. He will be greatly missed by his family and legions of friends. Considered one of the world's most respected marketing and branding consultants, Dr. Taylor served as Global Chief Marketing Officer of Ernst & Young and Gateway Computers. Prior to that, Dr. Taylor was CEO of Yankelovich, Skelly & White. More recently, he was a Vice Chairman at YouGov and a consultant on major education research studies. In 2015, he became a professor at Michigan State University (MSU). He held a B.A. in Rhetoric from Berkeley, along with a Master's and Ph.D. in Communication from MSU, where he was recognized as a distinguished alumnus. A memorial service will be held at 3:00pm on June 23, at Trinity Church, 651 Pequot Ave., Southport, CT. 1/3

CASPER--Chester, of Quogue, NY, passed away peacefully at home on June 16, 2016 at the age of 85. The son of Moses and Anna Casper, born in Brooklyn, graduate of NYU with an accounting degree in 1951. He led Delaware Industries, an import-export textile company for forty years. He is survived by his beloved wife of 61 years, Muriel (Brockman); sister Judy (Bernard) Kaufman, predeceased by Beverly (Sheldon) Thaler; daughters Marlane (Harvey) Guttmann, Carie (Spencer) Sax and Lynne Casper; grandchildren David (Katy) Guttmann, Arielle, Allison, Margaux and great-grandson Alexander. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to East End Hospice, Westhampton, NY. 1/3

JOSEPHSON--Joan Ellen. Beloved wife of Dr. Mark Josephson for 48 years, devoted mother of Rachel and Stephanie, adoring "Grammy" to Sylvie, Elan, and Sydney, died after a courageous battle with cancer on June 17th at the age of 72. With a BA from Penn State and an EdM from Columbia, she devoted her life to helping others. She was a teacher, advisor, and long term volunteer: at the Ronald McDonald House, as a leader of the surgical liaison service and a member of the Parent Connection at the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, and as a tutor for Read Boston. With a style of understated elegance and a motto to "always to do the right thing", she was inspirational to all who came into contact with her. The world is a better place because of her. Funeral services will be held on Monday, June 20th at 1:15pm Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, New York, NY. 1/3

BERNSTEIN--Daniel P. June 19, 2016-Wishing you love on the anniversary of your birth and Father's Day. Dearly missed since you were taken from us all. RILEY--George A.,of San Francisco, California, formerly of Memphis, Tennessee, age 59, died on June 8, 2016, after a determined and courageous fourteen-month battle with leukemia. He will be deeply missed by his sister, Peggy Thomson (Tim) of Germantown, Tennessee; his brother, John Riley (Maryellen) of Arlington Heights, Illinois; and his six nieces and nephews. George was preceded in death by his parents, Dr. Frances Riley and Dr. George A. Riley, both physicians in Memphis for many years. George was born on March 9, 1957, and grew up in Memphis. In 1975, he graduated from Whitehaven High School, where he was an active student leader for civil rights causes--a commitment to justice and public service he maintained throughout his life. George attributed that commitment to his chance meeting, as a young boy, with civil rights activist James Meredith shortly before Meredith was shot on June 6, 1966, while marching from Memphis to Jackson, Mississippi. In 1979, George graduated summa cum laude from Princeton University and began working with consumer advocate Ralph Nader. During that time, George and Carl J Mayer co-authored the book Public Domain, Private Dominion: A History of Public Mineral Policy in America, about land use regulation by the Department of the Interior. In 1983, George graduated cum laude from Harvard Law School, where he was instrumental in establishing the Harvard Fellowship in Public Interest Law. After law school, George returned to Memphis to clerk for the Honorable Judge Bailey Brown (U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit). In the mid-1980's, George moved to San Francisco, where he became special assistant to the San Francisco City Attorney and handled many of the city's most significant cases, including an action to open a local social club's membership to women and minorities. In 1993, George joined the San Francisco office of O'Melveny & Myers, an international law firm, becoming a prominent partner and one of the country's top intellectual property litigators. Known for his inexhaustible preparation and his eloquence in the courtroom, George was an invaluable global advisor to many iconic companies, including Apple, Samsung and Tesla. He shared an extremely special bond with Apple founder Steve Jobs and his family. George's high-profile clientele never diminished his commitment to the less fortunate. He donated hundreds of hours working with the Mississippi Center for Justice to help individuals displaced by Hurricane Katrina and others who faced seemingly insurmountable challenges. Throughout his life, George's love of running fueled his participation in countless long-distance races, creating many lasting friendships along the way. A cherished friend to so many, George always carved out time in his demanding schedule to counsel them on personal matters and share his passions for classical and sacred music, literature and Civil War history. Despite traveling the world, George's humility and Southern grace never waned. He returned to Memphis every February to run his favorite race, the Mike Cody Four Mile Classic, benefiting Rhodes College. George's premature passing is a tremendous loss to all who knew him. He defined generosity in mind, body and soul. A memorial service will be held Saturday, June 25, at 1pm in the auditorium at Memphis Brooks Museum of Art, with a reception to follow. Burial will be private. Memorial donations may be made to the Mississippi Center for Justice at mscenterforjustice.org. 1/3

Leslie and Ken Zuckerbrot 1/3

DUNN--Dr. Theodore F.,passed away on May 23rd, 2016, in Boynton Beach, FL at the age of 89. Ted Dunn worked at Benton and Bowles, and other prominent New York ad agencies, and had his own market research businesses. He was one of the first in the ad industry to develop advertising copy research measures and help set industry guidelines. Highly respected, his career spanned more than 50 years. He is survived by his wife, Gracine Dunn, and three of his four children, Meryl Freeman, Gary Dunn, and Laurence Dunn. He lived in NYC and Florida. Over the years he was an avid sailor, aspiring golfer, and world traveler. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

DWORK--Melvin, 94, died in New York City on June 14, following a brief illness. Born in Kansas City, Mel moved to New York to attend the Parsons School of Design, from which he graduated in 1945. A lifelong New Yorker thereafter, he was for several decades a highly successful interior designer renowned for his sensitive combination of eclectic styles to create a timeless modern look. Mel is survived by his brother Irvin of Kansas City and a wide circle of admiring friends across generations. Contributions in Mel's memory may be made to the John Butler Foundation. Alan Salz 1/3

MYRUS--Donald Richard. September 22, 1927-April 26, 2016. Author, editor died peacefully at home. Survived by wife Joyce, son Richard and his wife Alison, son Noah and his wife Holly and grandchildren Elizabeth, Carolyn, Parker and Lucinda. Also by a brother and two sisters. A Memorial Celebration was held June 11th on the East End of Long Island. 1/3

SPATER--Herman W.,M.D., child psychiatrist, neuro-researcher, passed away Friday, June 3, 2016 at home in Larchmont, NY. at age 93. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Gloria (nee Kalin), his children, Susan and Adam, and his grandchildren Shari and Jordan. Graduating NYU School of Medicine in 1952 with AOA honors, he was initially a pediatrician trained at Mount Sinai Hospital, University of Michigan and Mass. General Hospital. He trained in psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine where he became an Assistant Professor of Psychiatry and Experimental Pathology and trained psychiatric fellows. In WWII he served as a medic in the US Army and was awarded the Bronze Star. Recently he was a Voluntary Police Surgeon for the NYPD. An avid photographer, music and art enthusiast, we will miss his warmth, humor and wisdom. A private graveside service was held June 5, 201 at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Services handled by Zion Memorial Chapel, Mamaroneck NY. 1/3

DWORK--Melvin. The family of the late Arthur G. Cohen is saddened by the passing of Melvin Dwork on June 14, 2016 at the age of 94. Mel, a U.S. Navy veteran who served honorably during World War II, brought his sense of style and love of beauty to three generations of our family. Though recognized professionally during his 70 years in the interior design field as one of Architectural Digest's Top 100 interior designers and as a member of the Interior Design Hall of Fame, to Arthur and Karen he was more importantly a dearly-loved, good-hearted friend and welcome presence at family gatherings, while to their adoring daughters, Lauren, Susan, Debra, Rochelle and Kathy, and their nine admiring grandchildren, he was simply "Uncle Mel". We will all miss him. 1/3

WYMAN--M. Richard. The partners and employees of First Manhattan Co. mourn the passing of our long-time friend and colleague, Dick Wyman. Dick became a Managing Director in 1993, and served as a wonderful ambassador for the Firm. His clients trusted his sage advice and he was respected and beloved by them and us. We offer our sincerest condolences to his wife, Judy, and his family. 1

FOA--Linda. Pioneer in Design Journalism and Marketing Linda Rimanich Foa passed away peacefully at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on June 17, 2016 after a long battle with cancer. She is survived by her husband, Conrad, their sons, Justin and Barrett, and grandchildren, Max and Luke. Her abiding interest in others, her incomparable style, and her take no prisoners demeanor, meant that everyone knew that she was "in the room". Her always-positive impact on her family and friends will be sorely missed. The stars were already aligning because Linda and Conrad were both born in Wickersham Hospital (across the street from Bloomingdale's); Linda was born there 51 weeks after her future husband. Her family resided in Jamaica Estates, New York City, where she graduated from The Mary Louis Academy. Linda majored in Fashion and Fine Arts at Parsons/NYU. Linda's sense of style, superb writing ability, and natural beauty were a unique combination that was unleashed on the world of design journalism. Linda began her professional career at Fairchild's Home Furnishings Daily and HFN where she was an editor, and penned the still-remembered FYI column. While mothering, she wrote several lead cover articles for New York Magazine, articles for The New York Times Style Section, and co-authored Kids' Stuff, the definitive furnishings guide to children's furniture and home environments [Pantheon/Random House]. In the 1990s, Linda headed and brought Designer's Saturday to prominence; producing a world-renowned annual contract furniture show in New York City that featured over 100 participating showrooms. The food and ambiance offered in the showrooms were even reviewed by Mimi Sheraton in The New York Times. For the past 11+ years, Linda was the Marketing Director of the Architects & Designers building at 150 East 58th Street. She is credited with burnishing the building's ability to attract high-end kitchen, bathroom and furniture showrooms. She contributed to a soaring occupancy rate and was instrumental in partnering with The New York Times to host the building-wide Taste of T foodie event for over a decade. Walking through the building with her, it was obvious that she was loved by tenants and co-workers alike. Linda, along with her spouse, were prominent members of the Lexington Democratic Club. She rose to the party post of District Leader and was a fierce proponent of the Club's role in forwarding and bettering the Democratic agenda. It was with great pleasure that she witnessed the presumptive nomination by the Democratic Party of the first female presidential nominee. The success of her children, Justin [fifth generation owner and CEO of 155 year-old international insurance brokerage firm, Foa & Son] and Barrett (respected, multi-talented lead actor, singer, dancer in two Tony Award-winning Broadway shows, with an eight year series-regular role on CBS's "NCIS: Los Angeles") speaks volumes about her exceptional mothering. Linda and her husband, Conrad, did everything together and were rarely apart during their 50 year relationship. A memorial service for Linda will we held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls at 1157 Lexington Avenue (80th Street) on July 28, 2016 at 11:00am. There will be a reception for Linda's friends after the service. 1/3

McLEAN--Linda Durfee, died peacefully at home on June 12. A Colorado native, Linda graduated Phi Beta Kappa from the University of Denver and began her career as a UN guide followed by a successful 30 year career as an institutional stockbroker. The love of her life was husband, Robert Ludlow McLean, with whom she shared 25 treasured years until his death in 2011. She is survived by her sister, Judy Snow (Roger), her stepdaughters Elissa McLean (Andy) and Maggie Suniewick (Josh) and her adored grandchildren Emmy, Sam, Theo and Benjamin. Linda was loved by everyone who had the privilege to be her friend. All who knew her well will miss her loving presence. Family private interment. Should friends desire, remembrances may be made to a favorite charity and acknowledgements to Linda's family at her home address. 1/3

AMSTER--Arni, passed away after a brief illness on June 13, 2016 at the age of 75 surrounded by his loving family and many special friends. Arni was a gifted mathematician with a degree from New York University's Courant Institute. Early in his career, he worked on software for the defense industry and the ascent engine for the first landing on the moon. He then changed direction for a career on Wall Street, doing risk arbitrage for several firms before starting his own boutique arbitrage firm, Amster & Company. He is survived by his wife Peggy Amster, daughter Wendy Amster, son-in-law David Hinkes, grandson Micah Hinkes, sister Loretta Nordon, nephew Mitchell Nordon, niece Ann Nordon, sister-in-law Linda Preuss and mother-in-law Gladys Preuss. He was smart, charming, generous and really enjoyed a good bet. He will be sorely missed but remains in our hearts...eating a hot dog. He had a great ride! Donations in his memory may be made to acaringhand.org 1/3

ARMENTO--William J.,101, died in San Mateo, CA. Survived by Elvina, his wife of 70 years, daughters Valerie, Anne (Patrick Dunn), Janice (James Scherba) and Lisa Armento, seven grandchildren, Jill Armento Curran of Greenwich, Connecticut, numerous nieces and nephews. Bill graduated from Stuyvesant in 1931, from CCNY in 1935, and earned an MS in civil engineering at Columbia in 1949. He taught engineering courses at CCNY from 1938 through 1950 as well as evening classes at Brooklyn Polytechnic. In the 1930's he worked for Madigan-Hyland designing the upper levels of the Henry Hudson and Whitestone Bridges and supervised construction of the East River (FDR) Drive. At Parsons, Brinkerhoff he worked on designs for the Bay Area Rapid Transit System and relocated to San Francisco in 1963. A licensed professional engineer in five states and a licensed land surveyor in New York, he served on the New York State Board of Examiners for Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors. Eternal tribute at www.ssofunerals.com 1/3

HOHOL--Barbara (Baer), passed away May 29 after a courageous final battle with cancer. Grateful for the six years she had after the first diagnosis, she lived well, traveling when she could and enjoying music and theatre. She was a community gardener, activist, craftswoman, and avid collector of folk art and crafts including northwestern coast and African sculpture and southwestern pottery. Her Upper Westside neighbors will miss her. Cats, Imp and Goblin seem happy together in their new home. A memorial celebration will be held at St. John the Divine on Monday, June 20 at 5pm. 1/3

PETERS--Murray, passed away peacefully on June 7, 2016 in his 98th year surrounded by family. Beloved and cherished husband of the late Charlotte Peters and adored father of the late Jon Peters. He is survived by his daughter, Lonnie Resnick, son-in-law Norman Resnick, grandchildren Mitchell Resnick, Lindsay Resnick, Bruce Resnick, Jessie Peters, and his great-granddaughters, Carly Resnick and Kasey Resnick. He dedicated his adult life to his family and as an ardent supporter of Israel and the Jewish people. To the very end he had his wonderful stories and sense of humor. He is forever in our hearts and will be missed each and every day. 1/3

JONES--Jeanne McNichols, 83, of 912 5th Avenue New York, NY, died peacefully on Tuesday, June 7th in Nice, France, with her loving family and friends by her side. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Carlisle Jones. Born in Chicago, IL on July 9, 1932, daughter of Austin A. McNichols and Marie Doherty McNichols, Jeanne was a graduate of Barrat College of The Sacred Heart. She was predeceased by her siblings Austin McNichols, Marilyn McNichols Hosty and Frank McNichols. Jeanne was a lover of life and the embodiment of classic New York. She surrounded herself with friends and family throughout the world. She could often be found in New York City, Chicago, Essex Fells, Bay Head, Princeton, Point O' Woods, Bermuda, the Bahamas, London and France. She brought love and laughter to all who crossed her path. Jeanne loved to entertain and play games of all sorts; with a particular fondness for bridge and crosswords. After a stint as a fashion model and a long career as a renown international interior designer, she settled in and devoted her time to charitable pursuits. She was a twenty year board member of the Central Park Conservancy; a member of the Tree Trust Committee; faithful benefactor of the Central Park Conservancy luncheon; and great patron of The New York Botanical Garden, to name a few. Survived by her loving children Joseph Fusco (Pamela), William Fusco, John Fusco, Thomas Fusco (Laurie), Stephen Fusco (Michele), Julie Fusco Lanning (Michael); her cherished grandchildren Davis, Scott, Tracey, Carly, Brooke, Katie, Austin, Matt, Kerry, Tommy, Lindsay, Dalton, Tripp, and Gardner; and her five dear step-children Debbie Jones Lupton (Steve), Geoffrey Jones, Leslie Jones Brittain (John), Betsy Jones Hall (Tyler), Andrew Jones, eleven step-grandchildren, and one step-great-grandchild. There will be a celebration of life in Manhattan during September, with time and place to follow. In lieu of flowers, please give donations to the Central Park Conservancy or The New York Botanical Garden. 1/3
SEGALL--Robert L. Six Years, Gone Too Soon. Missed Always. Loved Forever. Mom, Debbie, Jesse 1/3
BRADY--Roscoe. A truly wonderful and dedicated physician who devoted his life to medical research. Stuart Berman and Kevin Kline 1/3

AUBY--Scott Nathan, died on June 14, 2016 at age 47 of brain cancer. Among those grieving are his wife of 20 years, Jill Newman, their sons, Jake and Noah, Scott's parents, Carolyn and Alan Auby, his brother Gregg (Kristina) and their children, and his brother, Michael. Scott graduated from Sun Prairie High School in Wisconsin, where he was recently honored. He graduated from Lawrence University in 1990 with a degree in Music Theory and Composition. He spent two summers in the elite College Orchestra at Disney World, playing the trumpet and as assistant conductor. Jill and Scott met at Harvard Law School where Scott graduated Cum Laude in 1993. For 22 years, he practiced law in the DC office of Debevoise & Plimpton, where he was highly respected for his intellect and humor. Throughout his life, Scott continued to compose music and sing professionally, including with Cathedra at the Washington National Cathedral and with the Washington Bach Consort, where he also served on the Board. Rabbi Bruce Lustig (Washington Hebrew Congregation) and the Reverend Gini Gerbasi (St. John's Church, Georgetown) will preside at a memorial and celebration of life to be held 3pm on Sunday, June 26 at Washington Hebrew Congregation, 3935 Macomb Street NW in Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Johns Hopkins Hospital or any brain cancer research organization. 1/3
PERLSTEIN--Harvey L. You are still thought of with love. Audrey and Suzanne 1/3

Before I LeaveWritten and illustrated by Jessixa Bagley. 32 pp. Neal Porter/Roaring Brook. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)
 
In emotionally direct prose and watercolors full of tiny, charming details, Bagley (“Boats for Papa”) turns two of the forest’s less charismatic creatures into heart-stealing stars. Zelda, a hedgehog, looks forlorn as she tells Aaron, an anteater, he can’t come along to her family’s new house. But before the move they spend an afternoon playing and having ice cream cones — his miles-long tongue makes an astonishing appearance — creating a reassuring balance between happy, funny and sad.

WYMAN--M. Richard. Dick was a long-time friend whose loss will be deeply felt but whose perseverance will remain as an inspiration. Our hearts go out to Judy for whom we care so very much. Giovanna and Dan Rosenbloom 1

ALEXANDER--Marjorie, of Scarsdale, NY, on June 17th, 2016. Loving wife, mother, grandmother and great- grandmother. Predeceased by her husband, Norman E. Alexander. Survived by her children, Gail Binderman, Sharon Zoffness, Dr. Mark Alexander and Leslie Alexander. Grandmother to Deborah, Dan, Rachel, Courtney (Jeremy Gough), Benjamin (Mandy). Great-grandmother to Oliver, Leo and Hayden. Services will be private. 1/3

BURPEE--Robert N. "Bob", 90, of Yorktown Heights, NY, formerly of Ardsley, NY for 54 years, passed away June 13th, 2016. Born in Brooklyn in 1925, to Burt and Sadie "Susan" Burpee. Predeceased by his wife of 60 years, Jeannette (Heyer). Graduated from High School in Queens, and Upsala College and received a Master's from Columbia University. Bob was the owner and Headmaster of the Gramercy Park and Stuyvesant Private Schools in New York City. Bob is survived by three children and their spouses, eight grandchildren, four great-grandchildren and nieces and nephews. Memorial service at the Presbyterian Church in Yorktown Heights, Monday, June 20th, at 3:00pm. For additional information: www.burpeefamily.us 1/3
BREIDENBACH--Lester "Mickey," passed away June 15, 2016. Survived by loving wife, Carolyn; daughter Lynn Phillips, (Rick), stepson Robert Klineman, and three grandsons. 1/3

O'BRIEN--Thomas Brennan III, 30, of New York, NY passed away Wednesday, June 15th after an eight month battle with cancer. He was born in Philadelphia, PA on February 26, 1986 to Thomas B. O'Brien, Jr. and Federica F. O'Brien. Brennan graduated from Moorestown High School and went on to receive a Bachelor of Science from the University of Richmond. He was married to Allison Sottile on November 8, 2014 in Lake Placid, NY. Brennan took great pride in both his career and relationship with colleagues, working at Barclays Capital for six years within Structured Investments and most recently as an Executive Director at CIBC World Markets. His infectious love of life and competitive nature were a testament to his unrelenting spirit throughout his cancer battle, even taking part in Memorial Sloan Kettering's Cycle for Survival on his 30th birthday this past February to fundraise for rare cancer research. Brennan is survived by his loving wife Allison, his parents Tom and Freddi O'Brien and sister Alexandra Lunkenheimer. A celebration in honor of Brennan's life will be held at a future date for friends and family. Memorial donations may be made to Team O'Brien at Cycle for Survival: www.cycleforsurvival.org/ brennan-obrien-memorial. Services are under the direction of John F. Pfleger Funeral Home, Middletown, NJ. 1/3

PATTEN--Walter W.,Jr. (1928 - 2016) died peacefully on May 29 in Boston, MA where he was a longtime resident. "Bud" was born in New Jersey, attended the Pingry School and was a graduate of the Sibley College of Mechanical Engineering of Cornell University. He served on active duty in the United States Air Force during the Korean War and went on to have a long career with the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company in New York City and Boston. He is survived by his adoring wife Charlotte Jorgensen Patten, his brother John Wills Patten of Stowe, VT, and by numerous nieces and nephews along with great-nieces and nephews to whom he was devoted. A Memorial for him will be held at a later date. Donations may gratefully be made in his name either to the Society of Colonial Wars in Massachusetts, 227 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston 02116 or to the Society of the Cincinnati in New Hampshire, 2118 Massachusetts Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20008. 1/3

DRAKE--Harrington "Duke." Passed away at his home in Wickenburg, AZ on June 7th. Mr. Drake, 96, was the former chairman and chief executive of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation and led the firm 1975 to 1985. He was named "CEO of the Year" in 1984 by the Financial Times Magazine, and "One of the Great American Business Leaders of the 20th Century" by Harvard Business School. Mr. Drake was also president of Ruben H. Donnelley Corporation from 1972 to 1975. He served on the boards of Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, Baxter International Corporation, Rockwell International Corporation, Irving Trust Bank Corporation, Magnavox Corporation, Seaman's Bank for Savings, and the Desert Caballeros Western Museum. Mr. Drake graduated from Colgate University in 1941 with a Bachelor's Degree in Philosophy and Religion. He also received an honorary Doctor of Laws Degree from Colgate in 1985. He was Chairman Emeritus of Colgate University's Board of Trustees, having served as chairman of the board from 1979-1985. This is a position that was also held by his beloved stepfather Wellington Powell. For his extraordinary volunteer work at Colgate, Mr. Drake received the Ernest T. Stewart Award from the Council for Advancement and Support of Education, the organization's highest award, presented by the U.S. Secretary of Education in 1983. He and his wife, Shirley Grant Drake (who predeceased him in 1993) established the Drake Chair in the Humanities in 1988 and the Library and Scholarship Funds in 1990. In 2004 Mr. Drake and his wife Patricia van Eybergen Drake also established another scholarship fund. As a business leader, Mr. Drake was a life-long champion of the value of having a liberal arts education, which he believed taught critical and independent thinking. Additionally he felt strongly that colleges should encourage students to become bi-lingual in order to be truly prepared to work in our modern interconnected world. During World War II Mr. Drake served as a pilot, rising to the rank of Lt. Colonel in the Air Force Reserve and received the Air Medal and Oak Leaf Cluster while in the 20th Troop Carrier Squadron in the 6th Air Force. While in the South Atlantic Theater he flew two five star Generals: Hap Arnold and George C. Marshall to visit air bases. He flew the Brazilian chief of staff General Gaspar Dutra (later president of Brazil) on a tour of the European Theater of Operations to review Brazilian troops. He also flew the Bob Hope Troupe on an entertainment tour of the 6th Air Force. Mr. Drake was born in Kansas City, MO in 1919. He finished growing up in Caldwell, NJ. He lived in New York, New Hampshire, Los Angeles and Connecticut. In retirement he divided his time between homes in Carpinteria, CA and Wickenburg, AZ. Mr. Drake was a person who would take on challenging projects and bring a combination of imagination, perseverance and dynamic leadership. Those who worked with him benefitted from his willingness to set very high goals and create a strong team spirit. At the same time he adhered to high moral standards, explaining to his teams that, "We're Boy Scouts." All who got to know him were blessed by his personal warmth, loyalty and very active sense of humor. He greatly enjoyed people and made deep enduring friendships wherever he lived and worked. Many of those whose lives he touched would attest to the fact that, due to his interest and encouragement, he changed their lives. While, in his last years he was not blessed with good health, his love of life and for the people around him overcame all his adversities. He remained to the end a cheerful and delightful companion in life and will be sorely missed. Mr. Drake was married to Shirley Grant, daughter of William T. Grant, from 1943 until her death in 1993. He married Patricia Van Eybergen of Mexico City, Mexico in 1995 and is not only survived by her but also by his sons Ted, Jeffrey (Barbara Smith) and Andy, as well as by three grandchildren, two great- grandchildren, his brother Donald Powell, along with many nieces and nephews and the children and grand- children of his stepfamily. 1/3

MIKLOS--Jack C. died on June 16, 2016, at his San Francisco home, just one month shy of his 90th birthday, with his wife and son at his side. A native of Moscow, Idaho, Jack earned a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart in the Asian Pacific Theater during World War II before serving in the American Foreign Service for 36 years. During his diplomatic career, he was posted in Yokohama, Japan; Tangier, Morocco; Istanbul, Turkey; Nice, France; Bombay, India; Colombo, Sri Lanka; and twice in Tehran, Iran. During his later posting in Tehran as Deputy Chief of Mission at the American Embassy, he also served as interim Charge d'Affaires during the Pahlavi regime. Before he retired, Jack was stationed in Washington, D.C., as Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Near East Affairs. Jack received a master's of science degree from Stanford University. He attended Gonzaga University in Spokane, Washington, where he established a permanent scholarship endowment in memory of his father, Jack D. Miklos, which supports 15 students each year. Jack is survived by his wife of 13 years, Helga Justman, and was predeceased by his first wife, Rhoda Virginia Knudten Miklos. He also is survived by his son, Stephan Douglas Miklos (Lorraine); two daughters, Shari Judith Behrens (Tom) and Melpomene Irina Doner (Dennis); seven grandchildren; nine great-grandchildren; his stepson, Alex Justman (Sandy); his step-daughter, Dr. Jessica Justman (Jack Lerner); three step-grandchildren; his sister, Margaret M. DuBois; and one nephew. He loved and was loved by all and will be greatly missed. 1/3
JACOBS--Samuel JACOBS--Dr. Bertrand FINEMAN--Joseph Miss you and love you more than ever. Carol won a Tony! Frances Jacobs Fineman 1/3

BERTCHER-- Robert W.,MD, passed away peacefully in his sleep on June 5, 2016. Dr. Bertcher was born on April 24, 1925. He attended the University of Pennsylvania as an undergraduate and received his medical degree from NYU Medical School. Dr. Bertcher was a Veteran of the Korean War, serving as a Captain in the United States Army. Dr. Bertcher practiced internal medicine in Lynnbrook, NY for more than 40 years before retiring to Gainesville, FL. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Georgia; his brother Harvey, in Ann Arbor, MI and several nieces and nephews, including Quincy Thoeni, in Plant City, FL and Corey Bertcher, in Ypsilanti, MI. Memorial services have not yet been planned and will be held at the discretion of the family. 1/3
