AUBY--Scott Nathan, died on June 14, 2016 at age 47 of brain cancer. Among those grieving are his wife of 20 years, Jill Newman, their sons, Jake and Noah, Scott's parents, Carolyn and Alan Auby, his brother Gregg (Kristina) and their children, and his brother, Michael. Scott graduated from Sun Prairie High School in Wisconsin, where he was recently honored. He graduated from Lawrence University in 1990 with a degree in Music Theory and Composition. He spent two summers in the elite College Orchestra at Disney World, playing the trumpet and as assistant conductor. Jill and Scott met at Harvard Law School where Scott graduated Cum Laude in 1993. For 22 years, he practiced law in the DC office of Debevoise & Plimpton, where he was highly respected for his intellect and humor. Throughout his life, Scott continued to compose music and sing professionally, including with Cathedra at the Washington National Cathedral and with the Washington Bach Consort, where he also served on the Board. Rabbi Bruce Lustig (Washington Hebrew Congregation) and the Reverend Gini Gerbasi (St. John's Church, Georgetown) will preside at a memorial and celebration of life to be held 3pm on Sunday, June 26 at Washington Hebrew Congregation, 3935 Macomb Street NW in Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Johns Hopkins Hospital or any brain cancer research organization. 1/3

WILKS--Richard, of Albuquerque, NM, died June 7 at the age of 85. He is survived by his wife of 60 years Sandra, sons Jono and Matt, brother Donald and six grandchildren. Born in Newark, graduated from Weequahic High, in Navy three years during Korea. He received scholarships to Antioch and University of Chicago Law. He practiced law in Phoenix and was counsel to the Pima Indian community. Richard was active in civil rights, argued in front of the Supreme Court and was McGovern's campaign manager. He practiced law but served under justice and fought hard for people less fortunate. There was a military service conducted by the US Navy at the Santa Fe National Cemetery. 1/3

MERMELSTEIN--Dr. Steven, on June 18, 2016. Beloved husband of Helene. Loving father of Dana (Martin) Weeks. Cherished grandfather of Carter and Jordan. Services Tuesday, June 21, 2016 at 9:30am at the Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore, 1001 Plandome Rd., Manhasset, NY. For information contact Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 516 487-9600. 1/3

MARTIN--Susan Melvoin, beloved mother, daughter, sister, teacher, and friend, died peacefully at home at age 60. She had been living with ALS for five years. A funeral service is planned for 11am, Wednesday, June 22, at Ansche Chesed Synagogue, 251 West 100th St. The family has designated The ALS Foundation (for research) or MACAngels (for support of those living with ALS) for memorial contributions. 1/3

JOSEPHSON--Joan Ellen. Beloved wife of Dr. Mark Josephson for 48 years, devoted mother of Rachel and Stephanie, adoring "Grammy" to Sylvie, Elan, and Sydney, died after a courageous battle with cancer on June 17th at the age of 72. With a BA from Penn State and an EdM from Columbia, she devoted her life to helping others. She was a teacher, advisor, and long term volunteer: at the Ronald McDonald House, as a leader of the surgical liaison service and a member of the Parent Connection at the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, and as a tutor for Read Boston. With a style of understated elegance and a motto to "always to do the right thing", she was inspirational to all who came into contact with her. The world is a better place because of her. Funeral services will be held on Monday, June 20th at 1:15pm Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, New York, NY. 1/3

ARMENTO--William J.,101, died in San Mateo, CA. Survived by Elvina, his wife of 70 years, daughters Valerie, Anne (Patrick Dunn), Janice (James Scherba) and Lisa Armento, seven grandchildren, Jill Armento Curran of Greenwich, Connecticut, numerous nieces and nephews. Bill graduated from Stuyvesant in 1931, from CCNY in 1935, and earned an MS in civil engineering at Columbia in 1949. He taught engineering courses at CCNY from 1938 through 1950 as well as evening classes at Brooklyn Polytechnic. In the 1930's he worked for Madigan-Hyland designing the upper levels of the Henry Hudson and Whitestone Bridges and supervised construction of the East River (FDR) Drive. At Parsons, Brinkerhoff he worked on designs for the Bay Area Rapid Transit System and relocated to San Francisco in 1963. A licensed professional engineer in five states and a licensed land surveyor in New York, he served on the New York State Board of Examiners for Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors. Eternal tribute at www.ssofunerals.com 1/3

LEDBETTER--Myron C. died at his home in Belle Terre, NY on June 1, at the age of 92. He had been an active and well-known member of his community for many years. Myron was born in Ardmore, OK on June 25, 1923, the son of the late Robert and Adeline Ledbetter. Myron was a freshman at Oklahoma State when World War II began. During the summer of 1942 he earned a commission as an ensign in the United States Navy and was assigned to LST 947. His ship was part of the invasion of Okinawa and occupation of Japan. Upon his discharge Myron returned to Oklahoma to finish his studies in plant biology at Oklahoma State, then realizing he needed further education in his chosen field of plant biology, went to UC Berkeley for a Master's Degree. Myron worked as a Research Assistant at Boyce Thompson Institute in Yonkers, NY while pursuing his PhD work in botany at Columbia University. To further his specialized work on the plant cell research, Myron then went to Rockefeller Institute to work with Dr. Keith Porter to develop new techniques on the electron microscope. A year later to continue his research, he went to Harvard University with Dr. Porter's team. Working with the electron microscope, Myron and Dr. Porter published many new important findings, ultimately resulting in the publication of an atlas of plant cells "Introduction to the Fine Structure of Plant Cells." Finally in 1965 Myron accepted a position as a cell biologist and ultimately senior cell biologist at Brookhaven National Laboratory where he stayed until his retirement in 1989. Myron was a highly respected cell biologist and well known for his work on the electron microscope. He and Dr. Porter published research in 1963 on the discovery of a new organelle in plant cells, the microtubule, which initiated a whole new area of plant cell biology research, a discovery so significant that fifty years later the July 2013 issue of the scientific journal "Plant Journal" devoted its entire issue to the importance of this finding. Myron, and another colleague Robert Dell, invented a self-cleaning aperture to correct a problem with the electron microscope, a gad- get which saved hours of down time of the microscope and is still widely in use. Myron was elected as the president of the Electron Microscopy Society of America for 1978. That Society also awarded him the Distinguished Scientist Award, Biological Sciences, for 1996. Myron possessed a keen inquiring intellect and had a seemingly encyclopedic knowledge of and interest in many areas. He was particularly interested in social justice and human rights and established the Myron C. Ledbetter Diversity Scholarship at Oklahoma State University. In 2000 he was given the OSU Distinguished Alumni Award. Myron enjoyed theater and classical music, travel, reading, book discussion groups, entertaining and dining out. He and his life partner of over 55 years, John D'Aquila who predeceased him in 2014, had been subscribing members of the Metropolitan Opera and the Roundabout Theater Company for many years. In Port Jefferson they particularly enjoyed Theatre Three. Myron was a co-founder of OLLI (Osher Lifelong Learning Institute) at Stony Brook University and participated in many of its programs. He became interested in stained glass and created many beautiful imaginative pieces, some even based on his own microscopic plant cell enlargements. He was an active member of the memoirs group and continued as long as his health permitted. Myron traveled extensively. He and John had friends everywhere, including the group with whom he served in WWII. In 2012 Myron and John were married, an event which gave great joy to their family and friends. Myron was predeceased by his brother Robert. He is survived by a sister-in-law Marcia Ledbetter and by a cousin Margaret Garland, and by many loving nieces and nephews and by a host of lifelong friends. Myron Ledbetter was a gracious and kind man and a thoughtful friend. He will be greatly missed. Memorial donations in Myron's name may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10065. Expressions of condolence may be sent to the family of Myron C. Ledbetter c/o www. obdavisportjefferson.com A celebration of Myron's life will be held on June 26, at the Belle Terre Community Center, Cliff Road at 11am. 1/3

WOODS--Michael F.,of Bronxville, NY on June 19, 2016 at the age of 85. Beloved husband of the late Helen, loving father of Teresa W. (Shaun) Daley, Stephen (Cindy) and Michael (Sherry), devoted grandfather of five. Dear brother of Sr. Mary Denis (Imelda), Connie Fonseca and the late Joan and Patricia. Proud graduate of Regis, Fordham University and New York Law School. He was the former New York State Deputy Commissioner of Commerce and retired as the Vice President of the New York Power Authority. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son funeral home, Bronxville between the hours of 5 to 8pm Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Josephs Church, Bronxville on Wednesday at 10:45am. 1/3

LEVY--Lawrence, on June 18, 2016 at age 87. Survived by Toba Sherwood Levy, father of Ford (Cindy) Levy and Hope Levy. Grandfather of Kristen and Maxwell Levy and George Kaslow. Graveside service Monday, June 20 at 3:00pm, Beth David Cemetery Elmont, NY. 1/3

McLEAN--Linda Durfee. The Board of Governors of Squadron A Association and the Board of Trustees of Squadron A Foundation deeply mourn the passing of Linda, the beloved wife of the late COL Robert L. McLean, Squadron A's esteemed Board Chair and President for many years. Linda was a longtime member and staunch supporter of both organizations and served with distinction as a Governor and Trustee. We will miss her friendship, sense of humor and wise counsel. We extend our sympathy to her sister, stepdaughters and their families and her many friends. At long last she and Bob are together again. Major General Edward G. Klein, Board Chair Michael D. Witter, President Squadron A Association and Squadron A Foundation 1/3

FOA--Linda. Pioneer in Design Journalism and Marketing Linda Rimanich Foa passed away peacefully at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on June 17, 2016 after a long battle with cancer. She is survived by her husband, Conrad, their sons, Justin and Barrett, and grandchildren, Max and Luke. Her abiding interest in others, her incomparable style, and her take no prisoners demeanor, meant that everyone knew that she was "in the room". Her always-positive impact on her family and friends will be sorely missed. The stars were already aligning because Linda and Conrad were both born in Wickersham Hospital (across the street from Bloomingdale's); Linda was born there 51 weeks after her future husband. Her family resided in Jamaica Estates, New York City, where she graduated from The Mary Louis Academy. Linda majored in Fashion and Fine Arts at Parsons/NYU. Linda's sense of style, superb writing ability, and natural beauty were a unique combination that was unleashed on the world of design journalism. Linda began her professional career at Fairchild's Home Furnishings Daily and HFN where she was an editor, and penned the still-remembered FYI column. While mothering, she wrote several lead cover articles for New York Magazine, articles for The New York Times Style Section, and co-authored Kids' Stuff, the definitive furnishings guide to children's furniture and home environments [Pantheon/Random House]. In the 1990s, Linda headed and brought Designer's Saturday to prominence; producing a world-renowned annual contract furniture show in New York City that featured over 100 participating showrooms. The food and ambiance offered in the showrooms were even reviewed by Mimi Sheraton in The New York Times. For the past 11+ years, Linda was the Marketing Director of the Architects & Designers building at 150 East 58th Street. She is credited with burnishing the building's ability to attract high-end kitchen, bathroom and furniture showrooms. She contributed to a soaring occupancy rate and was instrumental in partnering with The New York Times to host the building-wide Taste of T foodie event for over a decade. Walking through the building with her, it was obvious that she was loved by tenants and co-workers alike. Linda, along with her spouse, were prominent members of the Lexington Democratic Club. She rose to the party post of District Leader and was a fierce proponent of the Club's role in forwarding and bettering the Democratic agenda. It was with great pleasure that she witnessed the presumptive nomination by the Democratic Party of the first female presidential nominee. The success of her children, Justin [fifth generation owner and CEO of 155 year-old international insurance brokerage firm, Foa & Son] and Barrett (respected, multi-talented lead actor, singer, dancer in two Tony Award-winning Broadway shows, with an eight year series-regular role on CBS's "NCIS: Los Angeles") speaks volumes about her exceptional mothering. Linda and her husband, Conrad, did everything together and were rarely apart during their 50 year relationship. A memorial service for Linda will we held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls at 1157 Lexington Avenue (80th Street) on June 28, 2016 at 11:00am. There will be a reception for Linda's friends after the service. 1/3

ARFFA--Robert C. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton and Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of Dr. Robert C. Arffa, beloved brother of our friend and partner Allan J. Arffa. We express our deepest sympathies to Allan, Kay and to all other members of the family. 1/3

ROSE--Stanley H. Stanley was the eldest child of Rose and Walter Rose. Stanley is survived by his beloved siblings, Marion and Martin. Stanley is also survived by his loving wife, Lenore, and their two sons, Michael Rose and Gordon Rose. Stanley and Lenore with some help have graced the world with six grandchildren, Garrett, Neilly, Margaret, Evelyn, Sam and James. Stanley was a long time New Yorker, a veteran of the Korean War and a graduate of Syracuse University and Columbia Business School. Stanley worked with Merrill Lynch and its predecessors for almost 40 years. Services 9:45am, Sunday at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

ZELANKO--Seymour, a retired tax accountant and partner at Margolin, Winer & Evens for almost five decades, died June 15, 2016 at age 86. He was a brilliant, kind and generous man. Survived by his loving wife of nearly 50 years, Diane (Desreau), his devoted children, Amy Gostfrand and husband Maury and Marc Zelanko and wife Rhonda Weiner, and five grandchildren, Jack, Jess, and Justin Gostfrand and Lilah and Amelia Zelanko. Graveside funeral June 20 at 1pm at New Montefiore Cemetery. 1/3

ZEIGERMAN--David, It is with a profound sense of loss and sorrow that we note the passing of David Zeigerman on June 17th in Edgewater, NJ. David was a devoted husband to Mindy Gale, a loving father to Arianne and Zara, and a beloved brother to Ziggy. Born in Vienna, his family then moved to Malmo, Sweden, where he grew up and began his creative career. David was an award-winning art director, artist and entrepreneur. His passion for the arts was exceeded only by his lifelong desire to mentor the talents of young artists. A tireless champion for the State of Israel, he was also an advocate of Holocaust awareness and education. In addition to his immediate family, he leaves behind a host of family and friends who will cherish his memory, legacy and indomitable spirit forever. Funeral services will be held at 11am on Tuesday, June 21st at Temple Emanu-El in Cloister, NJ. 1/3

NEWBURGER--Doris, died peacefully at the age of 91 on June 18, 2016. Beloved wife of 67 years to Dr. Howard Newburger. Loving mother to Dr. Amy E. Newburger (Dr. Lawrence Posner), Barry Newburger (Andrea) and Cary Newburger (Devorah). Devoted grandmother to Dr. Amanda Posner (Ben Neumann), Russell Posner (Dr. Melissa Posner), Nicholas Newburger and Grant Newburger. Doris was a radio actress prior to her marriage. She obtained her PhD from NYU and retired as a Professor and Chairperson of the Speech, Communications and Theater Arts Department, Borough of Manhattan Community College. She enjoyed a lifetime filled with travel, theater, and her cherished family. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, June 21, 2016 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment at Old Montefiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Boulevard, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: CurePSP.org or The Breast Cancer Research Foundation (bcrfcure.org). 1/3

GREENWALD--Ted. With profound sadness, we announce the death of Theodore Mitchell Greenwald, 73, who died on June 17, 2016. He is survived by his wife, Joan McClusky, their daughter, Abigail Greenwald, and three sisters. Born in Brooklyn in 1942, Ted was first, last and always a New Yorker. He was also a prolific and gifted poet, a great friend, and had a passionate love of and interest in life and people. He will be greatly missed by the many who enjoyed his company, his works, and his generous and joyous spirit. A memorial service is planned for the fall. 1/3

ATNALLY--Richard, of Broomfield, CO, passed away on June 14th from complications following a fall. Dick, as he was known, is survived by his beloved wife Mary, daughter Diane Conlin of Superior, CO, son David of Cambridge, VT, grandchildren Kevin and Julia, and brother Edward of Bronxville, NY. He was predeceased by his parents Olive and Edward, and his twin brother, William. He was a Professor of English Literature at William Paterson University in Wayne, NJ for 24 years where he founded and directed the Humanities Honors Program, a program designed to challenge students with ideas and concepts beyond their normal experiences. Dick enjoyed sharing with his students his love of poetry, literature, and the history of ideas. He involved them in making films about significant poets of Greenwich Village and Paterson, NJ, including William Carlos Williams and Alan Ginsburg. Dick also taught at Queens University in Charlotte, NC, New York's School for Social Research, and Yale University. He and Mary were married for 56 wonderful years, during which time they shared their passion for traveling, art, and history. Services will be private. Contributions in Dick's memory may be sent to the WB Yeats Society of New York, c/o National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, NYC 10003. 1/3

LEIDERMAN--Abraham "Al", 98, of Palm Beach, FL and Great Neck, NY June 19, 2016. Beloved husband (73 years) of the late Lillian; father of Michael (Hermine), Beth (Martin Statfeld) and the late Robert; grandfather of Jill (Robert Cohen), Eric (Natalie), Jenna (Aaron Harris) and Dani (Todd Elkins); great-grandfather of Anna Ray Harris and Rocket Lee Cohen; brother of Bernice Fein and the late Ralph Leiderman; successful businessman and volunteer extraordinaire, he loved friends, jokes, ice cream and deli (but not together), and his family most of all. 1/3

COX--Robert (Bob) Bartley, 78, died in his home in Sherman, CT on Saturday, June 18, 2016. Son of Dessie Mae Skinner and Robert Spencer Cox, he leaves behind his wife, Loretta D. Cox, sister Virginia Binford, son Spencer B. Cox and wife, Denise D. Cox, daughter Jennifer A. Cox and husband Patrick S. Stettner and grandchildren, Heather Nazario, Marta M. Cox and Lucas E. Stettner. Bob was a highly recognized icon in the advertising industry known for such groundbreaking campaigns as Nancy Regan's, 'Just say No', Honda's 'We Make it Simple', and the seminal Salvador Dali ad for Alka Seltzer. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to furthering the pursuits of students at The Art Student's League (http://www.theartstudents league.org) in his beloved New York City. Services by the Lillis Funeral Home, 58 Bridge St., New Milford, CT. 1/3

FOA--Linda. Pioneer in Design Journalism and Marketing Linda Rimanich Foa passed away peacefully at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on June 17, 2016 after a long battle with cancer. She is survived by her husband, Conrad, their sons, Justin and Barrett, and grandchildren, Max and Luke. Her abiding interest in others, her incomparable style, and her take no prisoners demeanor, meant that everyone knew that she was "in the room". Her always-positive impact on her family and friends will be sorely missed. The stars were already aligning because Linda and Conrad were both born in Wickersham Hospital (across the street from Bloomingdale's); Linda was born there 51 weeks after her future husband. Her family resided in Jamaica Estates, New York City, where she graduated from The Mary Louis Academy. Linda majored in Fashion and Fine Arts at Parsons/NYU. Linda's sense of style, superb writing ability, and natural beauty were a unique combination that was unleashed on the world of design journalism. Linda began her professional career at Fairchild's Home Furnishings Daily and HFN where she was an editor, and penned the still-remembered FYI column. While mothering, she wrote several lead cover articles for New York Magazine, articles for The New York Times Style Section, and co-authored Kids' Stuff, the definitive furnishings guide to children's furniture and home environments [Pantheon/Random House]. In the 1990s, Linda headed and brought Designer's Saturday to prominence; producing a world-renowned annual contract furniture show in New York City that featured over 100 participating showrooms. The food and ambiance offered in the showrooms were even reviewed by Mimi Sheraton in The New York Times. For the past 11+ years, Linda was the Marketing Director of the Architects & Designers building at 150 East 58th Street. She is credited with burnishing the building's ability to attract high-end kitchen, bathroom and furniture showrooms. She contributed to a soaring occupancy rate and was instrumental in partnering with The New York Times to host the building-wide Taste of T foodie event for over a decade. Walking through the building with her, it was obvious that she was loved by tenants and co-workers alike. Linda, along with her spouse, were prominent members of the Lexington Democratic Club. She rose to the party post of District Leader and was a fierce proponent of the Club's role in forwarding and bettering the Democratic agenda. It was with great pleasure that she witnessed the presumptive nomination by the Democratic Party of the first female presidential nominee. The success of her children, Justin [fifth generation owner and CEO of 155 year-old international insurance brokerage firm, Foa & Son] and Barrett (respected, multi-talented lead actor, singer, dancer in two Tony Award-winning Broadway shows, with an eight year series-regular role on CBS's "NCIS: Los Angeles") speaks volumes about her exceptional mothering. Linda and her husband, Conrad, did everything together and were rarely apart during their 50 year relationship. A memorial service for Linda will we held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls at 1157 Lexington Avenue (80th Street) on June 28, 2016 at 11:00am. There will be a reception for Linda's friends after the service. 1/3

WAMSLER--Karl M.F. The Trustees and Staff of The New York Botanical Garden wish to record their great sadness at the death of Karl M.F. Wamsler. Karl was a distinguished scientist and businessman and lived in Pocking, Germany, near Munich. He was the father of five daughters, including Caroline A. Wamsler, Ph.D., Chairman of the Education and Nominating Committees of the Board of this institution. Karl's late wife Honore was a long-term Vice Chairman of the Board. Karl participated in many aspects of the life of NYBG, and we will truly miss his acute intelligence, charm, and joie de vivre. He and Honore were greatly valued friends. Our most sincere condolences to his daughters and their families. Maureen K. Chilton, Chairman; Gregory Long, The William C. Steere Sr. President 1/3

BAY--Eugene A.,83, passed away on June 18, 2016 in New York. Born in 1933 to Eugene Albert Bay and Helene Carlin Bay in New York City, he graduated from Phillips Academy Andover and The University of Pennsylvania. He served in the U.S. Marine Corps from 1957- 1960. A legendary advertising and publishing executive, "Gene" Bay served as publisher of Field & Stream Magazine. Later at Gene Bay Associates he pioneered the transformation of fishing and hunting programming to mainstream media with ESPN Outdoors. Trustee Emeritus of The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, a lifetime member and former governor of the New York Athletic Club, and from the Polo Grounds to MetLife Stadium, a life-long New York Football Giants season ticket holder. Predeceased by his brother, John M. Bay, he is survived by his beloved wife of 53 years, Deidre Lesage Bay, his children Willow Bay and husband Robert A. Iger, Kacey Bay and husband Nick Pappas, and Eric M. Bay and his seven grandchildren: Max and William Iger, Carlin and Nicholas Pappas, Savannah, Isabella and Emma Bay. Memorial Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st Street and Madison Avenue, on Thursday from 5pm-8pm. Prayer Service will take place at 7pm. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, on Friday 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made In Memory of Gene Bay to Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home, 1339 York Avenue, NY 10021. 1/3
SEGALL--Sean S. Six Years, Gone Too Soon. Missed Always. Loved Forever. Noonie, Jesse 1/3

WAMSLER--Dr. Karl Maximilian Friedrich, beloved and revered father and father-in-law of Bettina Wamsler and Christian Bechtle, Susanne Wamsler and Paul Singer, Irene Banning and Jack Banning, Caroline A. Wamsler and DeWayne N. Phillips, and Pauline Wamsler and David J. Sales died peacefully surrounded by his family at his home in Pocking, Germany on Saturday, June 18, 2016. He is also survived by his twelve grandchildren: Clara, Luisa, Christopher, Johanna, Inga, Kaspar, Marie, George, Charlotte, Schuyler, Karl and Sophia. His commanding intellect, pervasive charm, love of family, and unfailing belief in a good world informed a life of integrity and extraordinary achievements. He was the rock of his family and an example for all who knew him. The burial and requiem will be held in Pocking, St. Pius on June 29, 2016. Services are being made by Zirngibl Funeral Home, Hanfelder Str., 53, Starnberg 82319. (+49.8151.36140). 1/3

HAIMOWITZ--Patricia Hurley. Pat died peacefully at home June 20. Loving wife, mother, and stepmother. A bright star in the public relations firmament for more than a half century, notably at St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, 1960-1972, then as partner in Hurley & Haimowitz Public Relations. Funeral mass Thursday 10am, St. Augustine Church, 116 Sixth Ave., Brooklyn. 1/3
KINZEL--David. June 21, your 79th birthday. You will be loved always. Pat Lynch 1/3
COHEN--Daniel, dies at 92, Pharmacist, WWII Veteran, husband of Joan Oxhorn, father of Alice, Susan, Ceil, Irene and Roger. Funeral, June 22, 11:30am at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76st. 1/3

ARFFA--Robert C. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton and Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of Dr. Robert C. Arffa, beloved brother of our friend and partner Allan J. Arffa. We express our deepest sympathies to Allan, Kay and to all other members of the family. 1/3

SOLOMON--Alan, beloved father, brother, grandfather, uncle, passed away peacefully on Sunday, June 19, surrounded by loved ones. Alan was the loving father of David, Andy and Jeff; adoring brother to Steve, doting grandfather of Katie, Carrie, Samantha and Lyla; and, caring uncle of Amy, Ken and Emily. Alan was the loving husband for fifty years to Sandra, who died in 2010. He was lucky to find the love and companionship of Ellen in his last five years. Alan took great joy from spending time with his family, especially his granddaughters. Alan was a passionate life-long lover of food and wine. He taught his sons and granddaughters the pleasures of a delicious cheese, paired with a hearty red wine. Alan was also a longtime student of the market, excited by business and finance for his entire life. He also enjoyed being involved in his local community, chairing for several years the Armonk Art Fair. And he was an original founder of Woodlands Community Temple. Alan was a friend to many, a mentor to his sons and a generous and affectionate grandfather. He will be deeply missed by all those who were lucky to know him. Funeral services will be held at 12 noon on Tuesday, June 21 at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mount Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, Alan's family will be grateful for any donations made in his memory to Prostate Cancer Foundation (PCF.org), 1250 4th Street, Santa Monica, CA 90401 (1-800-757-2873). 1/3

DIAZ--Rosa. Lissett has been a supportive and loving daughter, and the entire department is saddened by her loss. 1/3

MARTIN--Susan Melvoin, beloved mother, daughter, sister, teacher, and friend, died peacefully at home at age 60. She had been living with ALS for five years. WILKES--David R. It is with a profound sense of loss and sorrow that we note the passing of David R. Wilkes on June 18, in Los Angeles. Beloved husband to Ruth; father to Stephen, Bette, Donald, Kimberly, Sharon and Robert; grandfather to Jennie, Sam, Jacob, Rachel, Michaela and Aliya. Born in Providence, RI, David was an innovative pioneer in the food and flavoring business. From his work on developing K-rations during WWII to creating some of the most beloved ice cream and soda flavors such as, Haagen Dazs coffee ice cream and Dr. Browns black cherry soda, he was a creative inspiration to us all. He was defined by hard work, passion and empathy, but his first priority was always his family. You will always be in our hearts Opa. Services to be held at Lincoln Park Cemetery Chapel, Tuesday, June 21, 10:30am, 1469 Post Road, Warwick, RI. 1/3

ZINNEMAN--David. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of David Zinneman, associated with The New York Times from May 31, 1973 until retiring on July 1, 2014. 1/3

UBAKIVI--Dr. Mary R.,94, passed away peacefully at her residence in Manhattan on June 15, 2016. In 1945, at the age of 24, she fled Estonia alone during a period of great political turmoil, to Germany. She immigrated to the US in 1950. A professor at NYU Dental School, she was the only female instructor during her tenure there. She had a successful private practice in Manhattan and was a member of The American Dental Association. Mary was a vivacious, glamorous and independent woman who enjoyed travel and explored the world. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. 1/3

NEWBURGER--Doris, died peacefully at the age of 91 on June 18, 2016. Beloved wife of 67 years to Dr. Howard Newburger. Loving mother to Dr. Amy E. Newburger (Dr. Lawrence Posner), Barry Newburger (Andrea) and Cary Newburger (Devorah). Devoted grandmother to Dr. Amanda Posner (Ben Neumann), Russell Posner (Dr. Melissa Posner), Nicholas Newburger and Grant Newburger. Doris was a radio actress prior to her marriage. She obtained her PhD from NYU and retired as a Professor and Chairperson of the Speech, Communications and Theater Arts Department, Borough of Manhattan Community College. She enjoyed a lifetime filled with travel, theater, and her cherished family. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, June 21, 2016 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment at Old Montefiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Boulevard, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: CurePSP.org or The Breast Cancer Research Foundation (bcrfcure.org). 1/3

QUINN--Cecilia Ann, (85), on June 17, 2016 of Garden City, NY. Beloved wife of the late James J. Quinn. Loving mother of Maureen, Matthew, Eileen, Patricia, and the late Catherine. JOHNSON--Walter C.,Headmaster of Hackley School, died on June 16 at age 64. The son of Carroll F. and Betty K. Johnson, he was born on June 6, 1952 in Northampton, MA into a family of educators. A 1974 graduate of Amherst College, he earned his MA in English from the University of Pennsylvania and MA in Educational Administration from Teachers College, Columbia University. A teacher at heart, he began his career in education teaching English at Trinity School in New York before serving as Upper School Director at Collegiate School. He found his life's work at Hackley, where he served as Headmaster for 21 years. He helped lead the school through unprecedented growth and development and deepened the school's commitment to its core values of community, inclusion, respect, and kindness. Survived by his wife Tracey Eve Johnson, sister Katherine Sussman, stepmother Susan K. Johnson and children Meg and Will. Memorial Service, Sunday, June 26, 3pm at Hackley School. Memorial contributions may be made to the Walter C. Johnson Financial Aid Endowment Fund at Hackley School, 293 Benedict Avenue, Tarrytown, NY 10591. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Lolita E.,died peacefully in her Manhattan apartment on June 21 following a short battle with cancer. An inspirational nonagenarian, she was fluent in many languages and taught French at Riverdale Country School for three decades. A beloved member of the extended families of her late husband Melvin S. Goldstein and of her late sister Carmen Magalhaes (nee Eshborn), she is survived by sister-in-law and brother-in-law Eileen and Milton Putterman, and by sixty-one nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grandnephews, great-grandnieces and greatgrandnephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to American Associates of Ben Gurion University. 1/3

PRATT--Carol H.,on June 20, 2016 of East Norwich, NY. Beloved wife of Hon. George C. Pratt, U.S. Circuit Judge, Second Circuit Court of Appeals (retired). Loving mother of George (Charlotte), Lise Pratt, Marcy (James) Burke and Duffy (Yanzi). Dear grandmother of Jessica Wilde, Elizabeth (Jason) Tea, Clayton (Katy) Pratt, Dylan (Lizzie) Pratt and Elijah Pratt and great- grandmother of Charles Wilde, Clementine Pratt and Samson Pratt. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Road, Syosset, NY. Visiting: Wednesday, 7-9pm and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Service Friday, 10am at The Community Church of Syosset, 36 Church Street, Syosset, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Carol Pratt Memorial Fund, The Community Church of Syosset. 1/3

COHEN--Charles. Charles passed away June 19, 2016 at the age of 81. While professionally a periodontist and implantologist, he was a true Renaissance man. Eagle Scout, Order of the Arrow, birder, photographer, sculptor, painter, archaeologist, he was a lifelong student and teacher. He was past president of the Mohegan Park Jewish Center where he was for many years the shofar blower. At Congregation Kehillat Jeshurun, he was a charter member of the Chevra Kadisha, past president of the Men's Club and longtime lyricist for the KJ players. He is survived by his loving wife, Ellen Dede, his children Deena (Sammy) Zimmerman, Matthew (Sharon Koren) Cohen, Jessica (Richard) Langer and twelve grandchildren. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

SEINFELD--Evelyn. It is with profound sadness that we announce the loss of Evelyn Seinfeld, 68, on Monday, June 20, 2016, after a courageous battle with cancer. She was predeceased by her mother, Libby Seinfeld, father, Louis Seinfeld, and brother, Melvyn Seinfeld. She is survived by loving twin sister Phyllis Feinberg of Dobbs Ferry, NY, and sister and brother-in-law Bernice and Norman Colten of Ocean, NJ; devoted nieces Rachel Feldman of Bergenfield, NJ, Jennifer Colten of Arlington, VA, and Marissa Kaplan-Dobbs, Lee Miuccio, and nephew Jake Kaplan, all of Brooklyn, NY; proud great-nieces Malka and Esther Feldman, Grace Miuccio, and Ruby Dobbs; and great-nephews Jack Miuccio, Simcha, Yosef, and Moshe Feldman. A lifelong resident of Brooklyn, NY, Evelyn advocated for 125,000 employees of the City of New York as the director of research and negotiations for DC37. She retired after over 40 years in public service. Evelyn was fiercely dedicated to improving the lives of others, as evidenced by her success as a contract negotiator and enforcer. She enjoyed spending time with her family and cherished friends, especially when coffee and New York Times crossword puzzles were involved. She was a source of comfort and guidance to all who knew her, and her memory will live on in those inspired by her generosity of spirit. Donations in Evelyn's name may be made to Congregation Sons of Israel, 1 Poplar Place, Ocean, New Jersey 07712 or Jobs with Justice at www.jwj.org. 1/3

WAMSLER--Dr. Karl Maximilian Friedrich, beloved and revered father and father-in-law of Bettina Wamsler and Christian Bechtle, Susanne Wamsler and Paul Singer, Irene Banning and Jack Banning, Caroline A. Wamsler and DeWayne N. Phillips, and Pauline Wamsler and David J. Sales died peacefully surrounded by his family at his home in Pocking, Germany on Saturday, June 18, 2016. He is also survived by his twelve grandchildren: Clara, Luisa, Christopher, Johanna, Inga, Kaspar, Marie, George, Charlotte, Schuyler, Karl and Sophia. His commanding intellect, pervasive charm, love of family, and unfailing belief in a good world informed a life of integrity and extraordinary achievements. He was the rock of his family and an example for all who knew him. The burial and requiem will be held in Pocking, St. Pius on June 29, 2016. Services are being made by Zirngibl Funeral Home, Hanfelder Str., 53, Starnberg 82319. (+49.8151.36140). 1/3

FOA--Linda. The Women's Forum of New York records with sorrow the death of our member Linda Foa, a renowned expert in Design Journalism and Marketing. Deepest sympathy is extended to her family and colleagues at the Architects & Designers building, where she served as Marketing Director. Carolyn Carter, President; Rita B. Crotty, Executive Dir. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Lolita E. The board and staff of American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev (AABGU) are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, Lolita E. Goldstein, a devoted Zionist and kind-hearted woman of valor, who was instantly loved by everyone she met. Her contagious enthusiasm, compassion and abundant joy for the students, faculty and projects of Ben-Gurion University of the Negev (BGU), and her friendship with the staff and leadership of both AABGU and BGU filled our hearts with love. Lolita will be sorely missed. We extend our profound condolences to Lolita's sister-in- law, Eileen Putterman, and her husband, Mickey; to Lolita's eight nieces and nephews; to her large extended family in the U.S., Portugal and Israel; and to the hundreds of friends, students and countless others who had come to cherish her and whom she had inspired. Lloyd Goldman, President Lite Sabin, Chair, Grtr. NY Reg. Doron Krakow, EVP Kevin M. Leopold, N.E. Exec. Dir. 1/3
WYMAN--M. Richard. We mourn the passing of our dear friend. You will be sorely missed. All Your Friends at The Admirals Cove Gin Game 1

ZEIGERMAN--David. The Board of Governors and Membership of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Scott Tesser, President 1/3

KANTRO--Beatrice "Bunny," of Boca Raton, FL passed away on June 21, 2016, one month before her 86th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Ira "Sonny," mother to Scott, Mark, Meryl and Millie. Beloved grandmother of Matthew, Lauren, Jason, Ben and Harris and beloved aunt to many. Born to Hyman and Minnie on July 6, 1930 in Brooklyn, NY. Bunny was a passionate advocate for the Cancer Care organization and served as President of her local Chapter. Her loving warmth, generosity and huge heart for her family will be sorely missed as we continue life's journey with her always in our thoughts. The Kantro Family 1/3

LEIDERMAN--Abraham "Al", 98, of Palm Beach, FL and Great Neck, NY June 19, 2016. Beloved husband (73 years) of the late Lillian; father of Michael (Hermine), Beth (Martin Statfeld) and the late Robert; grandfather of Jill (Robert Cohen), Eric (Natalie), Jenna (Aaron Harris) and Dani (Todd Elkins); great-grandfather of Anna Ray Harris and Rocket Lee Cohen; brother of Bernice Fein and the late Ralph Leiderman; successful businessman and volunteer extraordinaire, he loved friends, jokes, ice cream and deli (but not together), and his family most of all. 1/3
BODZIN--Annette G.,88. Preceded in death by her husband, Paul, and son, Robert, and survived by her daughters, Kate Scheinman and Wendy Kadens. May her memory be for a blessing. 1/3

CHESTON--Morris Jr.,The board of directors and staff of the Garden Conservancy mourn the loss of our former Vice President of the Board - a legal expert, avid horticulturist, philanthropist, civic leader, and dear friend. His commitment to community service extended from health and cultural organizations in Philadelphia to state and national organizations. Morris was co-leader of our endowment campaign, host of garden-study tours and Open Days at his homes in Pennsylvania and Maine, and wise and witty counselor for many of our programs. We send our deepest condolences to Cynthia and all of his family and friends. 1/3

BAY--Eugene A.,83, passed away on June 18, 2016 in New York. Born in 1933 to Eugene Albert Bay and Helene Carlin Bay in New York City, he graduated from Phillips Academy Andover and The University of Pennsylvania. He served in the U.S. Marine Corps from 1957- 1960. A legendary advertising and publishing executive, "Gene" Bay served as publisher of Field & Stream Magazine. Later at Gene Bay Associates he pioneered the transformation of fishing and hunting programming to mainstream media with ESPN Outdoors. Trustee Emeritus of The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, a lifetime member and former governor of the New York Athletic Club, and from the Polo Grounds to MetLife Stadium, a life-long New York Football Giants season ticket holder. Predeceased by his brother, John M. Bay, he is survived by his beloved wife of 53 years, Deidre Lesage Bay, his children Willow Bay and husband Robert A. Iger, Kacey Bay and husband Nick Pappas, and Eric M. Bay and his seven grandchildren: Max and William Iger, Carlin and Nicholas Pappas, Savannah, Isabella and Emma Bay. Memorial Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st Street and Madison Avenue, on Thursday from 5pm-8pm. Prayer Service will take place at 7pm. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, on Friday 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made In Memory of Gene Bay to Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home, 1339 York Avenue, NY 10021. 1/3

HAIMOWITZ--Patricia Hurley. Pat died peacefully at home June 20. Loving wife, mother, and stepmother. A bright star in the public relations firmament for more than a half century, notably at St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, 1960-1972, then as partner in Hurley & Haimowitz Public Relations. Funeral mass Thursday 10am, St. Augustine Church, 116 Sixth Ave., Brooklyn. 1/3

FINDLAY--Stella M.,69, of Greenwich, Connecticut died on June 16, 2016 at home. Born in Manchester, England on July 14, 1946, she was the daughter of the late James Morris and Theresa Hayes Morris. She is survived by beloved husband David Findlay, cherished children: son James Findlay, daughter Alexandra Young and son-in-law Bruce Young, brother Michael Morris and sister Rita Lamb. Mrs. Findlay was a member of Ocean Reef Club, The Milbrook Club, and Card Sound Golf Club. A memorial service will be held on Friday, June 24, 2016 at noon at The Milbrook Club in Greenwich, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the NYU Langone Medical Center Faculty & Friends Campaign (referencing Ruth Oratz, M.D. (F/C 416107)) at www.nyulangone.org/give/ facultyandfriends. 1/3

FINDLAY--Stella M.,69, of Greenwich, Connecticut died on June 16, 2016 at home. Born in Manchester, England on July 14, 1946, she was the daughter of the late James Morris and Theresa Hayes Morris. She is survived by beloved husband David Findlay, cherished children: son James Findlay, daughter Alexandra Young and son-in-law Bruce Young, brother Michael Morris and sister Rita Lamb. Mrs. Findlay was a member of Ocean Reef Club, The Milbrook Club, and Card Sound Golf Club. A memorial service will be held on Friday, June 24, 2016 at noon at The Milbrook Club in Greenwich, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the NYU Langone Medical Center Faculty & Friends Campaign (referencing Ruth Oratz, M.D. (F/C 416107)) at www.nyulangone.org/give/ facultyandfriends. 1/3

GOLDSCHMIDT--Beatrice C.,died June 22, 2016. Funeral arrangements private. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Henry J. Goldschmidt. Survived by her son, Lawrence E. Goldschmidt (Maya D.), and daughter, Ellen C. Goldschmidt; grandchildren, Alix (Beneth), Erica (James), and Lisa (Luke), and great-grandchildren, Eli, Nathaniel, and Leo. She was an avid reader, world traveler and lover of classical music and opera. The family will be at the home of Lawrence E. Goldschmidt from 5pm to 9pm on Thursday and from 4pm to 8pm on Friday. Donations in Bea's memory may be made to The Goldschmidt Family Scholarship Fund at Columbia College or to the Henry J. Goldschmidt Scholarship Fund at Columbia Law School. 1/3

MIGLIUOLO--Dagmar, (nee Zlatohlavkova) (10 April 1927 - 8 May 2016) wife of Giovanni Migliuolo (1927-1989) former Ambassador of Italy to the United Nations, Egypt and the USSR. Longtime resident of New York, she peacefully passed into grace in Turin, Italy. She leaves her children and their spouses (Andrea and Laura, Anna and Marialaura, Michele and Gina, Stefano and Sarah), grandchildren (Adriana, Alessandro, Giancarlo, Sebastian and Vittorio). Tenacious archaeologist, traveler, voracious reader and fluent in multiple languages, she dedicated herself to service in the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Her friends are invited to join in the celebration of her life at the Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola (Park Ave and 84th St., New York City) at 10am on 29 June 2016. Burial will follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery (Hawthorne, NY), where Dagmar (Zlatohlavkova) Migliuolo will be laid to rest with her husband in this world and the next. 1/3

GIAMBOI--Joseph John III. Beloved son of Joseph Jr. and Eva (nee Sierra). Loving brother of Elizabeth. Cherished grandson of Mary and the late Joseph and Pablo Sierra and the late Eva. Reposing Scarpaci Funeral Home, 1401 86th Street, until Saturday, 9am. Mass St. Saviour Church, Park Slope, 10am. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. 1/3

SEINFELD--Evelyn. It is with profound sadness that we announce the loss of Evelyn Seinfeld, 68, on Monday, June 20, 2016, after a courageous battle with cancer. She was predeceased by her mother, Libby Seinfeld, father, Louis Seinfeld, and brother, Melvyn Seinfeld. She is survived by loving twin sister Phyllis Feinberg of Dobbs Ferry, NY, and sister and brother-in-law Bernice and Norman Colten of Ocean, NJ; devoted nieces Rachel Feldman of Bergenfield, NJ, Jennifer Colten of Arlington, VA, and Marissa Kaplan-Dobbs, Lee Miuccio, and nephew Jake Kaplan, all of Brooklyn, NY; proud great-nieces Malka and Esther Feldman, Grace Miuccio, and Ruby Dobbs; and great-nephews Jack Miuccio, Simcha, Yosef, and Moshe Feldman. A lifelong resident of Brooklyn, NY, Evelyn advocated for 125,000 employees of the City of New York as the director of research and negotiations for DC37. She retired after over 40 years in public service. Evelyn was fiercely dedicated to improving the lives of others, as evidenced by her success as a contract negotiator and enforcer. She enjoyed spending time with her family and cherished friends, especially when coffee and New York Times crossword puzzles were involved. She was a source of comfort and guidance to all who knew her, and her memory will live on in those inspired by her generosity of spirit. Donations in Evelyn's name may be made to Congregation Sons of Israel, 1 Poplar Place, Ocean, New Jersey 07712 or Jobs with Justice at www.jwj.org. 1/3

FISHER--Marjorie. The Board of Directors, Musicians, Trustees, Governing Members, and Staff of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra mourn the loss of treasured donor and longtime champion, Marjorie S. Fisher. Marjorie and her beloved husband Max M. Fisher are among the most generous patrons the orchestra has ever known. Her benevolence paired with that of their family foundation has helped take the DSO on tour domestically and abroad, and provided a catalyst for the reclamation of Orchestra Hall to its glorious self, positioning the Max M. and Marjorie S. Fisher Music Center as a hub for community and performing arts in the heart of midtown Detroit. Max and Marjorie Fisher gave boundlessly of their time and hearts to shape a viable and artistically excellent future for the DSO, and we will be forever grateful. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Fisher family. Anne Parsons, President & CEO, Mark Davidoff, Chairman of the Board, Leonard Slatkin, Music Director 1/3

Morse, JD, PhD, President & CEO 1/3

His dedicated leadership, wonderful personality and delightful sense of humor were an inspiration. We all simply loved him. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife DeDe and family. Lee Iacocca, Founding Chairman; Albert Bellas , Chairman; Stephen Briganti, President and CEO 1/3

FRANKEL--Andrew John "Pete", passed quietly Monday, June 13th in his Sarasota, FL home. Mr. Frankel attended Trinity-Pawling School, Oberlin College, Julliard, and Columbia University. He was also an officer in the U.S. Navy. His fifty-plus-year business career involved acquisition, development and disposition of various manufacturing, service, and entertainment businesses. Between 1966 and 1971, Mr. Frankel served as Executive Vice President and Director of Warner Communications, now Time Warner, Inc. Mr. Frankel resigned to become Chairman and CEO of National Kinney Corp. whose businesses involved parking, real estate, building maintenance and construction subcontracting. In 1983 the company changed its name to Andal Corp. and added Steve's Homemade Ice Cream and Multi-Arc Scientific Coatings to its company holdings. BRENNER--David, died peacefully at his home on June 22, 2016, after a courageous battle with cancer at the age of 57. Beloved husband of Alyson. Loving father of Michael and Sarah. Born April 29, 1959 in New York City to Deborah and Erv. Graduated from Ramapo Sr. High School in 1976 and earned a MA from SUNY Albany, and pursued doctoral studies at RPI and Penn State. He married Alyson, his high school sweetheart in 1982. During the course of his career he worked at CSI, NYNEX, and Videobureau. He was a board member at the Dysautonomia Foundation for 10 years, after which he served as Executive Director. His dedication, talents and accomplishments in making life better for those with FD were exceptional. Donations in his memory may be made at www.famdys.org. Service Sunday 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3
WEISBERGER--Eugene. Our beloved Gene of Manhattan and Hauppauge, NY, died June 18, 2016. Funeral on Friday, June 24. For more information read: http://facebook.com/tribute toeugeneweisberger. 1/3

GUTH--Polly W. The Board and Staff of Planned Parenthood of New York City are deeply saddened by the death of our honorary board member, Polly W. Guth. Polly joined our Board in 1994 and was an ardent advocate for reproductive rights and access to education and health services. We are grateful for her extraordinary generosity, which improved the rights and health of women and girls. Polly will long be remembered for her kindness, passion for life, and commitment to this agency. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her entire family. Katie Danziger, Chair, Board of Directors Joan Malin, President and CEO 1/3

CONNELL--Gordon, an actor best remembered by Broadway audiences for his performance as Mark Twain in the hit musical Big River, passed away on June 12th in Englewood, NJ. He was 93 years old. Other Broadway credits include Subways Are for Sleeping, and Hello Dolly. On television, Connell appeared in The Sid Caesar Revue Series, The Jeffersons, and Sex and the City. Also a musician, Connell composed songs for cabaret artists and musical theatre. Long-married to actress Jane Connell (deceased 2013), he is survived by daughters Melissa Connell and Maggie Connell. 1/3

FISHER--Jerome. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Jerome "Jack" Fisher. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. The beautiful qualities of his life shall endure forever. 1/3
SIMON--Jay S. 3/06/37-6/24/06 To the love of my life. I am truly blessed. Jo-Ann 1/3

YESSELMAN--Robert. Bob spent 36 years in dance management. He was the executive director of the Paul Taylor Dance Company and the Joffrey Ballet and founding director of Dance/NYC. He was the President of the 1987 "Dancing for Life" gala which was the first dance world response to the AIDS crisis. He passed away in Palm Springs, CA and is survived by his brother and family and by the loving memory of his eternal partner Lee Bruner. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Lolita. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are saddened by the passing of Lolita Goldstein. Lolita, along with her beloved husband Melvin (z"l), established scholarships at Hebrew University. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Menahem Ben-Sasson, President; American Friends of The Hebrew University, Michael S. Kurtz, Chairman; Daniel I. Schlessinger, President; Beth Asnien McCoy, National Executive Director 1/3

HYAMS--Ira L. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of Ira L. Hyams, 85, of Somers, NY, beloved husband of Miriam, adored father of Paul, Ron and Jennifer Prizer, son-in- law, Scott Prizer and daughters-in-law Lisa Kwong and Carole Hyams, cherished grandfather of seven grandchildren. Devoted brother of Norman Hyams and sister Joan Geismar. A graduate of Cornell University and Columbia Law School, an intelligent, kind, gentle man who loved his family, the practice of law, outdoor sports and the Adirondacks. He will be sorely missed by the many who enjoyed his company and wonderful sense of humor. Funeral service Friday, June 24th, 1:30pm, Temple Beth El, 220 South Bedford Road, Chappaqua, NY. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

POMERANCE--Robert S.,on Thursday, June 23, 2016, Robert S. Pomerance of Chevy Chase, MD. Beloved husband of Betty Ferber. Devoted father of Laura (Gerry Castillo) and Sara Pomerance. Loving grandfather of Olivia and Mateo Castillo. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, June 26, 2016, 10:00am at Temple Sinai, 3100 Military Rd., NW, Washington, DC. Shiva will be observed from Sunday through Thursday at the late residence. Services entrusted to Torchinsky Hebrew Funeral Home, 202-541-1001. 1/3

LEVY--Ira A. The City College of New York mourns the passing of our distinguished alumnus Ira A. Levy, Class of 1971 from the Grove School of Engineering. Mr. Levy, former Executive Vice President of AECOM, served on the Civil Engineering Advisory Committee at the Grove School of Engineering. His generosity and devotion to the CCNY community inspire us all. City College extends our sincerest condolences to the Levy family and their friends at AECOM. Lisa S. Coico, President 1/3

FISHER--Jerome. The Board of Directors and Staff of the American Friends and of The Israel Museum, Jerusalem deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend, Board member, and generous donor, Jerome Fisher. Jerome's commitment to the Museum was exceptional. Together with his wife Anne, Jerome led the Museum's 30th Anniversary Endowment Campaign with a gift naming the Anne and Jerome Fisher Directorship of the Museum. Thereafter, they continued their support in myriad ways at the Museum in Jerusalem and with our American Friends in New York and Palm Beach. He will be missed greatly, and we extend deepest condolences to Anne and the entire family. Stephen Lash and Judy Steinhardt, Board co-chairs, AFIM Stacey Bronfman, President, AFIM James Snyder, Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir, IMJ Leah Siegel, Exec Dir., AFIM 1/3

MIGLIUOLO--Dagmar, (nee Zlatohlavkova) (10 April 1927 - 8 May 2016) wife of Giovanni Migliuolo (1927-1989) former Ambassador of Italy to the United Nations, Egypt and the USSR. Longtime resident of New York, she peacefully passed into grace in Turin, Italy. She leaves her children and their spouses (Andrea and Laura, Anna and Marialaura, Michele and Gina, Stefano and Sarah), grandchildren (Adriana, Alessandro, Giancarlo, Sebastian and Vittorio). Tenacious archaeologist, traveler, voracious reader and fluent in multiple languages, she dedicated herself to service in the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Her friends are invited to join in the celebration of her life at the Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola (Park Ave and 84th St., New York City) at 10am on 29 June 2016. Burial will follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery (Hawthorne, NY), where Dagmar (Zlatohlavkova) Migliuolo will be laid to rest with her husband in this world and the next. 1/3
FISHER--Jerome (Jack). In loving memory of our dear friend. He will always be in our hearts. Our condolences to Anne and the family. Ginger and Mike Feuer 1/3

EINBENDER--Alvin H.,passed away peacefully on June 22, 2016. He was surrounded by his loving family: his wife, Joan R. Einbender, their four children, Alison, Jay, Gail and Karen; his son-in-laws Paul Jacobson and Rink Smith; and his ten grandchildren, Erin, Bennett, Kirsten, Kim, Dana, Eli, Jake, Graham, Brooke and Halie. A service in celebration of Alvin's life will be held on Sunday, June 26, 2016 at 2pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Contributions may be made in his honor to the UJA Federation of New York. 1/3

ENGEL--Sylvia. The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our good friend and longtime member, Sylvia Engel. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to her family and friends. Board of Governors The Woodmere Club 1/3

FARMAN--Jack, M.D.,of Great Neck, NY. Beloved husband of the late Vilma. Devoted mother of Nicola Farman (Lance Wangel), Jessica Farman (Brian Dooley) and Peter and Gayle Farman. Adored grandfather of Sloan Wangel and Katie and Emma Farman. Memorial services will be held Friday, June 24th at 3pm at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY. For more information, visit: www.jewishfunerals.com. 1/3

GOLDSCHMIDT--Beatrice C.,died June 22, 2016. Funeral arrangements private. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Henry J. Goldschmidt. Survived by her son, Lawrence E. Goldschmidt (Maya D.), and daughter, Ellen C. Goldschmidt; grandchildren, Alix (Beneth), Erica (James), and Lisa (Luke), and great-grandchildren, Eli, Nathaniel, and Leo. She was an avid reader, world traveler and lover of classical music and opera. The family will be at the home of Lawrence E. Goldschmidt from 5pm to 9pm on Thursday and from 4pm to 8pm on Friday. Donations in Bea's memory may be made to The Goldschmidt Family Scholarship Fund at Columbia College or to the Henry J. Goldschmidt Scholarship Fund at Columbia Law School. 1/3
BRODSKY--Judith. We cherish the precious memories - still and forever. With love, Grace and Ruth 1/3

DIAMOND--Robert S.,a New York journalist and business executive, died June 15 in Arizona after a brave, lengthy struggle to overcome complications following heart valve surgery in New York. He was 77 years old. Born in Phoenix, he was the son of Rose G. and Bertrand A. Diamond; and grandson of Nathan Diamond, pioneer merchant, who co-founded one of Arizona's early department stores. Journalism and public affairs were a passion. A graduate of Claremont McKenna College and Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism, he wrote for the Arizona Republic, Los Angeles Times and was one of the youngest staff writers for Fortune Magazine in the 1960's. Throughout his career Mr. Diamond lived in New York with his wife of 52 years, Susan. He was a senior officer of the Dun & Bradstreet Corp (now retired) the majority of his business career. Yet his never-ending pride in his Arizona heritage dominated his desire to return to Arizona as he neared life's end. Mr. Diamond was a member of national and local boards including Reading is Fundamental where he retired as vice chair; the Arizona Community Foundation; and he was a current Trustee of the Heard Museum. Survivors include his wife, Susan; brother-in-law, Larry Arnsberg; niece Lilli and cherished cousins. 1/3

SERBAN--Dr. George, passed away on June 16, 2016 at the age of 89. A graduate of Carol Davila University of Medicine and Pharmacy in Bucharest, Romania, he emigrated to the United States in 1956, and became a Board Certified psychiatrist and Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at New York University School of Medicine. For many years, he was Principal Research Investigator on schizophrenia at NYU-Bellevue Medical Center, and in the 1970s he served as Medical Director of the Kittay Scientific Foundation, under whose auspices he organized successful international medical symposiums. He also built a flourishing private practice and was a consultant to business corporations as well as an author and editor of numerous books and articles in the fields of psychiatry, social psychology and sociology. Dr. Serban is survived by his wife, Dr. Theodora Serban, and son, Andrew Serban, and will be greatly missed. 1/3

FRANKEL--Andrew. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved longtime member Andrew "Pete" Frankel. The Frankels were members at the club for sixty years; Pete served as President from 1996-1998. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest sympathy to his wife Anita, their children Donna, Liz and David, their three grandchildren, and the entire family. Fredric C. Apter, President; Linda Wiltsek, Secretary 1/3

HAFFNER--Norman. With great sadness, ICL remembers Dr. Norman Haffner. For eight years, Norman served on ICL's Board. He will always be remembered for his penetrating questions as well as his high regard for ICL and our responsibilities to the people we serve. His iconic humor will remain in our hearts and memories. 1/3
EINBENDER--Alvin H. The Harmonie Club notes with sorrow the passing of our honored member Alvin H. Einbender. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. 1/3

EINBENDER--Alvin H.,passed away peacefully on June 22, 2016. He was surrounded by his loving family: his wife, Joan R. Einbender, their four children, Alison, Jay, Gail and Karen; his son-in-laws Paul Jacobson and Rink Smith; and his ten grandchildren, Erin, Bennett, Kirsten, Kim, Dana, Eli, Jake, Graham, Brooke and Halie. A service in celebration of Alvin's life will be held on Sunday, June 26, 2016 at 2pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Contributions may be made in his honor to the UJA Federation of New York. 1/3

KATZ--Terry, died peacefully at her home in Boca Raton, FL, on June 21. Beloved wife of Irwin Katz. Beloved mother to Toni Ponnel and Tracy Katz and grandmother of Craig and Lauren Ponnel. In addition, she leaves her brother and sister-in-law Joel and Sandy Busel. 1/3

YABLON--Leonard. We note with sorrow the passing of our member Leonard Yablon and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

MIGLIUOLO--Dagmar, (nee Zlatohlavkova) (10 April 1927 - 8 May 2016) wife of Giovanni Migliuolo (1927-1989) former Ambassador of Italy to the United Nations, Egypt and the USSR. Longtime resident of New York, she peacefully passed into grace in Turin, Italy. She leaves her children and their spouses (Andrea and Laura, Anna and Marialaura, Michele and Gina, Stefano and Sarah), grandchildren (Adriana, Alessandro, Giancarlo, Sebastian and Vittorio). Tenacious archaeologist, traveler, voracious reader and fluent in multiple languages, she dedicated herself to service in the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Her friends are invited to join in the celebration of her life at the Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola (Park Ave and 84th St., New York City) at 10am on 29 June 2016. Burial will follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery (Hawthorne, NY), where Dagmar (Zlatohlavkova) Migliuolo will be laid to rest with her husband in this world and the next. 1/3
O'BRIEN--Lois. Dearest Lois, it has been twenty years since you are gone. Every day I miss your wit and common sense. Time has not, nor ever will, diminish my love for you. Jack 1/3

BIRNBAUM--Gerald, 87, of Flushing, NY, passed away June 16, 2016. Beloved husband of 57 years to Mary (Aronson). Devoted father of Debbie Weiss (Hal) and Rhona Seymour (Michael). Adored poppy to Alexa, Jordana, Zachary and Dylan. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Merrick Jewish Center or the Hospital for Special Surgery. 1/3

HAFFNER--Alden N. Orchestra of St. Luke's mourns the loss of Board member Dr. Alden N. Haffner. His passion for music and generosity of spirit will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to friends and family. Board, Musicians, and Staff of Orchestra of St. Luke's 1/3
RIPPS--David. June 25, 1967. Remembered on his birthday and every day with love. Mom, Dad, Van, Leah and Emily 1/3

BARNETT--Lois. Born May 20, 1933, Died June 17, 2016. Daughter of Ernest and Jayne Deutsch Barnett. Beloved mom of Marshall (Brenda), Julie (David), sister of Gene (Enid), and aunt of Lynn, Mike (Angie), and Larry (Barbara). Mutual adoration with grandchildren Isabel and Raphael. Teacher, educator, and friend, Lois explored many paths over the course of her life, and supported others in following their hearts. Services at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY, 1pm, Sunday, June 26, 2016. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to: mskcc.convio.net/ goto/loisbarnett. 1/3

YABLON--Len. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Len Yablon, and extend sincere condolences to his family. James Dreyfus, President 1/3

JACOBSON--David Burton, (90) passed away on June 23, 2016. Born on February 28, 1926 in Worcester, MA, he was the son of Nathan and Frieda Jacobson. David is survived by his children Michael (Sharon), Neil, and Jodi Anatole (Mark), and his grandchildren Emily and Carter Anatole. He was predeceased by Barbara, his loving wife of 32 years, his parents, brother Arthur and sisters Ruth and Deena. A funeral service will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY on Sunday June 26, 2016 at 12:00pm. Dad will always be loved and missed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Arthur B. & David B. Jacobson Judaic Studies Fund, Brown University, P.O Box 1877, Providence, RI 02912 or Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583. 1/3

RUDYK--Andrew, 69, died suddenly on May 17, 2016. The family will be receiving friends at Preston Funeral Home, 153 South Orange Ave, South Orange, NJ on Sunday, June 26th from 2:00-2:45pm followed by a Memorial Service. Born in Koblenz, Germany he has lived in Maplewood, NJ for many years. He served in the United States Army, from 1971-1973. He graduated from City College and New York Law School. He was a college professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York City for many years. He is survived by his beloved wife of Irene Winicov. 1/3

SCHAFFIR--Walter. Management consultant, painter, sculptor drummer, pianist, world traveler, essayist, gastronome and all-around bon vivant passed away at 94 surrounded by his family. He adored and indulged his wife Judy, his daughter Nancy, his brother Kurt, and his Praetorian Guard of grandsons. Who will make our chestnut mousse now? And so it goes. 1/3

EINBENDER--Alvin. Dear friend Alvin, such a wonderful life lived to the fullest with love, wit and charm. You had such great taste. For 40 years we shared so much and talked so often about life. I will miss you so. Elliot 1/3

LUTFY--Isabel, passed away peacefully early on June 23rd at age 92. Devoted wife of the late Edmund R. Lutfy, beloved mother of James, Jeanne and Carol. Proud grandmother of Michael, Christopher, Stephen, Daniel, Mick and Ketsara. Loving mother-in-law to Pat, Henk-Jan and Andy. Daughter of Richard and Wadia Haboush, Isabel was born in Brooklyn Heights and grew up in Bay Ridge. As the family matriarch, Isabel presided over family events and holiday meals for decades, her Lebanese cooking renown. Isabel was a voracious reader, masterful bridge player, and avid politico, who was passionate about everything New York. She also loved to dance, especially in Cape May, NJ where she spent summers for most of her life. Isabel was beloved by her children, siblings, nieces, nephews, grandchildren and a host of dear friends. She will be greatly missed. A funeral service will be held at Church of the Virgin Mary in Park Slope on Saturday, June 25th at 10:00am. Donations can be made to Church of the Virgin Mary, 216 8th Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11215. 1/3

NUZUM--John Martin, Jr.,76, beloved father, grandfather, friend, and neighbor, died on June 21, 2016, after a brief but difficult illness. Born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, John left the Midwest for Princeton University, which he loved and where he was "Nuz" to his many treasured friends from the Class of '62. After graduating from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, John had a long and distinguished career in credit risk management at Chase Manhattan Bank, where he worked until he retired from his Senior Vice President role in 2003. John settled in Park Slope, Brooklyn, which he happily called home for 45 years. As often as he could, however, John escaped the city for the peace and beauty of the Adirondacks, where his home away from home, Big Shanty, is located near the top of Garnet Hill. Wherever he was, John was a devoted father and the much loved "Gramps" to his grandchildren. Beyond career and family, John enjoyed cheering on his beloved Princeton Tigers basketball and football teams, listening to classical and jazz music, solving the NYTimes crossword puzzles every day, and reading for his book club. He also valued his role as a member of both the NYU Lutheran Medical Center Board of Trustees and the Adirondack Architectural Heritage Board of Directors. John is survived by his four children, Kimberly Nuzum, Courtney Jimenez, Leah Ervi, and Jonathan Nuzum, and seven grandchildren, Ruby and Jake Lippert, Isa and Carlos Jimenez, Stella and Milo Ervi, and Illianna Hye Seul Lee Nuzum. He is also survived by his cherished sons- in-law, Aaron Lippert, Alexander Jimenez, and Tomi Ervi, and daughter-in-law, Kyoung Sook Suh. He was predeceased by his older sister, Constance Hall. A memorial service will be held at Grace Church in Brooklyn Heights on September 10, 2016 at 1:00, with a reception to celebrate his life at the Montauk Club in Park Slope. In lieu of flowers, donations in John's memory can be made to the Lutheran Medical Center or the Adirondack Architectural Heritage. 1/3

OKORONKWO--Sylvia. A woman of valor. A lady, who was an inspiration to all fortunate enough to be a part of her life. A remarkable mother of three marvelous children, and a most devoted and beloved grandmother of eight. We send our condolences and much love to the family. Gail, Marc, Allie and Jess 1/3

DONOHUE--Alana, 19, of New York City, died June 23, 2016 as a result of anaphylaxis. She was born on July 3, 1996 in New York City, the daughter of Teddy and Niki Donohue. She attended The Chapin School, an all-girls independent day school located in Manhattan. She spent her junior year of high school in Beijing, China studying Mandarin as part of the SYA program. She was currently enrolled at Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire as part of the class of 2018. Alana lived a life of joy and passion that revolved around family and friends, adventure and intellectual curiosity. Alana was an intrepid traveler, crossing the globe to such faraway places as Vietnam, Cambodia, Egypt, Turkey and South America. At the age of sixteen, she headed off to China for a year of language immersion and travel. In addition to Mandarin, early in her academic career she exhibited both a strong interest in and a keen aptitude for mathematics. It became a cornerstone of her academic pursuits, which she continued upon arriving at Dartmouth in the fall of 2013. Finally, Alana's life was full of friends and laughter. She was a whirlwind of fun and energy, and these traits characterized all of her interactions with everyone who was lucky enough to cross paths with her. Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home of New York City is handling funeral services. Calling hours will be Sunday, June 26 from 2-7pm. The funeral will be held on Monday, June 27 at 10:30am at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity. She is survived by her parents, Teddy and Niki; her brother, Peter; her grandfather Peter and grandmother, Carolann; and numerous aunts, uncles and cousins. Donations may be made to the Alana Donohue Fund at Dartmouth College. 1/3

SCHAINMAN--Stephen. Stephen "Big Chief Steve" Schainman, former Director of Mohawk Day Camp and Day School in White Plains, NY for 51 years, passed away Thursday, June 23rd. For over half a century, tens of thousands of campers, staff and families benefited from Steve's wisdom, expertise and commitment to children. He will also be remembered by campers as "Mohawk Man," his camp's superhero. A graduate of Yale and Harvard Business School, Steve became Director of Mohawk Day Camp and School in 1966. He married his future Co- Director, Barbara Baskind, in 1967. A recognized leader and innovator in the camp profession, Steve received the American Camp Association's highest honor in 2005, the "Legend in Camping" award. He was especially known for his many contributions to camp safety. Mohawk became the first camp or school in New York State to put seat belts on buses. Steve then lobbied for New York's 1984 pioneering school bus seat belt law. Steve is the former President of the New York State Camp Directors Association, board member of the New York Section of the American Camp Association, and Chair of the Tri-State Camp Conference. Steve is survived by his wife Barbara, children Kenneth and Lauren, sister Roe, and seven nieces and nephews. A Celebration of Steve's life will be held at Mohawk Day Camp on September 18, 2pm. 1/3

Born in Texarkana, AR, she was the daughter of Esther Mills and Willard Lyman Wood. She attended The Hockaday School and graduated from Radcliffe College in 1949. She married writer Clement Biddle Wood, Jr. that same year. Together they lived in Philadelphia and Paris before their divorce in 1964. In 1972 she married C. Daggett Harvey of Chicago, where she lived for several decades and served on the Board of the Art Institute of Chicago. Following his death in 1976 she spent portions of the year in Gstaad and London, where she completed a degree in horticultural restoration. During much of the 1990's she lived and worked at the Villa Noailles in Grasse, France, restoring its garden, before moving to New York in 2001. She is survived by her children from her first marriage, Marion Wood Covey (Joseph Harmon) of Chicago, Clement Biddle Wood III (Sally) of New York City, Willard Lyman Wood (Susannah) of Norfolk, CT, and Alexander Mills Wood (Susan Manno) of Canajoharie, NY, and by eight grandchildren and stepgrandchildren. MOFFETT--Kenworth William (1934-2016). Kenworth William Moffett, 81, died peacefully from complications of heart disease in Stamford, CT on June 21, 2016. Kenworth (Ken) was born in East Orange, NJ, the son of Kenworth Alvin Moffett and Kathryn Lily Moffett. Moffett earned his bachelor's degree from Columbia University in 1960 and his doctorate in art history from Harvard University in 1968, where he became an expert on 19th- and 20th-century art and art criticism, and an advocate of abstract expressionism and color field painting in particular. Early in his career, Moffett achieved full professor of art history at Wellesley College, where he taught from 1969 to 1978. While a professor, he started his tenure as the first Curator of Modern and Contemporary Art at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, a role he held from 1971 to 1984. After five years spent advising art collectors on impressionist, early modern, and contemporary art acquisitions from 1984 to 1989, he served as Director of the Fort Lauderdale Museum from 1989 to 1997 and helped found the Museum of Contemporary Art in Denver, CO in 1998. Over the course of his prolific career, he organized or supervised more than 100 exhibitions; built public, private, and corporate collections; co-curated the first large exhibition of American art to tour China; and wrote monographs on Morris Louis, Kenneth Noland, Jules Olitski, Fairfield Porter, and Odd Nerdrum, as well as a volume, New New Painting, which he co-authored with the Belgian critic Marcel Paquet. His dissertation was also published as a book, Meier-Graefe as Art Critic, by Prestel Verlag (Munich) in 1973. During the eighties, he published Moffett's Artletter, which contained news and opinion about the art world and art market, and more recently had an online version, Moffett's Artletter 2.0. For the last 25 years of his life, he championed a group of artists called the New New Painters, who he considered to be the successors of Jackson Pollock and the New York School of abstract expressionism and color field painting. He is survived by his wife Cynthia Horvath Moffett, daughter Kathryn (Kay) Moffett, son-in-law Neil Parker, granddaughter Matilda Moffett Parker, and hundreds of friends and artists who loved him. 1/3
