DOYLE--Margaret Brew, "Peggy", beloved Matriarch of Babylon, NY, passed on June 21, 2016. Margaret was born in New York City, and was among the first women to graduate in 1948 from the Fordham Business School obtaining a Master's Degree in Finance. She began her career at Whiteweld & Co. on Wall Street. She re-entered the job force when she became a widow and was employed by Grumman Aerospace in the purchasing Department. Margaret retired as Superintendent of North Babylon School District in 1995. She began yet another career at the age of 70 and was a founding principal of Kinetics Mutual funds (The Internet Fund). Margaret was an avid reader of all literature among her favorites were historical novels and biographies. She enjoyed NYC Theater and most cultural events in addition to bridge and crossword puzzles. Margaret traveled the world and for the past 35 years spent the winter months in Rincon, Puerto Rico. She was a friend to many due to her warm nature and her generosity. Margaret was a longtime member of the Babylon Rotary and received the prestigious Paul Harris Award. Balkonis, Richard and Katherine Doyle, Kaitlin, Keenan and Alexa Doyle and Brigitte Abel. Margaret had a remarkable life and touched many lives. She will be greatly missed. BERLINER--Rena. Rena Berliner, beloved wife of the late Moses Berliner, passed away peacefully on June 21, 2016, after a brief illness. She was surrounded by her family, daughter Rochelle Berliner, son Sherwin Borsuk and his wife, Ruth, and her cherished grandchildren Declan Kurant, Ethan Borsuk and wife, Maritza and Amaranth Borsuk and husband, Brad Bouse. She leaves behind her Canadian nephews and nieces, Sam and Betsy Berliner, Assaf and Betty Drori and their families. She also leaves her beloved and closest friend of 80 years, Clara Lato. Rena and her mother, Clara Schoenthal, survived the Holocaust but lost the rest of their immediate family: father, grandmother and sister. She spent part of the war in the Lvov ghetto, under Russian and, later, Nazi control. She escaped the ghetto by selling her Mother's diamond ring so the two could pay to be smuggled out. They spent the rest of the war hidden in a sub-cellar. A Mrs. Tokazewicz was paid to hide them and another family. When they ran out of funds they were helped by an underground Polish organization, Zegota, which aided many Jewish fugitives. While in hiding, Rena met her first husband, Mathias Borsuk, whom she thought the last living Jewish young man in Europe. After the war Rena and her mother lived in the Neu Freimann displaced persons camp in Munich, where Rena studied voice at the Handel-Konservatorium and helped found a touring musical group, which performed at DP camps and brought pleasure to many fellow survivors. After emigrating to the U.S. in 1949, she divorced Mathias, and she and her mother settled in Rego Park, NY, where Rena continued singing for Jewish organizations while raising her infant son, Sherwin. She soon met her second husband, Moses Berliner, a survivor from Lodz, Poland. Because of his mechanical expertise, Moses and his brother Jack survived the Holocaust and Auschwitz as slave laborers fashioning propellers for the Nazis. Rena and Moses were the adoring parents of a daughter, Rochelle, and were very proud of their children's careers as a radiologist and lawyer, respectively. Though Rena lost her faith in God during the war, she never lost her connection to Judaism. She was president of the Tel Chai Chapter of Hadassah, and its area Vice President, in Queens, NY. She loved opera, which she once sang professionally, and despite paraplegia, which left her wheelchair-bound for the last fifteen years, her kindness and bright spirit remained undimmed. She was an inveterate dispenser of chocolate to everyone she met. She loved to read, and her home was filled with books. She read The New York Times daily, and was honored to be profiled on January 15, 2000. She loved all animals, plants, and children, and her dog, Mimi, was a source of much joy. She will be deeply missed by those whose lives she touched. 1/3

NUZUM--John Martin, Jr.,76, beloved father, grandfather, friend, and neighbor, died on June 21, 2016, after a brief but difficult illness. Born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, John left the Midwest for Princeton University, which he loved and where he was "Nuz" to his many treasured friends from the Class of '62. After graduating from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, John had a long and distinguished career in credit risk management at Chase Manhattan Bank, where he worked until he retired from his Senior Vice President role in 2003. John settled in Park Slope, Brooklyn, which he happily called home for 45 years. As often as he could, however, John escaped the city for the peace and beauty of the Adirondacks, where his home away from home, Big Shanty, is located near the top of Garnet Hill. Wherever he was, John was a devoted father and the much loved "Gramps" to his grandchildren. Beyond career and family, John enjoyed cheering on his beloved Princeton Tigers basketball and football teams, listening to classical and jazz music, solving the NYTimes crossword puzzles every day, and reading for his book club. He also valued his role as a member of both the NYU Lutheran Medical Center Board of Trustees and the Adirondack Architectural Heritage Board of Directors. John is survived by his four children, Kimberly Nuzum, Courtney Jimenez, Leah Ervi, and Jonathan Nuzum, and seven grandchildren, Ruby and Jake Lippert, Isa and Carlos Jimenez, Stella and Milo Ervi, and Illianna Hye Seul Lee Nuzum. He is also survived by his cherished sons- in-law, Aaron Lippert, Alexander Jimenez, and Tomi Ervi, and daughter-in-law, Kyoung Sook Suh. He was predeceased by his older sister, Constance Hall. A memorial service will be held at Grace Church in Brooklyn Heights on September 10, 2016 at 1:00, with a reception to celebrate his life at the Montauk Club in Park Slope. In lieu of flowers, donations in John's memory can be made to the Lutheran Medical Center or the Adirondack Architectural Heritage. 1/3

HERMAN--Anita. Anita Herman, a singer who performed in many popular Broadway shows in the 1950's and 60's, died peacefully at her home in Lantana, Florida on May 15, 2016. She was 92. Anita was born in 1924 in Brooklyn and raised in the Bronx. Her father, Alexander Alpert, owned a yarn importing business and was a respected oil painter. Although she showed early talent as a singer and artist, Anita did not actively devote herself to singing until after her marriage. Anita made her debut as a mezzo-soprano at Carnegie Hall in 1948 under the stage name Anita Alpert, and first sang in the chorus at the City Center and the Metropolitan Opera. She sang for many years on Broadway, including the 1959 production of Once Upon a Mattress with Carol Burnett, where, as understudy to the Queen, she performed the role when the lead fell ill. She was the understudy for Lady Thiang in the King and I, and sang in Bajour with Chita Rivera and Herschel Bernardi in 1964. She also appeared in the 1964 revival of The King and I, and in the 1965 revival of Kismet at Lincoln Center's New York State Theater, where she performed the role of Zubedya. After moving to Long Island, Anita sang at the Jones Beach Marine Theatre with Guy Lombardo and his orchestra in the 1956-57 production of Show Boat, where she was the understudy for Julie, and in the Song of Norway in 1958. In addition to her work on the stage, she formed a folk singing duo, Allan & Arden, with her friend and neighbor, Sherry Arden, the President of William Morrow & Company. Anita married Samuel Herman in 1946. They moved to Merrick, Long Island in 1953, where they raised two children. Anita relished her role as glamorous entertainer, throwing lavish parties and cooking international food not yet familiar in suburban Long Island. Through her singing on Holland America cruise ships, they were able to travel extensively. Their most memorable cruise was to Cuba during Castro's revolution, where they shared a hotel with machine gun carrying revolutionaries. After her singing career, Anita attended Fordham College and graduated summa cam laude at the age of 56. She worked as an intern for the McNeill Lehrer Report, and then worked for several years as a paralegal for the firm of Squadron Ellenoff. She was active in her community, and volunteered for many years with Recordings for the Blind. Anita is survived by her daughter, Beth Herman, and a grandchild, Anna Kazan. She was predeceased by her sister Selma, her husband, and their younger daughter, Deanne. 1/3

FISHER--Jerome. The Fashion Footwear Association of New York (FFANY) mourns the loss of Jerome "Jack" Fisher, a legend in our industry and esteemed philanthropist. JOHNSON--David Willis, died in Doylestown, PA June 19, 2016. Born in Tumut, N.S.W. Australia he was educated at Canberra Grammar, Newington College and The University of Sydney. He earned a scholarship to the University of Chicago which prepared him for an illustrious career as CEO of Entenmanns Inc., Gerber Products Company and Campbell Soup Company. His career began at Colgate Palmolive Company in Sydney as a management trainee, then transferred to South Africa. He joined Warner Lambert Company in Hong Kong and came to the United States when the Company moved its international Headquarters. He became CEO of Entenmanns in Bay Shore, NY and expanded the Company nationally. From there he moved as CEO to Gerber Products Company and his final position was as CEO of Campbell Soup Company. He believed in capitalism, American exceptionalism and personal responsibility. He was known for his motivational enthusiasm. His mandate for professional accountability earned him the nickname "Quantification Johnson." Although he received many accolades, scholastically and in business, he was proudest of the award for "Director of the Year" because it was awarded by his peers. In his retirement years he travelled extensively and visited both the North and South Poles. After residing for 15 years in Philadelphia he moved to Solebury, PA. He will be laid to rest in a private ceremony in Australia. He is survived by his wife and three sons. His epitaph reads: "David Willis Johnson, 1932 - 2016, Gone to Glory. Called by his Maker." Services by Reed and Steinbach Funeral Home, Doylestown, PA. www.reedandsteinbach.com. 1/3

KRAININ--Bette Finley, died peacefully June 16 at home in Kailua, Hawaii. Born in Maine, was a successful model, married photographer Ewing Krainin (deceased) and travelled the world. Their loving daughter Cameron survives her. 1/3

ROUSMANIERE--Jessie P. Age 97, died on June 19 in Andover, Massachusetts, where she moved following the death of husband James A. Rousmaniere in 2004. Until her final few days, she was alert and interested in family, politics and life in general. She and her late husband were longtime residents of Oyster Bay, NY, where they raised seven sons and a daughter. Her earliest years as an Army child included three years in Germany where her father John L. Pierce (husband of Kate Bodine Stone) served in the Occupation. She met her future husband, then a young Army officer, in California during World War II. They maintained a happy marriage during which he introduced her to sailing on Long Island Sound and also during which she gracefully endured his serial candidacies for local political office; she enthusiastically supported progressive politicians at the national level, taking particular interest in the election of the nation's first black president and enthusiastically looking forward to the election of its first female president. She demonstrated an early proficiency in art, which she studied at Texas State College for Women and Auburn; to the amazement of friends, she continued to paint amid the clatter of a growing houseful of children. She was an avid reader of fiction and nonfiction, and she encouraged each of her children to keep an open and expanding mind. She leaves a sister, Isabel Ward of Indianapolis, and children John, Peter, James Jr., David, Joe, Ned, Arthur and Kate and their spouses and children. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am July 23 at Christ Church, 33 Central St., Andover, MA. 1/3

PARK--Dorothy Dent, died quietly at her home in Ithaca, New York, on Saturday, June 18, 2016 among her family and devoted staff and nurses dedicated to her care and well-being. Known as "Dottie" she was preceded in death by her husband Roy Hampton Park, founder, chairman and CEO of Park Communications whose broadcast, newspaper and outdoor media conglomerate reached 25 percent of the American public when he died in 1993. Growing up in Raleigh, North Carolina, she met her husband, a graduate of North Carolina State University, on a blind date. They moved to Ithaca, New York when her husband was hired to run the ad agency for the Grange League Federation, one of the largest farm cooperatives in the world, which later became Agway. Through this Agricultural Advertising and Research agency, Dottie's entrepreneurial husband went on meet Duncan Hines at the Waldorf Astoria to co-found Hines-Park Foods with 124 companies licensed to use the gourmet Duncan Hines name on 250 products, of which the cake mix line survives today. During the launch of the Duncan Hines food line, Dottie and Roy traveled with Duncan Hines for months at a time to just about every major city in America to meet with mayors and dignitaries for Duncan Hines Days. After Proctor & Gamble approached Park and purchased the company, Mr. Park used the stock to launch into the media business. With his wife's devotion and support, and always at his side, they met and charmed legions of prospective businesses in the media field across the country. Her husband's job was to acquire properties and Dottie's job was to host the wives of the owners of the properties he acquired. Dottie constantly entertained during their travels and at home, being always the consummate southern lady, but more than once thought of as a steel magnolia. After all the years of helping her husband through his separate careers, Dottie and Roy joined Walter Cronkite and his wife, Betsy, at the Waldorf to celebrate their joint 50th wedding anniversaries. When Walter asked Dottie what her husband had given her, she proudly replied "One thousand dollars for each year we've been married." To which Cronkite said "That's all he gave you? That's awful. If you figure it out, it only comes to $2.74 a day." One can imagine the repercussions from that. During his career her husband was a trustee of the Museum of Broadcasting in New York City, president and treasurer of the Sales Executive Club of Greater New York, a member of the New York Athletic Club, the Cornell Club of New York, the Union League Club of New York City and owner of WPAT-FM serving the greater New York City area. Upon the death of her husband, Dottie decided to sell Park Communications in its entirety with the proceeds going to the Park Foundation that she and her husband had founded 29 years earlier. With her husband's will designating her President of the newly funded Park Foundation, Inc. It was agreed by its Board of Trustees its core mission was to fund the academic institutions with which her husband had been affiliated during his lifetime. Park Scholarships were established for four- year undergraduate programs at North Carolina State University and Ithaca College as well as graduate Roy H. Park Fellowships for MBAs at the Johnson Graduate School of Management at Cornell University, and Master's and PhD Park Fellows at the School of Media and Journalism at the University of North Carolina. Initial core grantees also included the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research in Ithaca, the only board position her husband retained until he died, and Public Broadcasting Service programming such as Nova and Nature. Under her leadership as President of the Park Foundation, Dottie's philanthropy was also spread far and wide, from the country's first no-kill animal shelter, to Ithaca College, home of the Roy H. Park School of Communications, to the Park Atrium addition to the Cornell School of Hotel Administration, and the Roy H. Park Library at the School of Media and Journalism in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. In 2003 members her son along with his son and daughter created a second foundation, Triad Foundation, Inc., which permitted both foundations to pursue the philanthropic objectives that best reflected the diverse needs of their respective Boards. To date, between the two Foundations over 2,000 students have graduated from the four Universities with full tuition paid. Since 1995 charitable grants given by both Foundations have totaled over half a billion dollars. All in all, Dottie was an ardent lover of nature, animals and mankind. Numerous people received hospitality in this transplanted Southerner's northern home. She will be missed. Surviving are her son, Roy Hampton Park, Jr. and his wife Tetlow, her daughter Adelaide Park Gomer, all of Ithaca, New York; her grandchildren: Elizabeth Park Fowler and husband Troy of Tampa, Florida, Roy Hampton Park III and his wife Laura of Charlotte, North Carolina and Alicia Park Wittink and her husband Mark of Ithaca, New York. Also surviving are nine great grandchildren: Noble Brooks Fowler, Chase Hampton Fowler, Elizabeth Sumner Park, Samantha Tetlow Fowler, Roy Hampton Park IV, Lawson Brooks Park, Cameron Parham Park, Anneke Dickson Wittink, and Mathijs August Park Wittink. A Memorial service will be held at 1:00pm on Thursday, June 30 at the First Presbyterian Church of Ithaca with a reception to follow at the Country Club of Ithaca. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her memory to the SPCA of Tompkins County or the Tompkins County Public Library. 1/3

LANG--Helen S.,69, died in Riverdale, NY on June 20th, after a more than year-long struggle with brain cancer. Born in Urbana, IL, she grew up in Albuquerque, received her B.A. and M.A. degrees from the University of Colorado and then her Ph.D. in Classical Philosophy from the University of Toronto. After teaching for more than twenty years at Trinity College, Hartford, where she was the Koeppel Professor of Classical Studies, she became Chair of the Villanova University Philosophy Department and was a department member at the time of her death. Her books, other writings, and lectures have had a strong influence on the study of Greek philosophy, especially on the analysis of Aristotle. She is survived by her brother, Richard Schutzberger, her two daughters Ariella Lang (Alex) and Jessica Lang (Joerg), and six grandchildren. A graveside service was held on June 21st, and Shiva continues through the week. Contributions in memory of Helen S. Lang may be made in her name to Darkhei Noam Synagogue, www.dnoam.org. 1/3

DIAMOND--Robert S.,a New York journalist and business executive, died June 15 in Arizona after a brave, lengthy struggle to overcome complications following heart valve surgery in New York. He was 77 years old. Born in Phoenix, he was the son of Rose G. and Bertrand A. Diamond; and grandson of Nathan Diamond, pioneer merchant, who co-founded one of Arizona's early department stores. Journalism and public affairs were a passion. A graduate of Claremont McKenna College and Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism, he wrote for the Arizona Republic, Los Angeles Times and was one of the youngest staff writers for Fortune Magazine in the 1960's. Throughout his career Mr. Diamond lived in New York with his wife of 52 years, Susan. He was a senior officer of the Dun & Bradstreet Corp (now retired) the majority of his business career. Yet his never-ending pride in his Arizona heritage dominated his desire to return to Arizona as he neared life's end. Mr. Diamond was a member of national and local boards including Reading is Fundamental where he retired as vice chair; the Arizona Community Foundation; and he was a current Trustee of the Heard Museum. Survivors include his wife, Susan; brother-in-law, Larry Arnsberg; niece Lilli and cherished cousins. 1/3

YESSELMAN--Robert. Bob spent 36 years in dance management. He was the executive director of the Paul Taylor Dance Company and the Joffrey Ballet and founding director of Dance/NYC. YOUNG--Patricia Morris. September 16, 1919 - June 8, 2016. Asian art historian, founding director of the Asia Society Texas Center, long-time resident in Thailand, wife and mother, Patricia Morris Young's life revolved around her passion for art history, her deep commitment to passing her knowledge on to others, and her unalloyed delight in the wonders of other cultures. From an early age she enjoyed visual expressions of beauty particularly painting and sculpture. Refining this sensibility became a lifelong pursuit. She began with a foundation in European art history which led to her vocation as a lecturer and writer on Southeast Asian art. Born in Washington, DC, she was educated at the Potomac School, Miss Hall's School in Massachusetts, and graduated from Vassar College in 1941 with a degree in History. In 1943 she married Kenneth T. Young, Jr. She raised four children in Washington and New York before moving the family to Bangkok, Thailand, where her husband served as American Ambassador from 1961 to 1963. Her encounter with Asia changed her life. She traveled extensively in Southeast Asia, began her study of Southeast Asian art, and worked to promote contemporary Thai artists. Returning to the United States she combined her roles as wife and mother with graduate studies in Asian art. In 1976 she went to work for the Asia Society, running the Society's Asian tour programs. In 1979 she moved to Houston to become the founding director of the Asia Society Texas Center. She retired in 1986, returning to Bangkok where she spent seventeen years deepening her knowledge of Asian art and culture, traveling widely from Japan to India. Thai art and culture were her special areas of interest and expertise. For many years she pursued a fascination with Thai Buddhist lacquer murals, writing several articles on her findings. A member of the Association of Asian Studies and the Siam Society since the early 1960s, she worked tirelessly to promote an understanding of Asian cultures. Her gifts were her ability to listen, to establish friendships, and to connect like-minded individuals who shared her passion. She was particularly interested in bringing Thai and Western art historians together. She loved learning and encouraged others to do so through teaching and lecturing in Asia and the U.S. She wanted to help others see and appreciate the beauty she saw in Asian painting, sculpture, music, dance, crafts, and architecture. Her graciousness and kindness won her friends wherever she traveled. She is survived by her four children, six grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. Donations can be made in her honor to the University of Washington Art Library Slide Fund for Patricia M. Young slide collection at: https://www.washington.edu/ giving/make-a-gift/?page= funds&source--typ=3& source=ARTLIB 1/3

JONES--Randy. British-born, New York Citybased drummer Randy Jones passed away in Calvary Hospital on Monday, June 13, 2016, of heart failure. Known as one of the most versatile drummers of his time, he was 72 years old. Randy began as a drummer in an English rock-and-roll band and became a session drummer in London before joining the Maynard Ferguson Big Band. He came to the United States in 1972, and was soon recognized for his work with such noted jazz greats as Chet Baker, Gerry Mulligan and Bill Watrous. In 1978 he joined the Dave Brubeck Quartet, with which he toured and recorded for more than three decades. Randy was a passionate collector of classical records, and his drum solos reflected that interest. He is survived by his son, Thad Jones; grandsons Bryce and Peyton Jones; sister, Christine Wickham-Jones; and former wife and close friend, Laurie Beckelman. A memorial service will be held in the fall. 1/3

FISHER--Jerome. The Trustees, faculty, and staff of the University of Pennsylvania are deeply saddened by the death of our great friend and Emeritus Trustee, Jerome Fisher. A devoted alumnus of the University, Jerome served on Wharton's Board of Overseers, as well as on the Penn Medicine Board of Trustees. Jerome's memory will live on at Penn through the many ways in which he helped to transform the University's physical and academic landscape over more than two and a half decades. He and his wife, Anne, endowed the Jerome Fisher Program in Management and Technology, a renowned model of interdisciplinary learning; supported the restoration of landmark campus buildings; provided scholarship aid; and established professorships at Penn Medicine. Jerome was extremely proud that five of his grandchildren continued his legacy by attending his alma mater. As we remember Jerome for his great warmth, devotion and service to the university community, we extend heartfelt condolences to Anne, his children, grandchildren, and extended family and friends. David L. Cohen, Chairman; Andrea Mitchell, Vice Chair; Amy Gutmann, President; Geoffrey Garrett, Dean, The Wharton School; J. Larry Jameson, Executive Vice President of the University of Pennsylvania for the Health System and Dean, Perelman School of Medicine 1/3

MIGLIUOLO--Dagmar, (nee Zlatohlavkova) (10 April 1927 - 8 May 2016) wife of Giovanni Migliuolo (1927-1989) former Ambassador of Italy to the United Nations, Egypt and the USSR. Longtime resident of New York, she peacefully passed into grace in Turin, Italy. She leaves her children and their spouses (Andrea and Laura, Anna and Marialaura, Michele and Gina, Stefano and Sarah), grandchildren (Adriana, Alessandro, Giancarlo, Sebastian and Vittorio). Tenacious archaeologist, traveler, voracious reader and fluent in multiple languages, she dedicated herself to service in the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Her friends are invited to join in the celebration of her life at the Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola (Park Ave and 84th St., New York City) at 10am on 29 June 2016. Burial will follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery (Hawthorne, NY), where Dagmar (Zlatohlavkova) Migliuolo will be laid to rest with her husband in this world and the next. 1/3

Alvin served as a Carnegie Hall Trustee from 1986 to 1992 with grace and distinction. He will be remembered by all of us at Carnegie Hall not only for his remarkable business acumen, but also for his tremendous kindness. We express our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Joan, and their four children, Alison, Jay, Gail and Karen. Robert F. Smith, Chairman; Sanford I. Weill, President; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director 1/3

STACIVA--Camille. Died on June 19 at age 73. Daughter of a psychiatrist and a graphic artist. Like her sister, Cleo Whitten, graduated from Harvard College. Then made a 30-year career in market research in New York City, working for ad agencies (Advertising to Women, J Walter Thompson, Kenyon & Ekhardt, others). She leaves her partner of 52 years, Jack Linn, long-time Assistant Commissioner at New York City Parks, her sister Cleo, her niece Jennifer Govan, and nephews Peter, Adam and Joshua Tomei. Wake: Monday, June 27 5-8pm. Service: Tuesday, June 28, 11am. Both at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., near 6th Ave. 1/3

GAULKIN--Roseanne F.,87, passed away at home in New York City on June 17 after a long illness. Beloved mother of David and Daniel, daughter of the late Louis Fusco, Sr. and Mary Fusco. She is also survived by her brother, Louis Fusco. Born and raised in Connecticut, a graduate of Radcliffe, she began her career in human resources in New York City and went on to become a highly regarded real estate agent in New York for more than 20 years. She was actively involved with the Harvard Club of New York where she was the first woman Chairperson of the Admissions Committee and the Program Committee. Lively, humorous and brave, she will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved her. 1/3

CARR--Sara Maffitt Lockhart, was born April 8, 1924 in Charlotte, NC and died June 8, 2016 in New York City. She was predeceased by her parents Sara Laurens Maffitt Lockhart and James Alexander Lockhart, Jr. of Charlotte, NC and her brother James Alexander Lockhart, III of Charlotte, NC. She is survived by her brother Thomas Ashe Lockhart (Ann) of Charlotte, NC; nephews Thomas Ashe Lockhart, Jr. (Stephanie) of Charlotte, NC, James Wilkinson Lockhart (Julie) of Decatur, GA, John Laurens Lockhart (Amy) of Charleston, SC; nieces Ann Lockhart Mayeux (Craig) of Charlotte, NC and Eloise Lockhart Sample of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL; great-nieces Grace Maffitt Lockhart of Decatur, GA, Charlotte Olivia Laurens Gillman of Charlotte, NC and Ashley Sample Rutland (Taylor) of New Orleans, LA and a great-great-nephew and niece. Sara received her Bachelors degree in Sociology from Women's College at University of North Carolina in 1945. Sara was married and divorced with no children. She was a model as a "Power's Girl" with the John Robert Powers Agency in the 1940's and had lived in New York City for over 60 years. Sara was a member of Saint Thomas Episcopal Church. She loved to travel, go to the opera, watch tennis and discuss politics. She will be greatly missed by her family. A memorial service will be held in the Chantry Chapel at Saint Thomas Church, June 28 at 1pm. Services entrusted to Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel." 1/3

KELLOGG--Frederick Fuller, Jr.,on June 22, 2016 of Little River, SC and New York City. He was a graduate of Stevens Institute of Technology (1950). He was a licensed Professional Engineer and served as Chief Engineer for the Village of Larchmont for over two decades. He was a member of the Circumnavigators Club, Mayflower Society, Society of Colonial Governors, and the SAR. He was active in sports and in his youth won several championships in track and field as well as the 1946 Westchester county diving championship. He is survived by his sister, Dr. Joan Renz, by his sons Freddie and David, and by his four grandchildren. Services will be held on Tuesday, June 28, 2016 at 11:00am at Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison, New York, NY 10016. Interment with his late wife Dyane at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery. 1/3

BECKER--Jacqueline L.,age 90, of Boca Raton, Florida, died Sunday, June 12, 2016, at Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton. Born in New York City, Mrs. Becker was a Vassar graduate who had diverse careers including artist relations specialist at Decca Records in the late 1940's, local and state political activist in Indiana, Florida, and Massachusetts, and real estate agent/broker in Boca Raton. Mrs. Becker valued education and sponsored many scholarships and endowments both at Indiana State University and at Florida Atlantic University. Mrs. Becker was preceded in death by her parents, Henry and the Hon. Judge Frances Lehrich; her husband of 59 years, Herman D. Becker; and her son, Richard L. Becker. Survivors include her daughter Susan M. Becker of Indianapolis, IN; grandchildren Tracy Bartow of Indianapolis, and Jon D. Becker of Henderson, KY; and great-grandson Max G. Becker, also of Henderson. A celebration of life will be held at a later date. Memorial contributions can be made to the Boca Raton Firefighter and Paramedic Fund for the Rick Becker Memorial CPR fund, PO Box 565, Boca Raton, FL 33429; or the Jacqueline L. Becker Award in Political Science, FAU Foundation Inc., 777 Glades Rd., ADM 285, Boca Raton, FL 33431. 1/3

OKORONKWO--Sylvia Pauline Johnson, passed away peacefully on June 22, 2016 surrounded by love; her children Chinyere Y. Okoronkwo, Kanu David Okoronkwo, Ifeoma Okoronkwo and daughter-in-law, Nieves Chevalier Okoronkwo were all present at her bedside as she was ushered from this world to the next. Also, present were her grandson, Jean Pierre Hernandez who represented all of her eight grandchildren, as well as two of her most beloved caregivers, Carol Blair and Synetta Smith. Sylvia Okoronkwo was born in Weldon, North Carolina to Wilbert Johnson and Pauline Stith. After gaining the highest accolades in academics, she went on to study nursing where once again she excelled. While pursuing graduate studies in nursing at Columbia University she met Kanu Okoronkwo, Sr., and in May, 1959 the two were married at St. John's Cathedral in New York City. The young couple returned to Kanu Okoronkwo Sr.'s native land, Nigeria, where Sylvia Okoronkwo pursued volunteerism at the local hospitals and played hostess to various actors and dignitaries, while her husband became the head of telecommunications of southeast Nigeria. Sylvia and Kanu Okoronkwo brought three children into the world, Chinyere, Kanu and Ifeoma. But, at the climax of the Biafran War in 1967, with their lives in danger, Sylvia Okoronkwo fled Nigeria with her three children in tow and one suitcase in hand to her birth land of the United States of America. Still known for her excellence in nursing and having kept her credentials active, Sylvia Okoronkwo was appointed surgical nurse to the newly opened cardiothoracic unit at the New York Hospital. Mrs. O, as she was famously known, ended up working for New York Hospital for almost 40 years in the pediatric urology unit and finally as the medical nursing supervisor of the evening shift. It was her love of nursing, and the love of her grandchildren, that truly sustained her throughout her life. Sylvia Okoronkwo is survived by her children Chinyere Okoronkwo, Kanu David Okoronkwo, Ifeoma Okoronkwo, her daughter-in-law, Nieves Chevalier Okoronkwo, her dear Yeimi Chevalier and her grandchildren, Anastasia Williams Okoronkwo, Aaron Hernandez, Kate Aitkenhead, Jean Pierre Hernandez. Sophie Aitkenhead, Lauren Aitkenhead, Daniel Okoronkwo and Samantha Okoronkwo, whom she called her "dancing girl". A Funeral Mass, with Father Emmanuel Oktalauwaekwe presiding, will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., at 11am, Monday, followed by a burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York. There will be a lunch to follow at Casa Rina Restaurant in Thornwood, New York. 1/3

WALPIN--Gerald, suddenly on June 24, 2016 after being struck by a car. He is remembered as a man of integrity, who, even when he retired, never stopped practicing law. He always liked a good debate, was logical and committed to his positions, but was respected by those whose point of view was completely counter to his own. His achievements were admirable -- he was a graduate from City College of New York and Yale Law School, clerked for two federal judges, served in the Air Force, served as an US ADA in the Southern District, was the head of litigation at Rosenman Colin, was the IG of the Corporation for National and Community Service, authored a book on the Constitution and lectured across the country. But most important of all was his family, his beloved wife of almost 60 years, Sheila, his three children, Amanda, Edward and Jennifer, his son-in-law, Allan, and daughter-in-law, Cynthia, and the pride and joy of his life, his six grandchildren, Justin, Dylan, Jacob, Sophie, Carrie and Alexandra. Service Tuesday, June 28 at 12:00 at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to the Federalist Society or the Intrepid Museum. 1/3

STEINBERG--Roslyn, of Elmhurst, age 21+. Died at home, surrounded by family, on June 24, 2016. Adored wife of the late Richard Steinberg. Cherished mother of Michael and Victoria. Beloved mother-in-law of Margaret and grandmother of Shauna. Daughter of the late Eli and Pearl Yellin. Sister of the late Fay Goldstein, Ann Savage, and Jack and Sylvia Yellin. Treasured aunt, great-aunt and friend. Services, Tuesday, June 28, 2016 at noon, Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. 1/3

GUTH--Polly. The Glimmerglass Festival family fondly remembers Polly Guth, whose warmth and generosity will forever linger among those who had the honor and pleasure of knowing her, and through the many programs and buildings she helped to bring to life through her gracious generosity. Not one to have things "named" for her, her gifts were always for "the cause" not the glory. But among her most treasured gifts were her compassion, joy for life and passion to help make extraordinary things happen. We will greatly miss this special lady and leader. 1/3

BERNSTEIN--Joseph. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime member and past president and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Helene K. Gray, President Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor 1/3

FISHER--Jerome. The Fashion Footwear Association of New York (FFANY) mourns the loss of Jerome "Jack" Fisher, a legend in our industry and esteemed philanthropist. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Anne, to his son Marc, a dynamic member of FFANY's Board, and to the entire Fisher Family on the loss of their patriarch. Jack brought talent, tenacity, passion and a generous spirit to all his pursuits. He catapulted the footwear industry to new heights and was a respected benefactor of many health, education and arts organizations. Jack saved countless lives through his visionary founding and leadership of "FFANY Shoes on Sale" and generations to come will continue to benefit from its funding of innovative breast cancer detection and treatment. While our hearts are heavy with this loss, they are uplifted knowing Jack's legacy of compassion and strength lives on through his cherished family and will inspire us all to follow in his footsteps to bring our industry and community together for good works. Jim Issler, Chairman Ron Fromm, President & CEO Joe Moore & Dick Jacobson, Presidents Emeritus FFANY 1/3

CUNNINGHAM--Bill. The Trustees and Staff of the New-York Historical Society mourn the passing of Bill Cunningham, a dear friend of our institution and great New York icon. Bill's association with New-York Historical began nearly fifty years ago with research in our Patricia D. Klingenstein Library relating to "Facades," an eight-year project that documented the architectural riches and fashion history of New York City. We were honored to celebrate the opening of a new exhibition of "Facades" in 2014 with photographs Bill gifted to us, on his 85th birthday. We will always recall Bill telling the guests, "I just have fun whatever I'm doing. Otherwise, it's not worth doing... Money isn't worth it. It's much better to go out and do what you want." Our hearts go out to Bill's devoted friend John Kurdewan at the New York Times, and to his extended family. Pam B. Schafler, Chair Richard Reiss, Vice Chair Roger Hertog, Executive Committee Chairman Louise Mirrer, President & CEO Valerie Paley, Vice President & "Facades" curator 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Barbara. Author, historian and beloved mother of Andrew Goldsmith, Alice Elgart, John Goldsmith and grandmother of six. Private funeral. Memorial service at later date. In lieu of flowers, donations to Barbara Goldsmith Preservation Division at NYPL or Wellesley College. 1/3

MIGLIUOLO--Dagmar, (nee Zlatohlavkova) (10 April 1927 - 8 May 2016) wife of Giovanni Migliuolo (1927-1989) former Ambassador of Italy to the United Nations, Egypt and the USSR. Longtime resident of New York, she peacefully passed into grace in Turin, Italy. She leaves her children and their spouses (Andrea and Laura, Anna and Marialaura, Michele and Gina, Stefano and Sarah), grandchildren (Adriana, Alessandro, Giancarlo, Sebastian and Vittorio). Tenacious archaeologist, traveler, voracious reader and fluent in multiple languages, she dedicated herself to service in the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Her friends are invited to join in the celebration of her life at the Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola (Park Ave and 84th St., New York City) at 10am on 29 June 2016. Burial will follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery (Hawthorne, NY), where Dagmar (Zlatohlavkova) Migliuolo will be laid to rest with her husband in this world and the next. 1/3
ROSENTHAL--Edward H. The Queens County Bar Association records with deep sorrow the passing of its distinguished member and Past President 2002-2003 on June 25, 2016. Gregory J. Brown, President 1/3

RABINOWITZ--Robert Marc. Born 1928 and raised in Brooklyn, NY, Robert was an artist, professor, and designer of multimedia Broadway productions. He is survived by wife Kate O'Toole Rabinowitz, son Marc, daughter Molly, sons-in-law John Pitsikalis and Rick Michalek and grandchildren Julia and Zelda. Informal reception: Riverdale on Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, Wednesday, June 29, 2-5pm. 1/3

GORDON--Kenny. On your 44th Birthday. Not a day goes by for us without memories bringing smiles to our faces or tears to our eyes. You are missed every minute of every day. Our aching hearts are always filled with love for you. Mom, Dad, Jonny, Catherine, Kenya, Chloe & Gemma 1/3

CUNNINGHAM--Bill. The Rudin family and Rudin Management Company mourn the passing of Bill Cunningham, a treasured and talented photographer, a wonderful friend and iconic New Yorker. Bill loved the City's vitality in its most fashionable form and his talents were realized and enjoyed by us all in between the pages of the New York Times. We will deeply miss his kindness, humility, passion and great talent and we send condolences to his entire family. Jack Rudin and the Rudin family 1/3

LEASS--Shirley Molbert, on Saturday, June 25, age 85. Admired art and antiques dealer, fine artist in her garden. A rare and dynamic woman of beauty, heart and exquisite taste who lived life on her own terms. Survived by children Jeffrey, Robin and Andrew Molbert, granddaughter Evera. Predeceased by husbands Harry Molbert and Reuben Leass. Loved by friends, family, her big dogs. At peace, forever in our hearts. Services 10am, Friday, July 1, Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck. 1/3

ERTLE--Edward Peter, II, 61, suddenly on June 20, 2016. Eight-time New York City marathon runner, avid biker, passionate lover of the arts, The New York Times crossword puzzle (in ink!). Lover of games, the ocean, hot peppers, seasons and all holidays, especially Christmas, and above all, family, friends and God. Loving partner to Gary for 32 joyful years. You will be deeply missed. Irreplaceable. Celebration of Life, "The Riverside," New York City, June 30, 5:30pm. 1/3

CUNNINGHAM--Bill. It is with great sorrow we learned of the passing of our one and only Bill Cunningham. This very special, dear man, so humble, yet so kind and caring. Always calling some of us "child". He was and always will be a New York landmark. His appreciation of fashion, its changes and moods as shown by all people, was matched only by his appreciation and love of the arts. His Sunday pictures helped so many not for profit organizations become recognized - he was truly a man for all people. Dear Bill, you will never be forgotten, your legacy is forever! We will have a Number One at the Star Deli in your honor! With much love and great sadness. Joan and Sandy Weill 1/3

CUNNINGHAM--Bill. We celebrate the life of Bill Cunningham. He brightened New York City by generously sharing his unique perspective during a trailblazing career spanning decades. The Board of Trustees, staff and dancers of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater 1/3

FEHER--Anthony Langford XIV, March 2, 1956 - June 24, 2016. Raised in Corpus Christi, TX, resided in New York City, he was 60 years old. A truly original artist who saw beauty in everything. A shaman and an alchemist who made magic out of thin air. Tony was a Gentleman, a Prince and a Queen. Always the life of the party, he was the first to arrive and the last to leave. An activist, collector, cultural historian, geologist, world traveler, carpenter, ballroom dancer, gardener, aviator, tart and a mighty raconteur. Above all, Tony was a transplendent friend. He is survived by his loving wife of seven months, Andrea Blum, his sister-wives Nancy Brooks Brody, Joy Episalla, Zoe Leonard, Carrie Yamaoka, his soul brother Mike Malena and a vast family of beloved friends. His parting words were "You all still look the same". Tony left us at 5:25pm in Bellevue hospice, surrounded by his chosen family, not before saying, "it ain't the Carlyle". 1/3

WALPIN--Gerald. The Robert Morgenthau AUSA Association mourns the tragic, untimely death of our dear friend and formidable former colleague, Jerry Walpin, and send heartfelt condolences to Sheila and the Walpin family. 1/3
WALPIN--Gerald. With our deepest sorrow we extend our condolences to Sheila and the entire Walpin family. Shelley & Robert W. Berend 1/3

VOUGHT--K. Dean, of Garden City, NY died June 25. Beloved husband of the late Susan E. Vought and amazing father to: Laurie V. Gallagher, Victoria V. King, Melinda V. Best, Amanda V. Abrahm, Alexandra V. Bohn. He will be remembered as a dedicated professional with over 40 years of service at Kurt Salmon Associates, a fervent Penn State Alumni and an ardent family man. He will be missed by many, most particularly his daughters, sons-in-law, and 11 grandchildren! Services will be held at Garden City Community Church at 2pm, Wednesday, June 29. 1
FELSEN--Esther and David. Missed, loved and remembered always by the Felsen, Sokol and Rivard families, including our most recent additions, Micah Felsen and Nat and Leo Felsen. 1/3
KERR--Michael R.,48, of Brooklyn, died June 17, 2016. Beloved son of Bobby, brother of Khristen and Theresia. 1/3

CUNNINGHAM--Bill. It is with great sorrow we learned of the passing of our one and only Bill Cunningham. This very special, dear man, so humble, yet so kind and caring. Always calling some of us "child". He was and always will be a New York landmark. His appreciation of fashion, its changes and moods as shown by all people, was matched only by his appreciation and love of the arts. His Sunday pictures helped so many not for profit organizations become recognized - he was truly a man for all people. Dear Bill, you will never be forgotten, your legacy is forever! We will have a Number One at the Star Deli in your honor! With much love and great sadness. Joan and Sandy Weill 1/3

DAVIS--Edward J. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm Davis Wright Tremaine LLP note with profound sorrow the untimely death of our beloved partner Edward J. Davis on June 27, 2016 after a valiant battle with cancer. A New Jersey native, Ed graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Harvard College and magna cum laude from Harvard Law School. Ed was a Marshal Scholar and received masters' degrees from the London School of Economics and Political Science and the London School of Oriental and African Studies. His brilliant mind and devotion to their interests made him a valued advisor to his many clients who benefited from his unerring judgment. Ed's humility and generosity of spirit made him a mentor to all who had the privilege and good fortune to know and work with him. Ed was committed to providing pro bono assistance to individuals and organizations in need of assistance, and was recognized for his efforts with the Dramatists Legal Defense Fund's "Defenders Award" and the Arthur Liman Public Interest Award by the Legal Action Center. We extend our deepest sympathies to his husband, Tom Phillips; his mother, Marian Davis; sister, Kathleen Davis; niece, Marissa Davis; extended family, and wide network of devoted friends. A celebration of Ed's life is being planned. 1/3

GOLDENBERG--Billie (Wallens), always the spirited light that brightened the room, she was loyally devoted to all whom she loved. Her life was filled with appreciation for arts, design and culture from New York to Florida. Billie passed on June 25 at age 64. She is survived by her father Eugene Wallens, husband Leon Goldenberg; daughters Lisa Toledano and husband Andy Toledano and Amy Tebbi and husband David Tebbi, and brother Bob Wallens and wife Shelly. Memorial service: Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, Wednesday, June 29, 5pm. Memorial hours: The Phillips Club, West 66th St., Wednesday, 6:30-9pm; Thursday, Saturday and Sunday, 12-3pm and 5-8pm; Friday, 12-5pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the National Alliance on Mental Illness. 1/3

CUNNINGHAM--Bill. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall celebrate the life of our friend, the legendary photographer Bill Cunningham. For decades, Bill was an integral and beloved part of New York's cultural community, documenting the ever-changing world of fashion and the city's social scene. Bill worked and later lived in a studio above Carnegie Hall for sixty years, and he frequently could be seen working in the blocks around the Hall. In 2012, we were proud to honor him with Carnegie Hall's Medal of Excellence, saluting him for all he taught the world about fashion, philanthropy, and the joy of creativity at an event supporting the Hall's artistic and music education programs, a cause close to his heart. Ever gentle and humble, he used this moment to thank his photographic subjects, whether famous or unknown, and those who support the arts. We express our heartfelt condolences to his family and dedicated colleagues. Robert F. Smith, Chairman; Sanford I. Weill, President; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Barbara. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of Barbara Goldsmith, a dedicated member of the Library family. She joined the Library's Board of Trustees in 1987 and was an active member for many years. She was a generous supporter and a strong advocate for preservation at the Library, where the Barbara Goldsmith Preservation Division bears her name. She served as a member of many key Board committees and on the Executive Committee of the Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers. She was named a Life Trustee in 2006. An accomplished author, she was honored both as a Literary Lion and as a Centennial Lion. We offer our sincere sympathies to all of her family and friends. Evan R. Chesler, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Catherine Marron, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Neil L. Rudenstine Chairmen Emeriti Anthony W. Marx, President 1/3

GILDIN--David, 95, on June 27, 2016. Beloved husband of the late Lucille. Cherished companion of Cecile Schrader. Devoted father of Beth Gildin Watrous, Marsha Gildin, Janis Gildin and husband Michael Roach. Grandfather of Lauren, Naomi and Heather Watrous, Jahdea and Shalom Gildin, Eyla and Eliani Roach Gildin, Andrew Wagner and Erin Lutes. Dear brother of Leon Gildin. A builder and Boiberikaner. Our one and only. Service Thursday, June 30th, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

GROSSBERG--Joseph, died peacefully from prostate cancer on Tuesday, June 28, 2016. It was his 83rd birthday. He is survived by his beloved wife, Barbara, and son, Andrew, and leaves behind his loving brother, David, (Miriam), niece, Amy, (Alison), nephew, Robert, (Marina) and great-niece, Francesca and great-nephew, Luca. Dr. Grossberg was born in East New York, Brooklyn; the son of Russian Jewish immigrant parents who embodied the American immigrant success story. He attended City College and earned an Ed.D. from Yeshiva University. He worked as a dedicated and caring psychologist in the New York City Public High School system for thirty-one years and also maintained a private practice and earned the gratitude of many patients helped by him. Upon retirement he volunteered with the Literacy Volunteers of America and did canine therapy at a local nursing home. He enjoyed the pleasures of good books, music and cinema, especially classic films. He also learned a new language, Spanish, and enjoyed the practice of tai chi, kayaking and walking his dog. Most of all he enjoyed people. Dr. Grossberg had a gentle and kind nature and was truly a light in today's darkness. He was loved immensely by his family and friends and respected and liked by all who met him. He will be deeply missed. Services will be held on Friday, July 1st, at 10:00am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue and 91st Street, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Guiding Eyes for the Blind, Yorktown Heights, NY and America's Vet Dogs, Smithtown, NY. 1/3

HANIGSBERG--Phyllis Hertz, 102, formerly of Rego Park, NY, died Monday, June 27th at home in Stamford, CT. Pre- deceased by husband Murray J. Hanigsberg, M.D. Much adored and admired wife, mother, grandmother, great- grandmother, aunt, friend and RN. 1/3

VOUGHT--K. Dean, of Garden City, NY died June 25. Beloved husband of the late Susan E. Vought and amazing father to: Laurie V. Gallagher, Victoria V. King, Melinda V. Best, Amanda V. Abrahm, Alexandra V. Bohn. He will be remembered as a dedicated professional with over 40 years of service at Kurt Salmon Associates, a fervent Penn State Alumni and an ardent family man. He will be missed by many, most particularly his daughters, sons-in-law, and 11 grandchildren! Services will be held at Garden City Community Church at 2pm, Wednesday, June 29. 1
KERR--Michael R.,48, of Brooklyn, died June 17, 2016. Beloved son of Bobby, brother of Khristen and Theresia. 1/3

LEASS--Shirley Molbert, on Saturday, June 25, age 85. Admired art and antiques dealer, fine artist in her garden. A rare and dynamic woman of beauty, heart and exquisite taste who lived life on her own terms. Survived by children Jeffrey, Robin and Andrew Molbert, granddaughter Evera. Predeceased by husbands Harry Molbert and Reuben Leass. Loved by friends, family, her big dogs. At peace, forever in our hearts. Services 10am, Friday, July 1, Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck. 1/3

SCHEPPS--J. Lew. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend and fellow member, J. Lew Schepps. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his entire family. Richard Fleder, President 1

GOLDSMITH--Barbara. Author, historian and beloved mother of Andrew Goldsmith, Alice Elgart, John Goldsmith and grandmother of six. Private funeral. Memorial service at later date. In lieu of flowers, donations to Barbara Goldsmith Preservation Division at NYPL or Wellesley College. 1/3

HOLQUIST--J. Michael. His wife Elise Snyder and his sons mourn the passing of J. Michael Holquist, emeritus professor of Comparative Literature at Yale University and past president of the MLA. He died in his sleep at home early on the morning of Sunday, June 26, 2016. Born in Rockford, Illinois, on December 20, 1935, he served in the US Army (where he learned Russian). He received a BA from the University of Illinois and a PhD from Yale University, where he helped establish the undergraduate literature major, Lit X. After serving as chair of Slavic Departments at the University of Texas, Austin and Indiana University-Bloomington, he returned to Yale, where he taught from 1986-2005. In his retirement, he taught in the Society of Senior Scholars at Columbia University and the Yale Alumni College--and also ran a wine importing business with his wife. He is survived by his widow, Elise Snyder; his sons Peter, Benjamin, Nicholas, and Sebastian; and his stepdaughters Katherine Snyder and Margaret Hamilton. He was predeceased by his son Joshua. The funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel on September 25, 2-4pm. 1

ROBINSON--Bertram, 94, Monroe Twp.,NJ, on June 28, 2016. Retired Commercial Real Estate Developer. Husband of the late Phoebe Robinson. Father of Marc and the late Barbara Robinson. Father-in-law of Donna Rosenstein. Grandfather of Zachary and Georgi. Brother of Sandra Linzer. To leave condolences, please visit: www.msmc.us 1/3

DAVIS--Edward. The staff and Board of the Legal Action Center mourn the untimely death of Ed Davis, our longtime Board member and former Staff Attorney who lifted the hearts of everyone he met. Ed was a champion of justice, a passionate advocate for the Center and the people we serve, and the kindest, most humble person to walk the earth. We were honored to work with and be inspired by Ed and will miss him terribly. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Linda N.,on June 28, 2016. Beloved wife of Neil. Devoted mother of Sara Mairs. Loving sister of Gloria Lehrman and Sylvia glazer. Services Friday, July 1st, 12:30pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to Congregation Habonim or The American Cancer Society. 1/3

SCHEPPS--J. Lew. The family mourns the passing of Lew, 96, on June 28, 2016, following a prolonged illness. He was predeceased by his beloved wives Sonia and Suzanne and brother Aaron, and is survived by his loving partner Geraldine Kory; son Solomon, daughter-in-law Karen, grandson Daniel; daughter Francine, son-in- law David, granddaughters Rachel, Jaclyn and Molly; brother Elihu, loving nieces and nephews. Lew, a veteran of WWII, retired from a successful career in the textile business as founding partner of Mastex Industries which he ran with his two brothers. He went on to dedicate himself to the Jewish National Fund, continuing the legacy begun by his parents, Isadore and Rae. Funeral service will be held on Thursday, June 30th, 10am at Congregation Kol Ami in White Plains. Donations can be sent to Jewish National Fund. 1

LEWIS--Ogden Northrop, known as "Denny," of New York City and Quogue, NY died on June 25 at age 73 after several years of declining health. He was predeceased by his adored only child and namesake, and is survived by Susan, his devoted wife of 42 years; brother William Hall Lewis, III (Barbara); nephew W.H. Ramsay Lewis (Julia) and great-nieces Amelia and Cecily; sister-in-law Margaret High. He was a litigation partner of the New York firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell. Denny received gratification as Chair of the Pro Bono Committee, especially when a capital case sentence was reversed. When of Senior Counsel status, he became a Senior Lecturing Fellow at Duke Law School from 2004-2010. Civic-minded in both NYC and Quogue, he sat on numerous boards as director and president. Denny was a graduate of the Buckley School, Phillips Exeter Academy, Harvard College (Phi Beta Kappa), Christ Church, Oxford (Keasbey Scholar), and Harvard Law School. A lover of the sea, he served as Navigator on the "U.S.S. Little Rock." He will be remembered as a keen scholar of history and the law, a wise mentor with an open door, and a respected consensus builder of gentle temperament. He was known for his immeasurable benevolent heart. The family requests no flowers. Those who desire to honor Denny may consider a contribution to the American Friends of Christ Church, Inc., 3900 NYS Rt. 22, Willsboro, NY 12996, or Saint Thomas Church Choir School, 202 West 58th St., NYC, NY 10019. In fulfillment of his wishes, a private graveside service is being held in the Quogue Cemetery. 1/3

YABLON--Leonard. We are profoundly saddened by the passing of our good friend Lenny. A true gentleman, always caring and thoughtful, with an incredible capacity to think deeply. Warm and wonderful friend to all, with a great sense of humor. Our thoughts and prayers are with Pam and the Yablon extended family. Earle Altman, Gregg Schenker, Peter Burack, Steven Hornstock, Jason Fein and the ABS Partners Team 1/3

BROGAN--Joseph Francis. On Monday, June 27, 2016 in Silver Spring, MD. Born March 24, 1925 in Manhattan, NY. Beloved husband of the late Annamae Kilcommons Brogan and the late May Brennan Brogan. Loving father of Stephen Joseph Brogan (Mary); grandfather of Kathleen Ann, Eileen Mary, Anne Marie, Mary Patricia, Joseph Peter, Theresa Brighid; great-grandfather of Mary Claire. A devout Roman Catholic, he graduated from St. Joseph School and Rice Catholic High School in New York City. He served in the South Pacific in World War II at Okinawa and other sites. He was a New York City Policeman serving as patrolman, Sergeant and Lieutenant, mostly in Harlem. Friends may call on Thursday, June 30, 2016 at St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church, 10103 Georgia Ave., Silver Spring, MD 20902 from 10am until time of Mass of Christian Burial at 11am. Interment Friday, July 1, at 12:30pm in Dagsboro, DE at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Catholic Coalition for Special Education, PO Box 673, Kensington, MD 20895, www.ccse-maryland.org. 1/3
HITTNER--Rebecca. To Becky, my dearest and best friend, I love you and will miss you. With Love, Evelyn. 1/3

WILSON--Philip D.,Jr. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our deepest sympathy at the passing of Philip D. Wilson, Jr., M.D., who made outstanding contributions to the hospital's growth, work and mission over five decades. He led Hospital for Special Surgery in advancing the field of joint replacement and orthopedic research, fostering the hospital's development as a worldclass center for patient care. As an educator and innovator of new techniques, Dr. Wilson introduced total hip replacement to the hospital in 1967, a new surgical procedure at the time. He went on to serve as the hospital's surgeon-in-chief from 1972 to 1989 and was recognized not only for his surgical skill, wisdom, integrity and sound judgment, but also for his compassion and thoughtfulness. His leadership and dedication helped transform Hospital for Special Surgery from an institution of local recognition to one of international acclaim. During his 17-year tenure as surgeon-in-chief, he developed a robust research department that brought together engineers and orthopedic surgeons and ushered biomechanics into the computer age. During this time, he held the dual role of Director of Resident Training, fostering innovation in graduate medical education and serving as a role model and inspiration for young, aspiring orthopedic surgeons. Dr. Wilson will be remembered as a leader in orthopedics, as an innovator, a mentor and a friend. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Kendrick R. Wilson III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Barbara. The Board of Trustees and staff of PEN America are deeply saddened by the loss of longtime Trustee Barbara Goldsmith. Barbara has been a passionate and enormously generous supporter of PEN's freedom of expression advocacy programming for more than three decades. Through the PEN/Barbara Goldsmith Freedom to Write Award for an imprisoned writer of conscience, she spotlighted writers who risk life and livelihood to tell truths. Of the past 39 recipient writers, 36 have been freed due partly to attention and pressure generated by the award. Ma Thida, the 1996 Award recipient who was jailed in Myanmar thanks Barbara "for the encouragement to writers in prison that what we had done for the freedom to write was right and for the sense of security that comes from not being ignored by the rest of the world." We will miss her and offer our profound sympathy to her family. Andrew Solomon, President Suzanne Nossel, Executive Director 1/3

CUNNINGHAM--Bill. The Trustees and staff of The Frick Collection feel deeply the loss of Bill Cunningham. He was one of the first photographers to shoot our events regularly, and did so particularly often over the last 20 years. The results in print, online, and video were keenly anticipated, but equally meaningful to us was the warmth and unforgettable spirit he brought to each occasion. He was the embodiment of joy as he moved among us New Yorkers, a chronicler and ambassador the likes of whom we may never know again. We offer our sincere condolences to his colleagues, close friends, and all who shared with us a love of Bill. Margot Bogert, Chairman Ian Wardropper, Director 1/3

CUNNINGHAM--Bill. To our dearest Bill, we join the chorus of mourners singing your praises. Well beyond the lens, however was your kindness. Every time you called us "Child", with your twinkling eyes, we loved you even more. We will miss being part of your world. You will forever have a place in our hearts. Alexandra Lebenthal, Somers Farkas, Dayssi Olarte de Kavanos, Muffie Potter Aston 1/3

MORRIS--Irving Nathaniel. Irving Morris, an attorney known for his tenacious representation of plaintiffs across a broad range of litigation over a five-decade career, died on Tuesday at his home in Palm Beach, Florida. He was ninety years old. Irving Nathaniel Morris was born in Trenton, New Jersey, on December 18, 1925, the third of Abraham and Katie Morris' four children. The family moved to Wilmington, Delaware, when Morris was two years old. He lived, practiced law and raised a family there until his retirement in 2001. Morris turned nineteen in a foxhole, was captured during the Battle of the Bulge, and spent six weeks as a "guest of the Germans" before being liberated in 1945. After completing studies at the University of Delaware and Yale Law School on the GI Bill, Morris served for two years as a law clerk to U.S. District Court Chief Judge Paul Leahy, before entering private practice in 1953. Morris specialized in representing shareholders injured by corporations' misstatements and misconduct, and spent decades fighting segregation and pursuing equal opportunity in education for Delaware's school children. He was a member of the American College of Trial Lawyers, the American Bar Foundation, the American Bar Association, and served as President of the Delaware Bar Association. He was awarded the Delaware Bar Association's highest award for leadership and service, The First State Distinguished Service Award. He was also a leader in his community, serving as President of Congregation Beth Shalom, where he was a lifelong member, and chairing fundraising campaigns for The United Way and the Jewish Federation of Delaware. Morris retired from the practice of the law on September 11, 2001, directing his energy to "The Rape Case", a book chronicling his successful 1950s defense on appeal of three accused rapists. The case established the principal that the presence of police perjury renders a trial fundamentally unfair, denying due process as guaranteed in the Constitution. Morris was predeceased by his siblings, Melvin, Sylvia Rochlin and Herbert; his son, Jonathan; son-in-law, Bruce Zakheim; and by Doris, his wife of 58 years. He is survived by his daughters, Deborah Zakheim and Karen Morris (Alan Levenson); and his son, David; and by nine grandchildren who were enriched by years of Grandpa's unwavering attention and unquestioning love: Jonathan (Amanda), Adam, Benjamin, Tyler, Joshua, Devin, Samuel, Shelby, and Peyton. Funeral services will be 11:00am, Friday, July 1, 2016 at Congregation Beth Shalom, 1801 Baynard Boulevard, Wilmington, DE 19802. Shiva will be observed 7:30pm, Saturday, July 2 through Thursday, July 7 at the home of Karen Morris and Alan Levenson. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions in memory of Irving Morris to the Brennan Center for Justice at the NYU School of Law (www.brennancenter.org) or to HIAS (www.hias.org). Schoenberg Memorial Chapel. 1/3

ROSENMAN--Robert, at the age of 84, passed away peacefully in his home on June 29, 2016, in New York City, with his wife of 62 years, Elizabeth, by his side. He will be deeply missed by his wife; his daughter, Deborah Evangelakos, and son-in-law, John; his daughter, Lynn Garland, and son-in-law, Merrick; and his six grandchildren, Lee, Rebecca, Jessica, William, Daniel, and Quinn. He is also survived by his brother, James Rowen. Born in New York City, Bob graduated from Deerfield Academy followed by Harvard College ('53, magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa) and Harvard Law School ('56, cum laude). He began work as an attorney at the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore in 1956, became a partner in 1965 and retired in 2001 after a highly respected career as one of the leading corporate and securities law attorneys of his day. He continued to serve as Of Counsel to the Cravath firm until 2008. Bob was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He was a part-time resident of Redding, Connecticut for over 39 years. A memorial service will be planned for a future date. 1/3

GORDON--Samuel L.,M.D., was born January 21, 1918 in Atlanta, GA. He died in Lantana, FL on June 28, 2016. He was the son of the late Jacob B. and Sadie G. Gordon, and brother of Jack Jr. Loving husband of Nancy Willstatter, father to Sam, Jr., Jack, and Peter. Caring grandfather, uncle, cousin, and generous friend. Long term resident of Hartsdale, NY. New Haven, VT vacationer. A Georgia boy comes home to rest. Graduated Boys High School, Emory University and Medical School. WWII volunteer, U.S. Navy Flight Surgeon in U.S. and South Pacific. Thorough and careful ENT specialist physician who loved his patients. Avid outdoorsman, horseman, amateur pilot, happy hunter, expert fisherman, and world traveler. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to your favorite charity. A graveside service will be held Thursday, June 30, 2016 at 9am at Historic Oakland Cemetery, Atlanta, GA. 1/3

DAVIS--Edward J. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm Davis Wright Tremaine LLP note with profound sorrow the untimely death of our beloved partner Edward J. Davis on June 27, 2016 after a valiant battle with cancer. A New Jersey native, Ed graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Harvard College and magna cum laude from Harvard Law School. Ed was a Marshall Scholar and received masters' degrees from the London School of Economics and Political Science and the London School of Oriental and African Studies. His brilliant mind and devotion to their interests made him a valued advisor to his many clients who benefited from his unerring judgment. Ed's humility and generosity of spirit made him a mentor to all who had the privilege and good fortune to know and work with him. Ed was committed to providing pro bono assistance to individuals and organizations in need of assistance, and was recognized for his efforts with the Dramatists Legal Defense Fund's "Defenders Award" and the Arthur Liman Public Interest Award by the Legal Action Center. We extend our deepest sympathies to his husband, Tom Phillips; his mother, Marian Davis; sister, Kathleen Davis; niece, Marissa Davis; extended family, and wide network of devoted friends. A celebration of Ed's life is being planned. 1/3

HALPERN--Shirley Edith Gold. Our beloved mom passed away on June 26, 2016, after a brief illness. She was 90 years old. She faced the end bravely and stoically, smiling and saying, "Que sera, sera." She never displayed self-pity, always saying, "I've lived a wonderful life." Mom was born in Union City, New Jersey, on October 30, 1925. Her family moved to Brooklyn when she was a little girl, and there she stayed until she and our Dad, Edwin, made the remarkable move to Phoenix in 1956. That's where she raised her four children, made a loving home for her family, earned her Bachelor's and Master's degrees at Arizona State University, and endured the sorrow of losing her youngest child, Michael John, and in 2003, the death of her soulmate, Edwin. Shirley is survived by her three children, Laurie Benenson (Bill), William Halpern (Veronique), and Glen, and granddaughters Amanda Benenson, Victoria Halpern and Rachel Halpern. Mom was smart, upbeat, funny, argumentative, and stylish. She looked younger than her years, and never lost her joie de vivre. People could never believe her true age. And we can't believe she's gone. Rest in peace, dearest Shirley. We love you. Laurie, Bill and Glen 1/3

RUSSELL--Robert "Bob" L.,son of the late John Andrew Russell and Olivia Isabelle (Tinsley) Russell, devoted historian of American History and advocate for the arts and culture, died Wednesday, June 8, 2016. He was 89 years old. Following graduation from Forest Park High School in Baltimore, Maryland in 1945, Bob joined the US Navy earning a Fleet appointment to the US Naval Academy. From Annapolis, he went to Trinity College, Hartford, Connecticut, where he majored in Modern European History, graduated with honors, and received a Fellowship from Trinity for graduate studies at Yale University, receiving his Master of Arts Degree in 1954. Twenty-six years of his business life were spent at Bankers Trust New York Corporation in charge of Corporate Human Resources. Bob leaves his cherished living relative John (Buddy) Cefalu (Helyne), the Mandel family and many friends. A memorial gathering to celebrate Bob's life will take place on Saturday, September 10 from 2pm to 4pm at 1515 Holicong Road, Buckingham, PA. Gifts in Bob's memory may be made to the James A. Michener Art Museum, 138 South Pine Street, Doylestown, Pennsylvania, Attn: Laurie McGahey. Leaver/Cable of Buckingham, PA. 1/3

ROSENMAN--Robert. The lawyers and staff of Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP mourn the passing of their partner, colleague and friend, Robert Rosenman. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife and family. Mr. Rosenman joined Cravath in 1956, became a partner in 1965 and retired in 2001. He served as Of Counsel to the Firm from 2002 to 2008. Mr. Rosenman's practice focused on securities and general corporate law, and his many clients included AVX Corporation; IBM; L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin; and LIN Broadcasting. He became an Adjunct Professor at the New York University School of Law in 1986, where he taught securities law. He was not only a successful practitioner, but also a mentor to multiple generations of Cravath attorneys who benefitted immensely from his intellect and guidance. 1/3
