GOLDSTEIN--Linda N.,on June 28, 2016. The Board of Trustees, the clergy, staff and members of Congregation Habonim mourn the untimely death of longtime member Linda Goldstein. Our hearts go out to her husband Neil, President of Habonim, and daughter Sara Mairs, whose recent marriage to Russell Mairs brought so much happiness to Linda and Neil. Linda, who lived life to the fullest, brought light, joy and compassion to her family, friends and her congregation. Neil was a constant loving presence during her life as well as these last few months. Our admiration and gratitude go to him for continuing to lead our congregation during these difficult days. May her life be a blessing. Funeral services will be held Friday, July 1st, 12:30pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. 1/3
BOOKSTAVER--Doug (7/60 -7/23/92) "It's the laughter we will remember whenever we remember the way we were." Mumsie, Bobbi, and Julie 1/3

DAVIS--Ed. The Board of Directors and staff of The New Press mourn the death of our brilliant, generous, loyal, and endlessly kind friend Ed Davis. We extend our deepest sympathy to Tom and the rest of Ed's family. 1/3

SLOAN--Marion. Marion Baker (Muffit) Sloan, of New York City, formerly of Rumson, NJ, passed away on June 17, 2016, age 59. Marion was the daughter of Samuel Sloan III and Marion Dryden Baker Sloan. She graduated from Rumson Country Day School, Choate-Rosemary Hall and Syracuse University. She was the sister of Cynthia Titus Powers of So Royalton, VT, Dorothy Titus McFeeters of Boston, MA and Ellen Sloan Nicholson of Savannah, GA. She was predeceased by parents and brothers Jay deWitt Titus and Samuel Sloan Jr. Services will be at St Georges by the River, Rumson, NJ, on July 6 at 10:00am. Interment will follow at FairView Cemetery in Middletown, NJ. Thompson Memorial Homes, Red Bank, NJ, is handling the funeral services. 1/3

GOLDBERG--William. It is with great sadness that we must say goodbye to a dear, compassionate, gentle soul. Billy was deeply devoted to his friends and family. His kindness and thoughtfulness will be missed. He is survived by his sister and her husband Debbie and Bruce Bottner, his cousin Marsha Block, her husband Leonard Walter, and his other cousin Robin Block Goldstein and her husband Mitchell, and many devoted friends. Billy, we love you. The Funeral will be held at Sinai Chapels in Fresh Meadows, NY, at 10:30am on Sunday, July 3, followed by a graveside service at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Barbara. The Board of Trustees and staff of The New York Society Library mourn the loss of Barbara Goldsmith, an acclaimed author and a Library Board member for 17 years. Her artistry, generosity, and dedication to the city's literary life live on. 1/3

HERRICK--Rhoda. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Rhoda Herrick, who leaves behind a loving family who will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Rhoda's siblings, Edythe Gladstein and Robert Rosenthal; and the entire family. Jeffrey A. Schoenfeld, President; Robert S. Kapito, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

LAMM--Rabbi Maurice. The National Institute for Jewish Institute mourns the passing of our founder and president, Rabbi Maurice Lamm. The former Rabbi of Beth Jacob of Beverly Hills, California, he was the author of five major books, including "The Jewish Way In Death and Mourning," and held the Chair in Professional Rabbinics at Yeshiva University. He lectured around the world. He is survived by his wife Shirley, his son David, his daughter Dodi, 18 grandchildren and 35 great-grandchildren. Shiva will be upon return from Israel Monday and Tuesday at 732 University St., North Woodmere, NY. Donations in his memory can be made online at nijh.org. 1/3

GACCIONE--Marion Bunnell, 98, Manhattan, died Monday. Nieces: Mary Katherine (Michael), Jane (James), grand- nephews, Jonathan, William, Damon, Matthew. Predeceased: husband, Anthony. Graveside: 11:15, Saturday, Montrose Cemetery. Viewing: one hour prior at BartronMyer Funeral Home, Inc., Montrose, PA. Contributions: St. Thomas Choir School. 1/3

GOLDBERG--Judy-Lynn, passed away on June 19, 2016 at age 62. She had a distinguished career in education and law. She served as an ALJ for the State of MD, DLLR for 23 years. She also was a Senior Lecturer at the John Hopkins University Carey Program and received the Faculty Teaching Excellence Award in 2003. Judy had a solo law practice in Baltimore City and Towson. She worked in advertising for a year in NYC and then moved to Baltimore where she taught at Sparrows Point High School. Judy grew up in Cranford, NJ and earned a BS degree at the University of Vermont in 1975. She graduated from the University of Baltimore School of Law in 1982. Judy enjoyed traveling, gardening, the New York Times crosswords and the fine arts. She cherished a loving circle of friends who will miss her deeply. She is survived by her brother, Alan B. Goldenberg and her sister-in-law, Joanne Moustakas of Boynton Beach, FL and numerous cousins. Judy was an avid animal advocate. Donations may be made in her name to the Best Friends Animal Society, Kanub, Utah, or another animal rights organization. 1/3

NOTKIN--Darcie Denkert. Darcie Denkert, longtime MGM executive and female pioneer in entertainment law, passed away at her home in West Los Angeles on June 10 after a long struggle with cancer. She was interred at Hillside Cemetery on June 13. Denkert became the first female lawyer at United Artists (UA) when she started her tenure there in 1976. She later moved on to become one of the first women in the industry to lead a business and legal affairs department at a major studio with her role at MGM. Denkert was a graduate of the NYU School of Law when she began her entertainment industry career as a Broadway theatre lawyer in New York City. With the exception of a short stint at ICM and Embassy Pictures in the mid-1980s, she spent 26 years at UA and its successor company MGM in various senior business and legal affairs positions. In 1997, she was named head of the department at MGM and served in that position for the next five years. In 2002, Denkert combined her love of Broadway theatre and film, and formed MGM ON STAGE with her longtime business associate and friend Dean Stolber. The new enterprise was aimed at exploiting MGM's film library in the theatrical world and its success inspired many other studios to take their films to Broadway. Together, Denkert and Stolber produced 10 shows using MGM's film library, creating such Broadway show hits as "Chitty Chitty Bang Bang," "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels," "Legally Blonde," and "Priscilla, Queen of the Desert." In 2005, Denkert wrote "A Fine Romance: Hollywood/Broadway (The Magic, The Mayhem, The Musicals)," a beautifully illustrated and insightful text on the great shows of Broadway and their translation to the screen. True to her commitment to the film and theatrical industries, Denkert donated all of the royalties from "A Fine Romance" to the Motion Picture & Television Fund (MPTF) and The Actors Fund. Denkert's "A Fine Romance" became the foundation for an annual musical fundraiser produced by MPTF to celebrate the intersection of Broadway and Hollywood and raise millions of dollars for the charity. Denkert was a board member of MPTF for five years and an outstanding contributor to serving the organization's mission of taking care of its own. In 2002, Denkert became the chair of its Case Committee where all key decisions about charitable support for industry members are adjudicated. She was also a board member of the Simms/Mann Centre at UCLA, from which she received invaluable care from a dedicated staff throughout her illness. Additionally, Denkert was a tireless advocate for the welfare of neglected and abused dogs. In August 2002, Denkert married Allen Susman, founding partner of the law firm Rosenfeld, Meyer and Susman. Susman passed away in January 2007. In 2011, Denkert married Shelby Notkin, chairman of the private client services division at Capital Group. Denkert is survived by her husband Shelby, her mother Renee, her stepdaughter Michelle, a step grandson, as well as four stepchildren from her marriage to Susman. At the family's request, donations can be made to the CPMC Foundation/Notkin Family Breast Cancer Recovery Program or JCCF Simms/Mann Center. 1/3

You became a great-uncle with the birth of James William. And we all missed you at your nephew's medical school graduation. With all my love, Sue 1/3

SELTZER--Regina. Reggie died overlooking the gardens she ardently tended and the Great South Bay, two of her favorite places. Reggie was a dynamo. Born in Poland in 1929, she immigrated to New York where she lived the American Dream. She married Stanley and had two children. Early on, she was a school librarian. Later she was elected to the Brookhaven Town Council. For a third career, she became a lawyer. She worked pro-bono protecting the environment and challenging questionable governmental actions. She was an expert on the law of standing. She ran for Congress defeating the incumbent in the Primary, but losing in the General Election. Her passions included gardening, tennis, sculpting, walking, cross country skiing, birding, and writing a mystery novel about Benedict Arnold. Reggie is survived by her son Eric, his wife Nealle, her granddaughters Veronica Jean and Bryn, and innumerable friends. 1/3
GOLDSTEIN--Linda Newman. Linda, we will love and miss you forever. Our deepest sympathy to Neil and Sara. Nancy Kestenbaum Moses, Bill Moses, Marcia Potash, Howie Friedman 1/3

MORRIS--Irving Nathaniel. Irving Morris, an attorney known for his tenacious representation of plaintiffs across a broad range of litigation over a five-decade career, died on Tuesday at his home in Palm Beach, Florida. He was ninety years old. Irving Nathaniel Morris was born in Trenton, New Jersey, on December 18, 1925, the third of Abraham and Katie Morris' four children. The family moved to Wilmington, Delaware, when Morris was two years old. He lived, practiced law and raised a family there until his retirement in 2001. Morris turned nineteen in a foxhole, was captured during the Battle of the Bulge, and spent six weeks as a "guest of the Germans" before being liberated in 1945. After completing studies at the University of Delaware and Yale Law School on the GI Bill, Morris served for two years as a law clerk to U.S. District Court Chief Judge Paul Leahy, before entering private practice in 1953. Morris specialized in representing shareholders injured by corporations' misstatements and misconduct, and spent decades fighting segregation and pursuing equal opportunity in education for Delaware's school children. He was a member of the American College of Trial Lawyers, the American Bar Foundation, the American Bar Association, and served as President of the Delaware Bar Association. He was awarded the Delaware Bar Association's highest award for leadership and service, The First State Distinguished Service Award. He was also a leader in his community, serving as President of Congregation Beth Shalom, where he was a lifelong member, and chairing fundraising campaigns for The United Way and the Jewish Federation of Delaware. Morris retired from the practice of the law on September 11, 2001, directing his energy to "The Rape Case", a book chronicling his successful 1950s defense on appeal of three accused rapists. The case established the principal that the presence of police perjury renders a trial fundamentally unfair, denying due process as guaranteed in the Constitution. Morris was predeceased by his siblings, Melvin, Sylvia Rochlin and Herbert; his son, Jonathan; son-in-law, Bruce Zakheim; and by Doris, his wife of 58 years. He is survived by his daughters, Deborah Zakheim and Karen Morris (Alan Levenson); and his son, David; and by nine grandchildren who were enriched by years of Grandpa's unwavering attention and unquestioning love: Jonathan (Amanda), Adam, Benjamin, Tyler, Joshua, Devin, Samuel, Shelby, and Peyton. Funeral services will be 11:00am, Friday, July 1, 2016 at Congregation Beth Shalom, 1801 Baynard Boulevard, Wilmington, DE 19802. Shiva will be observed 7:30pm, Saturday, July 2 through Thursday, July 7 at the home of Karen Morris and Alan Levenson. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions in memory of Irving Morris to the Brennan Center for Justice at the NYU School of Law (www.brennancenter.org) or to HIAS (www.hias.org). Schoenberg Memorial Chapel. 1/3

SOLIN--Dr. Jerome, age 89, died Sunday, June 26, 2016. Raised in Bayonne, he practiced dentistry in New Jersey and New York for 60 years. A United States Navy veteran of WWII, he graduated from University of Virginia and NYU Dental School. At the age of 40, he ran the first of 65 marathons. He was a collector and authority of jazz. Dr. Solin was preceded in death by daughters Nina and Alexa. Survivors include his wife of 59 years, artist Trudy Solin, son Dr. Seth Solin and daughter-in-law Janet Poon Solin and granddaughter Julia; son David Solin and granddaughters Serena and Alana. Graveside service on Friday, July 1 at 10:15am at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Contributions in Jerry's memory to Jazz Society at Lincoln Center. 1/3

Schoenfeld, President; Robert S. Kapito, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

COHEN--Elias A. Ever present in our thoughts, we lovingly recall our E.A. Cohen who left us 64 years ago on July 2, 1952. The Cohen Family The Elias A. Cohen Foundation 1/3

LANDESMAN--Jay. Jay Landesman, passed away peacefully at his home in Manhattan on June 27, 2016 at age 77. Jay was a first generation American, born in Brooklyn and raised in Long Beach, New York. He attended the University of Vermont and, after a year there, attended the University of Wisconsin and its Law School, where he achieved top tier ranks while attending only a few lectures, as he was busy driving back and forth selling real estate in Chicago resulting in becoming a millionaire before he graduated. He also received three degrees at the same time, in Law, Psychology and History. His wealth of intellectual talents and ability led him to pursue a career in law, where he was hired on the spot in an interview at the prestigious New York City law firm of Cravath Swaine & Moore. Jay's ambitions led him to later become an entrepreneur with various business successes, including forming and growing his real estate firm with its portfolio of properties across the United States. Jay enjoyed yearly trips to Sun Valley for skiing and the beauty of its slopes. He also enjoyed traveling to Paris and throughout Europe, as well as a safari to Botswana. He had a vast knowledge of numerous topics, one of which was World War II, where he could recite the key invasion dates, battles, defeats and the like, as he was an avid reader. He enjoyed the arts, especially ballet, and regularly attended the theater and opera. Jay thoroughly enjoyed many aspects of his life, and people he encountered from all walks of life all found him to be exceptionally charming, witty and a great raconteur. Wherever he went, he owned the room with his charm, elegance, brilliance, and modesty. He enjoyed spending his weekends at his beautiful property in Southampton. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends and business colleagues. Jay is survived by his devoted wife of 34 years, Maria Kimberly Landesman, whom he cherished, and by his sister, Rochelle Landesman Millen, his brother, Sheldon Landesman and many of his siblings' children and grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at Frank Campbell's Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, New York on July 6, 2016 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Wounded Warriors Project, P.O. Box 758517, Topeka, Kansas 66675 and to our veterans. 1/3

COHEN--Elias A. Although 64 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun filled weeks each summer since July 1st, 1919. In the spirit of Noblesse Oblige his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 98th year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc. Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President 1/3

KUGLER--Vivienne B. June 27, 2016 at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Solomon Kugler, dear sister of Adrienne Thau, cherished mother of Andrea Krimko (Howard) and Terry Makover (Michael), adored grandmother of Stuart, Heather, Matthew, Becca, and great-grandmother to her precious Ivy Maya. Forever wise, elegant and young. 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Barbara Lubin. The Board of Managers of the East Hampton Library mourns the passing of Barbara Lubin Goldsmith to whom all libraries and lovers of books are indebted: for making certain that all books are printed on acid-free paper, for fighting for the liberation of imprisoned writers worldwide, and for her own gifts to literature. We are grateful for having had her imprimatur as a Founding Honorary Co-Chair of our annual Authors Night literary event for the past 12 years, as she urged us to always maintain the highest standards. Her encouraging presence will be greatly missed and her memory honored. Sheila Rogers, President of the Board of Managers 1/3

LONE--Robert. age 86, passed away peacefully April 28, 2016. He was a Navy Veteran. His wide range of interests led to three successful careers. He was a top dancer, world traveler and art expert. As an actor, singer, and dancer, he appeared in six Broadway musicals, over 100 television shows (Lead Dancer - Ed Sullivan Show), movies and commercials (Aqua Velva Man 1970s). He performed with Carol Lawrence, Cyd Charisse and Ginger Rogers. He worked for the Wally F. Galleries, New York City. As the Designer and Director of Jasper Galleries, Houston, TX, he frequented Europe and America buying paintings and sculptures. He attended Parsons School of Design, became a successful Interior Designer and worked into his 80s. He was born in Minneapolis, MN and moved to New York City in the early 1950s. He will be missed by his family and wide circle of friends. He requested no memorial. Donations: Any art organization of your choice. Visit: www.facebook.com/ RobertMartinLone 1/3
MEPPEN--Samuel and Edith. In loving memory on their 94th Wedding Anniversary, July 2nd, 1922. 1/3

DUGGAL--Baldev, Founder of Duggal Visual Solutions, who revolutionized the photography industry and served as its sustained force of innovation for over five decades, passed away peacefully in his sleep on June 29th, one month shy of his 79th birthday. Baldev Duggal was made of eternal optimism. He saw opportunity where others saw none. "If you don't have a dream, you have nothing," he often remarked. Baldev's dream was to leave the world better than he found it, and he went on to paint on a broader canvas. Baldev Duggal is survived by his three children: Susheila Kidman and husband Scott, Dave Duggal and wife Jennifer, Michael Duggal and wife Mollie. He is also survived by his eight grandchildren: Ryan, Brett and Lauren Kidman; Cyrus and Eloise Duggal; Faith, John Alexander and Christian Duggal; as well as his brother Sukhdev Duggal. A public memorial will be held on Wednesday, July 6th, 3:00pm at the Duggal Greenhouse located at 26 Navy Street (Building 268), Brooklyn, New York. 1/3

RAMBO--Dr. John H. T. Dr. John H.T. Rambo was born April 21, 1915 in Menlo, GA to Gordon and Martha Mae Kennedy. His sister Martha was born March 16, 1920. When his father died in a car crash at age nine, he was shuffled between relatives until he wound up in New Castle, PA. There he quarterbacked the high school football team, winning a championship, before he decided to become a doctor with a loan from an uncle. He went to Emory University for his undergraduate and medical degree and began his rotation as an intern at Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta from 1940-41. He then joined the Army Air Corps in 1941 serving in Panama. Discharged in 1945, having achieved a rank of Lieutenant Colonel, he went to Boston to do his residency at Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary from 1946-48. Also he worked at the ENT laboratory at Harvard Medical School which he described as the happiest year he ever had in medicine. There he met and married Kathleen Foreman from Regina, Saskatchewan. They had two children, Michael and Tracy. After his residency in Boston he joined Dr. Julius Lempert at the Lempert Institute of Otology in New York City. Dr. Lempart was considered the father of otology, and Dr. Rambo became his associate and stayed at the Institute for many years, learning all he could along with the best otologists in medicine. It was at the Institute that he developed his own techniques in the field of middle-ear and mastoid surgery. His modesty, scrupulous attention to detail and fierce focus made him a much sought after surgeon. He loved his profession and was proud of it. He appeared on the cover of Modern Medicine in 1958. In 1957, he joined the staff of Lennox Hill Hospital in New York City where he said the generous support of his fellow doctors made it a joy for him. In 1958 he was invited to Alaska to lend his surgical skills to the native peoples of Pt. Barrow near the Arctic Circle. Flying by bush pilot he said it was an adventure and they were lucky to escape with their lives. He pursued golf and won a doctor's championship in 1973. He retired in 1983. He was fascinated by the family's civil war history and by the Rambo family origins, discovering that one young man who arrived from Sweden in 1640 helped start, and become the father of the New Sweden colony. Dr. Rambo died in New York City at his home on his 101st birthday. 1/3

BRYANT--H. Stafford, 90, died peacefully at his home on June 27. He was the most beloved husband and closest friend of his wife Sylvie and cousin to Christine, Rob, Charlotte and Jean. Always the Virginian gentleman, his was a long and graceful life. Raised in Lynchburg, Virginia, he attended Washington & Lee University and spent the last year of World War II in the US navy. Starting out as a journalist with the Lynchburg News, he went on to the Bethlehem Globe Times, and the Savannah Evening Press before moving to New York where he spent over 25 years at WW Norton Publishers. Author of "The Georgian Locomotive" and other publications on trains, he was also co-editor with Henry Hope Reed of the "Classical America" series and served on the Board of Directors of the organization. His passion for jazz was equaled only by his profound knowledge of French and American decorative arts, his ability to evoke them in his home, and his deep love for all matters related to Virginia. 1

BREEN--Daniel Anthony, Jr. Of Houston, TX and East Hampton, NY, passed away peacefully on Monday, the 27th of June 2016, at the age of 87. A nationally recognized pioneer in the field of investment management, Dan was a larger than life personality. He loved sports, he loved music - he never passed up the chance to sing "Danny Boy" and "My Way" before an audience - and he had an enormous capacity for friendship. Above all, Dan loved his family, his beloved wife Pat, his six sons, and his nine grandchildren. Dan was born in Minneapolis, MN, in 1928, the son of Dan Breen, Sr. and Helen Frances Brady. Dan took great pride in his Irish-Catholic heritage and was a great fan of Notre Dame sports. From his father he learned to respect all people, regardless of their station in life. From his mother, who dabbled in the stock market, he developed an early interest in investments. He attended Rockhurst University in Kansas City, MO, where he was two-time captain of the basketball team. After earning a degree in business administration Dan entered the Army, mustering out in 1953. He then joined IBM as a marketing representative, the first step in a long and successful career in business. While working for IBM in New York City, Dan noticed a strikingly beautiful young woman, Pat McCloskey. On the 11th of February 1961, they were married in St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. This past February they celebrated their 55th wedding anniversary. At IBM Dan rose through the ranks, eventually serving as director of sales promotion and co-director of industry marketing at the firm's world headquarters in New York. But the then-nascent field of investment management outside bank trust departments fascinated Dan, and in 1968 he joined National Securities and Research, a Wall Street mutual fund company, as senior vice president. Two years later, in a pivotal development in Dan's professional life, Fayez Sarofim, a rising young money manager in Houston, persuaded Dan to join him as a partner in Fayez Sarofim & Co. The two formed a close, complementary professional relationship, with Sarofim's stock-picking acumen complemented by Dan's management and marketing skills. When Dan joined the firm it had $600 million in assets under management. Over their 13 year association, during which Dan served as President of the company in addition to being Chairman of its Portfolio Management Group and a member of the Board of Directors, that figure grew to $14.5 billion. Dan took great pride in his association with Fayez Sarofim & Co. and in its accomplishments, but he always nursed the ambition of owning his own firm, and in 1983, at the age of 54, he struck out on his own, founding Daniel Breen & Co. By 1997 Daniel Breen & Co. and Breen Trust Co. had close to $3.5 billion assets under management. Major clients included Rice University, Rockhurst University, Davidson College, Wesleyan University, Rockefeller Dodge Foundation, Lincoln Center, New York Telephone, and Coca-Cola of New York. In that year Dan sold the two firms to Banque Indosuez. Some years later he started Breen Investors LP, transitioning ownership to two sons. At the time of his death he was Chairman Emeritus and adviser. During his career, Dan managed assets for more than 25 of the top 100 companies in the world. In the last years of his life he took particular pride in organizing the Our Future Speaker Series, in which he and his professional and personal friends - all high-achievers in their fields - traveled to Houston-area schools to offer career-development advice to kids graduating from high school and college. Left to mourn Dan's passing are his wife Pat; his sons Daniel Breen III and wife Dionne and their children Diandra and Daniel IV; John Breen and wife Zoe and their sons Jack and Dashiell; Thomas Breen and wife Chesie and their daughters Virginia, Eliza and Margaret; Brian Breen; Patrick Breen and wife Erin and son Declan; and Michael Breen and wife Erin and son Andrew. Survivors also include his brother Michael Breen and sister Nancy Creel and husband Walter; sister-in-law Jackie Donovan; and many nieces and nephews. Dan's professional affiliations over the years included: Member, Knights of Malta; Georgetown University Board of Regents; Rockhurst College Board of Trustees; Chairman of the Board, Strake Jesuit College Preparatory; President of the Board, St. Joseph's Hospital; Board of Houston Museum of Natural Science; and Pacific Rim Board, Banque Indosuez. He was a member of the Houston Country Club; Maidstone Club, East Hampton, New York; National Golf Links of America, Southampton, New York; Lyford Cay Club, Nassau, Bahamas. Family and friends gathered in Houston this past Thursday, the 30th of June, to celebrate Dan's life during a Mass of Christian Burial at St. Anne Catholic Church, followed by the Rite of Committal at Glenwood Cemetery. Honored to serve as casket bearers during the services were Milton Carroll, Donald Chapoton, Gordon Johnson, Johnny Johnson, Anthony Petrello, and Robert Whilden. Serving as honorary pallbearers were Leslie Alexander, A.L. Ballard, Lewis Brazelton, John Chapoton, Ernest Cockrell, James Crownover, the Honorable Charles Duncan, John Duncan, George Farris, Ronald Glauser, Gerald Hines, John Jakobson, Robert Mangan, James McCartney, Robert McNair, Dr. Walter McReynolds, Carl Menges, Dee Osborne, Risher Randall, Thomas Reckling, III and Selby Sullivan. Services in Houston entrusted to Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, the Funeral Directors Since 1936, 713-789-3005. www.geohlewis.com. The full obituary was published in the Houston Chronicle and remains accessible via the internet at the previously mentioned website and at www.chron.com. Dan Breen loved life, loved golf, loved his friends, but most of all, he loved us. He was our Danny Boy. Oh Dan, we loved you so. 1/3

HARTH--Dr. Erich, died June 27 in Syracuse. After fleeing Austria in 1938, he ultimately settled in Syracuse, where he received his PhD and had a successful career as a professor in the Department of Physics. He was renowned for his research in Neuroscience. He also authored three books on the brain, and consciousness. His wife Dorothy died in 2015. He is survived by his sons Peter (Julie), and Richard; and grandson Adam. www.siss kindfuneralservice.com. 1/3

SANDERS--Donald. Born NYC July 31, 1933, died June 24, 2016. Loved his family (who adored him), friends, Friday/Saturday puzzles, NYY, Tokyo, cooking, gardening and driving fast. Life was 'Terrific!' Linda & Family 1/3

HOLQUIST--J. Michael. His wife Elise Snyder and his sons mourn the passing of J. Michael Holquist, emeritus professor of Comparative Literature at Yale University and past president of the MLA. He died in his sleep at home early on the morning of Sunday, June 26, 2016. Born in Rockford, Illinois, on December 20, 1935, he served in the US Army (where he learned Russian). He received a BA from the University of Illinois and a PhD from Yale University, where he helped establish the undergraduate literature major, Lit X. After serving as chair of Slavic Departments at the University of Texas, Austin and Indiana University-Bloomington, he returned to Yale, where he taught from 1986-2005. In his retirement, he taught in the Society of Senior Scholars at Columbia University and the Yale Alumni College--and also ran a wine importing business with his wife. He is survived by his widow, Elise Snyder; his sons Peter, Benjamin, Nicholas, and Sebastian; and his stepdaughters Katherine Snyder and Margaret Hamilton. He was predeceased by his son Joshua. The funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel on September 25, 2-4pm. 1

LAMM--Maurice, Rabbi The Yeshiva University family and the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) are profoundly saddened by the passing of one of our institution's most illustrious alumni, Rabbi Maurice Lamm, Z"l, who graduated from Yeshiva College (1951), RIETS (1954) and The Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies (1973). He received an honorary Doctor of Divinity degree from our institution where he served as the Professor of Professional Rabbinics in the Chair established by members of Beth Jacob Congregation of Beverly Hills, where he served from 1972 to 1985 as spiritual leader before retiring from the congregation. He then established the Palm Springs Desert Synagogue and served as its rabbi for several years. Earlier, after graduating from RIETS, he started as a Chaplain in the United States Armed Forces and following that began his career as a pulpit rabbi in San Juan, Puerto Rico. Earlier, while in New York, he served as Rabbi of the Floral Park Synagogue and the Hebrew institute of University Heights in the Bronx. While there, he helped the other rabbis in the Bronx/Riverdale area and their lay leaders to establish the SAR Academy. His rabbinic career was capped by his founding and serving as the President of the National Institute of Jewish Hospice in 1985, in which his beloved wife, Shirley Lamm, assisted him. He was world renowned as the author of some five significant books; the first and most famous is The Jewish Way in Death and Mourning, of which 275,000 copies were sold, helping many more thousands of families cope with their bereavement. His other books are The Jewish Way in Love and Marriage, Becoming a Jew, The Power of Hope and Consolation. His kindness, warmth, wisdom and genuine concern for strengthening Jewish life was shared with young rabbinic colleagues in the field, whom he visited as a consultant under the Jack E. and Rachel Gindi Rabbinic Mentoring Program at RIETS. He was the proud younger brother of Rabbi Dr. Norman Lamm, President Emeritus of Yeshiva University, who served for 27 years as President, and of their cherished sisters, Tzibby Citner and Miriam Auslander. He was devoted to his beloved wife, Shirley Lamm, his Ayshet Chayil, a veritable "Woman of Valor," who helped him survive serious illness for many years. He was the revered father of his loving children, David Lamm, Judith Young, of blessed memory, and Dodi Lee Lamm, and the doting grandfather of 18 grandchildren and 35 great- grandchildren, all of whom carry on his legacy of love and concern for their Torah heritage, which he inspired. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Shirley Lamm, their wonderful children and all their progeny and their former congregants whose lives were touched by this unique leader of the Jewish people. May they be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

SHANK--Lt. USN Robert E. Lt. Robert E. Shank, USN, died peacefully June 16, 2016. A graduate of Schuyler Maritime Academy (1949), he pursued a career as a marine surveyor in 1962, based from his home on St Croix, USVI. A fixture at the Comanche Club, with friends Judge O'Brien and Warner Alexander and other Crucian luminaries, he sailed the Caribbean on his yacht "Tippler". Survived by his son Todd Shank, nephew Scott Shank, his wife Judy, sons Brendan and Colin, he will be sorely missed by his devoted friend Marcia Hollins. He will be laid to rest in Sleepy Hollow, Tarrytown, New York. 1/3

GOLDBERG--Judy-Lynn, passed away on June 19, 2016 at age 62. She had a distinguished career in education and law. She served as an ALJ for the State of MD, DLLR for 23 years. She also was a Senior Lecturer at the John Hopkins University Carey Program and received the Faculty Teaching Excellence Award in 2003. Judy had a solo law practice in Baltimore City and Towson. She worked in advertising for a year in NYC and then moved to Baltimore where she taught at Sparrows Point High School. Judy grew up in Cranford, NJ and earned a BS degree at the University of Vermont in 1975. She graduated from the University of Baltimore School of Law in 1982. Judy enjoyed traveling, gardening, the New York Times crosswords and the fine arts. She cherished a loving circle of friends who will miss her deeply. She is survived by her brother, Alan B. Goldenberg and her sister-in-law, Joanne Moustakas of Boynton Beach, FL and numerous cousins. Judy was an avid animal advocate. Donations may be made in her name to the Best Friends Animal Society, Kanub, Utah, or another animal rights organization. 1/3

GUAIPATIN--Gabi, 14, daughter of Carlos Guaipatin and Raquel Gomes, died on May 31 of complications associated with Loeys-Dietz Syndrome. Gabi was bright, sweet, and tender, with a witty sense of humor and love of books and musicals. Even in pain, Gabi embraced life with wisdom and grace. On the way to her last surgery, no tears, no complaints, just a simple request: "talk to me of happy thoughts." 1/3

HERRICK--Rhoda, died peacefully on June 28th at her sister's home in Scarsdale, NY. Rhoda attended Scarsdale High School and Smith College. Rhoda's passion for theater led her to a career of investing in productions both on and off Broadway. Some of her most recent credits included "The Garden of Earthly Delights," "The Gentleman's Guide to Love and Murder," and "Hamilton." A longtime resident of New York City, and Becket, MA, she is survived by her sister Edythe Gladstein, brother Robert Rosenthal, and niece and nephews Gina, Joshua, and John Gladstein. 1/3

FULENWIDER--Constance Morrow, died suddenly, of natural causes, at her home in Weston, Massachusetts on Friday, June 24. She was 73. Born in Carmel Valley, California, to Margot Loines Morrow and Dwight Morrow Jr., she grew up in New York City, where she attended the Brearley School before graduating from Concord Academy in Massachusetts in 1960. She proudly graduated Summa Cum Laude from Wellesley College as a Davis Scholar in 2006. A joyful connector of people, Constance was a vibrant member of the community in Weston, where she and her husband moved in 1972 and raised a family. She served on the board of the Boston Philharmonic and the Elisabeth Morrow School in Englewood, New Jersey, housed in her paternal grandparents' former home. A lifelong animal lover, she trained as an International Therapy Dog volunteer, and in 2013, she worked with survivors of the Boston Marathon Bombing. She is survived by her husband, Michael Fulenwider, her daughters, Anne Fulenwider and Wendy Fulenwider Liszt, two sons-in law, Bryan Blatstein and Jeffrey Liszt, four grandchildren, and her sister, Faith Williams, and her beloved black lab, Luna. A celebration of her life will be held at the First Parish Church in Weston on Thursday, July 14th at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Therapy Dogs International. 1/3

McDONOUGH--Richard D. died on June 27 surrounded by his beloved wife and extended family. Born in St. Stephen, Canada in 1931, Dick was graduated from Dartmouth College in 1952 and embarked upon a successful career in accounting and finance, retiring in 1994 as Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer of newsprint manufacturer Bowater, Inc. In his earlier positions with General Electric and the Singer Company, Dick and Caroline travelled the world. On their honeymoon in 1956 they drove to Mexico where their three children were born. During the 1960s and 1970s Dick with his family enjoyed many happy years working in Europe, traveling across the Atlantic six times as he took up positions in Scotland, Germany and England. Eventually, the family settled in Greenwich, CT in 1979. Dick made many life-long friends during his years in Hanover, New Hampshire and remained a devoted supporter of Dartmouth College. He served as his class president for eight years and was the recipient of multiple Alumni Awards for his contributions to the college and his Class of 1952, including the 2000 Dartmouth Alumni Award. Larger than life in stature, heart, generosity and humor, Dick was loved by his family, his friends, and the many who had the pleasure of working with him. Dick is survived by his wife Caroline; daughter Lisa O'Neill (Sean); sons David (Katrina) and Philip (Kristina); grandsons Richard, Spencer and Jack; sister Nancy and brother Michael; and many nieces and nephews. A service will be held 11:30am, Tuesday, July 26 at Christ Church Greenwich, Connecticut. A Celebration of Dick's Life will be held at his long-time home at Harbour Ridge, Florida in early autumn. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Dartmouth College Alumni Fund, Hanover, NH 03755. 1/3

KASLE--Gertrude. In loving memory of my aunt, Gertrude Kasle, of Detroit, MI and Sarasota, FL. Gertrude passed away peacefully on June 21, 2016 at the age of 98. She was born in New York City and earned a degree in art, which was her lifelong passion. After marrying, she moved to Detroit. She opened the Gertrude Kasle Gallery in the Fischer Building (1965-1978). Gertrude was a major force in the introduction of the post war New York School of artists to Michigan. Hers was the sole American gallery west of New York to show the abstract expressionists at that time. She championed many legendary artists including Guston, de Kooning and Motherwell while others were questioning their merit. She closed the gallery and moved to Florida in the 1980's. Gertrude will be missed for her loving spirit, her strength, optimism and her wonderful sense of aesthetics. Carol Goldstein 1/3

ALLBRAY--Igou Midian, 82. Beloved husband of Nedda (nee Cohen) and brother of Rose Aster, died on June 23, 2016. A long time Brooklyn resident, he was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School, Columbia College, Class of '55. and New York University School of Law. After graduating Columbia he served in the U.S. Army. Most of his legal career was as an Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of New York. There, for many years he served as Chief of the Civil Division. Prior to starting his legal career he traveled extensively spending two years in Israel where he participated in the Masada archeological dig and helped to found a Negev Kibbutz. At home in Brooklyn he was active in Fort Greene where he renovated an old brownstone and was part of the community based Fort Greene Not-for-Profit Corporation which built a 500 unit housing cooperative for low and moderate income families. Later, he moved to Prospect Park South where he was also an active member of the community. For the last year of his life he lived in Princeton, NJ. 1/3

EINHORN--Valery B.,of Rhinebeck, New York passed away on June 23, 2016. Born on March 19, 1954, in New York, NY, she was an architect and among her positions served as Borough Commissioner of The New York City Department of Buildings and as Architect in charge of Station Design for the Metropolitan Transportation Association of New York City. She is survived by her mother, Catherine Goldberg, her beloved husband Harold (Hal), her children Micole Taggart, Yiannes and Zoe Einhorn and her grandchildren, Zea Taggert and Nina and Olivia Einhorn. Memorial contributions may be made to the Church of St. John's the Evangelist, Barrytown, New York and the Poughkeepsie Day School, Poughkeepsie, New York. 1/3
ENGEL--Sylvia. Hewlett Hadassah mourns the passing of Sunny, our beloved Past President, member Society Major donors. 1/3

ROSENMAN--Robert, at the age of 84, passed away peacefully in his home on June 29, 2016, in New York City, with his wife of 62 years, Elizabeth, by his side. He will be deeply missed by his wife; his daughter, Deborah Evangelakos, and son-in-law, John; his daughter, Lynn Garland, and son-in-law, Merrick; and his six grandchildren, Lee, Rebecca, Jessica, William, Daniel, and Quinn. He is also survived by his brother, James Rowen. Born in New York City, Bob graduated from Deerfield Academy followed by Harvard College ('53, magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa) and Harvard Law School ('56, cum laude). He began work as an attorney at the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore in 1956, became a partner in 1965 and retired in 2001 after a highly respected career as one of the leading corporate and securities law attorneys of his day. He continued to serve as Of Counsel to the Cravath firm until 2008. Bob was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He was a part-time resident of Redding, Connecticut for over 39 years. A memorial service will be planned for a future date. 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Barbara. The board of directors, advisory board and staff of the Breast Cancer Research Foundation mourn the passing of Barbara Goldsmith, brilliant author, treasured friend and BCRF advisory board member. We send heartfelt condolences to the entire Goldsmith family. Leonard A. Lauder, Honorary Chairman; Kinga Lampert, Co-Chairman; William Lauder, Co-Chairman; Larry Norton, M.D., Scientific Director; Myra J. Biblowit, President 1/3

BERNSTEIN--Alison R. She won many battles: for gender equality, humanity in the arts, truth in history, and human rights. She lost the one against cancer. Love to Julia, Emma and Johanna. Cora, Peter, Judy, and Danny Weiss 1/3

CORWIN--Norman D.,MD, of Westwood, NJ, passed away on June 27, 2016, four months after the passing of Dorothy, his adored wife of nearly 60 years. Beloved father of Janice C. Linett (Robert), Michael R. Corwin, and Susan C. Yaros (Mark). Honored grandfather of Steven Linett, Jenny Linett, Ethan Yaros, and Matthew Yaros. Dr. Corwin graduated with honors from Rutgers University School of Pharmacy. He graduated magna cum laude from Boston University School of Medicine and was President of Alpha Omega Alpha Honor Medical Society. He completed his internship and residency at Mount Sinai Hospital in NYC. He served as a Captain in the US Air Force in Savannah, GA. Dr. Corwin was board certified in internal medicine and cardiology and was a Fellow of the American College of Physicians and American College of Cardiology. He was an extraordinarily dedicated physician who practiced in Westwood and was an attending physician at Pascack Valley Hospital for over 30 years. He was much loved by his patients and highly respected by the medical community. He read voraciously and had an intense intellectual curiosity. He was also an accomplished artist and organist and an avid gardener. He loved his Dalmatians and enjoyed world travel with Dorothy. He continued to study medicine daily throughout his 20-year retirement so that he could always "give good advice" to his family and friends. The family is honoring his wish for a private funeral service at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Animal Medical Center in NYC or to the Rutgers Athletics R Scholarship Fund. 1/3

BROOK--Jonathan Edward. Dearest Jon, We miss you and love you deeply one year after losing you. Beloved husband, adoring father, caring and loving son and brother, nephew, cousin, delight of our family. Your friendship meant a lot to many, and all who knew you miss you immensely. You will always be in our hearts. Words cannot describe the depth of our loss. Nicole, Juliette, Cassie, Judith, David, Adam and so many others 1/3

GEFFNER--Nancy Noonan, of Jupiter, Florida, formerly of Tarrytown and Manhattan, NY, passed peacefully on June 25, 2016, surrounded by her beloved husband of 58 years, Irving, and her children, Shari and Steven. Nancy fought to increase career opportunities for women during the 1970's and went on to become a Managing Principal of Right Management Consultants. After a long and successful career, she retired with Irv to the beaches of Jupiter, where she enjoyed spending time with family and many friends. She is survived by her husband, children and grandchildren. 1/3

VENTRE--Terese Virginia "Terry." Has passed after an incredibly short battle with lung cancer. Her sudden passing has been a rude awakening as to how unfair life can be, how lucky we are for the special people in our lives and the cherished friendships we find. Terry was an adoring mother to Harry and Ruby, loving wife of Elliot, cherished sister of Gina, Jack, Mark and Dominic, magical and generous aunt, great-aunt, Godmother, cousin and sister-in-law to a lucky few, and an extraordinary friend and colleague to many. Everyone she encountered considered Terry to be their best or special friend - including the nurses, support team and doctors at Dana Farber/Brigham and Women's Hospital who gave Terry extraordinary care and granted her wish for a dignified and peaceful passing. Terry was the proud owner of the Terry Ventre Showroom in New York City which celebrated it's 25th anniversary on June 16th. She ran her business as she lived her life with the utmost integrity, positive energy and incredible passion. She was beautiful, bright, charming, stylish times 10, funny times 20, interested, interesting, compassionate and determined. She taught many of us how to be. She is already sorely missed. We suppose angels can only stay on earth for a short time. Terry loved Central Park where she ran, walked, strolled, and met loved ones for long talks. A park bench will be donated in Terry's name. In Terry's memory, donations may be made to: Centralparknyc.org/Ventre or to the American Cancer Society. In lieu of sorrow, express your love for Terry. In her words: "Always start with yes," "Be kind and respectful" and "Buy the bathing suit." As Terry requested, memorials in NYC, Nantucket, Chicago and Miami are being planned for the Fall. 1/3

CUNNINGHAM--Bill. The Trustees and Staff of the New-York Historical Society mourn the passing of Bill Cunningham, a dear friend of our institution and great New York icon. Bill's association with New-York Historical began nearly fifty years ago with research in our Patricia D. Klingenstein Library relating to "Facades," an eight-year project that documented the architectural riches and fashion history of New York City. We were honored to celebrate the opening of a new exhibition of "Facades" in 2014 with photographs Bill gifted to us, on his 85th birthday. We will always recall Bill telling the guests, "I just have fun whatever I'm doing. Otherwise, it's not worth doing... Money isn't worth it. It's much better to go out and do what you want." Our hearts go out to Bill's devoted friend John Kurdewan at the New York Times, and to his extended family. Pam B. Schafler, Chair Richard Reiss, Vice Chair Roger Hertog, Executive Committee Chairman Louise Mirrer, President & CEO Valerie Paley, Vice President & "Facades" curator 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Barbara. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of Barbara Goldsmith, a dedicated member of the Library family. She joined the Library's Board of Trustees in 1987 and was an active member for many years. She was a generous supporter and a strong advocate for preservation at the Library, where the Barbara Goldsmith Preservation Division bears her name. She served as a member of many key Board committees and on the Executive Committee of the Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers. She was named a Life Trustee in 2006. An accomplished author, she was honored both as a Literary Lion and as a Centennial Lion. We offer our sincere sympathies to all of her family and friends. Evan R. Chesler, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Catherine Marron, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Neil L. Rudenstine Chairmen Emeriti Anthony W. Marx, President 1/3

KRASSNER--Jeff, died unexpectedly on June 27, 2016 at age 62. He was a one of a kind source of love, kindness and fun! He made our lives richer, and we will miss him dearly. Spence Halperin and Family 1/3

DAVIS--Edward J. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm Davis Wright Tremaine LLP note with profound sorrow the untimely death of our beloved partner Edward J. Davis on June 27, 2016 after a valiant battle with cancer. A New Jersey native, Ed graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Harvard College and magna cum laude from Harvard Law School. Ed was a Marshall Scholar and received masters' degrees from the London School of Economics and Political Science and the London School of Oriental and African Studies. His brilliant mind and devotion to their interests made him a valued advisor to his many clients who benefited from his unerring judgment. Ed's humility and generosity of spirit made him a mentor to all who had the privilege and good fortune to know and work with him. Ed was committed to providing pro bono assistance to individuals and organizations in need of assistance, and was recognized for his efforts with the Dramatists Legal Defense Fund's "Defenders Award" and the Arthur Liman Public Interest Award by the Legal Action Center. We extend our deepest sympathies to his husband, Tom Phillips; his mother, Marian Davis; sister, Kathleen Davis; niece, Marissa Davis; extended family, and wide network of devoted friends. A celebration of Ed's life is being planned. 1/3

MADDEN--Richard B. April 27, 1929 -- June 25, 2016. Richard Blaine Madden, a resident of Ross, California for the past 40+ years, died peacefully at home, surrounded by his loving family on Saturday, June 25, 2016. He is survived by his wife of 58 years Joan Madden, his children John Madden, Lynne McDonough, Kathryn Pandes, Andrew Madden, and their spouses and 10 grandchildren. Dick was born in Short Hills, New Jersey, attended Portsmouth Abbey School and graduated from Princeton University with a BSE degree in 1951. Following his graduation he served in the U.S. Navy from 1951-54 as a LTJG. Dick then attended the University of Michigan Law School, where he received his J.D. degree and met his wife Joan. They were married in 1958. He began his business career with Mobil in New York City while attending NYU at night, receiving his graduate business degree and later teaching there. Early in his 15 years with Mobil, he and his family moved to Rochester, NY where Dick served as President of Mobil-Plastics. He moved back to New York to become Group V.P. of MobiI Chemical and head of the company's Virginia Carolina Chemical Corp. He then served as Assistant Treasurer of Mobil Oil and Chairman of Mobil Oil Estates. In 1971, Dick, Joan and their family moved to Ross, California and Dick became President and Chief Executive Officer of Potlatch Corporation, a Fortune 500 company in the forest products industry. In 1977 he became Chairman and CEO. Dick ran Potlatch for 23 years. The Corporation consistently outperformed the S&P 500 and forest products return on investment indexes throughout this period. In 1972, Dick joined the Board of the American Enterprise Institute and served there until his death. He was Chairman of AEI for six years in the 1980's. Also, in 1972, Dick joined the San Francisco Symphony Board. He first chaired the long-range planning committee that established the need for a symphony hall and went on from there to chair and serve on many other committees until he retired in 2014 as a Life Governor. Dick also served on numerous other corporate and nonprofit boards. In 2013, Island Heritage Corporation published his children's stories "Menehune Tales of Hawaii," which he began while stationed in Hawaii as a young Naval officer. He was invested in the Order of Malta in 1988 and attended 14 Pilgrimages to Lourdes with the Western Association. During his time with the Order, Dick served as Hospitaller for six years, founding the Parish Nurse Program and the Good Samaritan Program, as well as co-founding the Northern California Clinic. He served as President of the Western Association for six years. He became Vice-Regent of the Order's Sub-Priory of Our Lady of Philermo and was awarded the Grand Cross in Obedience and the Grand Cross of Merit. He often said that the most rewarding aspect of membership in the Order of Malta was helping others in need. Dick was a member of the Metropolitan Club in Washington D.C., the Bohemian Club, The Villa Taverna, Lagunitas Country Club, and San Francisco Fly Casting Club. With all this, Dick found the time to be a loving husband and father to his family. His wife and children remember fondly his help and advice in projects great and small. He will be sorely missed. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Anselm Catholic Church, 97 Shady Lane, Ross, California on Friday, July 8 at 11am. Donations in Dick's memory can be made to: Order of Malta - Western Association, USA, 465 California St., Suite 818, San Francisco, CA 94104-1820. 1/3
REMICK--Miss Lee. 12/14/1935 - 7/2/1991 I will never forget you. John T. Stone 1/3

DAVIS--Ed. The Board of Directors and staff of The New Press mourn the death of our brilliant, generous, loyal, and endlessly kind friend Ed Davis. We extend our deepest sympathy to Tom and the rest of Ed's family. 1/3
WEILER--Gerald, 5/8/28-7/3/05. NYY'16, ugh. You are with me and loved. Helen 1/3

KOBLINER--Shirley (nee Cohen), passed away on July 1, surrounded by her loving family: her husband of 65 years, Harold Kobliner, who was her best friend, confidant and soul mate; her son, Perry Kobliner; her son and daughter-in-law, Kenneth and Miriam Kobliner; and her daughter and son-in-law, Beth Kobliner Shaw and David Shaw. Shirley was a spectacular wife, mother and grandmother, who cherished, more than would seem humanly possible, her husband, children, children-in-law and six grandchildren, Rebecca, Adam, Benjamin, Joshua, Sarah and Jacob. Shirley and Harold's marriage was a miraculous one in their unwavering support and admiration for each other. Theirs was a true love. He was her number one, and she was his. Anyone who ever crossed paths with them knows how extraordinary their beautiful union was. Shirley adored being a wife, mother and grandmother, and relished that experience with genuine joy, humor and zest. She was good, honest and kind, and encouraged her children always. Born in 1929 in Astoria, Queens, Shirley treasured childhood days spent with her mother Belle, father Ben, sister Betty, and brother Murray, who died at age 10. It was a time when resources were scarce, but love was abundant. Shirley would often recall fondly how much she loved helping her father weigh and measure the medications he dispensed at his business, Cohen's Pharmacy, and it was there that her love of chemistry took root. Shirley graduated with a Bachelor of Science in chemistry from Queens College in 1951. When she was 16 years old, at the encouragement of her mother, she attended a dance at the 92nd Street Y, where she met Harold Kobliner, then 17, who was from the Bronx. It turned out to be well worth the three subway trains and a bus that Harold had had to take to get there, since he won Shirley over, and they were married in 1951. Shirley taught chemistry in the New York City public high schools, and she was a wonderful support to Harold as he went on to get his Ph.D. in education. "I could never have done it without her," he would say to everyone they met, adding that she was his inspiration. After raising their three children in Bayside, Queens, Harold and Shirley moved to Great Neck, Long Island. As a member of Temple Israel, Shirley embarked on a series of roles in the Temple Israel Players' productions such as Oklahoma!, Fiddler on the Roof and Guys & Dolls, in which she played a Hot Box girl. Shirley also volunteered countless hours for the Association for Neurologically Impaired Brain Injured Children (ANIBIC) in Queens, where she was honored for her hard work and dedication. Funeral services will take place at 11am on Sunday, July 3, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research by mail at P.O. Box 5014, Hagerstown, MD, 21741-5014 or online at www.michaeljfox.org. 1/3

TASKER--John, age 76, a native of Greenport, Long Island, last week after a short illness. Son of late Madeline Iacovino and Supreme Court Justice Henry Tasker. Graduate of Brown University, BA ('61), MA ('64). A leader of Brown Crew's move from club to varsity sport in late 1950s followed by many victories. U.S. Navy 1965-1976, LCDR; served as Adjutant to President Naval War College; Operation Market Time, Vietnam, USS Finch (DER-328); Communications Officer, USS Long Beach (CGN-9); and Senior Adjutant to US commander of NATO Atlantic fleet. After Navy, Lykes Bros. Steamship Company and many years in Craftsman antique furniture trade in Manhattan. John leaves a twin, Arthur M. Tasker (Lucia Staniels) of Greenport; niece Alexandra Tasker Marx (Peter) and great-nephew Theodore Marx of Los Angeles; many cousins and four godchildren. Interment in Stirling Cemetery, Greenport, NY, August 6, 2016 2:00pm. Contributions to Brown University or God's Love We Deliver. 1/3

LANDESMAN--Jay. Jay Landesman, passed away peacefully at his home in Manhattan on June 27, 2016 at age 77. Jay was a first generation American, born in Brooklyn and raised in Long Beach, New York. He attended the University of Vermont and, after a year there, attended the University of Wisconsin and its Law School, where he achieved top tier ranks while attending only a few lectures, as he was busy driving back and forth selling real estate in Chicago resulting in becoming a millionaire before he graduated. He also received three degrees at the same time, in Law, Psychology and History. His wealth of intellectual talents and ability led him to pursue a career in law, where he was hired on the spot in an interview at the prestigious New York City law firm of Cravath Swaine & Moore. Jay's ambitions led him to later become an entrepreneur with various business successes, including forming and growing his real estate firm with its portfolio of properties across the United States. Jay enjoyed yearly trips to Sun Valley for skiing and the beauty of its slopes. He also enjoyed traveling to Paris and throughout Europe, as well as a safari to Botswana. He had a vast knowledge of numerous topics, one of which was World War II, where he could recite the key invasion dates, battles, defeats and the like, as he was an avid reader. He enjoyed the arts, especially ballet, and regularly attended the theater and opera. Jay thoroughly enjoyed many aspects of his life, and people he encountered from all walks of life all found him to be exceptionally charming, witty and a great raconteur. Wherever he went, he owned the room with his charm, elegance, brilliance, and modesty. He enjoyed spending his weekends at his beautiful property in Southampton. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends and business colleagues. Jay is survived by his devoted wife of 34 years, Maria Kimberly Landesman, whom he cherished, and by his sister, Rochelle Landesman Millen, his brother, Sheldon Landesman and many of his siblings' children and grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at Frank Campbell's Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, New York on July 6, 2016 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Wounded Warriors Project, P.O. Box 758517, Topeka, Kansas 66675 and to our veterans. 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Barbara. The Board of Trustees and staff of the American Academy in Rome mourn the passing of friend and noted author Barbara Goldsmith. Known for her kind and generous spirit, Barbara was an AAR Trustee Emerita and founded The Barbara Goldsmith Rare Book Room in the Arthur & Janet C. Ross Library. 1/3

COGUT--Justin, at the age of 97, passed away peacefully on June 30, 2016. Beloved husband of the late Marilyn "Lynn" Cogut (nee Gurien). Devoted father of Craig Cogut (Deborah) and Stephen Cogut. Loving grandfather of David, Jonathan, Daniel, Alexander, Gregory and Andrew. Private services will be held. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Polyphony Foundation. 1/3

ROTH--Charles W.,88, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly East Hills, NY, succumbed to Parkinson's after a long heroic battle surrounded by his daughters and companion on June 23, 2016. Charles is survived by adored daughters Karen Roth and Susan Sirbu, grandchildren, Jessica (John) and Madelynn. Loving brother of Rosalie and Judith and brother-in-law of David (Carolyn) and loving friend to Roz Lipps. He was married to Barbara Peyster Roth for 55 years until her passing in 2003. Charles was a devoted father, husband, grandfather and friend to all. Charles was the consummate fixer upper; from plumbing, electrical and carpentry to clocks, computers, golf carts, and more. While he loved his golf, tennis and cards, he most of all loved helping friends and family. His quick wit and storytelling will be greatly missed by family and friends from New York and Florida. Donations may be made in his memory to Boca Regional Hospital. 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. Moment Magazine mourns the passing of Nobel Prize laureate Elie Wiesel, co-founder of Moment in 1975. His commitment to Jewish life lives on in its pages. Nadine Epstein, Editor & Publisher and the Advisory Board of Moment 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. "Tzadik Haya Bedorotav-- Righteous Man of his Generation". I mourn my friend Elie, fellow Holocaust survivor, whose memories of Auschwitz, the graveyard of our families, we shared. Anchored to Torah, he emerged from the abyss to become a blessing and inspiration to the Jewish people, Israel and all of humanity. Elisabeth joins me in heartfelt condolences to Marion, his gifted Woman of Valor, his beloved son Elisha (Lynn) and grandchildren. Rabbi Arthur Schneier 1/3

HAGENDORF--Scott. 1958-2006. Scottie, "HAPPY BIRTHDAY" Baby Brother, Uncle, and Best Friend to Barry, Kathy and your nieces and nephews. Your candles blew out too quickly but your light stays as bright as ever. We miss you every single day and in our hearts you will be "FOREVER YOUNG." Sheryl and Sonny 1/3

KRASSNER--Jeff, died unexpectedly on June 27, 2016 at age 62. He was a one of a kind source of love, kindness and fun! He made our lives richer, and we will miss him dearly. Spence Halperin and Family 1/3

REED--Gordon Peter Q.,of Palm Beach, Florida died peacefully at home Saturday, June 25, 2016. He was born November 1, 1926, the son of Verner Z. and Gladys Reed. He attended Aiken Preparatory School, the Fay School and graduated from Milton Academy and Harvard College. He was a private in the Marine Corps in World War II. He is survived by his wife Polly and four children: Jessie Kendall, Alison Verner Reed, Gordon Peter Reed, Jr., Benjamin Dean Reed and step daughter Diane C. Pickering: three grandchildren, Ashley Campsie, Gordon Peter Reed III, Emily Reed and two great-grandchildren Cameron Campsie and Olivia Campsie. 1/3
WIESEL--Elie. The Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member Elie Wiesel. A truly great man. Jerry Lewis, Abbot; Larry King, Dean; David Cornstein, Prior; Bruce Charet, Scribe 1/3
SPALTER--Harold, You are my heart, my soul, my love--Forever and a day... Diane 1/3

HAGENDORF--Sylvia. 1926-1996. Mommy we cannot believe 20 years have passed and the woman that was larger than life who had great style, compassion and humor is gone. But you have passed that on to your children and their children. We will be forever grateful. Missing you more than ever, Your Loving Family 1/3

WIESEL--Professor Elie. Fifth Avenue Synagogue mourns the loss of its esteemed Honorary Trustee, Nobel Laureate, and global humanitarian Professor Elie Wiesel. He was a luminary, an educator, an inspiration, and above all else, a tzadik. It was a sincere privilege to have him daven in our pews and we will miss him greatly. His spirit continues to inspire our congregation. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Marion, Elisha, and the entire Wiesel family. Rabbi Eli Babich, Associate Rabbi Walter J. Molofsky, M.D., Chairman Jacob D. Gold, President 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The Board of Directors of Gatestone Institute mourn the loss of their esteemed Board of Advisors Member Elie Wiesel. He was the moral conscience of the world, speaking out against injustices on behalf of all of us. The world will be a sadder place without him. Deepest condolences to dear Marion, Elisha and all the family. May his memory be an inspiration. Nina Rosenwald, President Naomi Hass-Perlman, Vice President 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. Clal mourns the loss of our co-founder Elie Wiesel, a beacon of moral conscience, a passionate defender of both the Jewish people and of universal human dignity, and a visionary social architect who inspired and created institutions and texts which focused our attention on humankind's most important ethical questions, and helped us to answer those questions with greater efficacy and meaning. He was not only our co-founder, but our teacher and a genuine role model. May we continue to be inspired by the legacy he created in both words and deeds, and may his wife Marion, his son Elisha, his extended family, and all those who mourn the loss of this contemporary sage, find a place of comfort among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Steven J. Rotter, Chairman Rabbi Brad Hirschfield, President Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Rabbi Yitz Greenberg, Co-Founder and President Emeritus 1/3

STORR--Carol. Carol Frances Storr (nee Schoenfeld) of Greenwich, CT passed away peacefully at home on June 29, 2016 at the age of 76 due to pancreatic cancer. Carol is survived by her husband, Hans G. Storr, of Greenwich, CT; children, Suzanne Storr, of Greenwich, CT, John Hernandez-Storr (Luanne) of Claremont, CA, Christina Wilson (David) of Vail, CO; sister, Kay Belich (Sam) of New York City; grandchildren, Colby and Nicole Wilson, Jonah and Naomi Storr, Cassidy Hernandez-Storr, and Megan Carson; as well as many cousins, nephews, nieces and friends. She was preceded in death by her sister, Jean Hester. Carol was born October 2, 1939 in Staten Island, NY to Lorna and Robert Schoenfeld. She attended Nathan Hale High School (West Allis, WI) and earned degrees from The University of Wisconsin (B.S. 1961), Manhattanville College (B.A. 1989), and Columbia University (M.S. 1992). As a young woman, she worked as a physical therapist in San Francisco and London and participated in a cultural exchange program in Italy. Back in Wisconsin, she met a widower with a little girl named Suzanne, a German accent, and a briefcase full of ambition. She and Hans were married in July 1965 and welcomed John and Tina over the next two years. Hans would go on to be the CFO of Philip Morris for 17 years. Carol shared her love of the performing arts, especially ballet and opera, with her children and grandchildren. She was actively involved in their schools and loved attending performances, competitions and horse shows, even across the miles. She was a great supporter of many charities and a volunteer social worker for Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York City for many years. She loved to travel and learn about archeology. Her beautiful photos of architecture, exotic animals and children from around the world are family treasures. A visitation will be held at Christ Church Greenwich, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT on July 6, 2016 from 9:00am- 10:45am. A funeral service will follow at Christ Church Greenwich at 11:00am. All are welcome to attend and celebrate Carol's life. In lieu of flowers, please send memorial donations to Greenwich Hospital Home Hospice, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830. Condolences may be offered online by visiting www.LeoPGallagherGreen wich.com. The family would like to give special thanks to the caregivers from Compass Care for their dedication and devotion to Carol throughout her illness. 1/3

LEWIS--Ogden. Citizens Union mourns the passing of Ogden ("Denny") Lewis, its former Chair (1997-2003) and board member for 24 years. Our condolences to his wife of 42 years, Susan, his family and his many friends and admirers. There was no kinder a man, no more precise a mind, no more caring a person, no more pleasingly warm a writer, no more attentive a listener, and no more humbler a person. He was an inspirational leader of great warmth, humility and sense of purpose who invested mightily in Citizens Union and guided us to a place where it could reach levels of activity and influence it had not previously known. Under his leadership, Citizens Union started its publication, www.GothamGazette.com. We will miss his gentle guidance, humor and abiding humanity. Peter Sherwin, Board Chair; Bob Abrams, Foundation President; Dick Dadey, Executive Director 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of Elie Wiesel, Holocaust survivor, Nobel laureate and human rights advocate. He received an honorary degree from YU in 1973 and served as an honorary trustee of Yeshiva. He said, "The opposite of love is not hate, it's indifference." This is why he worked tirelessly to help ensure no one remained indifferent to injustice, that no one would ever forget. His life and contributions will be remembered and missed by the entire world. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Marion and family. May they be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. With profound sadness, the staff and board of American Jewish World Service (AJWS) mourn the loss of Elie Wiesel, Holocaust survivor, Nobel laureate, tireless advocate for human rights and a founding member of our board. Wiesel helped establish AJWS thirty years ago, sharing our deep belief that the lessons of the Holocaust demand that Jews and others stand up against injustice for oppressed people everywhere. We extend our condolences to his entire family. May his memory be a call to action for human rights. Kathleen Levin, Board Chair Robert Bank, President and CEO 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The Board of Directors of American Friends of the Open University of Israel mourns the loss of their esteemed fellow Board Member Elie Wiesel. His kindness, his warmth, his wit and his wisdom are irreplaceable. A true Messenger of Peace, his passing leaves an empty place in our hearts. He will be greatly missed by all who have known and loved him. Ingeborg Rennert, President Naomi Hass-Perlman, Chairman 1/3
