BASILICE--Patrick J.,of Medford, formerly of Dix Hills. Age 92. Beloved husband of Carmela (nee: Messina). Devoted brother to Marie Accardi. Father of Joseph (Lisa) Basilice and Linda (Augie) Hoerrner. Adored grandfather of Patrick, Lucianna, Melissa, Diana, Tina, AJ, Petra, and Paul. Caring great-grandfather to six. Patrick served his country as a proud World War II Veteran and an honored Dean of Saint John's University. There was no kinder, caring, loving man who with his sharp mind, soft manner and great wisdom was able to enrich the lives of so many. Family to receive friends Wednesday 2:00pm-5:00pm and 7:00pm-9:30pm at Mangano Funeral Home, Inc., 1701 Deer Park Avenue, Deer Park. Funeral Mass Thursday 9:45am Saint Matthew R.C.C., 35 North Service Road, Dix Hills. Entombment to follow Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, NY. www.manganofh.com 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. With profound sadness, the staff and board of American Jewish World Service (AJWS) mourn the loss of Elie Wiesel, Holocaust survivor, Nobel laureate, tireless advocate for human rights and a founding member of our board. Wiesel helped establish AJWS thirty years ago, sharing our deep belief that the lessons of the Holocaust demand that Jews and others stand up against injustice for oppressed people everywhere. We extend our condolences to his entire family. May his memory be a call to action for human rights. Kathleen Levin, Board Chair Robert Bank, President and CEO 1/3

DUGGAL--Baldev, Founder of Duggal Visual Solutions, who revolutionized the photography industry and served as its sustained force of innovation for over five decades, passed away peacefully in his sleep on June 29th, one month shy of his 79th birthday. Baldev Duggal was made of eternal optimism. He saw opportunity where others saw none. "If you don't have a dream, you have nothing," he often remarked. Baldev's dream was to leave the world better than he found it, and he went on to paint on a broader canvas. Baldev Duggal is survived by his three children: Susheila Kidman and husband Scott, Dave Duggal and wife Jennifer, Michael Duggal and wife Mollie. He is also survived by his eight grandchildren: Ryan, Brett and Lauren Kidman; Cyrus and Eloise Duggal; Faith, John Alexander and Christian Duggal; as well as his brother Sukhdev Duggal. A public memorial will be held on Wednesday, July 6th, 3:00pm at the Duggal Greenhouse located at 26 Navy Street (Building 268), Brooklyn, New York. 1/3

LEWIS--Ogden. Citizens Union mourns the passing of Ogden ("Denny") Lewis, its former Chair (1997-2003) and board member for 24 years. Our condolences to his wife of 42 years, Susan, his family and his many friends and admirers. There was no kinder a man, no more precise a mind, no more caring a person, no more pleasingly warm a writer, no more attentive a listener, and no more humbler a person. He was an inspirational leader of great warmth, humility and sense of purpose who invested mightily in Citizens Union and guided us to a place where it could reach levels of activity and influence it had not previously known. Under his leadership, Citizens Union started its publication, www.GothamGazette.com. We will miss his gentle guidance, humor and abiding humanity. Peter Sherwin, Board Chair; Bob Abrams, Foundation President; Dick Dadey, Executive Director 1/3

RUBEN--Lawrence. September 28, 1926 - July 3, 2016. Cherished husband of Jan Ruben and the late Selma Ruben. Beloved father of Richard, Lenore, and Shelly and father-in-law of Howard Kivell and Amy Ruben. Adored grandfather of Tamara, Danielle, William, Andrew, Melissa, Robert, James, Allison and Caroline, and great-grandfather of Blake, Sasha, Jonah, and Owen. As Chairman of Ruben Companies, he helped shape the skyline of New York City. Life Overseer of Weill Cornell Medicine, and Honorary Overseer of Cardozo School of Law. His love and passion for his family, his work, and his city will be missed. Funeral services will be Tuesday, July 5, 12pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Donations in his memory may be made to Weill Cornell Medicine. 1/3

STORR--Carol. Carol Frances Storr (nee Schoenfeld) of Greenwich, CT passed away peacefully at home on June 29, 2016 at the age of 76 due to pancreatic cancer. Carol is survived by her husband, Hans G. Storr, of Greenwich, CT; children, Suzanne Storr, of Greenwich, CT, John Hernandez-Storr (Luanne) of Claremont, CA, Christina Wilson (David) of Vail, CO; sister, Kay Belich (Sam) of New York City; grandchildren, Colby and Nicole Wilson, Jonah and Naomi Storr, Cassidy Hernandez-Storr, and Megan Carson; as well as many cousins, nephews, nieces and friends. She was preceded in death by her sister, Jean Hester. Carol was born October 2, 1939 in Staten Island, NY to Lorna and Robert Schoenfeld. She attended Nathan Hale High School (West Allis, WI) and earned degrees from The University of Wisconsin (B.S. 1961), Manhattanville College (B.A. 1989), and Columbia University (M.S. 1992). As a young woman, she worked as a physical therapist in San Francisco and London and participated in a cultural exchange program in Italy. Back in Wisconsin, she met a widower with a little girl named Suzanne, a German accent, and a briefcase full of ambition. She and Hans were married in July 1965 and welcomed John and Tina over the next two years. Hans would go on to be the CFO of Philip Morris for 17 years. Carol shared her love of the performing arts, especially ballet and opera, with her children and grandchildren. She was actively involved in their schools and loved attending performances, competitions and horse shows, even across the miles. She was a great supporter of many charities and a volunteer social worker for Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York City for many years. She loved to travel and learn about archeology. Her beautiful photos of architecture, exotic animals and children from around the world are family treasures. A visitation will be held at Christ Church Greenwich, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT on July 6, 2016 from 9:00am- 10:45am. A funeral service will follow at Christ Church Greenwich at 11:00am. All are welcome to attend and celebrate Carol's life. In lieu of flowers, please send memorial donations to Greenwich Hospital Home Hospice, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830. Condolences may be offered online by visiting www.LeoPGallagherGreen wich.com. The family would like to give special thanks to the caregivers from Compass Care for their dedication and devotion to Carol throughout her illness. 1/3
WIESEL--Elie. Marion, Elisha and family: Our hearts go out to you for your irreplaceable loss. Irma and Norman Braman 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. American Jewish Heritage/ Dialogue Forum deeply mourns the immense loss of our Honorary Chairman, mentor, teacher, friend. Across more than four decades he strongly supported with encouragement advice and help our work of fighting hatred, promoting Judaism, building a better world. We who survive him shall always continue the legacy he handed over to us. Rabbi Perry Berkowitz Rabbi Leah Berkowitz 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of its Honorary Chairman, Elie Wiesel. Born in Romania before WWII, he was deported as a teenager to Auschwitz-Birkenau. Elie survived the horrors of the concentration camp to become the pre- eminent voice of Holocaust education and remembrance. His teachings, writings and lectures demanded that the world remain vigilant in the face of "moral indifference, intolerance and injustice". He was a tireless advocate for the six million souls who lost their voices in the Shoah. His message that we must never forget is the clarion call of the American Society for Yad Vashem. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Marion, his son Elisha, his stepdaughter Jennifer Rose and his two grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Leonard Wilf, Chairman Ron Meier, Executive Director 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The World Jewish Congress mourns the passing of one of the preeminent Jewish thinkers, human rights activists, authors, teachers, and moral authorities of our age, Nobel Peace Prize laureate Elie Wiesel. After surviving the horrors of Auschwitz and Buchenwald, Elie Wiesel taught the world the true meaning of remembrance and dedicated himself to fighting evil, bigotry and xenophobia in all its forms. More than anyone else, he ensured that the victims of the Shoah would be remembered, not only for how they were murdered, but for who they were and how they lived. We are proud to have counted him among the dearest friends of the World Jewish Congress, and that we were privileged to honor him with the Guardian of Jerusalem Prize in 2010, and with our highest honor, the Theodor Herzl Award, in 2013. We extend our deepest condolences and those of our more than 100 affiliated Jewish communities across the globe to his wife and life partner Marion, his cherished son Elisha, daughter-in-law Lynn, stepdaughter Jennifer, his beloved grandchildren, and his entire family. May his memory be a blessing and an eternal inspiration to us all. Ronald S. Lauder, President David de Rothschild, Chairman, Governing Board Chella Safra, Treasurer Robert Singer, CEO 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The Board of Directors of Gatestone Institute mourn the loss of their esteemed Board of Advisors Member Elie Wiesel. He was the moral conscience of the world, speaking out against injustices on behalf of all of us. The world will be a sadder place without him. Deepest condolences to dear Marion, Elisha and all the family. May his memory be an inspiration. Nina Rosenwald, President Naomi Hass-Perlman, Vice President 1/3
ABELS--Gusta (Zuckerman), 84, New York/Connecticut painter, died July 3rd. Beloved by her husband, Bob, daughters Margot and Julie, their spouses and children. 1/3

TAYLOR--Jack Crawford, of St. Louis, Missouri, died July 2, 2016, at the age of 94. Beloved father of Andrew C. (Barbara) Taylor and Jo Ann Taylor Kindle (Tom Caruso); devoted grandfather of Alison Kindle (Kyle) Hogan, Carolyn Kindle (Adam) Betz, Christine Taylor (Lee) Broughton, Kelly Taylor and Patricia Taylor (Andy Magee); and cherished great- grandfather of Grace and Amelia Broughton and Kylie Hogan. Taylor was the founder of Enterprise Holdings, which through its Enterprise Rent-A-Car, National Car Rental and Alamo Rent A Car brands is the largest and most comprehensive service provider in the car rental industry. Born and raised in St. Louis, Taylor served his country as a decorated Navy fighter pilot in World War II before returning home to build the company his family still owns and operates. In 1957, he launched a small, auto leasing operation with seven vehicles in the lower level of a Cadillac dealership--expanding to daily car rental a few years later as an additional service to customers. In the decades to come, he turned his start-up into one of the business world's greatest success stories. As the rest of the industry focused on serving airports, Taylor pioneered the "home city" car rental market. By renting cars from convenient, neighborhood locations to meet a variety of customer needs, Enterprise quietly but steadily developed a market segment that grew to be as large as or larger than the airport-based rental market. Today, Enterprise Holdings owns three of the most successful car rental brands in the world, a fleet of 1.7 million vehicles and offers extensive car rental and car-sharing services, truck rental, corporate fleet management and retail car sales. Taylor built his company on a simple philosophy: "Take care of your customers and your employees first, and the profits will follow." And indeed they did. Over the years, his passion for the business was equaled only by his devotion to his family and his generosity to his beloved home town. Through the years, Taylor--whose charitable giving ranked him No. 11 on The Chronicle of Philanthropy's 2015 "Philanthropy 50" list of America's top donors--made many notable private contributions to several of St. Louis's leading civic and cultural not-for-profit institutions, notably the St. Louis Public Schools Foundation, the Saint Louis Symphony Orchestra, the Missouri Botanical Garden, Forest Park Forever and the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center. Other local beneficiaries of his family's and his company's generosity have included St. Louis Children's Hospital, the Urban League of Metropolitan St. Louis, the St. Louis Zoo, the St. Louis Art Museum, the St. Louis Science Center, Harris-Stowe State University, Saint Louis University, the University of Missouri-St. Louis, Our Little Haven and Cardinal Glennon Children's Hospital. In his integrity, optimism and spirit of service, Jack Taylor was a shining example of the "Greatest Generation." With his passing, St. Louis has lost one of its greatest friends and benefactors. Funeral service private. The family requests that donations be made to the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center, 975 N. Warson Road, St. Louis, MO 63132; Forest Park Forever, 5595 Grand Drive, St. Louis, MO 63103; or the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, 718 North Grand Blvd., St. Louis, MO, 63103. Condolences may be sent via email to taylorfamily@ehi.com. 1/3

RUBEN--Lawrence. Fenway Golf Club expresses profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed, long-standing member, Lawrence Ruben, and extends sincere condolences to his entire family. Bruce Haber, President 1/3

BRYANT--H. Stafford, 90, died peacefully at his home on June 27. He was the most beloved husband and closest friend of his wife Sylvie and cousin to Christine, Rob, Charlotte and Jean. Always the Virginian gentleman, his was a long and graceful life. Raised in Lynchburg, Virginia, he attended Washington & Lee University and spent the last year of World War II in the US navy. Starting out as a journalist with the Lynchburg News, he went on to the Bethlehem Globe Times, and the Savannah Evening Press before moving to New York where he spent over 25 years at WW Norton Publishers. Author of "The Georgian Locomotive" and other publications on trains, he was also co-editor with Henry Hope Reed of the "Classical America" series and served on the Board of Directors of the organization. His passion for jazz was equaled only by his profound knowledge of French and American decorative arts, his ability to evoke them in his home, and his deep love for all matters related to Virginia. 1

ROBBINS--Albert, editor, author, lawyer and lifelong advocate for civil liberties, died July 2, 2016 in New York after a fierce fight with lengthy illness. He was 67. Son of Leo and Sylvia Sabel Robbins, Albert earned a B.A. and M.A. in American history at Temple University in his native Philadelphia, where he was an editor for The Drummer, a counterculture weekly. He moved to New York as associate editor at Harper's Magazine Company. He then went on to become executive editor of the ACLU Civil Liberties Review, publications director of the Educational Fund for Individual Rights, and managing editor of the National Law Journal. A graduate of Fordham Law School, he joined the New York law firm of Cahill, Gordon, and Reindel, litigating First Amendment issues and the scientific aspects of early asbestos cases. He returned to the Law Journal as General Counsel and associate publisher/editor of Law Technology Product News, collaborating on the first systems to manage court documents on the Internet. A passionate force for workers' and immigrants' rights, Albert authored "Coming to America, Immigrants From Northern Europe" (Delacorte, 1981) and co-authored "The Watergate File" (Flash Books, 1973); "Getting Angry Six Days a Week" (Beacon, 1979) and "Whistle-Blowing" (McGraw-Hill, 1978). He was a member of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, represented individuals seeking asylum in the US, and was secretary of the Committee on Immigration Law of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. In his retirement, he pursued his passion for collecting by selling rare books. Friends and loved ones will remember Albert for his encyclopedic intellect, sharp sense of humor, and appreciation for 1940s music. He is survived by his beloved partner, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Nancy Hershey Lord; his cherished children Laura Robbins, Charlie Robbins, and Alix Comeau; his treasured granddaughter Natalie Robbins; and two brothers. His dear wife, Amy Comeau, predeceased him. Services Wednesday, July 6 at 10:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. Burial at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Donations: the Perlmutter Cancer Center or the ACLU. 1/3

MURPHY--Edmund, May 1, 1930, died July 3, 2016. Beloved husband of Virginia, father of Anne, Edmund, Mary, Thomas, Brian, Ellen, Joseph, and Kevin. Grandfather of 20. Great-grandfather of five. Services, 10am, Wednesday, St. Agnes. 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. Clal mourns the loss of our co-founder Elie Wiesel, a beacon of moral conscience, a passionate defender of both the Jewish people and of universal human dignity, and a visionary social architect who inspired and created institutions and texts which focused our attention on humankind's most important ethical questions, and helped us to answer those questions with greater efficacy and meaning. He was not only our co-founder, but our teacher and a genuine role model. May we continue to be inspired by the legacy he created in both words and deeds, and may his wife Marion, his son Elisha, his extended family, and all those who mourn the loss of this contemporary sage, find a place of comfort among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Steven J. Rotter, Chairman Rabbi Brad Hirschfield, President Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Rabbi Yitz Greenberg, Co-Founder and President Emeritus Clal--The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership 1/3

OLICK--Arthur, died on July 2 in Bethesda, Maryland of multiple sclerosis (M.S.). He was 85. He will be remembered as a loving husband, devoted father, grandfather, and brother, and an attorney with few equals. Rising from modest beginnings in the Bronx in New York City, he forged a legal career of unusual accomplishment that included study at Yale University (B.A. 1952; J.D. 1955), public service in the U.S. Army (1956-57) and the U.S. Attorney's office for the Southern District of New York (1962-68), and private practice at several Manhattan law firms, most notably Anderson, Kill & Olick from which he retired. Through the course of a wide-ranging career he represented both local municipalities and prominent cultural figures, became one of the nation's leading experts on insurance coverage litigation, and was known to many as a lawyer's lawyer, as evidenced by his representation of law firms in high-profile bankruptcy proceedings. Arthur Seymour Olick was born on June 15, 1931 to Anita Babsky and Jacob (Jack) Olick, both first generation Americans born in New York City. Jack was a technical writer who was also what is now called an "early adopter" of new technologies, thanks to which Arthur was one of only a handful of Americans who learned of the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941 via television. He graduated from Evander Childs High School at age 16 before going on to study political science at Yale where he graduated magna cum laude and was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. He also excelled at Yale Law School where he was a moot court champion. It was at Yale where Arthur met and, in 1954, married Selma Ada Kaufman of New Haven. They were married for 62 years, during which Selma was Art's constant companion, mother to the couple's two children, Robert (born 1957) and Karen (born 1961), and, in later years as his M.S. progressed, Art's caregiver and advocate. Upon relocating to New York following his Army service, Art entered private practice for several years before joining the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York under Robert Morgenthau, where he worked for six years (1962-68), the last three as Chief of the Civil Division. He returned to private practice as a partner at several law firms before joining the firm of Gene Anderson, his former colleague at the U.S. Attorney's Office. Together, Anderson, Olick, and other attorneys at the firm became nationally recognized for their innovative litigation strategies on behalf of insurance policyholders seeking coverage for personal injuries and other damages related to exposure to asbestos. He also served as managing partner of the firm, lectured frequently on trial practice, partnerships, product liability, and business bankruptcy, and represented Zsa Zsa Gabor, Peter Max, Don McLean, Meatloaf, and Gloria Swanson on various commercial matters. Throughout his years of private practice, however, Arthur was continually inspired by the call of public service. He was very active in civic affairs in Westchester County where the family lived for most of the 1960s, 70s, and 80s, serving as attorney for several local townships. It was in this capacity that he engaged in a series of court cases to deny tax-exempt status under state and local laws for Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church. In one case, Arthur won a court order to cross-examine Moon, leading the Unification Church to quickly settle. In addition, he served as president of the Greenburg Central Seven School District, leading the implementation of a controversial busing program in the 1970s. He and Selma were also founding members of Bet Am Shalom, a Reconstructionist temple in White Plains. The family built a weekend home in Putnam Valley where they spent many weekends with family and friends, and where, true to his deep sense of patriotism, Art raised and lowered the American flag on national holidays to recorded military music. In retirement, Art and Selma spent part of the year in Florida and as much time as possible every year enjoying theater, opera, and their grandchildren. Arthur was defined by a lifelong drive to learn, to lead, and to serve. He pursued great passions with great energy, led nearly every institution in which he served, set high standards and expectations for colleagues and his family members alike, and, by any measure, achieved the success associated with the American Dream in which he so fervently believed. Arthur is survived by his children Robert (Manlius, NY) and Karen (Washington, DC), her husband John Gibson, and five grandchildren, Joshua, Sarah, Rachel, Stephen, and Grant, and his brothers Phillip (New York City) and David (San Francisco). His wife Selma preceded him in death earlier this year. Services Thursday, July 7th, at 11am at Riverside Chapel, Manhattan. Family will be receiving at the Yale Club at 50 Vanderbilt Avenue on Thursday from 5-8pm. Donations may be made in Arthur's name to the Multiple Sclerosis Society. 1/3
WIESEL--Elie. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their highly esteemed colleague and longtime friend, Elie Wiesel, and send condolences to his family. 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. S'iz gefaln a demb - we have lost a great man. The League for Yiddish mourns the passing of Eliezer Wiesel, our honorary Board member. His first book, "Un di velt hot geshvign", was published in his native Yiddish, and its adaptation into the volume "Night" introduced him to the wider world. May his support for our cause - Yiddish - inspire others. Sheva Zucker, Exec. Dir., and Gitl Schaechter- Viswanath, Chair leagueforyiddish.org 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The Zamir Choral Foundation joins the world in mourning the passing of Elie Wiesel, our conscience, transmitter of memory, and a giant among men whose voice and legacy will remain an inspiration for generations to come. A consummate teacher and scholar, and a master of Hasidic song, our Honorary Chairman for a quarter of a century combined his love of music with his profound understanding of text, bringing both to the Heavenly spheres. We are honored to share and continue to be motivated by his deep commitment to moral courage, respect for all humanity, love of Israel and Jerusalem, and the eternity of the Jewish People. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Marion, son Elisha (Lynn), grandchildren and the entire family. May his memory, as was his life, be a blessing to us all. Matthew Lazar, Founder and Director Steven C. Lorch, President Zamir Choral Foundation 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the loss of our dear friend and advisor, the Holocaust survivor, writer and Nobel laureate Elie Wiesel. A Jewish voice of conscience for a generation who witnessed humanity's darkest hour, Wiesel was unrelenting in his pursuit for justice and memory for all victims of genocide. A committed Zionist, he spoke out unfailingly against anti-Semitism as a moral disease that could lead to the dissolution of societies and civilization. He was an early recipient of ADL's Joseph Prize for Human Rights; and, along with his wife, Marion, accepted the ADL Jabotinsky Prize for Courageous Jewish Leadership. "Anti-Semitism," he once said, "is an attack not only on the Jewish people. It is an attack on all people." We extend our deepest condolences to the entire family. Marvin D. Nathan National Chair Jonathan A. Greenblatt CEO and National Director Abraham H. Foxman National Director Emeritus Anti-Defamation League 1/3

HOULIHAN--Kathrene "Kate" (nee Blish), of Chicago, IL; New Rochelle, Crestwood, and Bronxville, NY died July 2 at home surrounded by family. She was 96. She and Dan, her husband of 53 years raised nine children in love and faith: Kathie (Jim), Rita, Dorothy (Marcel), Daniel (Marie), Joe (Anna), Mark (Amy), Barbara (Bill), Gerry (Maureen) and Liz (Ralph). A graduate of Maplehurst Convent of the Sacred Heart (1937) and Manhattanville College (1941), she served on the board of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, Greenwich. Her faith and intellectual curiosity sparked many interests - American History, art, opera, embroidery, travel, baseball, and French cooking. Her legendary dinner parties were a key ingredient of Dan's and his partners' (James G. Houlihan and Howard Parnes) business, Houlihan-Parnes Realtors. Longtime parishioner of Annunciation Parish 1949-1999 (Crestwood, NY) she joined St. Joseph's in 1999. The Houlihans generously supported Catholic education. Kate is survived by 19 grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren, many nieces and nephews, her brother-in-law, Joe and his wife June (Northbrook, IL), five cousins, and her longtime nurse and friend Grace Sendras. Kate was predeceased by her husband, her brother (Syl) and sisters (Sally, Marie, Betsy) and sisters-in-law (Rita Anne, Janet). A woman of deep faith, Kate guided her family to "always do something worthwhile" and "to be good to everybody." Calling Hours at Fred H. McGrath's, Bronxville, July 5, 6-9; July 6, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, July 7, 9:45am. In lieu of flowers please contribute to Annunciation School, Crestwood, NY or The Pregnancy Care Center, New Rochelle, NY. 1/3

WEISEL--Elie. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Elie Wiesel, who served as Distinguished Professor of Judaic Studies at The City College of New York and continued to lecture at many CUNY campuses over the course of the last four decades. Elie Wiesel served as the conscience for humankind and a beacon for justice. His life's work was honored with the Nobel Peace Prize in 1986 in recognition of his eloquent and consistent message "not of hate and revenge, but of brotherhood and atonement." We extend our deepest condolences to his family. William C. Thompson, Jr. Chairman, Board of Trustees James B. Milliken Chancellor 1/3

BROWN--Roscoe. The board and staff of City Parks Foundation mourn the loss of founding secretary of the board and trustee emeritus Roscoe Brown. Brown, who served on our board for more than 25 years, was a thoughtful and dedicated member who helped ensure that small, neighborhood parks around our city received needed support. A Tuskegee Airman, decorated World War II hero, Congressional Gold Medal recipient, educator and professor, and nine-time NYC marathon runner. Roscoe was generous, humble and honorable. He was a great friend to City Parks Foundation and we will miss him. Our deepest condolences to Roscoe's children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. CARR--Helen B.,(nee Trainer), beloved wife, devoted mother, nurturing grandmother, loving sister, thoughtful aunt and faithful friend, died peacefully at her home in Southampton, NY on June 11, 2016, just 12 days before her 95th birthday. Helen was born June 23, 1921 in Central Falls, CT to Harold A. Trainer and Sarah E. Trainer (nee Fraser). Her family moved to Coventry, RI, where she graduated from Coventry High School, earning the senior superlative of "Miss Dependable". As an active 4H member, Helen was featured on radio programming as "Peggy Clover". Choosing to study nursing, she graduated from The Memorial Hospital School of Nursing in Pawtucket, RI. Helen garnered special recognition for her speed and proficiency administering The Sister Kenny treatment to patients victimized by Polio. While visiting family in Helen's care, Peter F. Carr asked Helen to a hospital dance. They would later marry January 30, 1945. Helen chose a career as a public health nurse, visiting neighborhoods and homes in service of the poor and disadvantaged. Peter, Helen and their son Peter, Jr. traveled The Thoroughbred Racing circuit eventually settling in New York. After welcoming a second child, Helen stopped working outside the home in nursing. However, she did become the "neighborhood nurse", ready to provide first aid, wipe a tear or apply a Band-Aid. As their family grew, they continued to travel for Peter's career in racing. This took them to Hialeah, Florida in the winter and Saratoga, NY during the summer but Long Island was home. Along with her husband, Helen conceptualized and created a health care insurance program for the New York State Jockey Agent's Benevolent Association. A program Helen administered long after her husband's death. Although she hadn't played for years, Helen developed a love of golf which she shared with her husband. Whether attending a symphony at Carnegie Hall, a ballet at The Met, cabaret at The Algonquin or a Broadway show, Helen loved music and the arts. Her love for poetry, both reading and writing lasted throughout her lifetime. With her ability to make friends easily, she was treasured by everyone who knew her. Dedication to her family was at the core of everything she did throughout her life. She was an extraordinarily caring person. Helen will be sadly missed by her daughter Karen and her wife Yvette Christofilis of Westchester, NY, her daughter Sharon of Southampton, NY, her cherished brother Arthur of Coventry, RI, grandson Kevin of Arkansas, dear friends and relatives. Helen was predeceased by her husband, Peter Sr. in 1985 and her son, Peter Jr. in 2014. A Funeral Mass and graveside memorial service in Coventry, RI, will be announced at a future date. Memorial donations may be made to Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS), www.lls.org; American Heart Association, www.heart.org; East End Hospice, www.eeh.org, The Hospital for Special Surgery's Autoimmunity and Inflammation Program (www.hss.edu), Group For The East End, www.groupfortheeast end.org. A kind thought and prayer for peace would truly honor Helen's spirit. 1/3

BURGUIERES--Philip Joseph Well-known Houston business and community leader, Philip Joseph Burguieres, passed away on the on the evening of June 30, 2016, surrounded by his family and loved ones. A devoted grandfather, father and husband Philip earned his Bachelor of Science degree in Mechanical Engineering from The University of Louisiana - Lafayette, where a Chair in the engineering department has been dedicated in his honor. In 1992 he received the Outstanding Alumni Award. Shortly after graduation, Philip married Cheryl Courrege and soon joined the Navy, completing training at Officer Candidate School. He served in the U.S. Navy for four years during the Vietnam era as a "Seabee", reaching the rank of Lieutenant. Upon completion of his service, Philip was accepted to The Wharton Graduate School of Business. Upon graduation he accepted a job with Cameron Iron Works, Inc. in Houston, Texas in 1971. Under the guidance of Herb Allen, Philip became President and Chief Operating Officer in 1981 at the young age of 38. By 1986 he was one of the youngest Chief Executive Officers to ever run a Fortune 500 company. Philip joined the board of the J.M. Burguieres Company in 1978, a family-owned, land-holding company that he would chair from 1986 until 2012. In 1990, Philip joined Panhandle Eastern Corporation, as President and Chief Executive Officer. Philip returned to the oilfield service industry in 1991 as President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of Weatherford International, Inc. Soon after merging the company with Enterra in 1996, Philip resigned, marking the end of a 30-year energy career, during which he was named Energy Service Industry CEO of the Year three times by Financial World Magazine. Philip provided unrelenting service to his industry and community. He served as President of the Petroleum Club of Houston, the Petroleum Equipment Suppliers' Association and as Chairman of the National Ocean Industries Association, the Board of Directors of Texas Commerce Bancshares, McDermott International and Cogen Technologies. He was a member of the Texas Heart Institute's National Advisory Council and chaired the Board of Duchesne Academy of the Sacred Heart. After a brief hiatus, Philip began helping his friend John Sage develop Bridges to Life, serving on its Board. He consulted for Cogen Technologies which led to Bob McNair inviting him to begin a new career as Vice Chairman of the Houston Texans in 1999. Philip served as Chairman of Mental Health America of Greater Houston and in 2000 he received the organization's Ima Hogg Award. He paved the way for the Texans to be the first NFL franchise to implement mental health parity in 2002. For these efforts, he was named the 2003 William Styron Award recipient by the National Mental Health Association. In 2005 Philip received the Woodrow Wilson Corporate Citizenship Award from the Smithsonian Institute. Philip served as Vice Chairman of both the Menninger Clinic and the Baylor College of Medicine as well as on the Executive Committee of M.D. Anderson Cancer Center. He crafted a vision for the Menninger Clinic "Mental Health Epicenter." In 2012, that vision became a reality with the opening of a state-of-the-art, 50-acre psychiatric hospital facility. Philip served as the Vice Chairman of the Meineke Car Care Bowl of Texas. He served the Board of Directors of FMC Technologies, Inc. and Newfield Exploration Company and was a member of the National Petroleum Council. Later that same year, Philip sustained a brain injury. He worked tirelessly over the following years to recover as much as he could and his efforts were nothing short of heroic. He was preceded in death by his parents, Denis Philip Burguieres, Jr. and Emma Louise LeBlanc Burguieres and his first wife Cheryl Courrege Burguieres. He is survived by his wife of nine years, Alice Kirkpatrick Burguieres, and his children Emily Burguieres Dalicandro and her husband Steve, and P. Martial Burguieres and his wife Valeria, his stepchildren Stephanie and Morgan Harcrow and Ashley Harcrow Moseley and her husband Seth, and numerous other family and friends. Although Philip will be sorely missed by everyone whose lives he touched and who had the privilege of knowing him. His remarkable legacy to his family and to the city of Houston will be recognized for generations to come. Services will be held on July 6 and 7 in Houston, Texas under the direction of Bradshaw-Carter Memorial & Funeral Services, 1734 West Alabama Street in Houston and July 8 and 9 in Franklin, Louisa, and New Iberia, Louisiana under the direction of Ibert's Mortuary, 1007 Main Street, Franklin, Louisiana. Memorial gifts may be made to The Menninger Clinic (www.menningerclinic.com/ donateake-a-donation-to- Menninger), Office of Philanthropy, 12301 Main Street, Houston, Texas 77035 or to the Burguieres Family Foundation (www.GHCF.org/donation- ghcf/) payable to the Greater Houston Community Foundation, ATTN: Gift Processor, 5120 Woodway Dr. #

RUBEN--Lawrence. September 28, 1926 - July 3, 2016. Cherished husband of Jan Ruben and the late Selma Ruben. Beloved father of Richard, Lenore, and Shelly and father-in-law of Howard Kivell and Amy Ruben. Adored grandfather of Tamara, Danielle, William, Andrew, Melissa, Robert, James, Allison and Caroline, and great-grandfather of Blake, Sasha, Jonah, and Owen. As Chairman of Ruben Companies, he helped shape the skyline of New York City. Life Overseer of Weill Cornell Medicine, and Honorary Overseer of Cardozo School of Law. His love and passion for his family, his work, and his city will be missed. Funeral services will be Tuesday, July 5, 12pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Donations in his memory may be made to Weill Cornell Medicine. 1/3

OLICK--Arthur, died on July 2 in Bethesda, Maryland of multiple sclerosis (M.S.). He was 85. He is remembered as a loving husband, devoted father, grandfather, and brother, and an attorney with few equals. From modest beginnings in the Bronx, NY, he forged a legal career of unusual accomplishment that included study at Yale University (B.A. 1952; J.D. 1955), public service in the U.S. Army (1956-57) and the U.S. Attorney's office for the Southern District of New York (1962-68), and private practice at several Manhattan law firms, most notably Anderson, Kill & Olick from which he retired. During his wide-ranging career he represented both local municipalities and prominent cultural figures, became one of the nation's leading experts on insurance coverage litigation and bankdruptcy law, and was known to many as a lawyer's lawyer, as evidenced by his representation of law firms in high-profile bankruptcy proceedings. Arthur Seymour Olick was born on June 15, 1931 to Anita Babsky and Jacob (Jack) Olick, both first generation Americans born in New York City. Jack was a technical writer and an "early adopter" of new technologies, thanks to which Arthur was among a handful of Americans who learned of the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941 via television. He graduated from Evander Childs High School at age 16 before going on to study political science at Yale, graduating magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa. He also excelled at Yale Law School where he was a moot court champion. While at Yale, Arthur met and, in 1954, married Selma Ada Kaufman of New Haven. They were married for 62 years, during which Selma was Art's constant companion, mother to the couple's two children, Robert (born 1957) and Karen (born 1961), and, in later years as his M.S. progressed, Art's caregiver and advocate. Following his Army service, Arthur entered private practice in New York City for several years before joining the U.S. Attorney's Office under Robert Morgenthau, where he worked for six years, the last three as Chief of the Civil Division. He returned to private practice as a partner at several law firms before joining the firm of Gene Anderson, his former colleague at the U.S. Attorney's Office. Together, Anderson, Olick, and their colleagues became nationally recognized for their innovative litigation strategies on behalf of insurance policyholders seeking coverage for personal injuries and other damages related to asbestos exposure. Arthur also served as managing partner of the firm, lectured frequently on trial practice, partnerships, product liability, and business bankruptcy, and represented Zsa Zsa Gabor, Peter Max, Don McLean, Meatloaf, and Gloria Swanson on various commercial matters. Throughout his years of private practice, however, Arthur was continually inspired by the call of public service. He was very active in civic affairs in Westchester County where the family lived for most of the 1960s, 70s, and 80s, serving as attorney for several local townships. It was in this capacity that he engaged in a series of court cases to deny tax-exempt status under state and local laws for Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church. In one case, Arthur won a court order to cross-examine Moon, leading the Unification Church to quickly settle. In addition, he served as president of the Greenburgh Central Seven School District board of education, leading the implementation of a controversial busing program in the 1970s. He and Selma were also founding members of Bet Am Shalom, a Reconstructionist temple in White Plains. Arthur was defined by a lifelong drive to learn, to lead, and to serve. He pursued great passions with great energy, led nearly every institution in which he served, set high standards and expectations for colleagues and his family members alike, and, by any measure, achieved the success associated with the American Dream in which he so fervently believed. Arthur is survived by his children Robert (Manlius, NY) and Karen (Washington, DC), her husband John Gibson, and five grandchildren, Joshua, Sarah, Rachel, Stephen, and Grant, and his brothers Phillip (New York City) and David (San Francisco). His wife Selma preceded him in death earlier this year. Services Thursday, July 7th, at 11am at Riverside Chapel, Manhattan. Family will be receiving at the Yale Club at 50 Vanderbilt Avenue on Thursday from 5-8pm. Donations may be made in Arthur's name to the Multiple Sclerosis Society. 1/3

FRAWLEY--Sigrid B. (nee Brandt), 64, of Woodcliff Lake, NJ passed away peacefully surrounded by her loving family and friends on Monday, July 4, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Franklyn "Chris" Frawley. Dear sister of John Brandt of Augusta, ME and Mary Brandt of Portland, OR. Also survived by step-brothers; Kevin Smith and his wife Peggy, Richard Smith and his wife Barbara and Christopher Smith. Cherished aunt of Jennifer, Allison, Emily, Kevin, Tom, Brian, Katie, Michael and the late Meghan. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Sigrid graduated with a BA in Child Study at St. Joseph's College (New York) and went on to earn a MS in Elementary Education at Fordham University and a MS in School Administration from Iona College. Sigrid was a beloved Kindergarten Teacher at the Stillman School in Tenafly, NJ for 26 years before retiring in 2011. Since 2007, Sigrid was Adjunct Instructor of Early Childhood Education and Literacy Education at Montclair State University. She had been a parishioner of St. John the Baptist R. C. Church since 1991 and had served on the Parish Council and as a Lector. Sigrid was active in the community and local government, working with various groups in Woodcliff Lake including the Helping Hands Food Pantry, Woodcliff Lake Senior Association and SEAS National. Sigrid's family and friends would like to thank the doctors and staff at Memorial Sloan Kettering and Mount Sinai Hospital for their compassionate care and on- going support. In particular, we would like to thank Diane Reidy Lagunes, MD and Laura Boucai, MD at MSK for their extraordinary support and care. Funeral Mass 10am on Saturday, July 9, 2016 at St. John the Baptist R. C. Church, Hillsdale, NJ. Visitation 5-9pm on Thursday and Friday at the Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, NJ. rsfhi.com. Interment in Christ the King Cemetery, Franklin Lakes, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Sigrid may be made to your favorite charity. 1/3

BROWN--Roscoe C. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of Dr. Roscoe C. Brown, Jr., former President of Bronx Community College, who served his country with great distinction in World War II as one of the famed Tuskegee Airmen and later as a leading champion for civil rights. During his 17 years of exemplary service as president, Dr. Brown intensified the College's outreach to New York City's economic and educational institutions through partnerships with business and industry. With his leadership, new programs were developed in high growth professions in the fields of health, technology and human services. He later joined The City University of New York Graduate Center as University Professor and Director of the Center for Urban Education Policy. Dr. Brown for many years hosted "African American Legends," a public affairs show produced by CUNY TV. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. William C. Thompson, Jr. Chairman, Board of Trustees James B. Milliken Chancellor The City University of New York 1/3

SCOTT--Sandra. The Legal Aid Family mourns the loss of our beloved colleague and officer. Her courage, integrity and dedication will serve as her legacy. We will miss her warm spirit and commitment to excellence. We offer our condolences to her husband and family. 1/3

KALLETT--Calvin. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Calvin Kallett, who leaves behind a loving family who will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Calvin's beloved wife, Annette; his children, Tricia Kallett (Craig Klosk), Sara Kallett, and Nancy El Naggar; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Jeffrey A. Schoenfeld, President; Robert S. Kapito, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

WIESEL--Eliezer (Elie), Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with its officers and employees, mourn the passing of Elie Wiesel, who was an esteemed member of the Board of Directors for more than twenty-five years. Elie Wiesel served on numerous Board committees and was one of the founding members of the Mutual of America Community Partnership Award Selection Committee. His many years of dedicated service were distinguished by his wise counsel and exceptional insights. Highly respected as a writer, teacher, philosopher and scholar, Elie Wiesel was an extraordinary, kind man, whose devotion to championing human rights was exemplary. He was fiercely committed to fighting indifference and served as a constant conscience, reminding us all of our moral responsibilities to one another. Elie Wiesel's wisdom, experience and commitment to personal and professional excellence and accountability profoundly touched and influenced many lives all over the world. Elie Wiesel was a friend to each of us. We who were privileged to have known him will gratefully remember his eloquence, strength of character and high ethical standards. His warmth and friendship will be deeply missed. While we mourn his passing, we greatly admire the manner in which he lived his life. Elie Wiesel, our friend and colleague, will be remembered with profound respect and affection. Thomas J. Moran, Chairman of the Board John R. Greed, President and Chief Executive Officer Mutual of America Life Insurance Company 1/3

TAYLOR--Jack Crawford, of St. Louis, Missouri, died July 2, 2016, at the age of 94. Beloved father of Andrew C. (Barbara) Taylor and Jo Ann Taylor Kindle (Tom Caruso); devoted grandfather of Alison Kindle (Kyle) Hogan, Carolyn Kindle (Adam) Betz, Christine Taylor (Lee) Broughton, Kelly Taylor and Patricia Taylor (Andy Magee); and cherished great- grandfather of Grace and Amelia Broughton and Kylie Hogan. Taylor was the founder of Enterprise Holdings, which through its Enterprise Rent-A-Car, National Car Rental and Alamo Rent A Car brands is the largest and most comprehensive service provider in the car rental industry. Born and raised in St. Louis, Taylor served his country as a decorated Navy fighter pilot in World War II before returning home to build the company his family still owns and operates. In 1957, he launched a small, auto leasing operation with seven vehicles in the lower level of a Cadillac dealership--expanding to daily car rental a few years later as an additional service to customers. In the decades to come, he turned his start-up into one of the business world's greatest success stories. As the rest of the industry focused on serving airports, Taylor pioneered the "home city" car rental market. By renting cars from convenient, neighborhood locations to meet a variety of customer needs, Enterprise quietly but steadily developed a market segment that grew to be as large as or larger than the airport-based rental market. Today, Enterprise Holdings owns three of the most successful car rental brands in the world, a fleet of 1.7 million vehicles and offers extensive car rental and car-sharing services, truck rental, corporate fleet management and retail car sales. Taylor built his company on a simple philosophy: "Take care of your customers and your employees first, and the profits will follow." And indeed they did. Over the years, his passion for the business was equaled only by his devotion to his family and his generosity to his beloved home town. Through the years, Taylor--whose charitable giving ranked him No. 11 on The Chronicle of Philanthropy's 2015 "Philanthropy 50" list of America's top donors--made many notable private contributions to several of St. Louis's leading civic and cultural not-for-profit institutions, notably the St. Louis Public Schools Foundation, the Saint Louis Symphony Orchestra, the Missouri Botanical Garden, Forest Park Forever and the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center. Other local beneficiaries of his family's and his company's generosity have included St. Louis Children's Hospital, the Urban League of Metropolitan St. Louis, the St. Louis Zoo, the St. Louis Art Museum, the St. Louis Science Center, Harris-Stowe State University, Saint Louis University, the University of Missouri-St. Louis, Our Little Haven and Cardinal Glennon Children's Hospital. In his integrity, optimism and spirit of service, Jack Taylor was a shining example of the "Greatest Generation." With his passing, St. Louis has lost one of its greatest friends and benefactors. Funeral service private. The family requests that donations be made to the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center, 975 N. Warson Road, St. Louis, MO 63132; Forest Park Forever, 5595 Grand Drive, St. Louis, MO 63103; or the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, 718 North Grand Blvd., St. Louis, MO, 63103. Condolences may be sent via email to taylorfamily@ehi.com. 1/3

RUBEN--Lawrence. Weill Cornell Medicine is deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend and benefactor Lawrence Ruben. An Overseer since 2010 and Life Overseer since 2015, Larry was an esteemed and dedicated leader, serving on the Clinical Affairs/Physician Organization and the Government Relations and Community Affairs committees. Larry championed cancer research and was devoted to advancing science and medicine. In memory of his late wife Selma, Larry, along with his children Richard Ruben, Lenore Ruben and Rochelle "Shelly" Kivell generously established the Selma Ruben Conference Center at the Weill Greenberg Center. The family also left an indelible mark on Weill Cornell Medicine with the creation of the Ruben Family Conference Center at the Belfer Research Building. Along with his family and the Belfer and Saltz families, Larry also helped to establish the R. A. Rees Pritchett Professorship of Microbiology, the Rochelle Belfer Professorship in Medicine, the Arthur B. Belfer Professorship in Genetic Medicine, the Belfer Gene Therapy Core Facility, and the Arthur and Rochelle Belfer Institute of Hematology and Medical Oncology, all at Weill Cornell Medicine. Larry was the endearing patriarch of a strong and close-knit family. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Jan, his children, family and friends. Dr. Augustine M.K. Choi, Interim Dean Jessica M. Bibliowicz, Chairman, Board of Overseers Weill Cornell Medicine 1/3
WIESEL--Elie. Marion, Elisha and family: Our hearts go out to you for your irreplaceable loss. Irma and Norman Braman 1/3
WIESEL--Elie. SSEJ mourns its honorary president Elie Wiesel and Ethiopian Jews grieve the loss of a compassionate champion. 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The World Jewish Congress mourns the passing of one of the preeminent Jewish thinkers, human rights activists, authors, teachers, and moral authorities of our age, Nobel Peace Prize laureate Elie Wiesel. After surviving the horrors of Auschwitz and Buchenwald, Elie Wiesel taught the world the true meaning of remembrance and dedicated himself to fighting evil, bigotry and xenophobia in all its forms. More than anyone else, he ensured that the victims of the Shoah would be remembered, not only for how they were murdered, but for who they were and how they lived. We are proud to have counted him among the dearest friends of the World Jewish Congress, and that we were privileged to honor him with the Guardian of Jerusalem Prize in 2010, and with our highest honor, the Theodor Herzl Award, in 2013. We extend our deepest condolences and those of our more than 100 affiliated Jewish communities across the globe to his wife and life partner Marion, his cherished son Elisha, daughter-in-law Lynn, stepdaughter Jennifer, his beloved grandchildren, and his entire family. May his memory be a blessing and an eternal inspiration to us all. Ronald S. Lauder, President David de Rothschild, Chairman, Governing Board Chella Safra, Treasurer Robert Singer, CEO 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The Trustees and staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage -- A Living Memorial to the Holocaust express profound sadness on the passing of Elie Wiesel. An Honorary Chairman of this institution, he survived the horrors of the Holocaust and used his experience to teach the world about the dangers of indifference and the importance of fighting for justice. His legacy will inspire future generations. We extend our condolences to his entire family. Bruce C. Ratner, Chairman 1/3

BROWN--Roscoe. The Association for a Better New York mourns the loss of longstanding board member Roscoe C. Brown, Jr. Dr. Brown was an educator, a civic leader, and a member of the famed Tuskegee Airmen. He was a hero who will be missed. William C. Rudin, Chairman 1/3

GLASSMAN--Paul, of Cliffside Park, Founder of Ropal Stationery NYC, beloved husband of Roslyn, father of Reed and Nancy Glassman, Leslie Glassman. Grandfather of Anna and Allison Glassman. For info "Eden Memorial Chapels," Fort Lee, (201) 947-3336. 1/3

COHEN--Philip M. Age 86, died July 3, 2016. Survived by his loving wife, Liliana, daughters, Martha Cohen Stine, Amy Z. Cohen, Dr. Susan Hirsch and Patricia Epstein Putney, stepsons, Robert and Andrew Romano, 13 grandchildren (predeceased by Benjamin Ziegelbaum), sister, Norma Barasch and former wife, Harriet Newman Cohen. Accomplished musician, chemist, businessman, avid skier and tennis player. Forever in our hearts. 1/3

MacLEOD--Whitney Burnett, who devoted her life to helping underserved populations, died peacefully in Los Angeles on Sunday, July 26, 2016. Born in New York City in 1946 to Whit and Hallie Burnett, Whitney began her career as an opera singer, performing as a mezzo-soprano in houses that included her cherished Santa Fe Opera. She then became the casting director for the soap operas The Edge of Night and Search for Tomorrow, where she took joy in casting young aspiring actors. Later, building on her experience as a board member for the Boys and Girls Clubs of America, and while raising three sons, she served as a fundraiser for The Women's Project Theater, as the development director of the Harlem School of the Arts, and finally, for 13 wonderful years, as the executive director of The National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, where she supported treatment for children with facial differences. Tireless even as she battled cancer, Whitney continued to serve those in need as a tutor and mentor to homeless youth through The Doe Fund. Only months ago, and just a week removed from a hospital bed, Whitney even traveled to Jordan to work with torture victims in refugee camps. Having lovingly raised three sons, in 2005 Whitney met her beloved husband Michael MacLeod, whom she cared for devotedly until he died in 2014. Whitney is survived by her three sons, McCaleb Burnett, Philip Voss, and Jeremy Voss; daughter-in-law, Brooksie Voss; and brother, John Burnett. Whitney made the world a much better place for her family and many others, and her loving presence will remain in their hearts. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that you consider donating to The West End Collegiate Church or The Center for Victims of Torture, an organization with which both Whitney and her husband Michael were closely involved. A memorial service will be held on Friday, July 8 at 11am at The West End Collegiate Church, where Whitney served as a deacon and whose community she treasured. 1/3
LISS--Elliott R. 7/6/1931 - 5/18/2004. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, and friend. You remain loved and missed. Your laugh and smile are always with us. Dotty, Laurie, Matthew, and Timothy 1/3

GUTTERMAN--Shirley. The Gutterman Family, The Board of Directors and all the Employees of Gutterman's Funeral Home and Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel mourn the loss of our Esteemed and Beloved Mother and CEO. She was a very strong willed woman who was never afraid to speak her mind or help someone in need. She was a female pioneer in the nursing profession for over 40 years before becoming involved in the funeral industry. She was instrumental in growing the company to what it has become today, one of the largest family owned and operating Jewish Funeral Homes in the country. Her dedication to her job, patients and family were second to none. She will always be remembered for her quick wit, great memory, class and generosity. She cared so very much about everyone and was truly interested in everything that her family and friends were involved with. She will be greatly missed and remembered every day by all who had the privilege to know her and love her. Rest in Peace. Services Thursday, July 7, 12 noon at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. There will be a memorial service in Florida at a later date. 1/3

RUBEN--Lawrence. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Lawrence Ruben and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela Buchdahl and President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

CHANLER--Harvey, a former senior advertising executive and Forest Hills High School basketball standout, passed away on July 1 in New Canaan, CT. He was 87. Born in NYC to immigrant parents from Eastern Europe, Harvey maintained a great sense of humor throughout his life. He was a master of Ideas for Marketing. Harvey is survived by his children, Ann, Bill and Cliff and grandchildren, Alex, Kaya, Casey, Liliana, Cole and Catalina, and his three nieces, Patricia, Beryl, and Polly. Donations can be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation pdf.org 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion mourns our beloved honorary alumnus, tenacious guardian of Holocaust memory, and inspiring advocate for the Jewish people, Israel, and humanity. Rabbi Aaron Panken, Ph.D. President Andrew Berger, Chair, Board of Governors 1/3

HAFFNER--Dr. Alden Norman. It is with great sadness that NYU Wagner remembers esteemed alumnus Dr. Alden Norman Haffner. The founding President of the SUNY College of Optometry, Dr. Haffner was a noted scholar and an indomitable advocate for optometry and public health. He will always be remembered for his immense contributions to public service. 1/3

BROWN--Dr. Roscoe C. Jr. New York City has lost a transformative leader, and Phipps Houses a valued trustee and friend. A long distance runner, fearless Tuskegee airman, superb educator, and wise advocate, Dr. Roscoe C. Brown, Jr. will be missed but his influence will remain with all of us. We extend our sympathies to his family. Ronay Menschel, Chairman/Phipps Houses Adam Weinstein, President/Phipps Houses Dianne Morales, Exec. Director/ Phipps Neighborhoods 1/3

ROBBINS--Albert, editor, author, lawyer and lifelong advocate for civil liberties, died July 2, 2016 in New York after a fierce fight with lengthy illness. He was 67. Son of Leo and Sylvia Sabel Robbins, Albert earned a B.A. and M.A. in American history at Temple University in his native Philadelphia, where he was an editor for The Drummer, a counterculture weekly. He moved to New York as associate editor at Harper's Magazine Company. He then went on to become executive editor of the ACLU Civil Liberties Review, publications director of the Educational Fund for Individual Rights, and managing editor of the National Law Journal. A graduate of Fordham Law School, he joined the New York law firm of Cahill, Gordon, and Reindel, litigating First Amendment issues and the scientific aspects of early asbestos cases. He returned to the Law Journal as General Counsel and associate publisher/editor of Law Technology Product News, collaborating on the first systems to manage court documents on the Internet. A passionate force for workers' and immigrants' rights, Albert authored "Coming to America, Immigrants From Northern Europe" (Delacorte, 1981) and co-authored "The Watergate File" (Flash Books, 1973); "Getting Angry Six Days a Week" (Beacon, 1979) and "Whistle-Blowing" (McGraw-Hill, 1978). He was a member of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, represented individuals seeking asylum in the US, and was secretary of the Committee on Immigration Law of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. In his retirement, he pursued his passion for collecting by selling rare books. Friends and loved ones will remember Albert for his encyclopedic intellect, sharp sense of humor, and appreciation for 1940s music. He is survived by his beloved partner, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Nancy Hershey Lord; his cherished children Laura Robbins, Charlie Robbins, and Alix Comeau; his treasured granddaughter Natalie Robbins; and two brothers. His dear wife, Amy Comeau, predeceased him. Services Wednesday, July 6 at 10:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. Burial at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Donations: the Perlmutter Cancer Center or the ACLU. 1/3

HOULIHAN--Kathrene "Kate" (nee Blish), of Chicago, IL; New Rochelle, Crestwood, and Bronxville, NY died July 2 at home surrounded by family. She was 96. She and Dan, her husband of 53 years raised nine children in love and faith: Kathie (Jim), Rita, Dorothy (Marcel), Daniel (Marie), Joe (Anna), Mark (Amy), Barbara (Bill), Gerry (Maureen) and Liz (Ralph). A graduate of Maplehurst Convent of the Sacred Heart (1937) and Manhattanville College (1941), she served on the board of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, Greenwich. Her faith and intellectual curiosity sparked many interests - American History, art, opera, embroidery, travel, baseball, and French cooking. Her legendary dinner parties were a key ingredient of Dan's and his partners' (James G. Houlihan and Howard Parnes) business, Houlihan-Parnes Realtors. Longtime parishioner of Annunciation Parish 1949-1999 (Crestwood, NY) she joined St. Joseph's in 1999. The Houlihans generously supported Catholic education. Kate is survived by 19 grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren, many nieces and nephews, her brother-in-law, Joe and his wife June (Northbrook, IL), five cousins, and her longtime nurse and friend Grace Sendras. Kate was predeceased by her husband, her brother (Syl) and sisters (Sally, Marie, Betsy) and sisters-in-law (Rita Anne, Janet). A woman of deep faith, Kate guided her family to "always do something worthwhile" and "to be good to everybody." Calling Hours at Fred H. McGrath's, Bronxville, July 5, 6-9; July 6, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, July 7, 9:45am. In lieu of flowers please contribute to Annunciation School, Crestwood, NY or The Pregnancy Care Center, New Rochelle, NY. 1/3

RUBEN--Lawrence. On July 3, 2016, Lawrence Ruben, a longtime member of the Board of Overseers of Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School, passed away at the age of 90. He is survived by his wife, Jan; his children Richard, Lenore, Shelley and Amy; and nine grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. He was Chairman of Ruben Companies, an organization renowned worldwide for its work in real estate investment, development and management. When Larry came on the Board of Cardozo, it was a fledgling law school. His vision and openhearted generosity were significant in setting Cardozo on its trajectory of excellence. We are deeply grateful. May his family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President, Norman Lamm, President Emeritus Melanie Leslie, Dean of the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law 1/3

GODLEY--Frederick A.,Jr. November 23, 1919 -- June 30, 2016. Born in Rye, New York, on November 23, 1919, Fred graduated from The Hotchkiss School in 1938 and later served on the board of trustees. He graduated from Yale in 1942 after an interruption to serve in the U.S. Navy during World War II. As a Naval Reserve Ensign, he was attached to the destroyer, USS Quick where he served for four and a half years as a Top Gunnery Officer. After service, he graduated from the Scheffield School of Engineering and began working at PerkinElmer. He then started the Continental Manufacturing Valve Company, later renamed Xomox, with his friend and co-founder, Lawson Reed. With his interest in medicine, Fred went on to spin-off Xomed, a biomedical application of the high temperature valve technology. Outside of his vocational pursuits, Fred was the head of the building committee of the Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Connecticut where he served on the vestry for many years, was a founding member of The Eaglesmere Conservancy, and with his wife, Mary, he founded the Godley House in Rutland, Vermont as a residential transitional house for Spring Lake Ranch, a mental health rehabilitation facility. Fred was predeceased by his daughter Margaretta Godly, is survived by his three children, Mac Godley, Rick Godley and Betsy Godley Spence and by his wife, Mary, to whom he was married for 75 years. Please visit our online Tribute at www.quinn-shalz.com. Services under the care and direction of Quinn-Shalz Family Funeral Home, Jacksonville Beach, FL. 1/3

BETTENCOURT--Anthony. Anthony James Bettencourt Jr. passed away early on Saturday morning, July 2, 2016, after a brave and courageous battle with cancer and an ailing heart. He was gentle, kind and loving--for all of his days. He was a warrior and always positive throughout his illness. Anthony was born in Niles, California and graduated from Washington High School in Fremont, CA. He was a Vietnam Veteran, serving early in the Navy. He worked hard all of his life as a laborer, doing great harm to his body to provide well for his family. In his retirement, he became an accomplished wood worker and happily attended to his rose garden. His greatest joy came from his wife of 57 years and his four granddaughters, with whom he was smitten. Anthony is survived by his loving wife, Sydney; devoted son Anthony of Pleasanton CA, and grandchildren, Jessica Bettencourt of New York City, NY, Candace Bettencourt of San Francisco, CA, Ashley Bettencourt of San Francisco, CA, and Tory Bettencourt of Boston, MA. He is also survived by his sisters, Patricia Rehrig of Milpitas, CA, and Doreen Ellsworth of Monrovia, CA. His generous spirit will be missed by all that knew him. Friends and family are invited to funeral services on Thursday July 7, 2016 at 11:00am at Graham-Hitch Mortuary, 4167 First Street, Pleasanton, CA 94566. Burial to follow at Irvington Memorial Cemetery in Fremont. 1/3

Lawrence leaves behind a legacy of exceptional philanthropic commitment and a family who will carry on a tradition of Jewish philanthropy. EDSALL--John Rupert, died Saturday, July 2, 2016 at the age of 91. He is mourned by Peggy, his beloved wife of sixty years, his children, Mary Agnes, Margaret Mary, John Francis, and Thomas More. He was predeceased by his daughter, Anne Marie. Born in London, John studied medicine at Downing College, Cambridge, and Kings College Hospital, London. In 1954 he qualified as a pulmonologist and moved to New York, taking up residencies at Bellevue and Roosevelt Hospitals. He started in practice at Roosevelt but was eventually appointed Clinical Professor of Medicine in the Chest Division at Columbia Presbyterian, where he ended his career. In 1999 he was honored by the founding of the John Edsall-John Wood Asthma Center. The visitation is Wednesday, 6 July from 6-8pm at Chas. Peter Nagel, 352 E. 87th Street. His funeral mass will be celebrated Thursday, 7 July, at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, 404 E. 87th Street. Donations may be made in his name to the Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70th St., New York, NY 10021. 1/3

LUBOW--Joyce S. Passed away peacefully at home. Very beloved wife of 60 years to Nathan M. Lubow, adoring mother of Andrew M. Lubow and Susan M. Russak, Idolized grandmother of Shai Russak, Tali Lev, Yaniv Russak and Sarah E. Lubow, loving great-grandmother of Leo Lev. Avid world traveler and devoted educator of special needs children. Services to be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on July 7, 2016 at 11am. 1/3

GUTTERMAN--Shirley. The Gutterman Family, The Board of Directors and all the Employees of Gutterman's Funeral Home and Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel mourn the loss of our Esteemed and Beloved Mother and CEO. She was a very strong willed woman who was never afraid to speak her mind or help someone in need. She was a female pioneer in the nursing profession for over 40 years before becoming involved in the funeral industry. She was instrumental in growing the company to what it has become today, one of the largest family owned and operating Jewish Funeral Homes in the country. Her dedication to her job, patients and family were second to none. She will always be remembered for her quick wit, great memory, class and generosity. She cared so very much about everyone and was truly interested in everything that her family and friends were involved with. She will be greatly missed and remembered every day by all who had the privilege to know her and love her. Rest in Peace. Services Thursday, July 7, 12 noon at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. There will be a memorial service in Florida at a later date. 1/3

STIEFEL--Maurice B. on July 3, 2016. Beloved husband of Miriam Goldman, and the late Marcia Stiefel. Devoted father of Judith, Susan, and Michael. Loving stepfather of Fred, James, and William. Dear stepbrother of Richard and Eleanor. Proud grandfather of six. Maurie practiced intellectual property law for over forty years, founding his own firm which subsequently merged with Bryan Cave. An avid reader, sailor, chess player, with strong interests in psychology and music, he was active in retirement. Maurie taught and took courses at various institutions. He will be deeply missed. A celebration of his life will be held in the fall. Contributions in his memory can be made to Death with Dignity. 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York mourns the loss of Elie Wiesel. A cherished friend and a man of impeccable integrity and conscience, he spoke out at many of our important events, vigils, rallies and demonstrations for justice, human rights, and peace. As a witness to and survivor of the Holocaust, Elie's haunting and poignant books and other writings gave voice to the murdered six million Jewish victims. Although the author of "The Jews of Silence" has now been silenced, his precious legacy of remembrance for all victims of indifference carries forward. May his wife Marion and son Elisha be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Charles S. Temel, President Michael S. Miller, Exec VP and CEO 1/3

MARSHALL--Louis, age 93, died in his home in Houston, TX on July 5, 2016. He was born in Manhattan, NY November 22, 1922, the third child of Bessie and Max Marshall. He was raised in Brooklyn, NY. He completed his B.S. in Chemical Engineering at City College of New York in 1944 with highest honors. At CCNY he served as president of the student chapter of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers and as treasurer of the Tau Beta Pi chapter (the honorary fraternity for engineering). Lou had two extraordinary passions, engineering and family. Lou approached engineering with an abiding curiosity that drove him to unravel phenomena that many would not even notice. He had a methodical attention to detail - careful analysis of multiple possibilities - and a keen awareness of how a given plant design could go wrong. As a chemical engineer, he initially worked as a plant operator for Shell Oil, but moved to a position with Lummus Engineering in 1950 to focus on petrochemical plant design, his passion. He remained with Lummus for 35 years, where he became known as the "Engineer's Engineer." His colleagues looked to Lou as a trouble shooter who could determine the source of problems and devise solutions. At his retirement dinner, a younger colleague said that he learned more about engineering from Lou Marshall than from his entire university training. Early on, Lou recognized the power of the digital computer to transform the practice of chemical engineering. He pioneered some of the first uses of linear programming to optimize petrochemical plant operation, and did initial work applying nonlinear programming to similar problems. After retiring from Lummus in 1986, he continued an extensive consulting practice applying linear optimization techniques to petrochemical plant operation. Lou's other great passion was his family. In 1945 he married his best friend and college sweetheart, Faith Gladstone. Their 71 years of marriage were an inspiration to all who knew them. In addition to being survived by Faith, Lou is also survived by their two children, Ellen Ruth Marshall, attorney in Orange County, CA (Robert Arnold, attorney), and David Aaron Marshall, economist in Chicago, IL (Maija Freimanis, physician) and their two grandchildren, Astrid Carla Marshall, medical student in Manhattan, NY (Jefferson Li, business student) and Max Benjamin Marshall, jazz pianist in New York. Lou served as a role model for his children and grandchildren, encouraging a passion for science and math, and conveying his deep love of music, photography, and woodworking. In a letter to his children on the occasion of his 90th birthday, he wrote, "If Mom and I have been examples to you in the way we have lived our lives, then I am doubly satisfied." The family acknowledges with special gratitude the loving care provided by Catalina Alvarez in recent years. The funeral will be held Friday, July 8, 2016 at 11am at the Proler Family Chapel at Beth Israel Memorial Gardens Cemetery, 1101 Antoine, Houston, TX. The family requests that any remembrances be made as memorial contributions to Congregation Beth Israel, Houston, TX, or to an educational or charitable organization of your choice. 1/3

LEVINE--Joy M.,on July 5, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Izzy. Loving mother of David Levine, Carol and Jeffrey Goldberg. Cherished grandmother of Samantha, Justin and Susie. Devoted great-grandmother of Julian, Emily, Sophie, and Ivy. Adored sister of Gerald and Delores Michael and Helen Levine. 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The 92nd Street Y Board, staff and community mourn the passing of Elie Wiesel, one of the world's most important humanitarian voices and an unwavering champion for memory and justice. For almost half a century, Elie Wiesel graced us with his teachings. We could not be more honored to have been his students. We offer our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Marion and his entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. 1/3

O'HEARN--Walter D. Jr.,of New York and Southampton, NY died peacefully on July 5th. He was 81. A devoted family man, Walter leaves his beloved wife of 53 years, Denise, and his three daughters, Meghan Benedict (Douglas), Kelly Evans (Jeffrey), and Mary Harris (Richard). He is also survived by his three sisters, Eileen O'Hearn, Neill Miller and Julie Taminiau and his brother, Peter O'Hearn. He is also survived by his seven grandchildren. Walter graduated from Portsmouth Priory, Williams College, New York Law School and New York University Graduate School of Law. He began his career with King and O'Conor, a law firm in New York. He became President of McGrath Services Corporation. He then became a partner in Keane Securities, which later merged into Rafferty Capital Markets. Walter was a member of the Bathing Corporation of Southampton, the Meadow Club of Southampton, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club and the Lost Tree Club in North Palm Beach. His family will receive friends at the O'Connell Funeral Home, Southampton, NY on Friday, July 8th from 3pm to 6pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said in celebration of his life at the Basilica Church of Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary, Southampton, NY on Saturday, July 9th at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his name to Wiener Family Palliative Care Unit at Mt. Sinai Hospital, NY. 1/3

EDSALL--John Rupert, died Saturday, July 2, 2016 at the age of 91. He is mourned by Peggy, his beloved wife of sixty years, his children, Mary Agnes, Margaret Mary, John Francis, and Thomas More. He was predeceased by his daughter, Anne Marie. Born in London, John studied medicine at Downing College, Cambridge, and Kings College Hospital, London. In 1954 he qualified as a pulmonologist and moved to New York, taking up residencies at Bellevue and Roosevelt Hospitals. He started in practice at Roosevelt but was eventually appointed Clinical Professor of Medicine in the Chest Division at Columbia Presbyterian, where he ended his career. In 1999 he was honored by the founding of the John Edsall-John Wood Asthma Center. The visitation is Wednesday, 6 July from 6-8pm at Chas. Peter Nagel, 352 E. 87th Street. His funeral mass will be celebrated Thursday, 7 July, at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, 404 E. 87th Street. Donations may be made in his name to the Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70th St., New York, NY 10021. 1/3
WIESEL--Elie. SSEJ mourns its honorary president Elie Wiesel and Ethiopian Jews grieve the loss of a compassionate champion. 1/3

ANDREADIS--Michelle, passed away on July 2, 2016. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Davide. Dear daughter of Marisa and Barry Tenzer. Niece of Diane (Michael) Schachter. Sister-in-law of Eleni Andreadis and Charles Lambiotte. Rest in peace.
