DUGGAL--Baldev. The Passing of a Visionary New York Businessman. Baldev Duggal (August 17, 1937 - June 29, 2016), a visionary entrepreneur, who over five decades built several iconic NYC businesses, including Duggal Visual Solutions and The Duggal Greenhouse, passed away peacefully in his sleep early last Wednesday morning, only days after an advance celebration of his upcoming 79th birthday with his family. Duggal was a proud New Yorker and a living manifestation of the American Dream. An immigrant, he came to the United States by himself from India in 1957 with only $200 in his pocket and managed to translate his last name into a global brand in the arts, graphics and media world. Made in India: In 1947, in Duggal's formative years, India won its independence. During the struggles that preceded independence, his father, Biasdev Duggal, an insurance manager, was imprisoned as a local leader for peaceful resistance to British rule. As a boy, Duggal learned a powerful lesson on the power of individuals to make change against the odds. The Land of Opportunity: Duggal arrived in New York Harbor in 1957, alone and with $200 in his pocket to start his new life. Coming from a then small village in India, far from being intimidated by the size and vibrancy of New York City he was energized by it. It began a lifetime love affair with the city he lived in until his death. He managed to get work in photo print shops and as a cameraman for famed NYC television correspondent Gabe Pressman. Whatever barriers existed for young 'third-world' immigrants in the 1950s, he simply couldn't afford to be hindered by them. It wasn't long before he started his own business, Duggal Color Projects. He was hand developing film in a bathtub in a basement apartment in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Soon the legends like Marcel Duchamp, Bert Stern, and Richard Avedon were giving him jobs. His lab was the go-to place for artists in the 1960s. One of his favorite anecdotes of those days was when Andy Warhol's studio once offered to pay him in-kind with original paintings, but he declined as he needed the cash for his struggling small business. The new challenge for Duggal became how to scale his business. Hand-processing film was slow and tedious but was far superior to the automated processes of the day which yielded dull whites. He knew there could be something better and he invented a revolutionary process for film development, the "dip-and-dunk" machine, that combined the quality of hand processing with the efficiency and consistency of a mechanical process. This marriage of art and science would be something he would repeat and be known for throughout his life. Vision, Timing and Tenacity: By 1970, his business had grown so much he needed more space. Seeking lower real estate prices, he moved to a 12-story building in Chelsea that he later purchased, in an area that later became 'The Photo District', as other labs and camera shops opened around him to share in the market Duggal was building. At this point, Duggal Color Projects had already expanded into a comprehensive film processing, printing and finishing company that could handle a wide range of jobs for photographers, advertising firms, museums, and corporations. To stay on top, Duggal kept innovating and adding new services for his burgeoning clientele. In the 1980s Duggal saw the potential for Digital services to transform the industry, and he pioneered early electronic retouching services and became the first commercial lab to feature drum scanning technology. While that business took a long time to grow, his early investments gave him a head start and experience no one else had. In the last decades, while many others, including Kodak, failed to make the transition to Digital, Duggal was already an established industry leader with a litany of pioneering firsts. Along the way, Duggal had to ride out many economic downturns, 9/11 and Hurricane Sandy. Events that would take him and his Company to the brink, but he embodied the toughness New Yorkers are famous for and kept coming back stronger. Today Duggal Visual Solutions, Inc. employs over 350 dedicated employees and boasts over 250,000 square feet of production space in New York City. Green Fields: Never one to stand still, in his 70s, Duggal began to start other businesses. Notably 'The Duggal Greenhouse', formerly a dilapidated warehouse at the Brooklyn Navy Yard he had rehabilitated with an eco-friendly design, and transformed into the pre-eminent event space in New York. The huge, column free space with tremendous views of the New York City skyline has attracted the likes of Beyonce, Nike, Christian Dior and CNN, which recently hosted a Democratic Party Debate at the facility. Duggal's interest in Green Technology as both an opportunity and a way to make a positive impact led him to start Lumisolair. The Man: Baldev Duggal was an upbeat charismatic man, always scanning the horizon for what came next. He took on each day with boundless energy and an optimism, which challenged individuals and teams to achieve more than they believed possible. His dreams found their ideal home in New York City, a place that allowed him to experiment without restraint and bring together his love for art and science into a platform that fundamentally transformed how artists and marketers would communicate with the world. Baldev Duggal is survived by his three children Sue, Dave and Michael and eight grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother Sukhdev Duggal. 1/3

RAFFA--Connie. Connie A. Raffa, beloved wife of Raymond T. Schmidt and a pre-eminent health care lawyer in New York, died July 7, 2016 following a battle with cancer. She was 67. Connie spent nearly four decades practicing law, first in the New York Office of Prosecution for Special Narcotics under Hon. Sterling Johnson, Jr. from 1973 to 1976, as New York County Assistant District Attorney from 1978 to 1980 under Robert Morgenthau, and a United States government lawyer. A dedicated public servant, Connie worked for the US Department of Health and Human Services for 15 years as a senior trial attorney and assistant regional counsel in the agency's Office of General Counsel. She represented HHS before federal district and appeals courts and in administrative hearings. As a prosecutor, Connie was appointed special assistant US attorney in the Eastern, Southern, and Northern Districts of New York and the District of Puerto Rico. She joined Arent Fox LLP in 1995 and founded its New York Health Care group, advising home health agencies, hospices, physician groups, state health associations, and palliative care programs on regulatory and reimbursement issues, fraud and abuse investigations, and sanctions. An advocate and leader for the palliative care and hospice communities, Connie worked tirelessly to raise money for those organizations, while providing vital pro bono legal advice. Connie received many awards, including a Certificate of Achievement from the United States Congress, served on the Board of Trustees and the Governance, Managed Care, and Palliative Care Committees of the Hospice and Palliative Care Association of New York for which she also was Counsel, and on the Regulatory and Public Policy Committees of the National Hospice and Palliative Care Organization. Beyond her professional accomplishments, Connie loved to study clowning and performed for nonprofits to help raise money. Connie was also a former member of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Chorus. Fluent in Sicilian, she enjoyed hiking, biking, visiting national parks and lighthouses, bird watching, photography, and scrabble. Forever a Beatles fan, Connie kept Paul McCartney's autograph from a brief meeting in the lobby of the Plaza Hotel and attended the band's iconic concert at Shea Stadium. Connie's parents, Anna and Dominick Raffa, raised three children, Connie, Lucretia and Anthony in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn. She is survived by her husband, Raymond, her beloved brother Anthony, his wife Martine, their daughter Emilie, her husband Johan and their children Dillon and Jake. She will be deeply missed and cherished by all whose lives she touched. Services will be held at: Westchester Funeral Home, Inc., 190 Main St., Eastchester, NY. 914-337-4585 www.westchesterfuneralhome.com. Visiting hours will be from 2pm - 4pm and 7pm - 9pm on Saturday, July 9 and Sunday, July 10. Funeral Mass to be held on Monday, July 11, 2016, 9:30am at: Immaculate Conception & Assumption of Our Lady Church, 53 Winter Hill Rd., Tuckahoe, NY 10707. assumption-immaculate.org. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Connie's memory to the American Cancer Society or Hospice Care Network. 1/3

CHERBULIEZ--Theodore, formerly of Scarsdale, Dr. Cherbuliez died July 2 at home in South Freeport, ME. Born in Geneva, Switzerland, he came to the US for psychoanalytic training in 1959. Psychiatrist with Albert Einstein College of Medicine; Montefiore Hospital; Cornell Medical School, Westchester, and in private practice for 53 years. In Geneva, consulted annually since 1974 with clinicians on innovative approaches to child welfare. Master Beekeeper, past President of American Apitherapy Society and Apimondia Apitherapy Commission. A consummate Swiss, his passions included mountain climbing, piloting, recorder playing, baking bread, and caring for generations of cats. Survived by his adored wife of 56 years Susan; sister Isaline (Geneva); daughters Ariane (Steven Orzack, Nora; Cambridge, MA); Nicole (Seth Clayter, Isabel, Lauren; Portland, ME); Lisa (John Terry, Eloise, Madeline, Charlotte; Needham, MA); Diana (Vinalhaven, ME); and Juliette (Matthias Rothe, Lucie and father Michael Opperman; Minneapolis, MN). Donations in his honor may be given to Doctors Without Borders, or The Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3

REISMAN--Marvin. It is with great sorrow that we announce the passing of Marvin Reisman at the age of 87 at West Boca Medical Center on July 3, 2016. Marvin, loving husband of 61 years to Sally Reisman. Cherished father and father-in-law of Marci and Michael Pomerantz and Allison and Peter Menkes. Devoted grandfather of Michaelan and Zhak Cohen, Sean and Sunny Menkes, Matthew, Jack, and Lianne Menkes. Marvin was formerly of Armonk, NY, and Manhattan. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on November 10, 1928 to Samuel and Anna Reisman. He graduated from Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School and became a founding partner of the law firm of Budin, Reisman, Kupserberg, and Bernstein. Marvin leaves a legacy of family love and respect, and the joy of living life to its fullest. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, July 10th, at 11am at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Ave., Valhalla, NY 10595. POWERS--Peter J.,former First Deputy Mayor of New York City, died this morning (July 7, 2016) at age 72, after a long and valiant fight against cancer. Peter served as the First Deputy Mayor of the City from 1994 to 1996. He is widely credited with initiating and leading the reform of the City under the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. He was also Mayor Giuliani's campaign manager, most important political advisor, and life-long closest friend. Peter James Powers was born in Queens, NY on April 9, 1944 to Thomas and Florence Powers. Peter's dad was Delegate/Organizer for the Retail Clerks' Union. Although Peter came from a union background, he described himself and was a Goldwater Republican and a very proud one. Peter graduated from Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in 1961, Manhattan College in 1965 and New York University Law School in 1968. He also earned an LL.M in taxation from N.Y.U. Law School and he was a Certified Public Accountant. He practiced tax law in New York City for many years before he began his involvement in politics. He was one of the foremost tax lawyers and had a thriving practice, when he left to take over Mayor Giuliani's 1989 run for Mayor at a time of real difficulties. He and Roger Ailes, then Mayor Giuliani's political consultant, are widely credited with guiding the campaign to a landslide victory in the Republican primary and, after beginning the general election run 29% behind, brought the campaign to within 2% of victory. Peter, this time teaming with David Garth, led Mayor Giuliani's campaign to a 2% victory in 1993. The victory was all the more remarkable because it was the largest percentage a Republican had received since Mayor LaGuardia. Peter's organization of a much more effective ground game is considered the difference that led to victory. After Peter Powers left City Hall he remained a close political advisor to Mayor Giuliani and his close friend and, later on, a very trusted business advisor. They handled a number of legal and business engagements together. Peter formed Powers Global Strategies. Through that company he and his partner -- later his wife -- Sylvia Ng, advised many multi-national corporations on government -relations matters. Peter was one of the most sought after consultants in the country. He also served on too many boards to list but, most notably, the boards of Fox Entertainment Group, Manhattan College, and Mutual of America Life Insurance, GFI Corporation, and the Partnership for New York City. He also served as Chairman and Director of Giuliani LLC and as Chairman of the New York City Public Initiatives Corporation. Mayor Giuliani said, "Peter Powers is one of the main reasons New York City is such a great city today. Without him my administration could not have achieved the reforms and the Bloomberg administration could not have continued and improved on them. He was a great leader, my most important advisor and my friend for 58 years. Everyone in our city owes a debt of gratitude to Peter and today we lost a great American. Judith and I lost a beloved friend, and I lost a brother." Peter died surrounded by his wife Sylvia, who hadn't left his side during his six week hospitalization, and his loving family. He is survived by his wife, soul-mate, and business partner, Sylvia Ng, his daughters Heather McBride and Krista Harvey, daughters from his previous marriage to Kathleen Ingrassia, his grandchildren Eve, Catalina, Luke and Patrick, his sons-in-law, with whom he had a very close relationship, Scott McBride and Jeff Harvey and two older brothers Don and Jack. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC, NY on Saturday, July 9th and Sunday, July 10th, 2pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Monday, July 11 at 10 am. Peter asked that anyone wanting to make a contribution send it to Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School or Manhattan College. 1/3

MACLEOD--Whitney Burnett. The Trustees and staff of myFace, formerly the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, and the staff and patients at the Wyss Department of Plastic Surgery at NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Whitney Burnett MacLeod. In her thirteen years as Executive Director of the foundation, she so generously provided her passion and energy to secure the success of our mission to provide comprehensive cutting edge surgical care and treatment to our patients with facial difference. The Foundation's activities grew enormously under her leadership. She directed a capital campaign that built a new administrative suite for the Foundation, a state of the art clinical facility to serve our patients and their families and the Bogert Plastic Surgery Learning Center. She also raised funds to establish two endowed professorships for the Wyss Department of Plastic Surgery. She truly epitomized the "can do" spirit. Whitney's warm smile and engaging personality drew supporters to our cause. Her kindness and generosity were boundless. She was a loyal and steadfast friend to everyone who knew her. Whitney will always remain in our hearts and in those of the thousands of patients whose lives were changed because of her efforts. We express our deepest sympathy to her children McCaleb Burnett, Philip Voss and Jeremy Voss. 1/3

GRAHAM--John Lawrence, passed away on July 5, 2016, having succumbed to the ravages of ALS, with which he struggled for the past two years. He died as he lived his life: on his own terms, surrounded by family and friends, and with a slight grin on his face as he savored the memories of a life well lived. John is survived by his two sons, JW and Rome, of New York City, whom he loved eternally and unconditionally; his mother Barbara Graham Williams of Houston, Texas; his father Jack Graham, of Austin, Texas; his sister Mary Margaret Graham and her wife Sheree Adams of Austin, Texas, who dedicated themselves to supporting John and his boys through this terrible disease and as his life came to a close; and his former wife and the mother of his boys, Michelle Gauthier of New York City. He is also survived by hundreds of friends and colleagues who will miss his quick wit, his hearty laugh and his unfiltered and unapologetic observations on life and the myriad circumstances in which we all find ourselves. The only thing that surpassed John's generosity was his loyalty; and if you were fortunate enough to get into his circle, you soon came to understand that you would never leave it. He will be deeply, deeply missed by all of us, but never forgotten. John was born on October 10, 1962, and grew up in Houston, Texas, where he attended The Kinkaid School and excelled at debate and was a multisport athlete. Following high school, John attended Princeton University, where he will forever be remembered for having founded one of the first Greek fraternities at Princeton in the modern era, the Princeton chapter of Sigma Alpha Epsilon. John was immensely proud of having founded the SAE chapter and to this day, his fraternity brothers remain among his most cherished and loyal friends. After graduating from Princeton with honors, John went to law school at the University of Texas at Austin where he earned his J.D., cum laude. John practiced law for 28 years; first with Baker Botts in Houston, Texas, and New York City; then with King & Spalding in New York City; and ultimately with Clifford Chance in both Abu Dhabi and New York City. He was a highly regarded and accomplished attorney, who focused on mergers, acquisitions and divestitures principally in the telecom and media sectors. John lived in the Tribeca neighborhood for much of the last 15 years, and he could often be found in the bar area of his beloved Wolfgang's sharing a steak dinner with his boys or his friends. Frequently, John presided over late afternoon weekend lunches at Felix on West Broadway, which were the stuff of legend and often extended until the early evening. He traveled extensively throughout his life, spearheading annual guys trips that took John and his cast of characters throughout Europe, including numerous trips to the Greek islands, the Caribbean, Mexico and Central America, Brazil, Africa and the Middle East. His antics and appetite for fun earned him the eternal moniker "the Crowd Pleaser." John spent his summers over the past twenty years in the Hamptons where he enjoyed fishing on his boat and relaxing with family and friends on the beach in Amagansett. It was within sight of this beach he loved that he gave his final breath and said goodbye. At John's request, there will not be a public service. A private wake will be scheduled at a future date. Those wishing to make a gift in his memory are asked to make a contribution to The ALS Association Greater New York Chapter, 42 Broadway, Suite 1724, New York, NY 10004. als-ny.org. 1/3

BROWN--Roscoe. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of esteemed educator and WWII hero Dr. Roscoe Brown. Roscoe will be remembered as an educational leader in New York and as a member of the famed Tuskegee Airmen, where he was a former squadron commander of the 100th Fighter Squadron of the 332nd Fighter Group. Roscoe served as a WCS Trustee from 1990-2000 and became an Honorary Trustee in 2000. WCS is grateful for his support and commitment to conservation. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Roscoe's family, friends, and colleagues. 1/3

SCHNEIDER--Charles, 85, of Sarasota, FL, formerly of New York, passed away on July 7, 2016. He is survived by his wife, Sandra, son, Jeff Schneider and his wife Caroline, two grandchildren, Andrew and Marc Schneider. He will live forever in our hearts. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, July 10th at 12:00 noon at Toale Brothers Funeral Home, Colonial Chapel, 40 N. Orange Ave., Sarasota. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations in his memory be made to Tidewell Hospice, Sarasota. 1/3

ZICHLINSKY--Elliott, passed peacefully in his daughter's home in Portland, Oregon on July 6. His wife, Lisette pre-deceased him. Elliott is survived by his son, Murray, daughter, Marlene, daughter-in-law, Cathy, and two grandchildren, Alder and Juliah. Funeral Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, New York, Sunday, July 10, at 9:30am. 1/3

KOHAN--Dr. Silviu, born in Bucharest, Romania on August 14, 1928 to Leon and Ernestina Kohan, Dr. Silviu Kohan was a loving husband and dedicated father. He married Simona Schor on December 26, 1951 and the couple had two children, Dodis and Darius. After many years of living under Communist rule, Dr. Kohan and his family left Romania to begin life in the United States. Having practiced medicine in Romania, Dr. Kohan was accepted to New York University Medical Center for a residency program in obstetrics and gynecology. After completing his residency program, Dr. Kohan began working in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at New York University Medical Center where he became a full professor. Dr. Kohan is accredited with bringing the colposcopy procedure, identifying the size and location of suspicious lesions through a magnifier to prevent cervical cancer, to New York University Medical Center more than 40 years ago. Dr. Kohan was a proud member of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology for many years. He retired at the age of 80 years old. The epitome of a doting grandfather, Dr. Kohan had the pleasure of seeing his three granddaughters, Jaqueline, Lauren, and Corinne, graduate from college. His greatest joy was spoiling these three special girls. The proud father of two physicians, Dr. Kohan enjoyed watching his son's follow in his footsteps to become successful doctors - Dodis is an obstetrician and gynecologist on Long Island, Darius is an otolaryngologist and neurotologist is Manhattan. Influenced by the love of his life, his wife and retired dentist, Simona, Dr. Kohan was the quintessential father and grandfather. Dr. Kohan's interests were not limited to the medical field. He was known as a prolific reader and European and American History expert. He was in essence a living encyclopedia of historical facts and dates. Dr. Kohan is survived by his wife, Simona, two sons, Dodis and Darius, daughter-in-law Ingrid, son-in-law Joseph, and three granddaughters Jacqueline, Lauren, and Corinne. Chapel Service Sunday, July 10, 9:30am at the Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" 1076 Madison Ave., (at 81st Street), NYC. 1/3

POWERS--Peter J.,former First Deputy Mayor of New York City, died this morning (July 7, 2016) at age 72, after a long and valiant fight against cancer. Peter served as the First Deputy Mayor of the City from 1994 to 1996. He is widely credited with initiating and leading the reform of the City under the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. He was also Mayor Giuliani's campaign manager, most important political advisor, and life-long closest friend. Peter James Powers was born in Queens, NY on April 9, 1944 to Thomas and Florence Powers. Peter's dad was Delegate/Organizer for the Retail Clerks' Union. Although Peter came from a union background, he described himself and was a Goldwater Republican and a very proud one. Peter graduated from Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in 1961, Manhattan College in 1965 and New York University Law School in 1968. He also earned an LL.M in taxation from N.Y.U. Law School and he was a Certified Public Accountant. He practiced tax law in New York City for many years before he began his involvement in politics. He was one of the foremost tax lawyers and had a thriving practice, when he left to take over Mayor Giuliani's 1989 run for Mayor at a time of real difficulties. He and Roger Ailes, then Mayor Giuliani's political consultant, are widely credited with guiding the campaign to a landslide victory in the Republican primary and, after beginning the general election run 29% behind, brought the campaign to within 2% of victory. Peter, this time teaming with David Garth, led Mayor Giuliani's campaign to a 2% victory in 1993. The victory was all the more remarkable because it was the largest percentage a Republican had received since Mayor LaGuardia. Peter's organization of a much more effective ground game is considered the difference that led to victory. After Peter Powers left City Hall he remained a close political advisor to Mayor Giuliani and his close friend and, later on, a very trusted business advisor. They handled a number of legal and business engagements together. Peter formed Powers Global Strategies. Through that company he and his partner -- later his wife -- Sylvia Ng, advised many multi-national corporations on government -relations matters. Peter was one of the most sought after consultants in the country. He also served on too many boards to list but, most notably, the boards of Fox Entertainment Group, Manhattan College, and Mutual of America Life Insurance, GFI Corporation, and the Partnership for New York City. He also served as Chairman and Director of Giuliani LLC and as Chairman of the New York City Public Initiatives Corporation. Mayor Giuliani said, "Peter Powers is one of the main reasons New York City is such a great city today. Without him my administration could not have achieved the reforms and the Bloomberg administration could not have continued and improved on them. He was a great leader, my most important advisor and my friend for 58 years. Everyone in our city owes a debt of gratitude to Peter and today we lost a great American. Judith and I lost a beloved friend, and I lost a brother." Peter died surrounded by his wife Sylvia, who hadn't left his side during his six week hospitalization, and his loving family. He is survived by his wife, soul-mate, and business partner, Sylvia Ng, his daughters Heather McBride and Krista Harvey, daughters from his previous marriage to Kathleen Ingrassia, his grandchildren Eve, Catalina, Luke and Patrick, his sons-in-law, with whom he had a very close relationship, Scott McBride and Jeff Harvey and two older brothers Don and Jack. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC, NY on Saturday, July 9th and Sunday, July 10th, 2pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Monday, July 11 at 10 am. Peter asked that anyone wanting to make a contribution send it to Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School or Manhattan College. 1/3

LIPSON--Norman, passed peacefully at his home in Sarasota, Florida on July 7 at age 88. Beloved husband of Linda for 28 years, he had two wonderful marriages. His first wife, Charlotte (Shai), passed away in 1988. Devoted father of Eileen Lipson, and June and Michael Cohen, loving grandfather of Paul and Ceci Sirota, Amy and Aaron Katz, Nikki Cohen, and Stephanie Cohen. Adored great grandfather of Tyler, Jake, Dylan, Aria and Nash. He will be remembered for his kindness, jokes, and loving manner. Private services will be held in Sarasota. 1/3

CHERBULIEZ--Theodore, formerly of Scarsdale, Dr. Cherbuliez died July 2 at home in South Freeport, ME. Born in Geneva, Switzerland, he came to the US for psychoanalytic training in 1959. Psychiatrist with Albert Einstein College of Medicine; Montefiore Hospital; Cornell Medical School, Westchester, and in private practice for 53 years. In Geneva, consulted annually since 1974 with clinicians on innovative approaches to child welfare. Master Beekeeper, past President of American Apitherapy Society and Apimondia Apitherapy Commission. A consummate Swiss, his passions included mountain climbing, piloting, recorder playing, baking bread, and caring for generations of cats. Survived by his adored wife of 56 years Susan; sister Isaline (Geneva); daughters Ariane (Steven Orzack, Nora; Cambridge, MA); Nicole (Seth Clayter, Isabel, Lauren; Portland, ME); Lisa (John Terry, Eloise, Madeline, Charlotte; Needham, MA); Diana (Vinalhaven, ME); and Juliette (Matthias Rothe, Lucie and father Michael Opperman; Minneapolis, MN). Donations in his honor may be given to Doctors Without Borders, or The Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3

MAXMAN--Bobbi, passed away suddenly on July 7th after 83 wonderful years. Beloved husband of the late Al; father of Joel (Sherri) and Ron (Helen); grandfather of Andrew, Elizabeth, Nicole, Sophie and Julia. Lived life to the fullest. Dedicated teacher and life-long learner. Theater and bridge devotee. She will be deeply missed. Services Sunday 11:00am; Plaza Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

KUCKENS--John H.,Jr. (Jack), of Sarasota, Florida, formerly of Rockville Centre and East Rockaway, NY, died on June 28, 2016 at home surrounded by his loving family. Jack was predeceased by his wife of 67 years, Loreen E. Kuckens. He is survived by his four children Candace DiPietro (Robert), John H. Kuckens III (Katherine), Craig A. Kuckens (Patricia), Karen Gogarty, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Jack attended Long Island's Lynbrook High School followed by one year at Cortland State Teacher's College prior to joining the army in 1943. He advanced to Second Lieutenant in the Third Division Army Infantry after Officer's Training, was stationed in the European Theatre. Jack was awarded the Bronze Star for valor in 1945 after leading his company in the capture of hundreds of German soldiers. After marrying Loreen in August 1946, Jack resumed his college career at Hofstra University, graduating with a B.S. in Accounting. He joined Price Waterhouse & Co., in 1949 as a junior auditor and rose through the ranks of the firm, eventually becoming a partner in 1968. As head of Personnel for the New York office, Jack, a CPA, identified and mentored many accounting professionals, recruited at various colleges and helped shape the organization's policies during a period of great change. Jack and Loreen were members of Bethany Congregational Church of East Rockaway, Long Island and The First Congregational Church of Sarasota. As an avid golfer, Jack was a member of the Rockville Links Country Club of Long Island, the Mountain Manor Golf Association in the Poconos, Florida's Sara Bay Country Club and the Bird Key Yacht Club. Jack received the George M. Eastabrook Award for Distinguished Service in 1977 from Hofstra's Alumni Association. Jack can be best remembered by making a donation to the Veterans of Foreign Wars or the Multiple Sclerosis Society. 1/3

HARRIS--Douglas James, died early in the morning of June 30, 2016, succumbing to complications during treatment for Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Doug was a lifelong New Yorker, having been born in Yonkers and enjoying the last 16 years of his life in Rye. He was employed by IBM for close to 40 years, rising to the level of Managing Director in the Global Financial Services Sector of the company. He is survived by his wife of 27 years, Darby, and his two daughters, Elizabeth and Caroline. His sister Diane and his mother Shirley, both in Texas, also survive him. Memorial tributes may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, NY. 1/3

RUBEN--Lawrence. September 28, 1926 - July 3, 2016. Cherished husband of Jan Ruben and the late Selma Ruben. Beloved father of Richard, Lenore, and Shelly and father-in-law of Howard Kivell and Amy Ruben. Adored grandfather of Tamara, Danielle, William, Andrew, Melissa, Robert, James, Allison and Caroline, and great-grandfather of Blake, Sasha, Jonah, and Owen. As Chairman of Ruben Companies, he helped shape the skyline of New York City. Life Overseer of Weill Cornell Medicine, and Honorary Overseer of Cardozo School of Law. His love and passion for his family, his work, and his city will be missed. Funeral services will be Tuesday, July 5, 12pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Donations in his memory may be made to Weill Cornell Medicine. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Geraldine C. Died on June 23, 2016, at age 93. A trailblazer for women in science, Jerry earned a PhD in physical chemistry from Columbia in 1948, was a post-doctoral fellow at Sloan Kettering, and had a research career at IBM in thin films for semiconductor interconnections, receiving more than a dozen patents. She was one of the early women senior engineers at IBM and the first woman elected a Fellow of The Electrochemical Society. She grew up in Brooklyn and lived in Poughkeepsie for almost 60 years. Her husband, Robert S. Schwartz, died in 1964. They met as chemistry students at Brooklyn College and married after graduating in 1943. Jerry was known as a fine cook, and enjoyed tennis, classical music, and reading - especially mystery novels. She is survived by daughters Anne M. Schwartz and Frances Wheeler, sons-in-law Daniel Levitan and Tobin Wheeler, and grandchildren Rebecca and Abe Levitan and Gus and Archer Wheeler. 1/3

BURNS--Edward Eliot, Jr.,aged 80, passed peacefully on July 3, 2016 in York, ME. A retired financial advisor, devoted husband, father and grandfather. Graduate of Deerfield Academy, Dartmouth and Tuck School of Business. Lieutenant for the United States Coast Guard. Joined First Boston Corporation, then Mitchell Hutchins/ Paine Webber. Married Windy Reid, 1979. Partner, Stover Haley Burns, Inc. Survived by his wife, Windy; two sons from first marriage, Ned Burns, wife Jennifer Burns, children Erik and Charlie Burns; and Christopher Burns, wife Gina Nagy-Burns. 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the loss of Elie Wiesel, Holocaust survivor and memory keeper of the victims of Nazi persecution who used his moral authority as a Nobel Laureate to focus attention on global atrocities and the plight of refugees. He was a longtime supporter of the IRC, an organization founded in 1933 to aid victims of the Nazis, joining the IRC Board in 1985 and the IRC Overseers in 2004. Before joining the IRC Board, Mr. Wiesel was a member of the IRC's Citizens Commission on Indochinese Refugees--a group whose advocacy work helped lead to the passing of the U.S. Refugee Act of 1980. In 1980, Commission members visited a Cambodian refugee camp, where Mr. Wiesel explained, "I came here because nobody came when I was there. One thing that is worse for the victim than hunger, fear, torture, is the feeling of abandonment, the feeling that nobody cares, the feeling that you don't count." In 1987, the IRC honored Mr. Wiesel with the Freedom Award, presented by Liv Ullmann, for his "extraordinary service to humanity, freedom and the cause of refugees." We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. International Rescue Committee Katherine Farley and Tracy R. Wolstencroft, Co-Chairs of the Board; Timothy Geithner Chair, IRC Overseers; David Miliband, President 1/3
GOLLUSCIO--Edward, died July 10, 2015. Beloved brother, brother-in-law, uncle. Sorely missed every day. The Moracho Family. 1/3

CHERBULIEZ--Theodore, formerly of Scarsdale, Dr. Cherbuliez died July 2 at home in South Freeport, ME. Born in Geneva, Switzerland, he came to the US for psychoanalytic training in 1959. Psychiatrist with Albert Einstein College of Medicine; Montefiore Hospital; Cornell Medical School, Westchester, and in private practice for 53 years. In Geneva, consulted annually since 1974 with clinicians on innovative approaches to child welfare. Master Beekeeper, past President of American Apitherapy Society and Apimondia Apitherapy Commission. A consummate Swiss, his passions included mountain climbing, piloting, recorder playing, baking bread, and caring for generations of cats. Survived by his adored wife of 56 years Susan; sister Isaline (Geneva); daughters Ariane (Steven Orzack, Nora; Cambridge, MA); Nicole (Seth Clayter, Isabel, Lauren; Portland, ME); Lisa (John Terry, Eloise, Madeline, Charlotte; Needham, MA); Diana (Vinalhaven, ME); and Juliette (Matthias Rothe, Lucie and father Michael Opperman; Minneapolis, MN). Donations in his honor may be given to Doctors Without Borders, or The Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3

FARRINGTON--Sylvia Stark. Flight attendant turned book indexer, lover of dachshunds, raspberries, jazz, theater and all things New York, Sylvia Stark Farrington died June 30 while hospitalized near her summer home in Center Harbor, New Hampshire. Born in Santa Clara, Cuba, November 16, 1926, to an American father and Cuban mother, she joined Pan American in its glory days to see the world. While airborne she met the love of her life-- whom she noticed because he was reading D.H. Lawrence--and with whom she traveled widely. Africa was a favorite destination. She is survived by her pilot husband, Robert "Bob" Farrington, extended family in Texas and Florida, and a wide circle of friends who will miss her keen intelligence, dry wit and loving embrace. 1/3

LADKA--Wendy June, May 30, 1954 - July 3, 2016 She had been a resident of Long Beach, NY. She leaves behind her mother, Dorothy Ladka, nephew Christopher Ladka and brother, Kerry Ladka as well as her partner, Patrick Dunworth. Words cannot express the depth of our sorrow. 1/3

LUBOW--Joyce S. Passed away peacefully at home. Very beloved wife of 60 years to Nathan M. Lubow, adoring mother of Andrew M. Lubow and Susan M. Russak, Idolized grandmother of Shai Russak, Tali Lev, Yaniv Russak and Sarah E. Lubow, loving great-grandmother of Leo Lev. Avid world traveler and devoted educator of special needs children. Services to be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on July 7, 2016 at 11am. 1/3
MacMANNIS--Sally Blake, of New Canaan, CT, formerly of Darien, CT, July 2, 1925- July 5, 2016. 1/3

GRAYSON--Richard M. March 25, 1941 - July 3, 2016. Richard Grayson was a pianist, composer, teacher and improviser extraordinaire. Yamaha and the Showa Conservatory of music repeatedly invited him to Japan, where he gave lectures, concerts, and seminars on classical and jazz improvisation. His last concert was at Los Angeles County Museum of Art in May of this year. He passed away after a long illness. He was born in Brooklyn, New York, grew up in North Hollywood, CA, and graduated from Van Nuys High School. He earned a Bachelor of Arts from UCLA, Master of Arts from Chicago University, and his Ph.D. in composition from UCLA. He was a professor of music at Occidental College, until his retirement in 2000. He was then invited to teach music theory and composition at Crossroads School in Santa Monica, where he remained until June of this year. He lived in Santa Monica for over 40 years with his wife of 46 years, Dr. Susan Grayson. He was highly respected and liked by his colleagues, and his students adored and challenged him, to their mutual delight. He leaves behind his beloved wife, Dr. Susan Grayson; sister, Florence Ginsburg; brother, Robert Grayson; nephew, Bret Ginsburg; loving cousins, extended family and friends. The date for a memorial gathering to honor Dr. Grayson is yet to be determined. 1/3

WILSON--Philip D.,Jr., M.D., died peacefully at home on June 29, 2016. He was 96. A man of unbounded wit and charm, Dr. Wilson possessed a warmth of character and caring for others that deeply endeared him to patients, colleagues, friends and family alike. Dr. Wilson was born in 1920 in Boston. His father was a prominent surgeon, his mother a native of France and the daughter of well-known French actress and comedienne, Rejane. His parents met in Paris during World War I. The second of three, Philip and his siblings often travelled to France with their mother on summer holiday. A graduate of the Kent School, "Ox" Wilson rowed on the varsity heavyweight crew that won the Thames Challenge Cup at Henley in 1938. Dr. Wilson's collegiate career started as a member of the Harvard class of 1942, but the onset of the Second World War led him to an accelerated MD program at Columbia. Although he will no longer take his daily walk in Central Park, Dr. Wilson is responsible for thousands who still can. He was a pivotal figure in the development and improvement of total hip replacement in the United States. Under his stewardship as Surgeon in Chief from 1972 to 1989, the Hospital For Special Surgery attained international prominence as a leading center of orthopedic care, research and clinical training. In an era when medical practice grew increasingly fast-paced, Dr. Wilson is universally lauded for maintaining a primary emphasis on the personal and human side of patient care. Leisure time often found him on the tennis court or golf course with his beloved late wife of 42 years, Katherine S. Wilson, who died in 2005. Nowhere were his recreational talents more readily apparent, however, than on the water, where the love of sailing he discovered cruising the coast of New England in his youth continued into his last years. Dr. Wilson will long be remembered for his immense love of family, his compassion, intelligence, wisdom, unassuming charm and limitless generosity. He is survived by two daughters, Lucy Watson, Elizabeth Watson and her husband Marc Sydorak, and two sons, David and his wife Janet, and Patrick and his wife Nina. He was preceded in death by his daughter Nicole Beebe and son William Watson. Philip leaves nine grandchildren, Mercy Watson, Brooke Noble, Peter Beebe, Erica and Matthew Wilson, and Gardner, Katherine, Harrison and Leverett Wilson; and two great-grandchildren Callie and Taylor Noble. A celebration of his life will be held in New York City this autumn. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Hospital for Special Surgery, 535 East 70th St., New York, NY 10021. 1/3

COGAN--Rev. William B.,S.J., on July 8, 2016. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NYon Monday 3-5pm and 7-8:30pm. Funeral Mass at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, Tuesday, 11:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Northeast Province of the Society of Jesus, 39 E. 83rd St., NY, NY 10028, For information contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors (718) 654-0500. 1/3

WIESEL--Elie: The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. His writing bears witness to the horrific capabilities of man, and powerfully advocates for human dignity and tolerance. 1

EDSALL--John R. Columbia University Medical Center and NewYork- Presbyterian celebrate the life and mourn the passing of John R. Edsall, M.D., longtime pulmonologist and Clinical Professor of Medicine. His talent, expertise and compassion will long be remembered by his patients, by those who benefited from his tutelage, and from those fortunate to have known him as a colleague and friend. The John Edsall-John Wood Asthma Center in the Division of Pulmonary, Allergy and Critical Care Medicine serves as an apt and enduring tribute to his life and work. We offer our condolences to his wife, Peggy; his children; and the extended Edsall family. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine, Chief Executive, Columbia University Medical Center Steven J. Corwin, M.D. President and CEO, NewYork-Presbyterian 1/3
FRIEDBERG BLUME--Elinor 1970-2011. Fascinating daughter, wondrous gardener, admired dancer, teacher, designer, pianist, potter, writer, producer, loving wife. I will remember you always. Mom. 1/3

BROWN--Roscoe. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of esteemed educator and WWII hero Dr. Roscoe Brown. Roscoe will be remembered as an educational leader in New York and as a member of the famed Tuskegee Airmen, where he was a former squadron commander of the 100th Fighter Squadron of the 332nd Fighter Group. Roscoe served as a WCS Trustee from 1990-2000 and became an Honorary Trustee in 2000. WCS is grateful for his support and commitment to conservation. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Roscoe's family, friends, and colleagues. 1/3

WARWICK--John Petersen, passed away of natural causes on June 26th, 2016 at the age of 90. John was a devoted and loving husband of 53 years to his wife, Janet, and a dedicated father to Brian of Larchmont, NY and to Jennifer of Shelburne, VT. John was always present for his family and devoted his heart and soul to ensure his 'family first' commitment. John served as a mentor to his grandchildren, nieces, nephews, cousins, friends and business associates offering sound advice and extraordinary generosity. This was the essence of his spirit. Born in New Rochelle, NY, John served three years in the US Navy during World War II. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1948. A New York City resident, John spent most of his professional career in New York's advertising business from the 1960's - 1980's. John dedicated 42 years of his life building one of New York's most prominent advertising agencies that was originally started under the name, Warwick & Legler in 1939. The name was later changed to Warwick Advertising, and finally, Warwick, Baker, O'Neill. John served as Chairman and CEO for 33 years and retired in 1991. With over 250 employees at their height in their New York City office, and 75 in their European offices, Warwick became an internationally recognized agency with offices in Paris, London, Frankfurt & Brussels. "Warwick Advertising" as it was commonly known, was considered a creative pioneer and, under John's stewardship, was responsible for many highly successful and noteworthy advertising campaigns. Some of the agency's clients included, Timex, Seagram's, Revlon, Pfizer, Mennen, Bausch & Lomb, Benjamin Moore, US Tobacco, Fruit of the Loom, Burlington Industries, Schering-Plough, Air Canada, Schaefer, Heineken and Amstel Light beers, Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield, and Sterling Drug. Warwick Advertising was a member of the Alliance International partnership of independent agencies that serviced clients with international needs. John also believed strongly in using the agency's talents to engage in Pro Bono and public service work. The Joseph E. Seagram & Sons company entrusted Warwick with some of their most prized brands such as 7 Crown, VO, Extra Dry Gin, Crown Royal Whisky and others for over 46 years. Warwick Advertising also enjoyed a multi-decade relationship with United States Tobacco. John served on the Board of AAAA; "Association of American Advertising Agencies" for two terms. His main interests included golf and American History. John is survived by his wife Janet, his children; Brian and Jennifer, his grandchildren Julia, Eric, Sydney and Kathryn; his sister Mary Lou Eaton, his first cousin Douglas Warwick and several nieces and nephews. In 1990, John was afflicted with a rare form of Peripheral Neuropathy. He became one of the founders of the "Neuropathy Association" based in New York City in efforts to understand and research this condition and achieve greater public and professional awareness which later merged with The Foundation for Peripheral Neuropathy. In memory of John, donations are welcome at The Foundation for Peripheral Neuropathy. www.foundationforpn.org. 1/3

BERNSTEIN--Alison R.,graduated from Vassar College summa cum laude with a B.A. in history in 1969. She was named to the Board of Trustees at age 22, the youngest person ever to hold that position. The then President Simpson noted on her appointment: "If anyone can mediate between hairy youth and hoary age, it is Alison Bernstein." Following Vassar, Alison entered a Ph.D. program in history at Columbia University. In 1974, while working on her dissertation on federal policy and Native Americans, Alison took a position with the Fund for the Improvement of Post-Secondary Education [FIPSE] in the US Department of Education. This launched her into a career in education and educational policy. In 1983, Alison joined the Ford Foundation, first as program officer and later as Vice President for Knowledge, Creativity and Freedom. At Ford, Alison became a leader in higher education and a voice for justice across the globe. She was the architect of countless initiatives that promoted a higher quality of education for diverse and marginalized populations. Alison was a vibrant presence; fostering the talents of others and encouraging bold programming pursuits and innovative thinking. Over the course of her life, Alison wrote and co-wrote five books on topics ranging from difference and diversity in South Africa and the United States to the role of philanthropy in higher education. In 2011, after a year at Spelman College, Alison became Director of the Rutgers' Institute for Women's Leadership where she focused particularly on Women and Health and Women, Media and Technology. Alison spent the last years of her life spearheading a campaign to endow the Gloria Steinem Chair in Media, Culture and Feminist Studies. Alison had a recognized jaunty and ebullient style; in moments of passionate conviction, she would wave her eyeglasses, usually perched atop her head. She adored her twins, Emma and Julia and instilled in them both her social justice values and also her unflagging love of life. Alison knew how to throw a party and organized her friends to travel with her. She cultivated a wide range of interests, from musical theater and romantic comedies to book clubs and bird watching. Alison was curious, perceptive and ferociously intelligent, adding a zest for life to every group she joined. She died on June 30th of cancer in her home surrounded by the love of her dog, friends, partner, and daughters. She is survived by her daughters Emma Brown-Bernstein, a public defender in Atlanta and Julia Brown-Bernstein, a public school history teacher in Los Angeles, and her partner Professor Johanna Schoen of Rutgers University. Anyone wishing to make a charitable gift in her honor should give to the Gloria Steinem Endowed Chair at Rutgers University. Checks should be made out to Rutgers University Foundation, noting the gift is for the Gloria Steinem Endowed Chair, c/o Lisa Hetfield, IWL, 162 Ryders Lane, New Brunswick NJ, 08901. 1/3

ANDREADIS--Michelle, passed away on July 2, 2016. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Davide. Dear daughter of Marisa and Barry Tenzer. Granddaughter of the late Honorable Herbert and Florence Tenzer. Sister of Stephen Tenzer and the late Maria Tenzer. Daughterin-law of the late Barbara and John Andreadis. Niece of Diane (Michael) Schachter. Sister-in-law of Eleni Andreadis and Charles Lambiotte. Rest in peace. 1/3

TONER--Tom, Tom died one year ago at age 87 from complications of lung cancer. His road to Broadway began in the theater of the Carnegie Library, Homestead, PA, where, from the wings, Tom watched his big sister Vernie perform. As part of the "Greenfield Gang" at Central Catholic High School in Pittsburgh, Tom acted, put on shows, and made lifelong friends. He worked ore boats on the Great Lakes, served in Japan with the US Army, graduated from UCLA, and launched his professional acting career. Swept into the growing regional theater movement, Tom performed all over the country, and was a long time company member at the Alley Theater, Arena Stage and Old Globe. Even as a young actor, his strong talent, plus expertise at make up and wigs brought Tom plum character roles. His special treat was playing the maid or maiden aunt, then thrilling audiences with his curtain call "reveal." Tom moved to New York, performed in plays on and off Broadway (notably, A Texas Trilogy, The Good Doctor, The Elephant Man), appeared in film (including multiple Coen Brothers movies) and TV. Then, to his great delight, found himself reborn in middle-age as a "Song and Dance Man!," continuing his career in Broadway musicals, including The Secret Garden, Me and My Girl, and Ragtime. Tom was known for his ability to bring acting companies together, but as a consummate storyteller, he sometimes caused fellow actors to linger too long, and race from the Green Room, barely making their entrance. He loved walking to work from his Manhattan Plaza home, or watching the glow of Times Square and Broadway from the "tropical retreat" of his balcony. If "all the world's a stage," Tom designed the set for his own world, magically magnifying his tiny apartment to suit his vision. The fifth of nine children, Tom grew up in a rambunctious, joy-filled, Irish family. His eccentric, free spirit will be forever celebrated by his remaining siblings, Betty Jean, Mary Alice, and Bob, dozens of loving nieces and nephews, his cherished confidants, friends and colleagues. His ashes are at St Mary's Cemetery, Munhall, PA, with Mother and Pop, and part of the sidewalk sparkle at 42nd Street. Please share stories at Legacy.com. 1/3

ZERVOUDAKIS--Ioannis A.,M.D., a distinguished and widely-respected obstetrician and gynecologist, passed away peacefully at his home in Manhattan on July 8, 2016. He was surrounded by his family. Dr. Zervoudakis was an Associate Attending Obstetrician and Gynecologist at New York-Presbyterian Hospital and an Associate Professor of Clinical Obstetrics and Gynecology at Weill Cornell Medical College. Dr. Zervoudakis practiced and taught at Weill Cornell since 1971, except for the period of 1979-1991 in which he returned to Athens, Greece, to teach and practice at the Alexandra Hospital and LITO Maternity Hospital. Dr. Zervoudakis earned his Medical Degree from the University of Athens in 1963 and his Ph.D. from the National University of Athens Faculty of Medicine. After obtaining his degrees, he completed his military service as a doctor in the Greek Navy. His post- doctoral training included an internship at Coney Island Hospital, a residency and the position of Chief Resident at The New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical Center, and a Fellowship in Maternal and Fetal Medicine at Cornell University Medical College. He was born on June 17, 1943, in Greece to his parents, Dr. Andreas Zervoudakis, also an obstetrician and gynecologist, and Aliki Zervoudakis (born Papaleonardou). He devoted his life to his family and the practice of medicine and estimated that he delivered over 20,000 babies during his career. Dr. Zervoudakis specialized in high-risk obstetrics and his research lead to the development of new techniques in treating uterine fibroids. He was a pioneer of the "fetus as patient" concept. He was a two-time Lalor Foundation Fellow and grant recipient from the National Institute of Health. Dr. Zervoudakis adored classical music and was a gourmet chef. He was a true gourmand and an extraordinarily generous and kind man. He enjoyed spending time with this wife, his children and his grandchildren. In his youth he was a well-respected scout leader of the Scouts of Greece or Soma Hellinon Proskopon. Dr. Zervoudakis was a member of the Hellenic Medical Society of New York, and served on the Board of Trustees of the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity. Dr. Zervoudakis is survived by his wife of nearly 46 years Rallou, his daughters Alice, Christina and Laura, sons-in- law Jim and Adam, grandchildren Natalie, John (his namesake), Alexander and Andreas, all of Manhattan, his sister Sophia Gouras and his nephews Andreas and Konstantinos Gouras, of Athens, Greece. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Ave on Monday, July 11, 2016, from 2:00-4:00pm and 6:00-9:00pm. Funeral services on Tuesday, July 12, 2016, at Holy Trinity Cathedral at 319 East 74th Street at 11:00am, with the repast Makaria luncheon to follow. Memorial donations may be made in Dr. Zervoudakis' memory to the Hellenic Medical Society of New York at (718) 398-2440 and to Dr. Howard I. Scher's prostate cancer research at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (646) 227-3546. 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. The 92nd Street Y Board, staff and community mourn the passing of Elie Wiesel, one of the world's most important humanitarian voices and an unwavering champion for memory and justice. For almost half a century, Elie Wiesel graced us with his teachings. We could not be more honored to have been his students. We offer our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Marion and his entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. 1/3

SERGI--Frances B. After a long, joyful and distinguished life, Frances Barbieri Sergi passed away on June 26, 2016. She was born July 31, 1919 in New York City to Theresa LaGumina Barbieri and Frank Barbieri, both of whom were born in Italy. Frances was raised in Queens, New York and was an honors graduate of Richmond Hill High School, Hunter College and New York University. She played a piano recital at Carnegie Hall in 1933, worked at the 1939 World's Fair and helped ship tanks from New York to Europe during WW II. Frances was predeceased by her parents, her beloved sister Eleanor, and her loving husband of 55 years, Rocco J. Sergi. She leaves her two devoted sons and their spouses, Vincent A.F. Sergi and Debbie (Chicago), Theodore S. Sergi and Barbara (West Hartford, CT), four treasured grandsons: Nicholas and spouse Jennifer Mabary (San Antonio), Gregory (Los Angeles), Justin (New York City) and Julian (Hollywood) and one very wonderful great-granddaughter, Carolyn Marcella Sergi (San Antonio). Frances was one of the greatest school teachers of modern history; elected as the first recipient of the Kew Forest School Hall of Fame in 2004 after 40+ years of teaching fourth grade. Her teaching of reading, writing, math, the multiplication tables, nature (bird projects), the arts, and thesis-like projects for 10-year-olds is legendary. She has been described by her former students as "stern but loving, tough but fair, demanding but praising" with a "no-nonsense classroom atmosphere that demanded that one must respect all others." Her philosophy was always one of "You can do it." The Sergi family would like all her former students to know that she was as great a mom and grandma as she was a teacher. At age 81 she retired from teaching and joined the Kew Forest School Development Office, working until age 88 cajoling her former pupils into making contributions. Frances loved music of all kinds: classical, opera, Frank Sinatra and The Mills Brothers. She was passionate about musical theater and made costumes for school play productions for decades. She loved history and her visits with Rocco to America's great historical sites. And she was proud of her hometown of New York City, its excitement and its international sounds and flavors. She also believed in the curative powers of witch hazel. Frances made a lasting impression on everyone she met, making everyone around her feel included and happy. Frances was devoted to the Church of the Resurrection, Richmond Hill and St. Luke's Church, Forest Hills, and served both in many capacities. Frances was very thankful to the devoted staff of The McAuley and St. Mary Home, West Hartford, CT. where she spent the last eight good years of her 97. Her last five years were especially joyful thanks to her faithful assistants Carmen Baig, Raenette Bowens and Ruth Daley. Mom, we are doing our best in your absence. We will remember to throw cold water on our faces and get back to working hard and helping others, just like you did. Ci vediamo, Nonna. A celebration of Frances' life will be held in Forest Hills and Richmond Hill, NY in October. Memorial contributions may be made to the Kew Forest School, 119-17 Union Turnpike, Forest Hills, NY 11375. Condolences may be sent to The Sergi family at 11 Castlewood Rd., West Hartford, CT 06107. Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, West Hartford has care of services. 1/3

SEERY--Carol Ranney, 88, on July 7. Graduated College of St. Rose, 1949 and received masters degree from Boston College. Nuclear engineer and co-author of Reactor Shielding Design Manual (1956), math teacher, hospital volunteer. Survived by husband Jim, children Florie, Jimmy and Michael, sister Mary Aileen and grandchildren Grace, Maggie, Lucy, Seamus, Owen, Angela, Alasdair and Kate. Funeral July 14, 11am at Church of the Epiphany, 375 2nd Ave. Memorial contribution may be made to: Camphillfoundation.org. 1/3

LIPSON--Norman, passed peacefully at his home in Sarasota, Florida on July 7 at age 88. Beloved husband of Linda for 28 years, he had two wonderful marriages. His first wife, Charlotte (Shai), passed away in 1988. Devoted father of Eileen Lipson, and June and Michael Cohen, loving grandfather of Paul and Ceci Sirota, Amy and Aaron Katz, Nikki Cohen, and Stephanie Cohen. Adored great grandfather of Tyler, Jake, Dylan, Aria and Nash. He will be remembered for his kindness, jokes, and loving manner. Private services will be held in Sarasota. 1/3

SAXE--Robert L. Scientist and businessman Bob Saxe was considered to be the father of the smart window industry. He passed away at age 81 on June 29, 2016, and is survived by his brother Stephen O. Saxe. Bob was married for 34 years to Marie Posner Saxe, an apparel industry executive who passed away in 2008. Robert Saxe started Research Frontiers Inc. over 50 years ago, and is the principal inventor on many of its patents. Under his leadership, the company achieved world-wide recognition as the premier developer of SPD-Smart light control technology currently licensed to over 40 companies, including most of the world's automotive glass producers. It is used in automobiles, aircraft, yachts, homes and offices, and museums, and was prominently featured at the most recent World's Fair in Milan. At the time of his death, Mr. Saxe was Research Frontiers' Chairman of the Board and Chief Technology Officer Mr. Saxe's published work on the nature of light allows scientists to derive several key fundamental constants used by physicists. He graduated from Harvard College in 1956 with an A.B. degree, Cum Laude in General Studies (with a major in physics) and received an M.B.A. degree from Harvard Business School in 1960. His technology makes cars, homes, offices, and aircraft more energy efficient, comfortable, and safer. Bob Saxe took great pride in the benefits that his SPD-SmartGlass technology brought to many industries, and the way it improved people's lives. A Memorial Service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue in Manhattan on July 13, 2016 at 6:00pm. 1/3

EDELSON--Phyllis Fahrie. Age 78, passed away in New York City on July 2, 2016, at home with her beloved husband of 60 years Dr. Stuart R. Edelson. The daughter of the late Bertha Cohen and Murray Fahrie, Phyllis Merle Fahrie was born on October 25, 1937 in the Bronx, New York. After receiving her Ph.D. in English from the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, Phyllis devoted her life to teaching. She was Professor and Chair of the Department of English and Communications at Pace University in Westchester County; she worked as a teacher of high school teachers, consulting widely in New York City and Westchester; and she was an expert in Australian literature, editing a book of Australian stories and serving as an editor of Antipodes magazine. After her retirement from Pace, Phyllis dedicated herself to working on her own creative writing, and then in recent years was a docent at the Morgan Library & Museum in New York City. Phyllis' life was filled with her intellectual and academic pursuits and her love of family, the opera, and the ocean. In addition to her husband, Phyllis is survived by her sons Maurice, Andrew and Glenn Fahrie Edelson, daughters-in-law Jennifer Altman and Natalia Goncharov, and grandchildren Rachel, Benjamin, Nathaniel, Ammie and Jesse. Services were on Monday, July4th. 1/3

POWERS--Peter J. The Board of Directors of Mutual of America Life Insurance Company, together with its officers and employees, mourn the passing of Peter J. Powers, an esteemed member of the Board of Directors since 2006. Mr. Powers served with distinction on the Law and Corporate Governance and Nominating Committees and was appointed Chair of the Nominating Committee in 2010. Peter Powers founded Powers Global Strategies LLC, a government relations and strategic consulting firm in New York and Washington, D.C. and served as its Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. He had a long and distinguished career as an attorney, Certified Public Accountant, consultant and public servant and served as First Deputy Mayor of the City of New York under Rudolph Giuliani from 1994 to 1996. Highly respected in his field, Mr. Powers served on the boards of numerous civic and charitable organizations including the Partnership for New York City and the United Hospital Fund and was recently elected Secretary of the Council of Governing Boards, a statewide advocacy group for private colleges and universities. Mr. Powers' sound judgment, integrity and wise counsel have been invaluable to Mutual of America and have greatly contributed to its success. We who were privileged to have known him will gratefully remember his unassuming manner, dedication to service and sincere commitment to professional excellence. His wisdom and friendship will be greatly missed. While we mourn his passing, we greatly admire the manner in which he lived his life. Peter Powers, our friend and colleague, will be remembered with profound respect and affection. Thomas J. Moran Chairman of the Board John R. Greed President and Chief Executive Officer Mutual of America Life Insurance Company 1/3

CHANLER--Harvey, a fine graphic artist and basketball standout at Forest Hills High School, passed away on Friday, July 1, in New Canaan, CT. He was 87. Harvey was born in New York City, a few months before the start of the Great Depression, to immigrant parents who fled eastern Europe for the United States. At Forest Hills, he competed for the league's scoring championship with Hall of Famer, Bob Cousy. He pursued his creative talents and enrolled at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. Harvey worked in advertising for some of the country's largest consumer companies such as Swingline Stapler and English Leather. At MEM Co, he served as Senior Vice President for Advertising. His creative mind led to numerous inventions such as soap on a rope, stories told on bubble bath paper washcloths and dramatic recordings of Bible Stories. Mr. Chanler also helped start the first international facsimile service in the 1970s. Harvey maintained a great sense of humor throughout his life. He enjoyed performing card tricks and became known as The Wizard for one of his most memorable tricks. Harvey is survived by his children, Ann of New York, NY, Bill of Atlanta, GA and Cliff of New Canaan, CT, their mother, Carole Chanler, and six beautiful grandchildren, Alex and Kaya (Scheman), Casey, Liliana, Cole and Catalina. He is also survived by three nieces, Patricia Doniger, Beryl Title and Polly Feiner, daughters of recording artist Arlene Title, his only sibling, and his beloved cousin Fred Wendrow. Contributions can be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation pdf.org. 1/3

LUBOW--Joyce. The Board of Directors of 465 WEA Owners Corp., and the shareholders, staff, and management of 465 West End Avenue, are deeply saddened by the passing of Joyce Lubow, the beloved wife of our Board member for the past 34 years, Nathan Lubow. Cherished mother of Susie and Andrew, adored grandmother and great-grandmother; an interested and concerned neighbor and friend. We will sorely miss her and extend our deepest sympathy to the entire family at this difficult time. 1/3

LIEBMANN--Lisa Isabel, born in 1955, passed peacefully at home on June 30. Daughter of the late Herman Liebmann and Loraine Pack Liebmann. Lisa was a respected art critic and writer often with her husband Brooks Adams who survives her as does their daughter Jane Juno and her mother. A light has gone out and Lisa will be forever missed. 1/3
SCULLY--Dorothy, died June 18th, 2016. Wife of James A. (Al) Scully. For more info go to: www.norwalkfh.com 1/3
BERNSTEIN--Alison R. We mourn the loss of the inspiring and entertaining head counselor at Camp Bernstein. Her bereft campers 1/3

WOODYATT--Lois Hoxie, November 3, 1915 - July 4, 2016. She was married to Philip Crandon Woodyatt. She worked all her life at the Dalton School, the Anne Andrews Employment Agency, as personal assistant to Dr. Benjamin Spock, at the National Academy of Design and at the Cooper Hewitt Design Museum. Her favorite was working in radio news during the war. Lois was a world traveler and the beloved friend of many, a wide community of admirers whose lives were enriched by her wisdom and biting wit. Her stories were better than anyone's but when she talked to you, it was about you, never herself. Her daughters, Rolly and Rachel; her son-in-law Emilio; her grandchildren, William, Abigail, Catherine, and Alessia; her grand-son-in-law, Felice; and her great-grandchildren Gabriele and Anna join all her friends in thanking her for sharing her wonderful life with us. 1/3

CUTLER--Wallace M.,formerly of New York City, died on July 3rd at age 93. He had a career as a sound engineer in the sound and motion picture industry and received an Emmy award. He was a member of Local 52 and the NYRC, The Melrose Chapter. He is survived by his son, Edward and locally his niece, Jacqueline Braunthal. Burial is private. Donations can be made to the New York Roadrunner's Club, Melrose Chapter and Local 52-Sound and Motion Picture Union. 1/3

SLATER--Selma Terner. We mourn the passing of our beloved aunt Selma who will live on in the hearts and minds of all who loved her. To cousins Michael and Rick Weber we offer our heartfelt sympathy. May her memory be a source of blessing, inspiration, and her soul be bound up in the bond of life. Our love forever, Vivian Mook Baer and Stephen Baer, RoseMarie Mook, Alex Maia, Shannon Mook, Nick, Stacy and Danielle Mook 1/3

MAXMAN--Bobbi, passed away suddenly on July 7th after 83 wonderful years. Beloved wife of the late Al; mother of Joel (Sherri) and Ron (Helen); grandmother of Andrew, Elizabeth, Nicole, Sophie and Julia. Lived life to the fullest. Dedicated teacher and life-long learner. Theater and bridge devotee. She will be deeply missed. Services Sunday 11:00am; Plaza Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

POWERS--Peter J. The board and staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the loss of this extraordinary man and good friend, who provided wise counsel and strategic leadership for more than a decade as a valued member of our board and as the deeply respected chairman of our budget, audit, and operations committee. His careful stewardship was matched by his steadfast commitment to UHF's mission and the imperative of investing in new ideas and programs to build a more effective health care system for every New Yorker. He has left a strong imprint on our city and UHF, and will be greatly missed. J. Barclay Collins II Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr. President 1/3

KOHAN--Dr. Silviu, born in Bucharest, Romania on August 14, 1928 to Leon and Ernestina Kohan, Dr. Silviu Kohan was a loving husband and dedicated father. He married Simona Schor on December 26, 1951 and the couple had two children, Dodis and Darius. After many years of living under Communist rule, Dr. Kohan and his family left Romania to begin life in the United States. Having practiced medicine in Romania, Dr. Kohan was accepted to New York University Medical Center for a residency program in obstetrics and gynecology. After completing his residency program, Dr. Kohan began working in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at New York University Medical Center where he became a full professor. Dr. Kohan is accredited with bringing the colposcopy procedure, identifying the size and location of suspicious lesions through a magnifier to prevent cervical cancer, to New York University Medical Center more than 40 years ago. Dr. Kohan was a proud member of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology for many years. He retired at the age of 80 years old. The epitome of a doting grandfather, Dr. Kohan had the pleasure of seeing his three granddaughters, Jaqueline, Lauren, and Corinne, graduate from college. His greatest joy was spoiling these three special girls. The proud father of two physicians, Dr. Kohan enjoyed watching his son's follow in his footsteps to become successful doctors - Dodis is an obstetrician and gynecologist on Long Island, Darius is an otolaryngologist and neurotologist is Manhattan. Influenced by the love of his life, his wife and retired dentist, Simona, Dr. Kohan was the quintessential father and grandfather. Dr. Kohan's interests were not limited to the medical field. He was known as a prolific reader and European and American History expert. He was in essence a living encyclopedia of historical facts and dates. Dr. Kohan is survived by his wife, Simona, two sons, Dodis and Darius, daughter-in-law Ingrid, son-in-law Joseph, and three granddaughters Jacqueline, Lauren, and Corinne. Chapel Service Sunday, July 10, 9:30am at the Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" 1076 Madison Ave., (at 81st Street), NYC. 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. S'iz gefaln a demb - we have lost a great man. The League for Yiddish mourns the passing of Eliezer Wiesel, our honorary Board member. His first book, "Un di velt hot geshvign", was published in his native Yiddish, and its adaptation into the volume "Night" introduced him to the wider world. May his support for our cause - Yiddish - inspire others. Sheva Zucker, Exec. Dir., and Gitl Schaechter- Viswanath, Chair leagueforyiddish.org 1/3

Beachy and meWritten and illustrated by Bob Staake. 32 pp. Random House. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6)
 
Living alone in a “dinky” lighthouse on a tiny island, little Pixie Picklespeare is understandably bored. But her luck changes when Beachy, a gigantic blue whale, washes ashore. They ride waves and swim in caves. Too bad he splits at summer’s end (“He had to migrate once a year / to be with other whales,” of course). Staake (“The Red Lemon”) serves up easy rhymes and bright digital art like a custard cone with rainbow sprinkles, and a sunny final twist: Next year, Beachy comes back.
SCHANBERG--Sydney H. The Society of the Silurians notes with sadness the passing of long-time member Sydney H. Schanberg, winner of the Silurians' 1988 Lifetime Achievement Award. 1/3

REISMAN--Marvin. It is with great sorrow that we announce the passing of Marvin Reisman at the age of 87 at West Boca Medical Center on July 3, 2016. Marvin, loving husband of 61 years to Sally Reisman. Cherished father and father-in-law of Marci and Michael Pomerantz and Allison and Peter Menkes. Devoted grandfather of Michaelan and Zhak Cohen, Sean and Sunny Menkes, Matthew, Jack, and Lianne Menkes. Marvin was formerly of Armonk, NY, and Manhattan. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on November 10, 1928 to Samuel and Anna Reisman. He graduated from Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School and became a founding partner of the law firm of Budin, Reisman, Kupserberg, and Bernstein. Marvin leaves a legacy of family love and respect, and the joy of living life to its fullest. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, July 10th, at 11am at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Ave., Valhalla, NY 10595. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to the Chiera Family Foundation, which helps send young cancer patients to summer camp and college. www.chierafamilyfoundation .org, or the Marvin Reisman Memorial Fund in Toronto at Baycrest.org/give or 416-785-2875. 1/3
RUDEEN--Anne Leigh, died at home on July 3, 2016 after 85 full years. Author of five novels, artist, music lover. We love you, Anne! 1/3
POWERS--Peter. I mourn with you the loss of our beloved Peter. My thoughts and prayers are with you. Liz Harding 1/3

WIESEL--Elie. With profound sadness, the staff and board of American Jewish World Service (AJWS) mourn the loss of Elie Wiesel, Holocaust survivor, Nobel laureate, tireless advocate for human rights and a founding member of our board. Wiesel helped establish AJWS thirty years ago, sharing our deep belief that the lessons of the Holocaust demand that Jews and others stand up against injustice for oppressed people everywhere. We extend our condolences to his entire family. May his memory be a call to action for human rights. Kathleen Levin, Board Chair Robert Bank, President and CEO 1/3

LOOMIS--William Farnsworth, 1940-2016, was born in Boston, MA. Son of Violet Amory and William Farnsworth Loomis, Sr. He was educated at Le Rosey, Phillips Exeter Academy and he a bachelor's degree from Harvard and a Ph.D. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Bill then joined the UC San Diego faculty in 1966 and became Distinguished Professor Emeritus. He was a passionate and erudite scientist, his enthusiasm and love of knowledge were infectious and his devotion to rigorous biological research and education was unwavering. Bill passed away in his lab working on his latest scientific endeavor. Bill was a beloved husband, father, and grandfather. He loved to paint, write, garden and travel. He had just returned from a three week European vacation with his entire family. His light, passion, humor and kindness will be greatly missed by all. He is survived by his wife, Maria Margarita Behrens, siblings, Tom La Farge and Jacqueline Quillen, Daughters Catherine Loomis Healy, Emily Loomis Murphey and Carolina Arahuetes and his six beloved grandchildren. 1/3

ZICHLINSKY--Elliott, passed peacefully in his daughter's home in Portland, Oregon on July 6. His wife, Lisette pre-deceased him. Elliott is survived by his son, Murray, daughter, Marlene, daughter-in-law, Cathy, and two grandchildren, Alder and Juliah. Funeral Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, New York, Sunday, July 10, at 9:30am. 1/3
