POWERS--Peter J. The Board of Directors of Mutual of America Life Insurance Company, together with its officers and employees, mourn the passing of Peter J. Powers, an esteemed member of the Board of Directors since 2006. Mr. Powers served with distinction on the Law and Corporate Governance and Nominating Committees and was appointed Chair of the Nominating Committee in 2010. Peter Powers founded Powers Global Strategies LLC, a government relations and strategic consulting firm in New York and Washington, D.C. and served as its Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. He had a long and distinguished career as an attorney, Certified Public Accountant, consultant and public servant and served as First Deputy Mayor of the City of New York under Rudolph Giuliani from 1994 to 1996. Highly respected in his field, Mr. Powers served on the boards of numerous civic and charitable organizations including the Partnership for New York City and the United Hospital Fund and was recently elected Secretary of the Council of Governing Boards, a statewide advocacy group for private colleges and universities. Mr. Powers' sound judgment, integrity and wise counsel have been invaluable to Mutual of America and have greatly contributed to its success. We who were privileged to have known him will gratefully remember his unassuming manner, dedication to service and sincere commitment to professional excellence. His wisdom and friendship will be greatly missed. While we mourn his passing, we greatly admire the manner in which he lived his life. Peter Powers, our friend and colleague, will be remembered with profound respect and affection. Thomas J. Moran Chairman of the Board John R. Greed President and Chief Executive Officer Mutual of America Life Insurance Company 1/3

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Chiera Family Foundation which helps send children with cancer to camp and college. www.chiera familyfoundation.org. Funeral service is Monday, July 11, 2016 at 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. 1/3

LOWE--William Webb II, 95, a pioneer in the introduction of nuclear electric power plants in the United States and abroad, died July 4, 2016, at his home in Alexandria, Virginia of cancer. He was a graduate of Purdue University in Chemical Engineering, a Fellow of the American Institute of Chemists, and a member of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, the American Chemical Society and the American Nuclear Society. He was also an independent scholar of 17th century English merchant marine history. Lowe was born on December 18, 1920, in Bartlesville, Oklahoma, the son of William Webb Lowe and Grace Evans Lowe. In 1944 he married Mary Jean Sanford of Webster Groves, Missouri. He was preceded in death by his ex-wife, Mary Jean Sanford Lowe; his brothers Lt. Col. Richard Wyche Lowe and Robert Evans Lowe; and one grandchild. He is survived by five children: William Lowe III of Lutz, FL; Judith Lowe of Vienna, VA; Dr. Barbara Lowe-Fierke of Northfield, MN; Dr. Robert Lowe of Lansdale, PA; and Jennifer Lowe Foley of Catlett, VA; fourteen grandchildren; four great grandchildren; his second wife of 42 years, Sylvia Stallings Lowe; and three stepchildren: Dr. Sarah Morris of Los Angeles, CA, Julia Morris Kashkashian of Boulder, CO, and Dr. Michael Morris of Falls Church, VA. In February 1942, two months after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Lowe volunteered for Army service and was assigned to continue chemical engineering studies at Purdue. In May 1943, he and three others were withdrawn from their units and sent to the University of Pennsylvania for additional engineering courses. In March 1944, with sealed orders, he took seventeen soldiers, all engineers, by train from Philadelphia to Lamy, New Mexico. They were taken by night in an unmarked bus to the now historic 109 East Palace Street atomic bomb project receiving station in Santa Fe, and then to Los Alamos to provide engineering support for scientists. Lowe was chosen by Dr. Arthur Charles Wahl, co-discoverer of plutonium, to help develop methods for producing the extremely pure plutonium thought to be essential for a successful plutonium weapon. Lowe was then 23 years old. Dr. Wahl was 25. Purifying plutonium was considered the second most difficult problem at Los Alamos. Wahl specified the chemistry, Lowe led the team that developed the equipment. By October 1944, they had a process and equipment that worked and Lowe was put in charge of operations. Lowe later wrote: "I was assigned to supervise receipt and purification of essentially all plutonium made during WWII. In July 1945, I walked down the hall to the metallurgy lab to view with long thoughts the first hemisphere of plutonium, about the size of a baseball, silver coated and resting on a tripod in a dry box." Dr. Wahl's group was a very small but important part of the enormous enterprise centrally directed and logistically supported by the Manhattan District of the U.S. Corps of Engineers. The project had the highest War Production Board priority. After the war, Lowe received letters of commendation from Major General Groves, leader of the Manhattan Project, and J. Robert Oppenheimer, Director of the Los Alamos Laboratory. He was authorized by the Secretary of War to wear the U.S. Army commendation ribbon. As the Cold War and then Korean War began, Lowe moved to Richland, Washington as Chief of the Nuclear Engineering Section of the Hanford office of the newly created U.S. Atomic Energy Commission. There he initiated a series of critical mass experiments that provided the basis for doubling the plutonium production rate of the original plants. In 1954, he became Chief Nuclear Engineer at Bath Iron Works in Bath, Maine. In 1956, Lowe joined James K. Pickard and Frederick H. Warren as a partner of the engineering firm Pickard, Warren and Lowe and eventually became chairman of it and its successor organizations. In 1960, he and his two partners were cofounders of the Nuclear Utilities Service Corporation. During his career, Lowe worked on behalf of electric power company clients to help select sites, set major design parameters, train people, and conduct safety oversight for a quarter of the 104 nuclear electric power units built in the United States and for several abroad. In the early 1960s, he pioneered the use of quantitative probabilistic risk analysis for choosing nuclear power plant sites and advocated its use for design, construction and operation to identify and reduce the probability of significant accidents. However, when concluding a talk about nuclear power in 1971, he said no new technology had evolved without there being accidents and that "We must be careful what we do." After the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant accident in March 1979, Lowe went to the site at the request of the owners, and was the first to recognize that a massive hydrogen ignition had occurred in the containment, that there was a hydrogen bubble in the primary system, and that the fuel core had been destroyed. He specified procedures for removing the hydrogen bubble in the primary system and other actions to stabilize and analyze the condition of the unit. Aside from his substantial contributions to science and humanity, William Webb Lowe leaves behind a legacy of a generosity of spirit, an unwavering sense of responsibility to those he loved, a firm belief in the importance of honesty, a curiosity about and respect for the forces of nature, a sense of fun and accomplishment in mastering nature, and a fascination in the history of those who have gone before. He now joins his ancestors and though he will be sorely missed, these legacies will live on in those who knew him, and will be passed on to the generations to come. Funeral services will be held on Friday, July 15, 2016 at 2pm at Christ Church, 118 North Washington Street, Alexandria, VA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Christ Church Foundation Fund: HistoricChristChurch.org. 1/3

CONNORS--Joseph J.,85, on Thursday, June 30, 2016 of Maywood, NJ. Joseph worked for The New York Times for 43 years as a Mailroom Production Manager before retiring in 1992. He was a Veteran of the United States Navy serving during the Korean War. Joseph was an avid golfer, a health, fitness and sports enthusiast, a longtime Brooklyn Dodger fan and cherished his Irish heritage. Beloved husband of 49 years to the late Patricia (nee Mullane). Loving father of Michael J. Connors and his late wife Lisa, Joseph J. Connors Jr. and his wife Debbie and Patricia Angeli and her husband Rich. Dear brother of the late Joan Hurley, the late Marie Schmidt, the late John Connors and the late Albert Connors. Uncle to many nieces and nephews. Cherished grandfather of Jessica, Angela, Joanna and Colin Joseph Connors. 1/3

SECUNDA--Madeleine, 86, of Castle Rock, CO, passed away peacefully on July 10, 2016. Survived by her children Gwynne (Walt) and Brent, grandchildren, Hannah, Charles Evan and James. Preceded in death by her husband, Arnold and son Ross. Born in Washington Heights, she worked for Chase Manhattan Bank and then the American Geographical Society. She went on to graduate from Lehman College later in life. She was loved by many and made everyone feel special in her loving way. For service information please visit: www.boulevard riversidechapel.com or call the chapel at: 516-295-3100. 1/3

PARKER--Henry Griffith III, age 89, died peacefully on Saturday, July 9, 2016. Born October 27, 1926 in Plainfield, New Jersey. Henry served in the Navy in World War II. He was forever a supporter of and an example for his family and an ambassador of America's greatness. Henry attended St. Andrew's School and Lawrenceville before graduating in 1944. He earned his undergraduate degree from Princeton University in 1948. Henry was the inspiration and a founding member of The Princeton Tigertones in 1946. For over sixty-five years the Tones have remained Princeton University's signature acappella group, pursuing opportunities to maintain a culture of good friends and good music to audiences across the globe. Henry spent 48 years working for Chubb and Son. During his distinguished career at Chubb, he held many positions, including Senior Vice President and Managing Director. Early on, Henry saw the opportunity to build-out a multi-national insurance infrastructure to support globalization. He was instrumental in building Chubb's global presence by establishing the Company's international offices in China, India, Japan, Cuba and throughout Europe and South America. Henry served on many boards, including the National Foreign Trade Council, Firemark Global Insurance Fund and Alliance Insurance Company. He was Chairman of the Business Advisory Committee for the United Nations Business Council and advisory board liaison for the People's Insurance Company of China. Henry also appeared on numerous television and radio programs and contributed articles to professional journals. He served as a trustee of Drew University and was Chairman of the Board at Overlook Hospital from 1973 - 1980. He received the International Insurance Award from the United States Chamber of Commerce in 1981 and a Distinguished Service Award from the International Insurance Council in 1988. At the time of his death, he held memberships with The National Association of Insurance, American Insurance Association, Devon Yacht Club, Morris County Golf Club, Princeton Club of New York and Psi Upsilon. Henry is survived by his wife of 59 years, Audrey Parker, his son H. Griffith Parker IV of Wayne, PA, his daughter, Elizabeth Parker Browne of Bethesda, MD, three grandchildren, three step-grandchildren, and one step-great-grandchild. A Funeral service will be held on Thursday, July 14th at 10:30am at Grace Episcopal Church, 4 Madison Avenue, Madison, NJ 07940. For further info or to send a condolence, please visit: bradleyfuneralhomes.com. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--William. William "Bill" Alfred Goldstein. April 19, 1931-July 4, 2016. He is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Bill and Laurie Goldstein, his daughter, Laurie Goldstein Hawver and son-in-law, Dean Chantiles, and his four greatest joys his grandchildren: Max, Mary, Jason and Lindsey. Bill owned and ran a multi-generational real estate brokerage and management company. In lieu of flowers, please raise a glass and celebrate a life well lived! 1/3

BRADEMAS--John. The NYU Community deeply mourns the loss of President Emeritus John Brademas, a great humanitarian, statesman, and educator whose vision and leadership helped to fundamentally transform this University. An Indiana native, John joined the US Navy officers training program after high school in 1945, was a Rhodes scholar, worked as an aide to Illinois governor and presidential candidate Adlai Stevenson, and taught political science at Notre Dame before going on to represent Indiana's Third Congressional District in Washington, D.C. for more than two decades, distinguishing himself as a champion of progressive legislation, education, and the arts. When he became the 13th President of NYU in 1981, it was a time of uncertainty for the University, which was only a few years removed from serious financial difficulties. But John did not shrink from the challenge: in 1984, he launched a major, transformative fundraising campaign that succeeded in raising more than $1 billion. He also oversaw the opening of a number of major campus programs and learning centers, including the Skirball Department of Hebrew and Judaic Studies, the Casa Italiana Zerilli- Marimo, and the Center for Japan-US Business and Economic Studies. His presidency marked the start of NYU's transformation from a regional university to its present status as a nationally and internationally renowned scholarly and research institution - one of the great success stories in higher education. He continued to be active in public life after stepping down as president - he served as chair of President Clinton's Committee on the Arts and the Humanities and as a member of the New York State Board of Regents. Deeply interested in Spanish history and culture, he was the driving force behind the creation of the King Juan Carlos I of Spain Center at NYU, which promotes research and scholarship on Spain and the Spanish- speaking world, and became the Center's first president. He served on NYU's Board of Trustees for 35 years. He was recognized by the University in 2001 with the Albert Gallatin medal, and the John Brademas Center for the Study of Congress was established at the NYU Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service in his honor. Our thoughts and prayers go out to his wife, Dr. Mary Ellen Brademas; his sister, Eleanor Brazeau; his stepchildren - Katherine Goldberg, Jane Murray, and John Briggs - and their children - James and Briggs Goldberg, Cameron and John Murray, and Alexandra and Molly Briggs - as well as all of his loved ones and friends. For his leadership, wisdom, dignity, commitment to service, and record of achievements, he will be sorely missed by the NYU community. William Berkley, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees Andrew Hamilton, President, NYU 1/3

DEUTSCH--Joan. Over the past 18 months, with the support of her family, friends and a dedicated medical team, Joan finally with grace succumbed to brain cancer at age 80 on Sunday, July 10th at her home in Irvington, NY. Joan was born and raised in Brooklyn. She graduated from Erasmus High School and then Brooklyn College with a degree in molecular biology, followed by additional courses at New York University. 60 years ago, at age 21, she was selected by The Sloan Kettering Institute for Cancer Research to join their tumor screening department under the supervision of two early prominent cancer pioneers. As a young woman, Joan too, was also then recognized as a cancer pioneer. During her 18 years there, she co-authored and published 10 scientific papers and contributed to important inter-department research. She was an inspiration and example for her daughters and other young women to emulate her in the field of science. Joan then continued her career at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the Einstein College of Medicine. Over the next 14 years, she co-authored and published 11 research papers while collaborating in many other scientific projects. Upon retirement from Einstein she dedicated her remaining years to volunteer work in animal preservation and nature. She spent five years in nutrition research at the Bronx Zoo Veterinary Hospital, followed by 14 years at the Bronx Botanical Garden Research Center conducting a program for the gene sequencing of plants, while mentoring graduates and interns. Joan was a voracious reader who traveled extensively with Marty and friends from Tibet to Alaska and points beyond, enriching her passion for music and the arts while also sampling the local cuisines. She was a skilled cook, a gracious hostess known for her gourmet dinners and daily family meals. She was reserved regarding her many accomplishments and considered them private. Joan was ahead of her time in many ways. All who knew this elegant and beautiful woman loved and admired her. She made the world a better place and her legacy will live on. She is survived by Martin, her husband and companion of 58 years, her devoted children Aline and Scott Hillman, Madeline and Scott Kerbel four precious grandchildren, Mathew, Amanda, Michelle, and Samantha and many other loving nieces and nephews. Her parents Louis and Esther Friedman and older sister Arline Rosenberg predeceased her. Burial will be private at gravesite. In lieu of Shiva, a memorial will be held at 11am on July 24th at Temple Beth Abraham located at 25 Leroy Avenue in Tarrytown, NY followed a light meal. Donations in her memory can be sent to The Jamie Deutsch Cancer Foundation, 146 Hardscrabble Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510. 1/3

SWAIN--Elizabeth. The New York Academy of Medicine acknowledges with profound sorrow the death of Elizabeth Swain, Fellow of the Academy since 2009. We join many in remembering her as an untiring advocate for the community health center movement, a generous colleague, and a thoughtful leader in health care policy. The Academy Board, Fellows and staff extend deepest condolences to her family. Jo Ivey Boufford, M.D., President George E. Thibault, Chairman, Board of Trustees 1/3

BROWN--Roscoe C.,Jr. The Community Service Society (CSS) and its President and CEO David R. Jones mourn the death of Roscoe C. Brown Jr., 94, a Tuskegee Airman in World War II, an educator, and mentor to a generation of African-American policy makers and civic leaders. Among his many achievements, he was the first U.S. pilot to shoot down a German fighter jet. A remarkable feat considering he did it from the cockpit of a propeller plane. At the time, the accepted view of blacks in the military was that they were not equally capable as their white counterparts. Brown, who received his doctoral degree from NYU, shattered that myth. Despite being subjected to vicious bigotry and racism, he went on to fly 68 combat missions, was heralded as a war hero along with his fellow Tuskegee Airmen and received the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Congressional Gold Medal and numerous other awards. Over his illustrious career in public service Brown worked tirelessly to address educational inequities and expand access to educational opportunities in New York's poor communities. With great sadness we mark his death, and extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. 1/3

BRADEMAS--John, husband of Dr. Mary Ellen Brademas, passed away following a long illness on July 11, 2016 at the age of 89. They were married in 1977 when he was a Member of Congress and she was a medical student at Georgetown University. John Brademas was a visionary leader in Congress and in higher education. A graduate of Harvard, he went on to earn a Doctorate at Oxford as a Rhodes Scholar. He represented Indiana's Third Congressional District in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1959-81, the last four years serving as Majority Whip. For over two decades on Capitol Hill, he became known as a champion of the arts, humanities, education, and services for children, elderly and disabled. In 1981, he became the 13th President of New York University, serving until 1992. As President, launching a $1 billion fundraising campaign, he led the transformation of NYU from regional commuter school to an internationally prestigious residential research university. Following his tenure as NYU President, he continued to be active in public life, dedicating himself to causes in the fields of democracy, peace building, fighting corruption and promoting arts and culture, including serving as Chairman of President Clinton's Committee on the Arts and the Humanities and founding at NYU two centers reflecting his lifelong interests: the King Juan Carlos I of Spain Center, supporting scholarship on modern Spain, and the John Brademas Center, focusing on Congress and public policy. He is also survived by his sister, Eleanor Brazeau; his stepchildren, Katherine Goldberg (Tom), Jane Murray, and John Briggs (Robin); his step-grandchildren, James (Alexis) and Briggs Goldberg, Cameron and John Murray, and Alexandra and Molly Briggs; and his step-great- grandson, Maxwell Jay Goldberg. Visitation will be held on Thursday 12-2pm and 5-7pm. Funeral Service will be on Friday at 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st Street and Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the Brademas family suggests contributions in John Brademas' honor be made to the NYU Brademas Center, 53 Washington Square S., Room 308, New York, NY 10012. 1/3

BRADEMAS--John. The trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center are deeply saddened by the death of former New York University (NYU) president John Brademas, a man who made singular contributions to NYU's history and direction. We extend our deepest condolences to the family and friends of Mr. Brademas including his wife, Mary Ellen, his sister, Eleanor Brazeau, his three stepchildren, John Briggs, Katherine Goldberg, and Jane Murray, and his six step-grandchildren. Kenneth G. Langone, Chair, Board of Trustees, and Robert I. Grossman, MD, Dean and CEO 1/3

Also survived by nephews, Steve Chenenko, Ricky Chenenko, Richard Glicksman, and Charles Glicksman, and niece, Joni Chenenko Winnick; great-niece and nephews, and great-great-nephews. LACOFF--David, age 92, died peacefully on Monday, July 11, 2016. David proudly served in the Army in World War II. He graduated from CCNY and started Mechanical Development Corp with his brother Hy. BROWN--Dr. Roscoe C.,an American hero, joined the board of the borough's community media network, BronxNet, in 1991, nearly two years before the station began broadcasting and training Bronx residents to produce programs. He was always well-informed about the needs of a television media center and how it could best serve the community. His in-depth media experience combined with his commitment to education, human rights and community development, equipped him with a wealth of ideas and resources that he willingly shared with other BronxNet board members, staff, producers, students and others for the betterment of the Bronx community. BronxNet Chairman Paul T. Gentile stated: "The entire BronxNet family mourns the death of Dr. Roscoe C. Brown, a board member for the past 25 years, whose service to our country and his community has been extraordinary. An educator and a World War II pilot with the Tuskegee Airmen, Roscoe C. Brown leaves a legacy of integrity, wisdom and courage in serving his fellow man. BronxNet celebrates and salutes the life of this great man who is impossible to replace. He will remain in our collective memories for all time." 1/3

FRANCO--Arnold C.,92, insurance executive and philanthropist, died Monday in his home on the Upper East Side. Born in Richmond Hill, Queens in 1923, Arnold majored in history at the University of Michigan and then Queens College, graduating with the class of 1943. Selected for the Army Specialized Training Program, he was trained in code breaking at Vint Hills Farm Station in Virginia before joining the Third Radio Squadron, a mobile unit designed to decode German Air Force messages for the Ninth U.S. Air Force in Europe. His section landed on Omaha Beach after the invasion of France, took part in the break out from Normandy and took over the Eiffel Tower during the Liberation of Paris for use as a grand radio antenna. At war's end, Arnold returned to New York and in 1946 founded Franco & Son, an insurance brokerage which became affiliated with Frenkel & Co. in 1998. In 1963, Arnold co-founded the international Open Door Student Exchange and served as a lifetime board member. A passionate historian, Arnold wrote "Code to Victory," the first book written on WWII mobile intelligence units, as well as numerous articles for military and historical journals. In the 1980's, he established history scholarships at Richmond Hill High School and Queens College, and in 2007 funded a colloquium at Queens College on historical revisionism. On November 11, 2006, he dedicated the Arnold C. and Beverly Franco WWII Memorial, a monument to honor the 1,100 Queens College students who fought in WWII. Arnold was made a Chevalier of the French Legion d'Honneur in 2005, and was awarded an honorary doctorate in Honoris Causa by Queens College in 2000 as well as a Lifetime Achievement Award in 2016. He was a longtime member of the Harmonie Club in New York. Arnold was pre-deceased by his wife, Beverly Rosenberg, who died in 2013, and is survived by his four children, Debra Franco of Los Angeles, Wendy Franco Almquist of Boston, Miriam Franco of Philadelphia and Edmond Franco of New York as well as three grandchildren, David and Harry Almquist and Margaux Blau and one great-grandson, Charles Arnold Almquist. Services Thursday, 11am, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Donations can be made to the Queens College Foundation: http://bit.ly/ArnoldFranco 1/3

BRAUN--Phyllis Thurlow Chase, 98, died July 3, 2016. Predeceased by husband Seymour Braun (1923-1986) and three brothers. Retired as editor of Scholastic's Arrow Book Club in 1985 after 42 years in publishing industry. 1/3

BROWN--Roscoe C.,Jr. The Community Service Society (CSS) and its President and CEO David R. Jones mourn the death of Roscoe C. Brown Jr., 94, a Tuskegee Airman in World War II, an educator, and mentor to a generation of African-American policy makers and civic leaders. Among his many achievements, he was the first U.S. pilot to shoot down a German fighter jet. A remarkable feat considering he did it from the cockpit of a propeller plane. At the time, the accepted view of blacks in the military was that they were not equally capable as their white counterparts. Brown, who received his doctoral degree from NYU, shattered that myth. Despite being subjected to vicious bigotry and racism, he went on to fly 68 combat missions, was heralded as a war hero along with his fellow Tuskegee Airmen and received the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Congressional Gold Medal and numerous other awards. Over his illustrious career in public service Brown worked tirelessly to address educational inequities and expand access to educational opportunities in New York's poor communities. With great sadness we mark his death, and extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. 1/3

SLATER--Selma. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Selma Slater. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Robert D. Lang, President Harvey Karofsky, Secretary 1/3

SPRAYREGEN--Nicholas (Nick), on July 13, 2016. Owner and president of Tuck-It-Away Storage. Founder and managing member of Rising Development. Beloved husband of Jaynee, devoted father of Matthew, Emily, Jonathan, Benjamin and Lilee Bea. Also survived by his loving mother Fredrica and father Gerald, former wife Karen, siblings Lisa and Pamela. He will be missed by extended family and many friends. Service Thursday, July 14th, 1pm at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Melanoma and Immunotherapy Research under Dr. Jedd Wolchok. 1/3

BRADEMAS--John, husband of Dr. Mary Ellen Brademas, passed away following a long illness on July 11, 2016 at the age of 89. They were married in 1977 when he was a Member of Congress and she was a medical student at Georgetown University. John Brademas was a visionary leader in Congress and in higher education. A graduate of Harvard, he went on to earn a Doctorate at Oxford as a Rhodes Scholar. He represented Indiana's Third Congressional District in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1959-81, the last four years serving as Majority Whip. For over two decades on Capitol Hill, he became known as a champion of the arts, humanities, education, and services for children, elderly and disabled. In 1981, he became the 13th President of New York University, serving until 1992. As President, launching a $1 billion fundraising campaign, he led the transformation of NYU from regional commuter school to an internationally prestigious residential research university. Following his tenure as NYU President, he continued to be active in public life, dedicating himself to causes in the fields of democracy, peace building, fighting corruption and promoting arts and culture, including serving as Chairman of President Clinton's Committee on the Arts and the Humanities and founding at NYU two centers reflecting his lifelong interests: the King Juan Carlos I of Spain Center, supporting scholarship on modern Spain, and the John Brademas Center, focusing on Congress and public policy. He is also survived by his sister, Eleanor Brazeau; his stepchildren, Katherine Goldberg (Tom), Jane Murray, and John Briggs (Robin); his step-grandchildren, James (Alexis) and Briggs Goldberg, Cameron and John Murray, and Alexandra and Molly Briggs; and his step-great- grandson, Maxwell Jay Goldberg. Visitation will be held on Thursday 12-2pm and 5-7pm. Funeral Service will be on Friday at 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st Street and Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the Brademas family suggests contributions in John Brademas' honor be made to the NYU Brademas Center, 53 Washington Square S., Room 308, New York, NY 10012. 1/3

MALINAK--Sandra, passed away July 10, 2016 after a brief hospitalization. She was born July 20, 1928 in Brooklyn, NY to Murray Chenenko and Jean Finkelstein Chenenko. She was a 1949 graduate of Brooklyn College and retired from the New York City School System where she taught math for 30 years. She was loved by each and everyone she knew, especially her surviving son, Jonathan Leigh Malinak and brother, Norman Chenenko. She was predeceased by her father, mother, and sister, Elaine Chenenko Glicksman. Also survived by nephews, Steve Chenenko, Ricky Chenenko, Richard Glicksman, and Charles Glicksman, and niece, Joni Chenenko Winnick; great-niece and nephews, and great-great-nephews. All who would like to share memories of Sandy may join family and friends on Thursday, July 14, 1-2pm at 138-52 Elder Ave., Flushing, NY 11355. Memorial donations may be made to: Independence Residences, Inc., 93-22 Jamaica Ave., 2nd Flr, Woodhaven, NY 11421 or Lighthouse Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65th Street, New York, NY 10023. 1/3

PAYNE--Richard Sylvester, of Larchmont, NY and Block Island, RI, died on July 12, 2016. Born November 27, 1931 in Providence, RI, he attended Providence College and graduated from Boston College Law School. He married Jane Frances Monahan in 1956, she predeceased him in 2005. Dick worked as a tax attorney for Mobil Oil, Celanese and Siemens Corporation. Dick is survived by seven children. He was predeceased by two sons. He is also survived by 16 grandchildren and two sisters. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name to Swim Across America would be gratefully appreciated. Visiting today, July 14th, 4-8pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont. Mass Friday 11am at St. Augustine Church. For full obituary go to JJFFH.com. 1/3
CAMPIA--Kenneth M.,died on July 7, 2016 in his home. For service info see obituary on legacy.com. 1/3

SWAIN--Elizabeth. The Board of Directors and staff of the Community Health Care Association of New York State mourn the loss of Elizabeth Swain, President and Chief Executive Officer since 2005. Elizabeth was a tireless advocate for the community health center movement who devoted her life's work to social and economic justice in health care. A strong and supportive leader, colleague and friend, she will be remembered for her fierce dedication to the belief that access to high quality, culturally-sensitive health care is a right of all people. We are deeply grateful to have worked with and learned from Elizabeth and for her many years of thoughtful and inspired leadership. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. 1/3

TILYOU--George C.,grandson and namesake of the founder of Coney Island's Steeplechase Park, and maternal grandson of Brooklyn political leader, John H. McCooey. Passed on July 11, 2016 at 90 years of age. Dearly beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle, cousin and friend. His special charm, wit and humor will be deeply missed. In repose at Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Ave., Northport, NY. nthfh.com. 1/3
ROBBINS--Lester. Your family and close friends are thinking of you, remembering your warmth, strength, wit and your deep, abiding interest in and love for each of us. Sheila 1/3

GOLDMAN--Muriel Lepolstat, passed away July 13, 2016, at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Irving, devoted mom of Ellen (Brian) and Elissa (David z"l), adored grandma of Jason (Jaclyn), Lauren (Tim), Samantha, and Erika, loving great-grandma of Nathan, and caring sister of Stanley Lepolstat and Helen Tepper. Service at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, at 10:00am on Friday, July 15. 1/3

SPRAYREGEN--Nicholas. We mourn the passing of our friend and esteemed client, Nick Sprayregen. Although Nick was a preeminent real estate investor and businessman, his true legacy is his family, to whom he was passionately devoted. He was a true renaissance man. We will long remember and miss his intelligence, loyalty and wit. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire Sprayregen family. Andrew, Steve and Goldberg Weprin 1/3

SPRAYREGEN--Nick. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the untimely death of our longtime member, Nick Sprayregen, beloved husband of Jaynee Sprayregen. ADAMS--Berenice (Halperin), 98, of Great Neck, NY on July 10th at home. Predeceased by husband Stanley Adams, President of ASCAP for 24 years and son Andrew Levin. Dearly loved. Survived by her son John Levin, and granddaughters Elizabeth and Katie and several nieces and nephews. She was an exceptional Interior Designer before retiring. 1/3

DRURY-JOHNSON--Susan. March 11, 1955 - July 10, 2016. Susan Drury-Johnson, 61, of Mamaroneck, NY, died at 1:15am Sunday, July 10, 2016 in the presence of her husband and three sons. She had been under palliative care for lung cancer. Susan was born March 11, 1955 in East Orange, NJ to Bob and Sylvia Drury. She is survived by her husband, David, of 29 years and her three boys--Christopher, Nicholas, and Dylan, as well as her three siblings, Robert, Ellen, and David. Susan and her family had been residents of Mamaroneck for 25 years. Susan graduated from Fairleigh Dickinson College and had a long, successful career on Madison Avenue. Susan was considered one of the pioneers of the digital age, introducing that process into the advertising community. She was often asked to address women's groups on the subject of being a successful female executive. Above all else, Susan was loving, caring, and selfless. She was the determined mother of three boys who she put before all else and who in turn wanted nothing more but to make her proud. She was a pillar of the community; she took active roles in the school system, church, and served as a counselor and role model for countless individuals who looked to her for wisdom and guidance. She will be long remembered for her leadership and contributions to her fellow friends of Bill. Susan was an avid reader. She cherished the beach, and enjoyed exercising. Susan loved the arts-- specifically music, movies, and theatre. Susan would want noted her special relationship with the Johnson family dog, Leo. A Memorial service will be held on July 23 at 11:00am, Rye Presbyterian Church, 882 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York 10580. Contributions as a memorial may be made to the American Cancer Society at donate.cancer.org. 1/3
SCHULMAN--Michael D. On July 9, 2016. A man of intelligence, faith and wisdom, Michael leaves behind adoring family and friends. 1/3

FRANCO--Arnold C. The Queens College family mourns the passing of Arnold C. Franco, 1943. Mr. Franco was an inspirational presence on campus whose legacy includes the Franco Award in History and the World War II Memorial Plaza. Queens College recognized his many achievements with an honorary doctorate in 2000 and a Lifetime Achievement Award in 2016. We are profoundly grateful for his heroism and dedication to his alma mater. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mr. Franco's family. He will be fondly remembered and deeply missed. 1/3

ABRAMS--Nancy A.,70, of St. Petersburg, FL, died Tuesday, July 12, 2016, at St. Anthony's Hospital. A former NYC resident, Nancy retired in 2008 from the Manhattan District Attorney's office. Nancy was predeceased by her parents, Lea and Harry Abrams of Worcester, MA, and her brother, Laurence, of St. Petersburg. Celebrate her memory by planting trees in Israel or making a donation to the charity of your choice. 1/3

HOLZ--Jeannette S. (nee Sudhop), on July 13, 2016. Retired Teacher, East Meadow School District. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Dear sister-in-law to Carl and Irmgard Holz and Family. Also survived by her extended family, Seamus Shanahan, Sheila Sheridan and Shawn Shanahan. Prayer Service at Edward D. Lynch Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Blvd., Sunnyside, NY, Sunday afternoon. Funeral Monday 9:30am. Interment All Faiths Cemetery at 11am. Visitation Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm. 1/3

BLANCK--Bertha "Barbara", of Great Neck New York died Wednesday, July 13, 2016. Born in Brooklyn, New York, on August 28, 1920 to Louis and Ann Horowitz, Bertha was a force to be reckoned with. She was strong, independent, had a wicked sense of humor, and always spoke her mind. She received her bachelor's degree in English and Anthropology from Hunter College in 1942. Later she went on to work for the Associated Press until she met Albert Blanck whom she married in 1945. Bertha loved books, reading, and collecting complimentary items from restaurants such as napkins, rolls, and condiment packets. She will be missed and remembered by her three children, Richard, Carol, and Peter, her eight grandchildren, David, Jennifer, Emily, Steven, Jason, Daniel, Albert, and Caroline, and her three great-grandchildren, Molly, Colin, and Rory. 1/3

MOORE--William Edward, of NYC, passed away on June 26, 2016, ending his quixotic quest to be the most cultured man alive. Bill's curiosity and charm was the basis for a career in sales and lively conversation. He is survived by his sons Eric and Jon, sister Randi and stepmother Peggy. Memorial will be July 24th in his home from 5-9pm. In lieu of flowers, buy and read a book. 1/3

TALBERT--Marilyn Joan, 86, formerly of Great Neck, NY, Fort Lee, NJ and Winchester Gardens, Maplewood, NJ, on July 12, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Jerome Talbert; devoted mother of Amy Hartwig and her husband, Charles; loving grandmother of Evan and Abigail; dear daughter of the late Ida and Irving Greenberg. Services were held on July 14, 2016. 1/3

ALPERT--Murray, of Pelham Manor, NY passed away on July 10th at the age of 87. He was born in New York City to Anna and Louis Alpert, the youngest of four boys. He served his military service during the Korean War, stationed at Landstuhl Hospital in Germany. On return, he went to the College of the City of New York, a BA, and then MS in Psychology, and then a Ph.D in Psychology from New York University. Murray met and married his first wife, Betty, and had his first child, Peter. After Betty passed away, Murray later married Toni, who had a daughter, Michelle, and together they had a son, Theodore. Years later, he also helped raise Amelia and Eliza with his third wife, Taffy. Murray's distinguished career was devoted to research, and training Ph.D candidates as a Professor of Psychology at NYU, where he was Director of Psychology, Department of Psychiatry. He also was Adjunct Professor at the University of Pais Vasco, Bilbao, Spain. Murray was elected President of the American Psychopathological Association in 1984. Murray was an avid biker, tennis player and swimmer, and went to the gym daily until his last year. He was interested in politics, and the downtrodden, and read The New York Times daily. He called Pelham his home for 13 years sharing his time between New York and New Hampshire. Murray is survived by his son Peter, daughter-in-law Donna, grandsons Christopher, Kevin, Eric and Peter, as well as son Theodore. He is predeceased by his first wife Betty and his brothers: Bernie, Harold and Philip. 1/3

Beloved husband of Jaynee, devoted father of Matthew, Emily, Jonathan, Benjamin and Lilee Bea. Also survived by his loving mother Fredrica and father Gerald, former wife Karen, siblings Lisa and Pamela. He will be missed by extended family and many friends. ARIAS-MISSON--Nela. One year ago today, artist Nela Arias-Misson passed away quietly in Miami, FL, a few weeks short of her 100th birthday. Born in Cuba, she studied art at the Student Arts League of New York. In the late 1950's, she moved to Provincetown to study with Hans Hofmann, the dean of abstract expressionism. She moved to Ibiza in 1961 and developed her own style. Always at the epicenter of developing artistic movements, she was close with Mark Rothko, Karel Appel, Walasse Ting and Antoni Tapies amongst others. She lived in Barcelona, Madrid and Brussels, where she was greatly influenced by visual poets like Paul DeVree, Joan Brossa, and her ex-husband, the poet Alain Arias-Misson. Although Nela lived to paint, the discovery of her genius by the contemporary art world is taking place after her passing, when many other women in her same era are being recognized. She is survived by her daughter, Carole Bird. 1/3

LOWE--William Webb II, 95, a pioneer in the introduction of nuclear electric power plants in the United States and abroad, died July 4, 2016, at his home in Alexandria, Virginia of cancer. He was a graduate of Purdue University in Chemical Engineering, a Fellow of the American Institute of Chemists, and a member of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, the American Chemical Society and the American Nuclear Society. He was also an independent scholar of 17th century English merchant marine history. Lowe was born on December 18, 1920, in Bartlesville, Oklahoma, the son of William Webb Lowe and Grace Evans Lowe. In 1944 he married Mary Jean Sanford of Webster Groves, Missouri. He was preceded in death by his ex-wife, Mary Jean Sanford Lowe; his brothers Lt. Col. Richard Wyche Lowe and Robert Evans Lowe; and one grandchild. He is survived by five children: William Lowe III of Lutz, FL; Judith Lowe of Vienna, VA; Dr. Barbara Lowe-Fierke of Northfield, MN; Dr. Robert Lowe of Lansdale, PA; and Jennifer Lowe Foley of Catlett, VA; fourteen grandchildren; four great grandchildren; his second wife of 42 years, Sylvia Stallings Lowe; and three stepchildren: Dr. Sarah Morris of Los Angeles, CA, Julia Morris Kashkashian of Boulder, CO, and Dr. Michael Morris of Falls Church, VA. In February 1942, two months after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Lowe volunteered for Army service and was assigned to continue chemical engineering studies at Purdue. In May 1943, he and three others were withdrawn from their units and sent to the University of Pennsylvania for additional engineering courses. In March 1944, with sealed orders, he took seventeen soldiers, all engineers, by train from Philadelphia to Lamy, New Mexico. They were taken by night in an unmarked bus to the now historic 109 East Palace Street atomic bomb project receiving station in Santa Fe, and then to Los Alamos to provide engineering support for scientists. Lowe was chosen by Dr. Arthur Charles Wahl, co-discoverer of plutonium, to help develop methods for producing the extremely pure plutonium thought to be essential for a successful plutonium weapon. Lowe was then 23 years old. Dr. Wahl was 25. Purifying plutonium was considered the second most difficult problem at Los Alamos. Wahl specified the chemistry, Lowe led the team that developed the equipment. By October 1944, they had a process and equipment that worked and Lowe was put in charge of operations. Lowe later wrote: "I was assigned to supervise receipt and purification of essentially all plutonium made during WWII. In July 1945, I walked down the hall to the metallurgy lab to view with long thoughts the first hemisphere of plutonium, about the size of a baseball, silver coated and resting on a tripod in a dry box." Dr. Wahl's group was a very small but important part of the enormous enterprise centrally directed and logistically supported by the Manhattan District of the U.S. Corps of Engineers. The project had the highest War Production Board priority. After the war, Lowe received letters of commendation from Major General Groves, leader of the Manhattan Project, and J. Robert Oppenheimer, Director of the Los Alamos Laboratory. He was authorized by the Secretary of War to wear the U.S. Army commendation ribbon. As the Cold War and then Korean War began, Lowe moved to Richland, Washington as Chief of the Nuclear Engineering Section of the Hanford office of the newly created U.S. Atomic Energy Commission. There he initiated a series of critical mass experiments that provided the basis for doubling the plutonium production rate of the original plants. In 1954, he became Chief Nuclear Engineer at Bath Iron Works in Bath, Maine. In 1956, Lowe joined James K. Pickard and Frederick H. Warren as a partner of the engineering firm Pickard, Warren and Lowe and eventually became chairman of it and its successor organizations. In 1960, he and his two partners were cofounders of the Nuclear Utilities Service Corporation. During his career, Lowe worked on behalf of electric power company clients to help select sites, set major design parameters, train people, and conduct safety oversight for a quarter of the 104 nuclear electric power units built in the United States and for several abroad. In the early 1960s, he pioneered the use of quantitative probabilistic risk analysis for choosing nuclear power plant sites and advocated its use for design, construction and operation to identify and reduce the probability of significant accidents. However, when concluding a talk about nuclear power in 1971, he said no new technology had evolved without there being accidents and that "We must be careful what we do." After the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant accident in March 1979, Lowe went to the site at the request of the owners, and was the first to recognize that a massive hydrogen ignition had occurred in the containment, that there was a hydrogen bubble in the primary system, and that the fuel core had been destroyed. He specified procedures for removing the hydrogen bubble in the primary system and other actions to stabilize and analyze the condition of the unit. Aside from his substantial contributions to science and humanity, William Webb Lowe leaves behind a legacy of a generosity of spirit, an unwavering sense of responsibility to those he loved, a firm belief in the importance of honesty, a curiosity about and respect for the forces of nature, a sense of fun and accomplishment in mastering nature, and a fascination in the history of those who have gone before. He now joins his ancestors and though he will be sorely missed, these legacies will live on in those who knew him, and will be passed on to the generations to come. Funeral services will be held on Friday, July 15, 2016 at 2pm at Christ Church, 118 North Washington Street, Alexandria, VA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Christ Church Foundation Fund: HistoricChristChurch.org. 1/3

GRAHAM--John. John Robert Graham, was born in Chicago, Illinois on October 11, 1930, and passed away peacefully on June 28, 2016. During his eighty-five years, he traveled widely, collaborated with intelligence and honor, and enjoyed international cultures. After his high school graduation, John attended the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, New York. Graduating in 1952, he was Class President and awarded the prestigious Academic Star. In 1997, Palmer Hall was named for him, honoring his "wholehearted interest, unswerving loyalty, and support" to the U.S.M.M.A. He was a member of the Academy's Superintendent's Council, and recipient of the Superintendent's Trophy, the Outstanding Professional Achievement Award (1972), the Superintendent's Award (1987), and the Kings Pointer of the Year Award (2012). During the Korean War, John served as a U.S. Navy officer on the minesweeper, Implicit (MSO 455). He received multiple commendations from the Navy Commander Mine Force, and was released from active duty in 1955. Returning to sea, John joined the Robin S.S. Line traveling to numerous port cities in South and East Africa and obtained his Master's License in 1957. After leaving professional sea faring, John attended Harvard Business School, and graduated in 1959. John Graham then began a long and successful career in business finance. His roles included Vice President of Hartford National Bank (1959-65), Heublein, Inc., Treasurer (1965-74), and Sr. Vice President of Finance and Administration at Sikorsky Aircraft Company (1974-80). From 1980-82, he served as Chief Financial Officer of Planning Research Corporation. In 1982, he joined Uniroyal, Inc. as Vice President of Finance, Chief Financial Officer and Director, Chairman of Uniroyal Canada and Uniroyal Europe. John was a Director of Uniroyal Holding at the time of his death, and is recognized in Who's Who in America, and Who's Who in American Finance. All his life, John Graham loved the sea, sailing, and exploring the East and West coasts of the United States and Canada. He crewed on several long voyages in the Pacific Ocean, and "doubled Cape Horn" as navigator aboard a 42' ketch from Argentina to Antarctica in 1996. John leaves his wife, Beverly Criley; sons, Jonathan and Karl Graham; stepchildren, Wayne Wager and Margit Moore; grandchildren, Austen and Bevan Moore, Emery and Abigail Wager, Ben and Will Graham; and great-grandchildren, Kellan, Campbell, Ellison Moore and Adriana Moore. Throughout his life, John Robert Graham was known and loved as a man of great warmth, intelligence, honor, and service. Please send gifts of remembrance to Seattle Children's Hospital. 1/3

SUPPLEE--Cochran B.,a retired Manhattan corporate communications executive, died on July 14, 2016 at his home in Santa Barbara, CA. After attending Choate and Princeton University he enlisted in the Army, training with the Colorado ski troops and emerging as an army lieutenant. He married Angela Toland Place In 1946 and they resided in Manhattan and their summer home In Millbrook, NY. He received his MBA from NYU and divided his career between advertising and corporate relations at the former Cluett Peabody Company, maker of Arrow shirts. Mr. Supple was very active in promoting and supporting the activities of the Boy's Club of New York serving as a trustee prior to his retirement. He was also a member of The Century Association and the St. Nicholas Society in New York City. He is survived by his wife, of over half a century, Angela P. Supplee and their daughter Angela S. Chesser, Ph.D. in Columbus, OH. Memorial donations may be sent to St. Peter's Church, PO Box 1502, Millbrook, NY 12545. 1/3

de MARGITAY--Virginia, VV, died on July 10 at age 90. Predeceased by her husband of 48 years, Gedeon de Margitay. Born in Brooklyn Heights, NY, daughter of John Ross and Elvina (nee Varet) Martin. VV was great-great-granddaughter of Dr. Abraham J. Berry, Chief Surgeon of the Civil War Second Army Corps. VV was educated at Packer Collegiate Institute, Spence School, Vassar College, and member of the National Society of Colonial Dames, the Society of Daughters of Holland Dames, the Junior League of New York, and the Colony Club. VV retired as Associate Director - American Council for Drug Education, and had worked as Editing Supervisor with McGraw-Hill. VV was an elegant individual, a wonderfully loyal and faithful friend. A memorial service will be held at St. Francis de Sales Church, 135 E. 96, New York City on Monday, July 25 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to Packer Collegiate Institute, 170 Joralem Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201; Spence School, 22 E. 91, New York, NY 10128; Vassar College, 124 Raymond Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12604-0725; St. Francis de Sales Church, 135 E. 96, New York, NY, 10128; or First Hungarian Reformed Church, 344 E. 69, New York, NY 10121. 1/3

BAUMANN--Andrea. On July 7, Andrea Baumann born Lilienfeld-Lechesne, passed away in her home in Ardsley on Hudson, aged 94. Born in Dresden in 1922 to Violette Lechesne and Karl Lilienfeld, she grew up in Berlin and in 1939 moved to New York. In 1941 she married Edouard Baumann (1906-99). They lived in Paris (1961-71), in Morges, Switzerland (1972-96) and New York (1996). The last ten years Andrea lived in Ardsley on Hudson, NY. She is survived by her loving daughter Bettina and son-in-law, Tom Speyer. A memorial will be held at the Irvington Presbyterian Church on Saturday, July 30th at 11am. Funeral will be at the cemetery of Huemoz in Switzerland in October. 1/3

DEUTSCH--Joan. Over the past 18 months, with the support of her family, friends and a dedicated medical team, Joan finally with grace succumbed to brain cancer at age 80 on Sunday, July 10th at her home in Irvington, NY. Joan was born and raised in Brooklyn. She graduated from Erasmus High School and then Brooklyn College with a degree in molecular biology, followed by additional courses at New York University. 60 years ago, at age 21, she was selected by The Sloan Kettering Institute for Cancer Research to join their tumor screening department under the supervision of two early prominent cancer pioneers. As a young woman, Joan too, was also then recognized as a cancer pioneer. During her 18 years there, she co-authored and published 10 scientific papers and contributed to important inter-department research. She was an inspiration and example for her daughters and other young women to emulate her in the field of science. Joan then continued her career at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the Einstein College of Medicine. Over the next 14 years, she co-authored and published 11 research papers while collaborating in many other scientific projects. Upon retirement from Einstein she dedicated her remaining years to volunteer work in animal preservation and nature. She spent five years in nutrition research at the Bronx Zoo Veterinary Hospital, followed by 14 years at the Bronx Botanical Garden Research Center conducting a program for the gene sequencing of plants, while mentoring graduates and interns. Joan was a voracious reader who traveled extensively with Marty and friends from Tibet to Alaska and points beyond, enriching her passion for music and the arts while also sampling the local cuisines. She was a skilled cook, a gracious hostess known for her gourmet dinners and daily family meals. She was reserved regarding her many accomplishments and considered them private. Joan was ahead of her time in many ways. All who knew this elegant and beautiful woman loved and admired her. She made the world a better place and her legacy will live on. She is survived by Martin, her husband and companion of 58 years, her devoted children Aline and Scott Hillman, Madeline and Scott Kerbel four precious grandchildren, Mathew, Amanda, Michelle, and Samantha and many other loving nieces and nephews. Her parents Louis and Esther Friedman and older sister Arline Rosenberg predeceased her. Burial will be private at gravesite. In lieu of Shiva, a memorial will be held at 11am on July 24th at Temple Beth Abraham located at 25 Leroy Avenue in Tarrytown, NY followed a light meal. Donations in her memory can be sent to The Jamie Deutsch Cancer Foundation, 146 Hardscrabble Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510. 1/3

MANGANARO--Felicia, age 95, passed away July 15, peacefully. She was the devoted wife of 67 years to her late husband John and a proud, loving mother to Peter and Rosemary. Felicia lived for her family and devoted her life in taking care of us with God-given love and passion. Mother we shall miss you dearly. 1/3

He was president of Dearborn Manufacturing, Etz Chaim Synagogue, and Middlebay and Boca Greens Country Clubs. He retired to Florida where he spent many happy years with his beloved wife, Rita. KELLOGG--Frederick F.,Jr. Kane Lodge No. 454 F. & A. M. announces with profound sorrow the death of our esteemed Brother Frederick Kellogg, Jr. on June 22, 2016 at the age of 88. A graduate of Steven Institute of Technology and Columbia University, Kellogg was a licensed engineer in four states, eventually serving as Chief Engineer for the Village of Larchemont for over two decades. To mention a few, He was a member of the Princeton Club and Mensa, as well as the Mayflower, St. Nicholas, and Huguenot Societies before joining the Lodge on December 2, 1980 where he served the craft faithfully for 36 years. Kellogg is survived by his sister, Dr. Joan Renz, by his sons Freddie and David, and by his grandchildren Alexander, Stephanie, Jennifer, and Brian. A brief memorial service was held on June 28th at the Church of the Incarnation in New York. As one of the pillars of Kane Lodge, he shall be greatly missed and warmly remembered. Mike Geller, Secretary 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Dr. Seymour, a wonderfully talented intelligent and innovative Endodontist and professor died on Tuesday, July 5th at home in Roswell, GA, he was 84 years of age. Seymour was a beloved husband to Naomi for 63 years and a cherished father to Lee (Brenda), Eugenia (Thomas), and grandchildren Cory, Hannah, Sarah and Gryffin. He will remain forever in our hearts. 1/3

SHIPPEE--Elizabeth Freeman Little, died peacefully at home on July 12 in her 96th year. Born November 10, 1920, in Central Falls, RI, she was a 64 year resident of Greenwich, CT. Elizabeth's early life was spent in China where her father, Lester Knox Little, rose to become Inspector General of the Chinese Maritime Customs Service. She lived in various coastal cities in China, graduating from the Shanghai American School in 1937. She spent a year in Switzerland before entering Wellesley College from which she graduated in 1942, with a degree in Ancient Greek. Elizabeth loved China and returned to Shanghai after World War II with her husband, Nathan; daughter Elizabeth was born in 1946. They left in 1948 as the Nationalist government fell. Elizabeth and her family moved to Greenwich in 1952, and for six decades she was an active member of many local organizations including the choirs at Second Congregational and First Presbyterian churches. As a board member of the Greenwich Symphony, she was honored for building the orchestra's subscription base to support a level of professional performances that continues to this day. Choral singing was her greatest artistic delight, and with the Greenwich Choral Society and Berkshire Choral International, she sang in dozens of concerts including performances at the Aldeburgh Festival and Canterbury Cathedral in England, and Carnegie Hall. She is survived by her four children and their spouses, Elizabeth S. Boylan (Robert J. Boylan), Robert W. Shippee (Gayle Beyer), Richard R. Shippee (Deborah Matz), and Arthur B. Shippee (Mary Porterfield), along with five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A Celebration of Life will be held at a later date. For information write: ELS.Service.2016@gmail.com No flowers requested but friends could contribute, or better, subscribe to the Greenwich Symphony or the Greenwich Choral Society in her memory. 1/3

VICTOR--I. Arnold III. Arnold Victor, a cultured, accomplished New Yorker, died unexpectedly on June 28, 2016 from complications of colon cancer. He was 76. Arnold grew up in Dallas, Texas and was a member of the Hillcrest High School Class of 1957. He received his B.A. from Rice University in 1961. He was awarded a Fulbright Scholarship for post-graduate study in Slavic Languages at the University of Vienna, Austria. He then received his Master of Science in Linguistics from Georgetown University before teaching Humanities at Howard University. Fluent in Esperanto, French, German, Russian and Mandarin, Arnold was always quick with a witty retort or a loving word. He lived in Greenwich Village for more than 40 years, happily serving as the consummate New York City tour guide for his many out-of-town friends and relatives. A world traveler who documented every trip with postcards mailed to family and friends, he was also devoted to studying and sharing his family history. A Mensan who was active in Esperanto circles, Arnold was also a longtime subscriber to the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic. Kindhearted and a great storyteller (and strong debater!), he will always be remembered for his keen mind and sense of humor and as a devoted son, brother, uncle, great-uncle and loyal friend. Arnold was predeceased by his parents, I.A. and Cecile Victor, and partner Michael Degenhardt. He is survived by his sisters Marion Perini; Carol Ann Luby and husband Dan; nieces Alice Liebman Angier, Dana Luby Roark, Julie Liebman Presnall, Caroline Perini; nephews Eric Liebman and Mark Luby, seven great-nieces, one great-nephew, all of Dallas- Ft. Worth, and many beloved cousins. He was buried in Green-Wood Cemetery, Brooklyn. If desired, memorial contributions may be made to: The Metropolitan Opera, Lincoln Center, New York, NY 10023. www.metopera.org/ Support/ Make-a-Gift/ Commemorative-Gifts 1

STANTON--Reginald, graduate of Xavier High School, St Peter's College, Balliol College Oxford University (Rhodes Scholarship), and NYU School of Law (Root-Tilden Scholar), passed away at his home in Morristown, NJ. Upon his retirement from the bench, he was Of Counsel at Drinker, Biddle & Reath. Reginald taught at Seton Hall Law School and the National Judicial College, was a board member of the Morris County School of Technology, and a long-time member of the Rhodes Scholarship selection committee. MISSETT, IV--Joseph Vincent, M.D. Died suddenly of a heart attack on Friday, July 8, 2016 in Santa Monica, California. He was 50. Born October 13, 1965 in New York City, he graduated from The Buckley School, Middlesex School and Emory University. After a successful career on Wall Street, "JV" found his true calling and became a doctor specializing in emergency medicine. He is survived by his wife Carol, son Santiago and stepson Emilio, his father Joe and stepmother Nancy, his brother Stephen and his wife Heidi, his stepbrother Henry and his wife Whitney, his stepsister Samantha and her husband John, and his many nephews, a niece, and godchildren. ROBINSON--Judith. (nee Gropper) Woman of compassion, valor and love. Wife of Ira for 58 years. Mother of Roni (Jed), Douglas (Leslie). Grandmother of Chelsea, Logan, Jake and Lily. Docent for over 30 years at the Jewish Museum. Loved Penn State, Sigma Delta Tau, art and life. Traveled extensively, National Honor Society, reached 80. Rest in peace, you've earned it many times over. Donations to The Jewish Museum or Temple Israel of South Merrick. 1/3

VELEZ--Anthony. Anthony "Tony" Velez, 69, photographer and activist, Vietnam veteran, beloved husband, father, brother, uncle, friend, died on July 6, 2016, surrounded by loved ones, from multiple myeloma, his second cancer linked to Agent Orange. A professor of photography for twenty-seven years, he retired in 2014 from Kean University. A lifelong artist, his work has been broadly recognized, including by the New York Historical Society, New Jersey Historical Society, Norwalk Historical Society; and is part of collections held at historical societies of Brooklyn, New York, Norwalk, New Jersey, El Museo del Barrio, Bronx Museum, and Brooklyn Museum. His recent project, commissioned by the Norwalk Historical Society, is exhibited at the Norwalk Historical Society Museum. He was recipient of numerous grants and commissions, including, National Endowment of the Arts and New York Foundation for the Arts, and his work featured in numerous publications, including, "This is Brooklyn: Its Historic Districts and Landmarks", "100 New york Photographers" (2009). He was born to Puerto Rican immigrants in the south Bronx and raised there and in public housing in East New York. After serving in Vietnam in the 11th Armored Cavalry (1966-67), he organized with other veterans in Vietnam Veterans Against the War. He attended New York City's High School for Art and Design, and studied at Brooklyn College with Walter Rosenblum, and was a member of the Photographer's Forum. A New Yorker at heart, he embraced the communities he became part of in Norwalk, Connecticut, where he relocated with his wife in 2007; including, Norwalk Arts Commission, Rowayton Arts Center, and Westport Arts Center, and the community of Village Creek where he lived. He received medical care at Memorial Sloan Kettering. Special thanks to Dr. Susan Slovin, Dr. Eric Lis, and Dr. Alexander Lesokhin. He also appreciated the care that he received from doctors at the West Haven VA Hospital. Tony's intelligence, enthusiasm, warmth and zest for life was contagious and his commitment to social justice unwavering. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him, and especially by his family - Barbara Zerzan, Sophia Velez (Emily Storm), Nick Zerzan (Alex), Jessica Zerzan (Joshua Rubin), and grandchildren, Rex, Charlie and Ellie. A memorial service will be held September 17, 2016, 2pm, at his home in Norwalk, CT. 1/3
SPATT--Peter. 2/20/52 - 7/18/06. May your dreams be larger than mountains. Have the courage to scale their summits, and make every tomorrow a vision of hope. 1/3

McALLISTER--Barbara Ann Rice. 88, died on July 13, 2016 of natural causes in West Palm Beach, FL. The former long-term resident of Belle Terre, NY, and Tequesta, FL, was born in Brooklyn, NY on September 29, 1927, the only child of Joseph A. and Dorothea Rice. She attended the College of New Rochelle where she studied to be a speech therapist. She married her best friend's cousin - Neill Alexander McAllister, a lifetime executive with McAllister Bros, a family-owned marine towing and transportation company founded in 1864; he predeceased her in 1991. Barbara and Neill were the proud parents of eight children: Mary Fader (Samuel), of Dover, MA; Alexandra Woodfield (Gary), of Palm Beach, FL; Suzanne, of Glenside, PA; Neill (Mary Ghegan), of New York, NY; Patrick, of Hamden, CT; Elizabeth Pope (Paul) of Jenkintown, PA; Dennis (Sarah Aderholt) of New Canaan, CT and Nancy (Richard Card), of New York, NY; nine grandchildren, and seven great- grandchildren. Barbara was fortunate to meet, laugh with, and marry Stanley (Bud) Doggett in 1998; he died in 2002. Those who knew, or heard of her, proclaimed she was the "most beautiful girl in Brooklyn." She maintained that beauty and elegance until the end. She was strong-minded, smart, a critical thinker, and had a way with words. Her proudest achievements were her children. She was happiest when surrounded by them and their families at reunions in Belle Terre. She was unforgettable. Her family is grieving. A wake for Barbara will be held at O.B. Davis Funeral Home in Port Jefferson Station, NY, on Tuesday, July 19 from 5pm- 8pm. Funeral Mass will be held at Infant Jesus Chapel at St Charles Hospital, in Port Jefferson, NY, at 10:30am on Wednesday, July 20. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her honor to Hope House Ministries, PO Box 358, Port Jefferson, NY 11777. 1/3

PERLOV--Betty Rosenberg, 98, of Brooklyn, NY, died July 4, 2016. Daughter of Vera and Israel Rosenberg, wife of the late Sidney Perlov. Died peacefully amidst love and warmth. Survived by children, Susanna and Daniel. Also by children in-law, Karen and Martin, three grandchildren, Miriam, Eva, Francesca and two great-grandchildren. She was a speech pathologist and in 2013 published a children's book, Rifka Takes a Bow, about her childhood in the Yiddish Theater. She was inspirational and will be missed by many. 1/3
ZEBRAK--Sheila Ruth, MD. July 18, 1966 Fifty Years.... All of life that was yet to live... In loving memory, brother Ira Zebrak and sister Mimi Zebrak 1/3

DALEY--Mildred, "Mimi" (Tunkel), age 94, died peacefully in her Clifton, NJ home of 61 years with her family at her side on Friday, July 15, 2016. Funeral Sunday, July 17, 2pm, Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Rd., Clifton, NJ. 1/3
GLICKSMAN--Albert, Aly-dearest husband, missing you every moment since July 18th, 2005, but still sharing my life with you. Love, Fran 1/3

SOLE--Sheila R. August 7, 1939 - July 16, 2016. Born and raised in Manhattan, a devoted and indomitable spirit. Survived by her beloved children, Andrew, Allison and Steven, grandson Samuel Asher and daughter-in-law Melissa. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., at 11am Tuesday, July 19. 1/3

YOKEN--Joan Frye, 88, wife of Richard Lewis Yoken (August 6, 2011), mom of Tony/Pam, Hollyce, David/ Tarja, grandmom of Max/ Maria, Lia, Anna and Hannah, sister to Connie/Les Martinson, aunt to Juli/Doug/Richard Carner; University of Chicago, Brandeis, Lincoln Center. 1/3

WILKER--Stanley Joel, on July 17, 2016. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of Deborah, Caroline, Steven, Jamie, Jonathan and Jeffrey. Cherished grandfather of Nicholas, Katelyn, Shayna, Devin, Shelby, Halle, Ben, David, Jordana, Daniel, Hannah, Callie, Ethan, Noah and Jake. Service 12 Noon today at Riverside Nassau North chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

FURLONG--Mary A.,of Westbury, NY (formerly of Garden City, NY and Wellesley, South Natick and Duxbury, MA). July 15, 2016. 86 years old. Beloved wife of Padric F.X. Furlong (deceased) and loving mother of Brenda Furlong of Cortland, NY, Padraic and Mary Furlong of Port Washington, NY, Myles and Jann Furlong of Falmouth, MA, Edmond and Carolyn Furlong of Needham, MA and Matthew and Maria Furlong of Needham, MA. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Raised on a farm in Rhode Island, Mary moved to New York City to work at Abraham and Strauss in Brooklyn, where she found Pat and over the next fifty years they created a life together. She was tirelessly devoted to her family and guided us with gentle warmth. Industrious, optimistic and humble, she made us laugh with her wry humor. She faced adversity with uncompromising perseverance. We thank her for being a model of how to live with grace and dignity. Visiting hours Tuesday, July 19, 7-9pm at Donohue Cecere, 290 Post Avenue, Westbury, NY. Services Wednesday, July 20, 9:45am, St. Brigid's Church, 75 Post Avenue, Westbury, NY. 1/3

PEARCE--Stewart, age 65, passed away from lymphoma on July 17 with Kevin Kellogg, his adored husband, at his side. Stewart was born in Brooklyn and raised in New Jersey, the son of Daniel and Dorothy Linn Pearce. After graduating Phi Beta Kappa from Brandeis, Stewart received his Masters in Arts Administration from NYU. Stewart Pearce's nearly 40 year career at the Metropolitan Opera and Metropolitan Opera Guild encompassed major leadership roles in every aspect of opera management. Beginning as an intern and ending his career as Managing Director of the Guild, over the years Stewart was promoted again and again within the Metropolitan Opera by five different General Managers. Working with Joseph Volpe for many years, Stewart was named Director of Planning, Budgets and Marketing. Peter Gelb further appointed Stewart Assistant General Manager, Operations, the post he held until his retirement from the Met. With his brilliant intelligence and innate calm and grace, Stewart was an inspirational mentor and a treasure to countless colleagues. Upon his retirement the Metropolitan Opera's Board of Directors formally paid tribute to "Mr. Pearce for his extraordinary expertise, leadership and commitment throughout the entirety of his distinguished career at the Met". Stewart's wide-ranging interests outside opera ranged from politics to pasta, pets to philanthropy. He had a passion for travel, film and theater. Stewart had a wondrous capacity for love and will be mourned by his many dear friends. Stewart Pearce is survived by his ever-devoted husband Kevin, his nephew Chris, and niece Noelle. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders in memory of Stewart Pearce. 1/3

LEOPOLD SARGENT-- Elaine (nee Albert), 1933-2016 Passed away peacefully, on Tuesday, July 12, 2016, in New York. Loving mother of Stephen Leopold and John Leopold, and mother-in-law Joanne Kussner Leopold. Adored grandmother of Arthur, Alex, Justin and Carolyn Leopold. Beloved daughter of the late Bernard Albert and the late Evelyn Vineberg Albert. Sister of the late Lois Albert Leterman. Elaine was laid to rest with her family at her side at the Shaar Hashomayim Cemetery in Montreal on Monday, July 18. A trailblazer in Montreal and New York City, Elaine broke the glass ceiling as not only one of the first female stockbrokers in both Montreal and on Wall Street, but also one of the leading stockbrokers in an era when women were almost nonexistent in the world of finance. Her keen mind and passion for the arts led her from Chairmanship of the Angel's Ball Committee in Montreal to being a great patron of the New York City arts including The New York City Opera, Lincoln Center Theater, New York Theater Workshop, Roundabout Theater, and to Chairing the Our Time Theater Company. Elaine established the Avon Chair dedicated to ovarian cancer research at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. In 1997, she founded a scholarship in the name of her late uncle, Dr. Arthur Vineberg, at McGill University, world renowned pioneer of modern day heart surgery. The family is immensely grateful to all those who were helpful along the way, including the late Dr. Leon Root, Dr. David W. Kennedy, Dr. Hooman Yaghoobzadeh and Dr. Frank A. Petito. In lieu of flowers, donations to the "Elaine Leopold Sargent Scholarship Fund for Faculty of Medicine" at McGill University, (514) 398-2787, would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

PEARCE--Stewart. The staff and board of the Metropolitan Opera Guild are profoundly saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Stewart Pearce. Stewart worked at the Guild and the Metropolitan Opera from 1976 until his retirement in 2015, and in the last five years of his career served as the Guild's Managing Director. He was a devoted opera fan as well as a savvy businessman, a caring, calm and thoughtful presence in an often tumultuous world. We will miss his unfailing humor, wisdom and strength, and send our deepest condolences to his husband, Kevin Kellogg. 1/3

Coleman "Cole" Glover; his mother, Mrs. Donald Findlay; his three sisters, eight nieces, three nephews, and 13 great-nieces and nephews. FURLONG--Mary A.,of Westbury, NY (formerly of Garden City, NY and Wellesley, South Natick and Duxbury, MA). July 15, 2016. 86 years old. Beloved wife of Padric F.X. Furlong (deceased) and loving mother of Brenda Furlong of Cortland, NY, Padraic and Mary Furlong of Port Washington, NY, Myles and Jann Furlong of Falmouth, MA, Edmond and Carolyn Furlong of Needham, MA and Matthew and Maria Furlong of Needham, MA. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Raised on a farm in Rhode Island, Mary moved to New York City to work at Abraham and Strauss in Brooklyn, where she found Pat and over the next fifty years they created a life together. She was tirelessly devoted to her family and guided us with gentle warmth. Industrious, optimistic and humble, she made us laugh with her wry humor. She faced adversity with uncompromising perseverance. We thank her for being a model of how to live with grace and dignity. Visiting hours Tuesday, July 19, 7-9pm at Donohue Cecere, 290 Post Avenue, Westbury, NY. Services Wednesday, July 20, 9:45am, St. Brigid's Church, 75 Post Avenue, Westbury, NY. 1/3

SPERO--Cecile (Ceil) Schiffer, 88 of Kendal at Ithaca, NY passed away Thursday, July 14 from cancer. Born in Atlanta in 1927, she grew up in New York City, the daughter of Allyn M. and Belle (Solomon) Schiffer. She graduated high school from the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, where she met James S. Spero. They were happily married for 63 years until his passing in 2011. Ceil graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1948 and received a Master of Library Science from SUNY Albany in 1967, after many years of part-time study while raising her family. She was an Elementary School Librarian and eventually the School Library Coordinator for the entire Ithaca City School District until her retirement in 1986. She was always involved in volunteer work in Tompkins County, including with Family and Children's Services, which honored Jim and Ceil for their dedicated support in advancing mental health services by creating the Spero Family Fund for Child Psychiatry; the Tompkins County Public Library Foundation; and Kendal at Ithaca, where she was instrumental in setting up the residents' library. Jim and Ceil made significant gifts that transformed services and lives and in 2010 were chosen as Philanthropists of the Year by the Association of Fundraising Professionals, New York Finger Lakes Chapter. Ceil will be remembered for her warm generosity, joy in spending time with family and friends, and her love of books, dancing and theater. She was also predeceased by daughter Jean Spero and sister Herma Shore. She is survived by children Bette Spero (Daryl Rasuli) of Buffalo, NY, Donald Spero (Julie Cooper) of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, Nancy Spero (Rob Sullivan) of Ithaca, NY; grandchildren Susannah Spero and Samuel Spero; sister-in-law Miriam Spero; and many loving nieces, nephews, and special friends. Friends are invited to attend a celebration of her life on August 1st at 3:30pm at Kendal at Ithaca. Memorial contributions may be made to "The Spero Family Fund for Child Psychiatry" at Family and Children's Services, 127 West State Street, Ithaca, NY 14850 or the Tompkins County Public Library. Contact Bangs Funeral Home, 607-272-1922 for more information. 1/3
