ROTHFELD--Betty R.,died July 15, peacefully as she slept, looking forward to her 95th birthday eleven days hence. She studied piano at Julliard, graduated from NYU, and served as a medical social worker at Bellevue and other New York hospitals. She was an active community volunteer, founding in the early 1950s, the Manhasset, L.I., chapter of United Cerebral Palsy. A daughter of Dr. Abraham and Dr. Ella Feldman Rabiner, she was married for 66 years to the late Dr. Samuel H. Rothfeld. She is survived by her daughter Carolyn, sons Michael and Robert, six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Burial service private. 1/3

HANDLER--Mark S. Warm, compassionate with a wicked sense of humor, Mark S. Handler (83 years old), passed away suddenly at his beloved home in East Hampton. Mark's career with Macy's began in 1958 in the executive training squad. He rose through the ranks from Junior Assistant Buyer in fabrics to Buyer in 1961. He was named Vice President in 1965, Senior Vice President in 1967, President of Bamberger's, a division of Macy's, in 1971 and Division Chairman in 1979. He became President and Chief Operating Officer of the Macy's Corporation in 1980, and Chief Merchandising Officer in 1992. That same year he was named co-Chairman and co-Chief Executive Officer of Macy's Corporation. He retired from his celebrated career with Macy's in 1995. He was beloved, respected and admired by all the many people's careers and lives he touched and advanced. A true gentleman who was madly in love with his family. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Barbara, son, Jon (Cindy) and daughter, Jody (Neal) and four loving granddaughters, Caroline, Lori, Evie and Sophie. Known for his culinary prowess, his charming hospitality, an avid but adequate golfer, and his Cary Grant looks. We will miss him very much. The funeral service will be held at the Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, 94 Pantigo Road in East Hampton, NY, at 11am on Wednesday. 1/3

EVANS--Paul Redmond, died on July 2 of heart failure. A longtime resident of Fishers Island, NY, Paul was born in New York City on October 3, 1958. Son of Katharine and Paul Evans he attended Buckley School, Lawrenceville and Boston University. After a career as a stock broker he retired to Fishers. He is survived by his five siblings, fourteen nieces and nephews and nine grandnieces and nephews whose birthdays he never failed to celebrate. He will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held at The Union Chapel, Fishers Island, NY on August 13 at 1:15pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider contributions to Fishers Island Library or Island Health Project. 1/3

PEARCE--Stewart. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our dear friend and colleague Stewart Pearce, whose Met career spanned 39 years from 1976, when he began at the Metropolitan Opera Guild as an intern, to his retirement in 2015 as Managing Director of the Guild. From 1982 he worked for the Metropolitan Opera Association in various business-related capacities, and was Assistant Manager of the Met from 1997 to 2014. The wide scope of his experience with the company included finance and budgeting, marketing, fundraising, and operations management. Few administrators in the Met's history have had such varied responsibilities, and Stewart's knowledge of the Met and how it worked was second to none. He was tapped by succeeding general managers to tackle some of the company's biggest administrative challenges, and he consistently carried out his tasks with efficiency, tact, precision, and an unflappable calm that earned him everyone's admiration and affection. Stewart loved opera and loved the Met. He played one of the most important roles in the Met's administration, perhaps invisible to the general public, but essential to making our company run smoothly. Stewart's passing came much too soon, and his many friends and colleagues express their deepest condolences to his husband, Kevin, and to all those in and outside of the Opera House who will miss him dearly. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director Emeritus 1/3

DWORKIN--Albert R.,passed away in his home in Sarasota, Florida on July 17, three days before his 100th birthday. He was born of immigrant parents in Newark, NJ, where he graduated from Weequahic High School. Bright and ambitious, he graduated from the NYU School of Commerce while working during the day for his father and later graduated from the Fordham Law School. A member of the New York bar, he became a CPA, tax attorney, and partner with the New York accounting firm of David Berdon & Co. He and his beloved wife of 73 years, Phyllis, lived for many years in Roslyn, Long Island until their retirement to Sarasota 30 years ago. He was predeceased earlier this year by Phyllis and by a son, Eric. A wonderful father and grandfather, he is survived by daughter Peggy Northrop of Barrington, Rhode Island, son Peter Dworkin of San Francisco, five grandchildren, and two great-granddaughters. May the memory of the righteous be a blessing. 1/3

SCHULMAN--Jerome L.,M.D., died at home in New York on June 30. He was 89. Dr. Schulman, a pioneering virologist in influenza research, was on the faculty of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine from 1968 until he retired in 2005. He was one of the first to discover the uniqueness of the Hong Kong virus of 1968 by differentiating it from previously prevalent Asian viruses. The Hong Kong strain had killed an estimated one million people worldwide. Surviving is his wife of 56 years, the poet Grace Schulman. 1/3

KAPLAN--Tobee. The board and professionals of Hillel International send our heartfelt condolences to the family of our dear friend Tobee Kaplan z'l. Tobee was a visionary who loved Hillel dearly and made it a passion with her late husband, Leonard z'l. They served with distinction on Hillel's Board of Governors and were honored with Hillel's Renaissance Award in 2009. Our condolences are with her son Randall Kaplan, former Chair of Hillel International's Board of Governors and Board of Directors, his wife Kathy Manning and the entire Kaplan family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. David Shapira, Chair of Board of Governors; Tina Price, Chair of Board of Directors; Eric D. Fingerhut, Pres/CEO, Hillel Intl 1/3

LEVY--Jacqueline. Died at home July 17, 2016. Sister of the late Edith Segal and the late Dr. William Levy. Loved and loving aunt of Jane Levy, Elizabeth Williamson, Margaret Levy, Susan Rai, and Paul Segal. Generous and life-loving, she will be missed by her relatives and her many, many close, caring friends and neighbors. Services Wednesday, July 20 at 4:00pm at Riverside Chapels, Amsterdam Ave. and West 76th St., followed immediately by shiva from 6:00 to 8:00pm at 285 Central Park West, Apt. 8W. 1/3

SCHULMAN--Jerome L.,M.D., died at home in New York on June 30. He was 89. Dr. Schulman, a pioneering virologist in influenza research, was on the faculty of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine from 1968 until he retired in 2005. He was one of the first to discover the uniqueness of the Hong Kong virus of 1968 by differentiating it from previously prevalent Asian viruses. The Hong Kong strain had killed an estimated one million people worldwide. Surviving is his wife of 56 years, the poet Grace Schulman. 1/3

Through the Glory of the Resurrection, may Ann be restored to the fullness of life. 1/3

BRADEMAS--John. The Board of Trustees of Anatolia College, Thessaloniki, Greece mourn the passing of its lifetime Board Member, Dr. John Brademas, distinguished former member of Congress and President of New York University. We acknowledge his impact on education and Hellenism. His wise counsel will be missed. Albert Elfner, Chair, Anatolia College Board of Trustees 1/3

HOLT--Jenny. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the loss of Jenny Holt, a Holocaust survivor born in Lodz, Poland and married to Irving Holt, also a Holocaust survivor, for 70 years. She is survived by her son, the Museum's Vice Chair Allan Holt and his wife Shelley, a daughter, Dot Cheriff and her husband Frank; four grandchildren, four great-grand- children and sisters, Esther Drew and Sally Wolfe. The Museum sends its heartfelt condolences to Irving Holt and the entire Holt Family. Tom A. Bernstein, Council Chair; Sara J. Bloomfield, Museum Director 1/3
GLENN--Thomas E. After three years you are still alive in the hearts and minds of all of us who cherish your memory. 1/3

DRESNER--Milton H.,October 13, 1925 -- July 20, 2016. Milton Dresner was born in Syracuse, New York, the son of Sadie and Hyman Dresner. He was predeceased by his seven siblings, David Dresner, Albert Dresner, Jack Brimberg, Morris Dresner, Sol Dresner, Joseph Dresner and Betty Cohen. Mr. Dresner is survived by his daughters Maryann Dresner of San Francisco, Jane Dresner Sadaka of New York City, his son Robert Dresner of West Bloomfield, Michigan, his son-in-law Ned Sadaka, his daughter-in-law Susan Dresner, and his grandchildren Lawrence Sadaka, Adam Sadaka, Charles Sadaka, Eric Dresner, and Katy Dresner. Mr. Dresner attended Central High School and Wayne State University in Detroit. During World War II, he served in the United States Navy aboard a destroyer in the Philippine Islands. Mr. Dresner returned to Detroit after the war and founded the Highland Companies with his twin brother, Joseph. He was active in the development of single family and multi family housing projects and commercial real estate throughout the United States. He was an active horseman, swimmer, and skier. Funeral services are in Detroit on Sunday, June 24th. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Dresner Family Fund at Karmanos Hospital in Detroit or to the Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County, FL. 1/3

KAPLAN--Tobee. The board and professionals of Hillel International send our heartfelt condolences to the family of our dear friend Tobee Kaplan z'l. Tobee was a visionary who loved Hillel dearly and made it a passion with her late husband, Leonard z'l. They served with distinction on Hillel's Board of Governors and were honored with Hillel's Renaissance Award in 2009. Our condolences are with her son Randall Kaplan, former Chair of Hillel International's Board of Governors and Board of Directors, his wife Kathy Manning and the entire Kaplan family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. David Shapira, Chair of Board of Governors; Tina Price, Chair of Board of Directors; Eric D. Fingerhut, Pres/CEO, Hillel Intl 1/3

MOTELSON--Stuart, of New York City, on July 7, 2016, at the age of 74. Father of Peter (Hillary) and Glenn (Jenny) Motelson, and beloved grandfather of four. A Bronx boy, born May 25, 1942, and a graduate of Syracuse University and NY Law School, he enjoyed a successful career as a real estate attorney with ABC/Disney, raised his family in Westchester County and returned to the Upper West Side. Warm and witty, he will be missed dearly by his family and many friends. In addition to his children and grandchildren, he is also survived by his sister Carole Jaffe. Interred at King Solomon in Clifton, NJ on July 10. Donations may be sent to Lighthouse / Jewish Guild for the Blind, www.lighthouseguild.org 1/3

MOONVES--Josephine Schleifer, A beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, died peacefully surrounded by family on July 15 at UCLA Hospital in Santa Monica, CA. She was 92. Moonves, best known to friends as Jo, was a gifted caregiver, who finished Number One in her class at nursing school, before beginning a long career in the healthcare field. She continued to practice nursing until she retired at age 70. Outside of nursing, Moonves was an avid traveler, having visited nearly 50 countries on all seven continents during her lifetime. She was also an avid reader. She loved visiting museums, watching movies and dining out. Family was the focus of her life. She was the beloved matriarch for an extended family of nieces, nephews and cousins. Josephine Schleifer Moonves was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. She was the oldest of five children and was predeceased by her four siblings. She married Herman Moonves, an Army veteran, in 1943. After marrying, the couple moved to Valley Stream, NY to raise their family. Together, the couple had three sons, CBS Chairman and CEO, Leslie Moonves (Julie Chen Moonves), entertainment attorney Jonathan Moonves (Dianne Moonves), and Alan Moonves, and a daughter, Melissa Moonves (Yves Colon). They later moved to Lynchburg, VA, Atlanta, GA and then to Pacific Palisades, CA in 1979. In California, Josephine and Herman were active members of the Santa Monica Family YMCA. In addition to her two sons and daughter, Josephine Moonves is survived by her husband of 73 years, Herman, plus eight grandchildren: Adam, Sara, Michael, Charlie, Jacques, Ian, Alaina, and Julia, and three great- grandchildren: Noah, Judah and Jack. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Josephine's name to the Alliance for Children's Rights, 3333 Wilshire Blvd, Suite 500, Los Angeles, CA 90010. (https://support.kids- alliance. org/Josephine MoonvesMemorial) 1/3

GRUEN--John. The Keith Haring Foundation Board of Trustees and staff mourn the passing of friend and Haring biographer John Gruen. We extend our sincere condolences and heartfelt sympathy to his daughter and our dear friend, Executive Director Julia Gruen. 1/3

SALITAN--Mark, A.,on July 20, 2016 his 87th Birthday. Beloved husband of Adele, nee Wechsler for 60 years. Devoted father of Michael Salitan (David Kulick), Laurie Salitan (Marc Kushner), James Salitan (Martine Davis), Diane Egleston (Michael Egleston). Cherished grandfather of Emily, Gabe, Ana, Nora, Molly and Nathan. Chapel Service Friday at Eden Memorial Chapels, Inc. at 10:00am. For information www.edenmemorial.com or call (201) 947-EDEN. 1/3

NAHAS--Edmund Alfred, born October 22, 1932, passed away after a brief illness on July 17, 2016. Ed is survived by his beloved wife, Vickie (nee Goolsby) from Tennessee and their children and grandchildren: daughter Jennifer Nahas of Cambridge, MA and her children, Sophia and Lukas; son and daughter -in-law, Stuart and Bronwyn Nahas of Paramus, NJ and their children, Aaron, Tara and Dylan; daughter and son-in-law, Heather Nahas and Matthew Waugh of Belmont, MA and their children, Katherine and Alexander; and son and daughter-in-law, Jeffrey and Kellyn Nahas of Amesbury, MA and their children, Natalie and Hannah. Edmund resided with Vickie in Brooklyn, New York. Ed graduated Trinity College in 1954 and earned his law degree from Columbia University in 1957. Thereafter, Edmund joined his uncle at the Manhattan firm that became Zraick, Nahas & Rich, where he practiced law until his retirement in 2011. Edmund's life was devoted to his family, friends, clients and his Church. He had a tireless work ethic and a driving desire to help others. When he was not working, Ed enjoyed the Pocono Mountains, visiting his children and grandchildren and following sports, particularly, the New York Giants. Ed is also survived by his brother, Alfred Nahas and his family, his nephew, Peter Poulakakos and his family and a host of extended family and friends. Services at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, 9620 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, New York will be held on Thursday, July 21st in the afternoon and evening. A funeral mass will be held at St. Mary's Antiochian Orthodox Church, 8100 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, New York at 10:00am on Friday, July 22, 2016. 1/3

LYSINGER--Pat. Her family, friends and associates on Broadway and the business mourn the passing of Pat Lysinger, who died in Colorado Springs on June 28, 2016. Patty came to New York in 1965 and quickly landed her first Broadway show, understudying Barbara Harris in "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever." She went on to appear in "No, No, Nanette"; "Dames at Sea" and a host of other on and off-Broadway shows. Over the course of a twenty-five year career she appeared in hundreds of television commercials and voice spots. She was a lifetime and loyal member of Equity, SAG and AFTRA. Everyone loved Patty, and she is so missed. She is survived by her Michael of 25 years, their four children, and her siblings, nieces and nephews. Memorials may be made to the organization that became the light of her life: The National Alliance on Mental Illness, 510 E. Willamette Ave., Colorado Springs, CO 80903. 1/3

PAUL--Eve W.,retired General Counsel of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, died peacefully Thursday morning in her Manhattan home following a long, hard-fought battle with cancer. Ms. Paul, a native New Yorker, graduated from Cornell University in 1950, where she was managing editor of the Cornell Daily Sun, and from Columbia Law School in 1952, where she served as an editor of the Law Review. She began her career at the New York law firm then known as Hays, Sklar before moving to Stamford, Connecticut and taking a break from practice to raise her children. She eventually opened her own law practice in Stamford, served on the Planning Board, and ran as a Democrat for the state legislature. Returning to New York in 1970, Ms. Paul worked for New York's Legal Aid Society and the law firm of Greenbaum, Wolff & Ernst before joining Planned Parenthood in 1978, where she served as General Counsel until 2003. In that same year, she lost her husband and partner in life of 51 years, Robert D. Paul. Ms. Paul leaves behind two children; Jeremy Paul of Newton, MA and Sarah Paul of New York City, their spouses Laurel Leff and Dr. Mark Nachamie; four grandchildren, Jason Paul, Russell Paul, Eli Nachamie and Owen Nachamie; and two devoted caregivers, Dell Hart and Evetta Clarke. A service will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023 on Sunday, July 24, 2016 at 9:45am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be directed to the Cooke Center for Learning and Development (https://www.cooke center.org), Northeastern University School of Law's Health Policy and Law Fund (http://www.northeastern.edu /law/giving/index.html) or Cornell University's College of Arts and Sciences. Eve will be sorely missed. 1/3

DRESNER--Milton H.,October 13, 1925 -- July 20, 2016. Milton Dresner was born in Syracuse, New York, the son of Sadie and Hyman Dresner. He was predeceased by his seven siblings, David Dresner, Albert Dresner, Jack Brimberg, Morris Dresner, Sol Dresner, Joseph Dresner and Betty Cohen. Mr. Dresner is survived by his daughters Maryann Dresner of San Francisco, Jane Dresner Sadaka of New York City, his son Robert Dresner of West Bloomfield, Michigan, his son-in-law Ned Sadaka, his daughter-in-law Susan Dresner, and his grandchildren Lawrence Sadaka (Kira), Adam Sadaka, Charles Sadaka, Eric Dresner, and Katy Dresner. Mr. Dresner attended Central High School and Wayne State University in Detroit. During World War II, he served in the United States Navy aboard a destroyer in the Philippine Islands. Mr. Dresner returned to Detroit after the war and founded the Highland Companies with his twin brother, Joseph. He was active in the development of single family and multi family housing projects and commercial real estate throughout the United States. He was an active horseman, swimmer, and skier. Funeral services are in Detroit on Sunday, June 24th. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Dresner Family Fund at Karmanos Hospital in Detroit or to the Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County, FL. 1/3

de MARGITAY--Virginia, VV, died on July 10 at age 90. Predeceased by her husband of 48 years, Gedeon de Margitay. Born in Brooklyn Heights, NY, daughter of John Ross and Elvina (nee Varet) Martin. VV was great-great-granddaughter of Dr. Abraham J. Berry, Chief Surgeon of the Civil War Second Army Corps. VV was educated at Packer Collegiate Institute, Spence School, Vassar College, and member of the National Society of Colonial Dames, the Society of Daughters of Holland Dames, the Junior League of New York, and the Colony Club. WOLMAN--Gladys, passed away January 22, 2016, aged 92. Beloved wife of 66 years of David L. Wolman and devoted mother of Nancy Rose Wolman. Gladys was a true New Yorker, born in Brooklyn to Rose and Barney Buzin. She was a passionate reader and an avid movie and theater fan. She served her community as a volunteer in the PTA and the Girl Scouts for over 30 years. Her favorite job was as an elections inspector for 40 years. The sweetest and most generous person, she is missed by David, Nancy Rose, and her many relatives and friends. She will live in our hearts forever. 1/3

ROSENFIELD--Herbert. Founding member of the BMCC Foundation Board of Directors Passes Away. Borough of Manhattan Community College/CUNY and the BMCC Foundation mourn the passing of our friend and longtime supporter Herbert Rosenfield, a founding member of the BMCC Foundation Board of Directors, on which he served for more than 30 years. Mr. Rosenfield, who passed away on Wednesday, July 20, 2016 at the age of 97, was a strong ally to the College. "Sadly today we've lost a true hero of Downtown Manhattan and a friend that will be missed by many," said BMCC President Antonio Perez. "Herb had a deep concern for those in need and a willingness to help make a difference in their futures." In the 1960s, the City of New York acquired 24 square blocks along West, Washington and Greenwich Streets. This area has since become, in large part, the Independence Plaza residential project and BMCC, whose 27,000-member student body has become a major force in Lower Manhattan. In addition, Public School 234 took up residence on Chambers and Greenwich Streets, while farther west on Chambers, an additional building for Stuyvesant High School was constructed. Mr. Rosenfield was serving as president of the Chambers Canal Civic Association during the 1980s when the city was looking to sell property in TriBeCa to encourage large-scale developments. The plan was protested by many, including Mr. Rosenfield, who spoke out as an ally in support of small businesses and neighborhood schools, including BMCC. In 1984, Mr. Rosenfield was presented with the BMCC Distinguished Service Award at BMCC's Commencement. The Abner B. Rosenfield Award Fund, which Mr. Rosenfield established to honor the memory of his father, has provided financial support and recognition to numerous BMCC students who exemplify academic excellence and participate in community service. We extend our condolences to Mr. Rosenfield's children Dr. Patricia L. Rosenfield, Thomas Priest Rosenfield and Nelson An-ping Chang and their families. 1/3

TULLY--William J.,90, of Pelham Manor, passed away peacefully at his home on Thursday, July 21. He was predeceased by his adoring wife of over 55 years, Kay. He was a loving father to nine, grandfather to 18 and great- grandfather to nine. He was a tennis legend both nationally and internationally, earning 22 national titles, the Canadian Tennis Championships and the World Singles Championships in the 75's Senior Division. KARPMAN--Esther, 98, of New York City, passed away on July 20th, 2016. She is survived by two daughters, Dahlia Japhet, and Diana Karpman and a son, Daniel Karpman and five grandchildren. PERERA--Charith, 58, loving husband and father, successful entrepreneur, and compassionate leader who on July 8, 2016 passed away. A graduate of the Sloan School of Management at MIT, he founded ShipXpress Inc., and led it as CEO for 16 years. He will live forever in the memory of his wife Chinta, his children Samantha, Chrisantha, Janaki, Rajiv, and Anita, and all those who came to know his tireless encouragement and ready smile. Services are being handled through Ponte Vedra Valley Funeral Home: www.pontevedravalley.com/ notices/Charith-Perera 1/3

REICH--Seymour "Sy", of New York, NY, died on Friday morning at New York Presbyterian Hospital of complications from pneumonia. He was 92. Raised in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn in the 1920s-30s with his younger brother Herb, Sy attended James Madison High School and St. John's University, Business School and Law School. He served in the Army in Korea as a telegrapher. Sy became an attorney and a CPA and established Seymour Reich & Company, where he worked actively for 55 years until this past week. Sy was devoted to bridge, which he played weekly until his failing eyesight prevented it. He was an extremely affable man with a caring demeanor and a good sense of humor. He could be tenacious in pursuit of his goals, and at the same time kind and generous to those with whom he had dealings. He engendered, both in his employees and friends, a great sense of loyalty. He was deeply committed to philanthropy through The Reich Fund, which he established in the 1970s. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Lilian Reich, his son Charles and daughter-in-law Ilana, his daughter Elizabeth and son-in-law Stan, and his four grandchildren, Evie and Laura, and Audrey and Max, all of whom will miss him dearly. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell, the Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC, on Monday at 11:30am. Interment will follow at Temple Israel Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. 1/3
REICH--Seymour. The Harmonie Club notes with sorrow the passing of our honored member Seymour Reich. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. The Harmonie Club 1/3

CHESTLER--Rita, November 3, 1934 - July 20, 2016. Nothing made her happier than her family, and nobody made her family happier than she did. Always caring, loving and so proud, "Rita-Belle," Mom, Grandma, "Dot," we will love you forever, miss you every day, and cherish our memories always. We love you. Herb, Steve and Carolyn, Daniel B. and Rhonda, Cathy and Jonathan, Jaclyn and Andrew, Jacob, Jessica, Emily, Gregory and Caitlin 1/3

PAUL--Eve W.,retired General Counsel of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, died peacefully Thursday morning in her Manhattan home following a long, hard-fought battle with cancer. Ms. Paul, a native New Yorker, graduated from Cornell University in 1950, where she was managing editor of the Cornell Daily Sun, and from Columbia Law School in 1952, where she served as an editor of the Law Review. She began her career at the New York law firm then known as Hays, Sklar before moving to Stamford, Connecticut and taking a break from practice to raise her children. She eventually opened her own law practice in Stamford, served on the Planning Board, and ran as a Democrat for the state legislature. Returning to New York in 1970, Ms. Paul worked for New York's Legal Aid Society and the law firm of Greenbaum, Wolff & Ernst before joining Planned Parenthood in 1978, where she served as General Counsel until 2003. In that same year, she lost her husband and partner in life of 51 years, Robert D. Paul. Ms. Paul leaves behind two children; Jeremy Paul of Newton, MA and Sarah Paul of New York City, their spouses Laurel Leff and Dr. Mark Nachamie; four grandchildren, Jason Paul, Russell Paul, Eli Nachamie and Owen Nachamie; and two devoted caregivers, Dell Hart and Evetta Clarke. A service will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023 on Sunday, July 24, 2016 at 9:45am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be directed to the Cooke Center for Learning and Development (https://www.cooke center.org), Northeastern University School of Law's Health Policy and Law Fund (http://www.northeastern.edu /law/giving/index.html) or Cornell University's College of Arts and Sciences. Eve will be sorely missed. 1/3

CASE--Dr. Robert B.,age 96, of NYC, Southampton and Naples, beloved husband of Dr. Nan Case and stepfather of Miles Robert and family, passed away peacefully in Southampton Hospital of natural causes. Dr. Case graduated from MIT, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and was on the staff of NIH and Harvard School of Public Health. He spent the majority of his career as Director of the Laboratory of Experimental Cardiology at St. Luke's Hospital and published numerous articles in peer reviewed journals. He was also an active member of the Multi-Center Cardiology Research Group and retired as Professor Emeritus of Columbia University. He was truly a brilliant scientist, a loving man and greatly respected. In lieu of flowers, please remember him with an act of kindness. The graveside service will be held at the Southampton Cemetery on Wednesday at noon. 1/3
SIMON--Robert. Our love for you is eternal Mimi, Eileen, Valerie, Rebecca, Jim 1/3

BAUMANN--Andrea. On July 7, Andrea Baumann born Lilienfeld-Lechesne, passed away in her home in Ardsley on Hudson, aged 94. Born in Dresden in 1922 to Violette Lechesne and Karl Lilienfeld, she grew up in Berlin and in 1939 moved to New York. In 1941 she married Edouard Baumann (1906-99). They lived in Paris (1961-71), in Morges, Switzerland (1972-96) and New York (1996). The last ten years Andrea lived in Ardsley on Hudson, NY. She is survived by her loving daughter Bettina and son-in-law, Tom Speyer. A memorial will be held at the Irvington Presbyterian Church on Saturday, July 30th at 11am. Funeral will be at the cemetery of Huemoz in Switzerland in October. 1/3

Hunter College mourns the death of an esteemed member of its community, Hugh Scott, dean of the Hunter College Division of Programs in Education and inaugural dean of the nationally acclaimed School of Education. He was admired by faculty, students and staff and was awarded the Hunter College President's Medal for his exemplary service. GIMBEL--Thomas S. T.,Jr. Educator, Author, Disability Pioneer, 1985 - 2016. Son of Thomas S. T. Gimbel and Lesley B. Gimbel of Glen Cove, NY and brother of Peter B. Gimbel, Lesley B. Gimbel and Hope K. Gimbel. He died Thursday, July 14, of heart failure associated with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy. Thomas "Tommy" was a graduate of the Portledge School, 2003; Brown University, B.A., 2007; Harvard University, M.A., 2009; and, NYU, M.A., 2012 having concentrated on religious studies and comparative religion. He published the book "God's Words in Human Voices" in 2007, writing by blowing Morse Code through a straw- like tube attached to his computer. His yet to be published autobiography, "Muscleman," is in its last editing stages. Tommy was a faculty member at Portledge School in Locust Valley, NY, and a revered teacher of both modern and ancient languages. He was a director of Youth Ministry at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church, a teacher of Adult Bible Studies, and he gave several sermons. He was a recently ordained Christian Minister. Earlier in his life, Tommy and his brother Peter, were featured on the MDA Labor Day telethon. Tommy spoke at certain conferences for the Parent Project including internationally. While he still had use of his arms, he was a painter and cartoonist. Later, he used the internet to tutor students and compete at chess. Tommy Gimbel was an example of "can do" optimism even with very limited physical capabilities, in a wheel chair and requiring full-time breathing assistance from a ventilator machine. He had clarity of vision and purpose and an aura of welcoming kindness to everyone. His soft spoken wisdom from personal experience and Christian philosophy delivered with a sense of humor drew and inspired people. Many have reported that his observations and appreciation of life's gifts changed their lives forever. Contributions in Tommy's memory may be made to: St. John's of Lattingtown / Memory of Tommy, 325 Lattingtown Rd., Locust Valley, NY 11560. 1/3

WOODROOFE--Martha. Martha "Molly" Reed Woodroofe, died on Wednesday, July 20, 2016 following a valiant battle with pancreatic cancer. Molly was born in Pittsburgh in 1975 and was a devoted daughter to and cherished by her parents the Reverend Robert "Woody" and Sally Woodroofe and extremely close to her older sister Louise. She remained passionate about Pittsburgh and its teams. She graduated from Butler Area High School in Pennsylvania, was an AllIvy soccer standout at Yale University, and later earned a Master's from Georgetown University. Molly was a beloved history teacher and coach at three independent schools starting at the Westminster School in Connecticut before moving to Washington, DC where she spent a decade teaching and coaching as the school's first female varsity coach at St. Albans. While at St. Albans she met her partner, Blair Parker, then a history teacher at National Cathedral School and with whom she shared a commitment to teaching. In 2013 Molly and Blair moved to New York City where Molly became the History Department Head at the Spence School. Molly lived life with purpose and joy that was felt by everyone she encountered. Even in the nine months after her diagnosis she continued to teach and carry forth her other responsibilities, which included making sure everyone in her presence was happy and comforted. Her passion for sports and world travel was unwavering. She watched every USWNT game and traveled to their World Cup victory in Vancouver. She spent her last days rooting for her favorite teams and planning vacations while surrounded by friends and family. A memorial service will be held at 10am on Monday, July 25 at the Washington National Cathedral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Yale Women's Soccer or the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network. 1/3

She will be sorely missed and dearly remembered. 1/3

POTTER--Priscilla Bowden, died after a brief illness on July 19th in New York City. A fine arts painter, her landscapes of Eastern Long Island where she spent much of her adult life were lauded. In the words of the former art critic for the East Hampton Star, "Priscilla Bowden had such a knack for capturing the very essence of the East End that to see her paintings, with their misty tones and sense of space and distance, meant that afterwards you went out to the woods and bays and beaches with a renewed appreciation of their beauty. She painted what she saw, but she conveyed so much more." Born in Glen Cove, Long Island in 1940 she graduated from Radcliffe College going on to the Art Student's League in New York to study painting. New York became her - as a gifted young woman she explored her passions - fashion, romance, far-flung travel. Yet painting was always in the forefront. In 1970 she won the Chaloner Prize awarding her further art studies in Paris but after a few years in France she returned to the landscape she loved most settling into the famed art colony of East Hampton. It was there she met and married the late Jeffrey Potter, the friend and biographer of Jackson Pollock. Together they were at the center of the artistic and literary world's heyday on the South Fork. As her reputation as a painter grew, her work was shown in numerous galleries and museums on Long Island and in New York with shows also in Washington, DC, Florida, Virginia, Connecticut and Oxford, England. Her first gallerist remembers, "Bowden shared with her contemporary, Jane Wilson, the quality of mystery when dealing with the sky and fog. She was a strong and gifted artist who created works of lasting beauty." Friends will remember her generous involvement in the East End community -- she played flute in a chamber group, loved the opera, donated her art and her name to charitable fundraisers, and for a while lent her unique talents to making quirky video "shorts" for East Hampton's local television. She is survived by two sisters, Linda Laux of Washington, DC and Mary Beth Bowden of New York City, and two nieces, and she enjoyed a close relationship with her husband's four adult children. She will be dearly missed by all who will long remember her gracious and hospitable company, her artistic talent and her wry sense of humor. A memorial service will be held at The Cathedral of St. John the Divine at a later date. 1/3

His beloved wife, Audrey Priest Rosenfield, like his parents and grandparents, predeceased him. A dedicated lifelong New Yorker, he was president for more than forty years of the family textile firm, Continental Convertors Corporation. He served in the Army from 1940-1946 and saw action in France and Germany as Warrant Officer/ Assistant Adjutant to the Commanding Officer of the 212th Coast Guard Artillery Anti-Aircraft and then Adjutant to the Commanding Officer of the 541st Field Artillery European Theater. Herb served regularly on the Grand Jury of the County of New York. As founder and then president of the Chambers - Canal Civic Association, he and his colleagues supported small businesses and fought for better residential conditions, such as the law allowing artists to work and live in lofts. She loved her family, her parents, and her country. As a teenager she came to the United States to attend graduate school at Yale University where she received an MA in History. WAYSER--Harold, died July 17, 2016. Born in 1929 in New York City. He grew up in Far Rockaway, NY and graduated from Far Rockaway High School. He served in the United States Armed Forces in the 101st Airborne. He graduated from City College with a BA, MA and PhD degrees. He owned National Express Trucking for many years. He retired from that and began teaching Accounting, Finance, Economics and Business Law at Rockland Junior College. He moved to Florida and continued teaching for 15 years at Lynn University. SPIEGEL--Siegmund. Architect and Holocaust survivor, born in Gera, Germany 1919, died July 14, 2016 while with his family, celebrating the 95th birthday of his beloved wife, Ruth. He fled Nazi Germany and lived his life honoring the deaths of his and Ruth's parents and all who died in the Holocaust. He volunteered to be drafted into the U.S. Army in 1941, serving in the G-2 section of the 1st Infantry Division, 'The Big Red One', through the invasions of North Africa, Sicily, and France. As an Architect, he received many awards for housing, planning, commercial, and institutional projects. He co-founded the Black- Jewish Coalition of Long Island and the Nassau County Holocaust Commission, and designed its Holocaust Memorial and Education Center. In the early 70's, Sig became very active in Jewish philanthropic work, founding the Architects, Engineers and Builders Division of United Jewish Appeal of Long Island. He served as President of the Long Island Board of the Anti-Defamation League, was active in B'nai B'rith, and organized Holocaust Victims Memorials. He lectured in schools about the Holocaust throughout his life. For his service in the Infantry and Military Intelligence, he attained the rank of Master Sergeant. And for his bravery he was awarded the Purple Heart, Bronze Star, the Croix de-Guerre-Avec Palme by the Belgian government, and the "Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor" by the French Government. Sig will be buried at Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors at a date to be announced. He is survived by his beloved family: wife of over 71 years, Ruth, daughters Sandra Bauman McGrath, Deborah Spiegel Rockwerk (husband Sandy), grandson Brandon Spiegel Bauman, nieces Susan Maier, Ada Golan Meir and nephew Amos Golan. Contributions in his memory can be made to The Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington D.C. and the Anti-Defamation League. 1/3

LAVINE--Melvin (Mel), 88, a gifted print and television journalist, died in Berkeley, CA, on July 5. A producer- writer for NBC and CBS News, he was raised in Brookline, MA, and graduated from the University of Maine. He became a reporter for Sanford Maine's Tribune in 1950 and later the Humboldt Times in Eureka, CA. In the 1960s, he was a news anchor for a Eureka TV station before winning a fellowship at Columbia University School of Journalism. In 1964, he joined NBC News in New York, assigned to local programs and The Today Show. In 1978, he switched to CBS's Sunday Morning and Walter Cronkite's documentary unit. Moving in 1991 to Berkeley, he continued as a producer with CBS. Mel's memoir, "A Strange Breed of Folks," is a vivid account of his career. Until his death, he was a columnist for The San Leandro, CA, Times. Predeceased by his first wife, Donna Willbanks, he is survived by his wife, Lorraine (Rainey) Sykes. 1/3

HONN--Francis Jerome, beloved husband, father and grandfather, passed away peacefully in West Caldwell, New Jersey on July 2, 2016 at age 94. A 60-year veteran of the chemical industry, he was the inventor of the yellow Hi-Liter, introduced by Carter's Ink Co. in 1963. He holds over 25 patents. Born in Syracuse, NY and raised in Ohio, he earned a B.S. from John Carroll University, M.S. from the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, and Ph.D. in organic chemistry from the University of Pittsburgh. Beginning his career in wartime research for General Cable Corp., he worked on substitute materials for natural rubber and subsequently developed wire insulation from newly invented synthetic plastics and elastomers. Following the war, he became a Fellow of the Mellon Institute in Pittsburgh where he conducted research for the Quartermaster Corps, the Office of Rubber Reserve and Armstrong Cork Co. His optical cement, designed to overcome the deficiencies of heat-sensitive Canada balsam, was adopted by the military. From the Mellon Institute, Honn joined M.W. Kellogg Co. where he pioneered the development of fluoroelastomers for use at high temperatures in missile and aerospace applications. When the Kellogg division was acquired by the 3M Company, he moved into the role of chemical industry executive, a path he followed with various global chemical companies for the next thirty years. His experience includes serving as vice president of technology for Carter's Ink, vice president of commercial development for the chemical division of Olin Mathieson, vice president of new products for the Mennen Co., and a number of positions with BASF Corporation, ending as director of corporate planning, development and marketing and a member of the executive committee. After retiring from BASF, he served as an outside director of Henkel Corp., the U.S. subsidiary of Henkel KGaA, until 1992. Never content to be anything other than active, in 1988 Honn accepted the Alfred Driscoll Chair and Professor of PharmaceuticalChemical Studies in the Business School at Fairleigh Dickinson University. For 15 years, he taught courses on managing research and technology, strategic management, and international business to MBA candidates employed by the chemical and pharmaceutical industries. While there he wrote three textbooks. Honn joined the American Chemical Society in 1944 and remained an active member for his entire career. Another long-term commitment was to the Commercial Development Association, for which he served as president in 1974-75. He was awarded the Golden C for his invention of the Hi-Liter and pioneering work in fluoroelastomers. He was founding chairman of the CDA Educational Foundation. Beyond his professional accomplishments, Honn shared a lifelong love of opera and classical music with his beloved wife of 66 years, Alyce. Their first date was attending "La Boheme" at the old Met. He served as trustee and trustee emeritus of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra for thirty years, and was a steadfast and enthusiastic supporter. Following his motto to "keep busy!", he was president of the Residents Association at Crane's Mill after moving there in 2010. At the time of his death, he was Chair of the Finance Committee of the Organization of Residents Associations of New Jersey, which includes all 25 continuing care retirement communities in the state. At the age of 92, he co-authored a 30- page report on the impact of Hurricane Sandy on Continuing Care Retirement Communities. In the last several years, he facilitated different lecture series for the Crane's Mill residents based on the Great Courses, including one on the technology of ancient Greece and Rome. His family knew well his prodigious memory, which was amply documented in the 254-page memoir he wrote at age 87. Among his many recollections are those detailing his commute to high school on trolleys heated by coal fired stoves, a 1937 trip on a Great Lakes iron ore carrier, and the research specialties of his professors at Brooklyn Poly, eminent scientists who had fled Nazi Germany. Ever intellectually driven, he leaves behind a stack of bedside reading that includes books on the Federal Reserve, materials science, and Harry Truman, as well as carefully catalogued copies of "Chemical and Engineering News." Throughout his long and productive life, he remained devoted to his family. He is survived by his son and daughter in law, David Honn and Leigh Davis Honn of Acton, MA, his son, Gregory Honn, of Greenwich, CT, and his daughter and son-in-law, Cynthia and Robert Hillas, of Princeton, NJ, as well as by his loving grandchildren, Robert Jr. and his wife Camden, Alison and her husband Jonathan, Mary and Timothy. He was predeceased by his wife, Alyce, and his daughter, Jasper Honn. A private burial service was held at Immaculate Conception Cemetery in Montclair, New Jersey. A Celebration of Life will be held on Saturday, August 27, at 11:00am at Crane's Mill retirement community, 459 Passaic Avenue, West Caldwell, NJ. A reception and lunch will follow immediately after the gathering. All friends and family are welcome. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, 60 Park Place, 9th floor, Newark, NJ 07102, or online at njsymphony.org. 1/3
SUNKIN--Sanford Daniel. 7/14/24 - 7/17/16 All my life he has been my precious, caring, loving Brother. He was also special to my Raymond. Rest in Peace Dear Brother. Estelle 1/3

STUPACK--Irwin Sheldon, 87, of Sarasota, FL, and formerly of Southbury, CT and Rockville Centre, NY passed away on July 16, 2016, after a five year battle with Mantle-Cell Lymphoma. Mr. Stupack was a graduate of James Madison High School in Brooklyn, and Long Island University where he was one of the first people in the United States to receive a MBA Degree. Irwin served as a Desk Sergeant in the U.S. Army. While stationed at Fort Dix, NJ, he married Betti Hamburger Stupack and the couple had two children. They remained married until Betti's death in 1999. Subsequently, Irwin married Frederika Jacobson and the couple lived in Sarasota, FL. During his long career in the Men's Apparel business, Irwin worked for J.P. Stevens, Wamsutta Mills, Fair-Tex Mills and Kellwood Corporation. He was instrumental in obtaining the first NFL Licensed clothing and was at the forefront of the "Made in America" trend of the 1990s when his clientele included the major catalogue companies of; L.L. Bean, Clifford & Wills, Lands End and Patagonia. He is survived by his wife, Fredy, his son Robert Stupack of Larkspur, CA, daughter Barbara Anton of Boulder, CO, his grandchildren, Stephanie Stupack, Michael Anton and Joel Anton. REICH--Seymour "Sy", of New York, NY, died on Friday morning at New York Presbyterian Hospital of complications from pneumonia. He was 92. Raised in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn in the 1920s-30s with his younger brother Herb, Sy attended James Madison High School and St. John's University, Business School and Law School. He served in the Army in Korea as a telegrapher. Sy became an attorney and a CPA and established Seymour Reich & Company, where he worked actively for 55 years until this past week. Sy was devoted to bridge, which he played weekly until his failing eyesight prevented it. He was an extremely affable man with a caring demeanor and a good sense of humor. He could be tenacious in pursuit of his goals, and at the same time kind and generous to those with whom he had dealings. He engendered, both in his employees and friends, a great sense of loyalty. He was deeply committed to philanthropy through The Reich Fund, which he established in the 1970s. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Lilian Reich, his son Charles and daughter-in-law Ilana, his daughter Elizabeth and son-in-law Stan, and his four grandchildren, Evie and Laura, and Audrey and Max, all of whom will miss him dearly. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell, the Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC, on Monday at 11:30am. Interment will follow at Temple Israel Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. 1/3

HIRSCH--Norma, on July 21, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Marjorie and Jerrold and mother-in-law of Cheryl. Cherished grandmother of Jason, Stephanie, Allison and Michael and great-grand- mother of Jessica. Loving sister of Arnold Cantor. Private services. Donations in her memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders. 1/3

EVANS--Paul Redmond, died on July 2 of heart failure. A longtime resident of Fishers Island, NY, Paul was born in New York City on October 3, 1958. Son of Katharine and Paul Evans he attended Buckley School, Lawrenceville and Boston University. After a career as a stock broker he retired to Fishers. He is survived by his five siblings, fourteen nieces and nephews and nine grandnieces and nephews whose birthdays he never failed to celebrate. He will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held at The Union Chapel, Fishers Island, NY on August 13 at 1:15pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider contributions to Fishers Island Library or Island Health Project. 1/3

PAUL--Eve W. Affiliates Risk Management Services, its Board of Directors, CEO, and staff, mourn the loss of Eve W. Paul. Eve was a dear friend and colleague, and a strong supporter of our work. She will be missed. We send our condolences to her family. 1/3
CAPLAN--Ann Heyman. Cherished sister, sister-in-law and aunt. We will share our wonderful memories of Andy with Jeff, Jamie and John. Stephanie and Jon Gillian, Caroline, William 1/3

CHESTLER--Rita, November 3, 1934 - July 20, 2016. Nothing made her happier than her family, and nobody made her family happier than she did. Married to her high school sweetheart, Herb Chestler, together for 68 years, she was the true matriarch of our family. Always caring, loving and so proud, "Rita-Belle," Mom, Grandma, "Dot," we will love you forever, miss you every day, and cherish our memories always. We love you. Herb, Steve and Carolyn, Daniel B. and Rhonda, Cathy and Jonathan, Jaclyn and Andrew, Jacob, Jessica, Emily, Gregory and Caitlin 1/3

CASE--Dr. Robert B.,age 96, of NYC, Southampton and Naples, beloved husband of Dr. Nan Case and stepfather of Miles Robert and family, passed away peacefully in Southampton Hospital of natural causes. Dr. Case graduated from MIT, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and was on the staff of NIH and Harvard School of Public Health. He spent the majority of his career as Director of the Laboratory of Experimental Cardiology at St. Luke's Hospital and published numerous articles in peer reviewed journals. He was also an active member of the Multi-Center Cardiology Research Group and retired as Professor Emeritus of Columbia University. He was truly a brilliant scientist, a loving man and greatly respected. In lieu of flowers, please remember him with an act of kindness. The graveside service will be held at the Southampton Cemetery on Wednesday at noon. 1/3

REICH--Seymour: The Board of Trustees, residents and staff of the Hebrew Home at Riverdale mourn the loss of Seymour Reich who was a dedicated and thoughtful trustee for many years. Seymour was a giant in the Jewish community and we will miss his good counsel and friendship. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale by RiverSpring Health Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President and CEO 1/3

COHEN--Frances Milgrim, peacefully, on July 22, 2016 in Scottsdale Arizona. Loving wife of the late Seymour, devoted mother of Nancy, cherished sister of the late Jean Dranoff, dear aunt of Steve. Fran was adored by her "Four Legged Fur Children," Sophie and Jackson. Her loving nature, impeccable style and fashionista sense will be missed. Service Wednesday, July 27, 12 noon at "The Riverside," 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her memory may be made to: azrescue.org or Stroke Association. 1/3

BROWN--Daniel J. Dan Brown, age 97. July 6, 1919 - July 21, 2016. Beloved husband of the late Norma (Selikoff), and later in life, the late Sybil (Hertzman). Loving father to Ronnie (Jonathan) Halpern, Judie (Harold) Bregman, and Nancy (Rick) Nasoff, and stepfather to Karen (Jerry) Biderman. Adored grandfather of Stephanie (Stuart) Rodnick, Jaclyn (Craig) Bonder, Lisa and Evan (Linnea) Bregman, Lauren (Mitch) Bloom, and Jodi Nasoff. And step-grandfather to Noel (Amanda) Biderman and Sandor (Shonna) Biderman. "Poppy" was great-grandfather to Justin and Jared Rodnick, Ethan and Jordan Bonder, Max Bloom, Abel, Soren, Sasha, Ryan and Romy Biderman. Dan was the "maven" of the family-with limitless knowledge about just about everything, and always willing to share it with all who would listen. Mr. Fix-It, Master Story-Teller, WWII Army Veteran, Turkey Carver, and Fisherman--He will never be forgotten. Service Monday, July 25 at Boulevard Chapel, Hewlett, NY. Donations may be made to the organization of your choice. 1/3

ROSEN--Annette. March 21, 1925 - July 22, 2016. A life-long New Yorker, Annette was active in many civic organizations, most fondly, the Women's City Club of New York. Annette was the daughter of Samuel and Molly (Weisbrod) Young. Annette is survived by Richard, her beloved husband of almost 60 years; her sons Michael (Susan) and Andrew (Brandi Beck); and grandchildren, Matthew, Sam and Charlie Rosen and Dasha Fowler. She was preceded in death by her brother, Paul, and her beloved granddaughter Elizabeth Hannah Rosen. A memorial service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Annette's memory to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America. 1/3

PETRAS--Nicholas George, of Plandome, NY on July 20, 2016. Three days shy of his 86th birthday. Beloved husband of the late Dorothea for over 57 years. Loving father of Catherine, Nicholas Jr. (Ruth) and Paul (Laura). Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth, Timothy, Katherine, Rebecca, Nicholas III, Charles and Samson. Devoted brother of the late Comninos Petras and Peter Petras. Cousin and uncle to a large extended family with roots in New York. Practicing Attorney for 60 years in the Greek American Community. Visitation will be held the Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Monday from 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Service Tuesday, 10am at the Archangel Michael Greek Orthodox Church 100 Fairway Drive, Port Washington, NY. Interment to follow at Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Pt. Washington. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Tower Foundation of Manhasset, Inc., P.O. Box 421, Manhasset, NY 11030. 1/3

WEST--Paul B.,on July 20, 2016. Patent attorney at Ladas & Parry LLP, avid skier, tennis player, devotee of art and music. Beloved companion of Judith Grandes, loving brother of Margo Otis, devoted uncle of Tracy, Steven and Martha Otis. 1/3

BALIFF--Robert Jay, MD. January 21, 1932 - July 17, 2016. Our man for all seasons, Physician and professor. Devoted husband of 61 years to Cora Manson died of Dementia. Rah! Midwood. Father to Keith, Ethan, Leslie and Dan Paisner. Grandfather to Jacob, Hana and Rose Paisner. Brother-in-law and uncle to Mansons, Kleins and Biers. Companion to Rusty the poodle. Caring cousin, friend, and partner. Outstanding doctor, teacher, mountain hiker, lover of all things with wheels, animal photographer, safari traveller, glacier climber, exceptional woodworker, model builder dog lover and master repairman. We are grateful to the friends and family who were there for him and us during these difficult years. You made life easier, took him to dinner, called, baked him goodies, walked his dog, expressed concerns, cared for him physically, smoothed the way medically, treated him with respect. He knew that you cared. Special appreciation to Keith's friends at Bayville who support Keith and welcomed his Dad. Private graveside service to the tune of "Leaving on a Jet Plane." Donations in his name may be made to United Cerebral Palsy, UCP Bayville, 85 Bayville Avenue, Bayville, NY, 11709. Attention Arios. 1/3

ROSENFIELD--Herbert. Born August 6, 1918 and died July 20, 2016. Son of Bertha Fischman Rosenfield and Abner Benjamin Rosenfield and grandson of William Fischman and Pauline Levy Fischman, and Solomon Rosenfield and Leah Robinson Rosenfield. His beloved wife, Audrey Priest Rosenfield, like his parents and grandparents, predeceased him. A dedicated lifelong New Yorker, he was president for more than forty years of the family textile firm, Continental Convertors Corporation. He served in the Army from 1940-1946 and saw action in France and Germany as Warrant Officer/ Assistant Adjutant to the Commanding Officer of the 212th Coast Guard Artillery Anti-Aircraft and then Adjutant to the Commanding Officer of the 541st Field Artillery European Theater. Herb served regularly on the Grand Jury of the County of New York. As founder and then president of the Chambers - Canal Civic Association, he and his colleagues supported small businesses and fought for better residential conditions, such as the law allowing artists to work and live in lofts. Appointed to Community Board #

SILLS--Ruth. July 24, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Irving, devoted mother of Robert (Carol Schwartz), Nancy (Franklin Moss) and of Judy, who predeceased her. Adoring and adored grandmother of Josh, Matt, Hannah, Becky and Joanna, and great-grand mother of Jackson, Harlow and Kendra. Services at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam, on Thursday, July 28 at noon. 1/3

BROWN--William K.,died at peace in his sleep at the age of 81. Survived by his beloved wife of 57 years, Anita and daughter Celia Anne. Bill was a entrepreneur, innovator, public speaker, theatrical producer, actor and community leader. Bill joined Marsh & McLennan in 1969 was expert in Professional Liability Insurance. As a Managing Director he served his clients for over 30+ years. A supporter of the theatrical arts, Bill helped Anita found Montauk Theatre Productions. Later, they formed the Shooting Star Theater in NYC and were active with The Lambs. As President of The John Street Club, he energized the Club and fostered fellowship. A memorial service is planned for the fall. 1/3
